description: This wine offers warming aromas of baking spice, cherry, chocolate brownies, ripe plums and some leafy notes. The palate is well-balanced by savory, chalky tannins.

Richness of flavor and an especially creamy, melting texture help this wine stand out in a crowd. The wine is 80% barrel fermented and aged on the lees. It has concentrated and ripe pear, peach and apple flavors and a silky mouthfeel.

Wild berry, dark spice, new leather and truffle aromas take center stage along with a whiff of violet. The linear medium-bodied palate is on the racy side, offering cranberry, star anise and crushed herb alongside tight, close-grained tannins and vibrant acidity. Drink 2019–2026.

There's a dried fennel note that shows on many Temecula Valley wines, but this blend of 48% Grenache, 34% Syrah and 18% Mourvèdre uses that spice note to its advantage. Plump red-plum and hickory-smoke aromas touch on that anise-like note on the nose, while the palate shows cherry wood, elegant red-fruit and roasted fennel-bulb flavors.
This medium-bodied white brings a stony mineral texture, with fleshy flavors of guava and mango. It offers complexity and nuance against a full embrace of ripeness.

Fine oak helps an otherwise ripe and earthy nose. A rich saturated palate ranks as syrupy, while this Tempranillo-led blend tastes of coconut, chocolate mint and blackberry jam. While thick and stout throughout, this off-vintage wine always seems a bit flat. Drink through 2021.
A smoky sage-like aroma and fruit flavors tinged with earthy, woody accents make this full-bodied wine a bit of a wild card, but an enjoyable one.

Slightly off-dry in style, this offers heady aromas of waxy lemon, nectarine, flower blossoms and a touch of honey. The residual sugar is subtle, adding more in the way of ripe fruitiness and texture than overt sweetness.
Juicy red-berry fruits are evident in this softly textured wine. Juicy acidity and tannins give it both structure and aging potential. Drink this generous wine from 2021.

Blended with just over 9% Syrah and a touch of Zinfandel, this is a thick, densely structured red, offering flavors of mocha, cherry and plum. The secondary aspects dive into herbal territory, a mix of dried herb, cedar and pencil shavings.
Aromas of white flower open the door to integrated acidity and a grainy texture in this nicely made white from the cool-climate site. Tangerine and lime speak loudest on the palate.

Some funk on the nose blends with aromas of scrambled eggs and arugula. A tangy palate is in accordance with blanc de blancs norms, while this tastes grassy and like lime in front of a finish that tastes like fresh lettuce.
designation: Conca del Riu Anonia Blanc de Blanc

description: Blended with 25% Malbec, this wine leads with dominant barrel notes, its vanilla, incense, anise, wood and baking spice aromas accenting fruit leather scents. The palate is lighter styled, with dried-out fruit flavors. A meat- and medicine cabinet-laced finish caps it off.
Nearly red in color, this wine is robust on the nose in earthy brambly berry that becomes pie-like in richness and girth. The generosity of fruit is laced in lemon zest.
This soft, wood-aged wine is spicy, ripe with smoky red fruit and finished with juicy acidity. It's aromatic, with fine fruitiness and some still-youthful tannins. Drink now.
This classic, dry Vinho Verde is full of lively fruitiness and crisp acidity. It strikes a balance between citrus and apple flavors, making it clean, poised and enjoyable.
This includes 25% mixed blacks, all old-vine—a study in compost earthiness and baked blueberry. Full bodied and quite ripe, it has a smokiness to the oak that contrasts against the fruit and dust.
Notes of ripe, green pear are subdued on the nose. They are more impressive on the palate where a little residual sweetness boosts them. Lemony freshness balances and creates an off-dry finish.

This is a gorgeous wine made in minuscule amounts, fermented in both stainless steel and one-third new French oak before aging in neutral French oak. The subtle touches give it a chance to speak softly in lemony quince, with a steely nose of jasmine. Fleshy and full bodied without being heavy, it has a succulence of apple skin on the midpalate.

Stainless-steel fermented and aged in neutral French oak, this well-made wine offers crisp acidity and supportive oak, with highlights of fennel, green apple and wet stone. Its grainy texture is layered and complex while also being deliciously drinkable now.

This is a finely made wine, with tones of herbs, smoked black cherry and blackberry. Thick, velvety smooth and concentrated, it finds its balance in high-toned, underlying acidity and sparks of cardamom and black tea.

Lively aromas of smashed black currants, caramelized berries, lilacs and açai make for a very inviting and pretty nose on this bottling. The palate is vivid with smoke, blueberry paste, violets, lavender and a savory charred component, finishing with a kiss of vanilla.

This refreshing wine is a blend of 62% Syrah and 38% Grenache. It quenches in notes of strawberry, peach and a hint of gaminess. Velvety smooth and dangerously easy to enjoy, it's light and brightly layered in acidity.

There are already indications of fine maturity in this wine. Yeast and toasty flavors mingle with the crisp acidity and ripe stewed apricots and apple to give richness. It also has the nervy acidity that is typical of Alfred Gratien Champagnes, which will allow the wine to age further.

Produced from parcels of the Aegerter family's own domaine, this wine is both rich and firmly tannic. Big black cherry and dark plum fruits are sustained by the dry core of this dense, structured wine. It will need time, so wait until 2022.
Dark berry, underbrush and eucalyptus aromas take shape on this solid red. The savory palate offers red plum, licorice and white pepper alongside firm tannins. Drink 2022–2028.

Subtle aromas of rose petal, leather and underbrush emerge from the glass. The juicy palate offers raspberry, red cherry and star anise alongside austere tannins that need time to unfold. Drink after 2023.

Done in a light tart refreshing style, this mixes strawberry fruit with hints of sliced orange peel. There's a snap to the finish suggesting wet stone. A change of owners (from King Estate to Foley Family) has not changed the success or style of this value rosé.

This enjoyable red opens with dark-skinned berry, pressed violet and star anise aromas. On the easygoing juicy palate, supple tannins lightly support ripe blackberry, clove and a hint of white pepper.

Black-cherry liqueur and a touch of brioche show on the nose of this promising bottling by students at Allan Hancock College. The palate's flavors of red cherry and earthy sagebrush are evenly distributed and framed by fresh acidity.

A tiny production from former Williams Selyem winemaker Bob Cabral, now also making the wines for Three Sticks, this is an entirely barrel-fermented and rich white wine made with focus and intent. Crème brûlée, brioche and a reduced nose highlight the slow evolution in the glass, which is joined by exotic notions of mango and clarified butter.

Aromas of baked apple and dried mandarin peel unite into a most alluring, almost lifted nose. The palate remains wonderfully dry, highlighting the beautifully pure lemon at its core and a textured, chalky freshness. This is concentrated, toned and totally delicious. The finish is of purest lemon. Drink now through 2028.

From a vineyard situated amongst ranchettes near the winery, this wine begins with extremely beautiful scents of black cherry, rosewater and sharp nose-tingling cola spice, proving juicy but elegant. The palate is full of brilliant flavors, from snappy black raspberry to more rounded strawberry sorbet, lifted by allspice, clove, vanilla and plenty of fresh acidity.

Aged in both small and larger barrels, this wine comes from the Douro Superior region in the upper Douro. Its tannins and generous texture are all part of a rich, full and powerful wine. Black fruits, a firm structure and acidity come together but need more time. Drink from 2022.

A wonderfully earthy note appears before lemon and crisp apple on the nose. The palate has something unusually savory, like crushed fennel, smoky cured meat and a creamier backdrop. All along, a bright lemon streak acts as a fault line of freshness. This is complex, unusual but utterly fresh. The finish is dry and wonderfully tangy. Drink through 2035.

A touch of apricot skin swings in with the ripe juicy pear notes on the nose. The palate scoops this fruity richness up with both a touch of residual sugar and a mellow phenolic earthiness that is reminiscent of almond skin and pear pips. Lemon freshness frames this while some alcoholic heat makes the aromas heady and expressive. This is a big, generous but very balanced and layered wine. Wait for this. Drink 2025–2035.
This herbal, perfumed wine is a simple blend of Grenache and Cinsault, bright with layers of crisp acidity. A touch of pepper adds spice to the delicious, easy fruit of the wine. Drink now.

A deliciously aromatic wine, this offers intense red fruits that are repeated on the crisp, refreshing palate. Produced near the coast and close to Bandol, the wine is fruity, bright and ready to drink now.

Delicate dark fruit and tilled soil aromas guide the nose of this blend of Sangiovese, Canaiolo and Merlot. The straightforward palate evokes ripe black cherries, clove and black pepper, with pliant tannins. Drink soon.

Made from a rare cross between Tannat and Cabernet Sauvignon created in 1955, this is a simple, fruity wine with soft tannins and fine, juicy acidity. Red fruit and a crisp texture mark the palate. It's ready to drink.

This bottling, which includes 14% Merlot and 6% Petite Sirah, shows tightly wound blackberry and plum fruit with touches of pepper and balsamic on the nose. The palate offers reduced strawberry flavors with a pinch of white pepper.

Hints of garrigue and bramble lend savory freshness to ripe, almost ruddy black cherry and preserved plum flavors. It's a plush, weighty wine held upright by fresh acidity and very ripe but firm, persistent tannins. Enjoy now–2030.

Crisp lemon flavors and white-blossom notes lend an invigorating feel to this fresh, fruity white wine. It's light on its feet but silky and expansive on the palate. The finish is moderately long and just a hint warming.

A nose of cassis, dark plum and juniper paves the way for black cherry, black currant, anise, violet and orange zest flavors in this wine. It's full bodied, with smooth tannins that recede into a bright finish.

Rich with dusty tannins and now-mature fruits, this wine is ripe, full bodied and concentrated. Black-plum flavors are up front along with the smoky flavors, juicy black-currant aftertaste and some further aging potential. Drink now or keep until 2020.

Ripe aromas of blackberry drift towards raisin and animal fur. This is immensely full in body, with ripping tartaric acidity. Flavors of coconut and vanilla are oak based, while blackberry fruit finishes bold, but with a reverb of choppy tartaric acidity. Drink through 2022.

Lip-smacking black-cherry and plum flavors are juicy and ripe but nuanced by fragrant layers of sun-dried thyme, sage and fennel. It's full bodied and voluminous on the palate but nicely integrated in alcohol and acidity. The finish is marked by ripe, finely edged tannins.

Extremely fresh and pungent aromas of smashed strawberries are enhanced by white pepper dust, whole green peppercorns, wet tobacco leaf and the smell of a dewy morning amidst pine trees and chaparral scrub on this wine by Chad Melville. The palate is simply stunning with juniper and pine-needle elements that slip into rich yet tart cherry and baked raspberry, proving extremely dynamic and lovely all around.

Enticingly fragrant, this stunning red opens with delicate but alluring scents of wild berry, Mediterranean brush, rose, crushed rock and a whiff of exotic spice. It's full bodied but loaded with finesse, delivering creamy red cherry, raspberry compote, star anise and white pepper. Taut, refined tannins and lively acidity provide support and balance, while a savory mineral note lingers on the close. Drink 2021–2036.

This is an awesome expression of cool climate Syrah, with rosemary-crusted lamb chops, peppercorns, asphalt and elderberry-jam aromas starting the show. The palate is intense with cracked pepper, bay leaf, rosemary oil and sage, which play against riper black-fruit tones and elegant lavender flavors.

The nose of this wine from the folks at Balo Vineyards is full of ripe fruit, giving it a powerful yet nuanced feel. Intense, deep fruit flavor mingles with sage, rhubarb, black tea and a touch of black pepper. It's delicious and complex on the palate, with smooth, fine layers of integrated tannins and acidity. Best after 2023.

Old vines dating to 1958 are the basis of this concentrated wine. Bold tannins and swathes of black fruits combine with the structure to give a wine that is superb and has an enormous life ahead. Wait at least until 2025.

Even among a lineup of fantastic peers in a fantastic vintage, this bottling of Les Souteyrades is a stunner. It's intensely rich, bursting with mulberry and cherry flavors, yet not brawny or dense. Finessed and fine in texture, it's marked by soft, chalky tannins and bright, sunny acidity. The finish is long, offering lingering hints of crushed earth and garrigue. A treat to savor now–2030.
Condensed black-cherry aromas meld with odd tones of fennel seed and caraway on the nose. Light in feel, the palate brings more of the same, with a dusty, tannic grip.

This rosé of Tempranillo opens with a popular pink Provence color and not too serious aromas of citrus fruits and cheese. The palate, despite the wine's light color, is chunky and a bit sticky. Chewing gum flavors flatten out on a finish that's showing the first stages of oxidation.
Apple-juice and pear aromas lead to a mostly flat palate that's plump but shapeless. Stale apple and stone-fruit flavors lack vitality and taste sweet, while this brut finishes wheaty and oxidized.

Raw reedy red-fruit aromas are scratchy and herbal. Given that, it's not a surprise that this Graciano is clampy on the palate. A mix of sweet and savory flavors includes red currant, pomegranate and tomato, while this is linear and doesn't generate much excitement on the finish.

Crushed violet petals, bramble and baking spice mixes with boysenberry and blackberry tones on the nose and mouth of this easy-to-like wine. Straightforward and solid, it's well balanced, with some textural interest that lends a subtle grip to the close.

Bright, fresh apple-flesh and sweet-orange aromas lead the bouquet of this wine, though only with moderate intensity. The palate offers enough acidity to balance the ripe fruit tones, while hints of dried herbs and wood spice unfold on the medium-length finish.

Extremely fresh and pungent aromas of smashed strawberries are enhanced by white pepper dust, whole green peppercorns, wet tobacco leaf and the smell of a dewy morning amidst pine trees and chaparral scrub on this wine by Chad Melville. The palate is simply stunning with juniper and pine-needle elements that slip into rich yet tart cherry and baked raspberry, proving extremely dynamic and lovely all around.

Enticingly fragrant, this stunning red opens with delicate but alluring scents of wild berry, Mediterranean brush, rose, crushed rock and a whiff of exotic spice. It's full bodied but loaded with finesse, delivering creamy red cherry, raspberry compote, star anise and white pepper. Taut, refined tannins and lively acidity provide support and balance, while a savory mineral note lingers on the close. Drink 2021–2036.

This is an awesome expression of cool climate Syrah, with rosemary-crusted lamb chops, peppercorns, asphalt and elderberry-jam aromas starting the show. The palate is intense with cracked pepper, bay leaf, rosemary oil and sage, which play against riper black-fruit tones and elegant lavender flavors.

The nose of this wine from the folks at Balo Vineyards is full of ripe fruit, giving it a powerful yet nuanced feel. Intense, deep fruit flavor mingles with sage, rhubarb, black tea and a touch of black pepper. It's delicious and complex on the palate, with smooth, fine layers of integrated tannins and acidity. Best after 2023.

Old vines dating to 1958 are the basis of this concentrated wine. Bold tannins and swathes of black fruits combine with the structure to give a wine that is superb and has an enormous life ahead. Wait at least until 2025.

Even among a lineup of fantastic peers in a fantastic vintage, this bottling of Les Souteyrades is a stunner. It's intensely rich, bursting with mulberry and cherry flavors, yet not brawny or dense. Finessed and fine in texture, it's marked by soft, chalky tannins and bright, sunny acidity. The finish is long, offering lingering hints of crushed earth and garrigue. A treat to savor now–2030.

Mint, chocolate and cherry flavors intermingle in this dry, full-bodied and firmly tannic wine blended from Bordeaux grape varieties. It offers plenty of blackberry notes shaded by black pepper and smoke and will stand up to the juiciest protein you can order.

This is a rich sparkling for those who like their bubbles full throttle. Enticing notes of bruised red apples, apricots, figs and honeyed nuts run throughout the wine. The mouthfeel is creamy, carried by fine bubbles. Less honeyed than the nose, the palate brings earthier flavors of wet hay and strawberry leaf.

This is a sort of ad hoc field blend, composed of estate-grown fruit that didn't find its way into any of the many single varietal blends. Ten different grapes are in the mix, but more than half, unsurprisingly, is Tempranillo. It blends seamlessly, a potpourri of black fruits, cacao and graphite, with a whiff of cigar box. At this price it's worth loading up by the case.
Fleshy in defined flavors of peach and pear, this is a bright white wine, defined by perfumed aromas of jasmine and white flower. Fresh acidity supports a moderate structure of balanced ripeness.

The production of this well-made wine keeps bumping up, while the price and quality remain consistent. Pungent, peppery fruit flavors center around bright cranberry and plenty of citrus. There's a gentle touch of cinnamon candy also, adding extra life to the finish.
This wine opens with a nutty, woody nose that delves quickly into a brazen blue-fruit flavor. Clove and pepper season it well and contribute to its length and depth.

This is a full-bodied grippy wine with deep black-fruit flavors and a very firm texture due to significant tannins and good acidity. It shows black-cherry, sour-cherry and cedar aspects that are tightly wrapped.
This has aromas of red berry, thyme and adhesive bandage that carry over to the dry, linear palate. It's crisp, with vibrant acidity, while a refined perlage softens the finish.
Turned earth and baked strawberry highlight this lightly ripe wine, which is seasoned distinctively in mint and dried herb.
This bold and bright wine has a hot-pink color that's almost fluorescent, followed by fruity candied aromas and ripe cherry flavors.

This wine comes from a new regional appellation that spans southern Burgundy and Beaujolais. The wine is soft and fruity, with the Gamay in the blend showing strongly. With attractive red fruits and gentle tannins, it is ready to drink.

A dense juicy core of tannin and oak rides beneath dark cherry, cassis and cinnamon in this relatively light-bodied wine, softened by the addition of 8% Cabernet Franc, 7% Malbec, 6% Merlot and 3% Petit Verdot.

This leads with tire rubber, asphalt and beef jerky aromas, seeming smoky, savory and oaky. Grippy tannins frame its slightly stewed berry flavors. It finishes on notes of licorice, smoked meat and baked blackberry.

Nearly equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec make up the core of this blend, along with 23% Syrah and 10% Petit Verdot. Simple in structure and approach, it's approachable rich and round, with a sweet tannin profile and dark cherry flavors.
This ruby colored Cabernet Sauvignon has aromas of cherry and cinnamon, with flavors of black cherry and black plum. The tannins are smooth and pleasant.
This garnet colored wine has aromas of black plum, cherry and leather. The palate is bolstered by smooth tannins, with flavors of ripe cherry and black plum.
This Nero d'Avola opens with aromas suggesting mocha, tilled soil and dark berry. The dense palate offers black plum, espresso and clove alongside rather firm tannins.

Quite heady notes of lime marmalade bundle with ripe and juicy pear on the nose before unfolding into an unashamed sweetness on the impactful palate. The inherent power of this wine is undeniable, the body is immensely concentrated, dense with fruit but also with the zestiness of lime which counters the sweetness. A pleasantly bitter, almost pithy and salty texture makes the mouth water and tingle. The finish is medium sweet and packs a real punch. Drink 2025–2035.

The golden hue and ample rich earthy aroma with its juicy hints of autumnal generosity immediately suggest some development. The flavors are evolved on the palate, too. Ripe pear fruit has muted into a rounded mellowness while freshness still pervades this smooth balance. The wine is dry but brings notions of richness and understated power. The finish is dry and wonderfully balanced, still tingling with freshness. Drink until 2030.

A balm-like combination of honey, lemon oil, chamomile tincture and baked apple washes over the senses with just one sniff. This aromatic richness is reprised on the concentrated palate but finds a perfect counterpoint in the resulting dryness. Bright, pure lemon guides and frames with its freshness while the aromas swirl and swish—oh the joy of mature Riesling! The finish is dry with pronounced lemon. Drink through 2028

The vanilla and Golden Delicious richness on the nose immediately suggests the roundness of oak. The vanilla notes attain extra creaminess on the palate but are countered by exquisite lemon freshness and a developed autolytic background that suggests the richness of butter pastry. Creaminess reigns on the midpalate but it is the pure bright ripe lemon that dominates the long finish. This is lovely now but will continue developing. Drink now–2025.

Both ripe Mirabelle plum and zesty lime notes appear on the intense, aromatic nose, signalling concentration from the start. The palate continues in this zesty vein with great concentration and a real zing. The lemon notes continue to tingle all the way to the dry, refreshing and pure finish. Drink now through 2040.
designation: Rangen de Thann Volcanique Grand Cru

description: Pure berry and cassis aromas are concentrated and show no holes. This Uco Valley Malbec feels pure, direct and linear, albeit with slightly scratchy tannins that should dissipate in due time. Blackberry and dry spice flavors finish full and grabby, with muscularity. Drink through 2028.
This wine's black raspberry, crushed rock, blackberry, smoke and plum aromas are brooding. Its rich but focused cranberry and cherry flavors linger on the finish.

This wine is 38% Mourvèdre, 38% Grenache, 21% Syrah and 3% Cinsaut. Its reserved blackberry, cherry cordial, herb and spice aromas lead to full-bodied red and black fruit flavors. Give it some time to open up.
This is an intensely perfumed wine, full with apricot, kiwi and tight apple flavors. Still young, this rich, full-bodied wine is concentrated and ripe, demanding time to mature. Drink from 2019.

Gorgeous white-blossom perfume and hints of sweet spice introduce this full-bodied Viognier. While rich and round on the palate, its pristine gooseberry and white-grapefruit flavors are fresh and invigorating. It's a juicy, vibrant wine to enjoy now–2022.
Packed with pineapple and yellow fruit that is a concentrated wine cut by juicy acidity. Its fruitiness and ripe character from old vines are well balanced, generous and deliciously ready to drink.

Mineral-driven, earthy and floral, this gorgeous white is elusive in fruit, youthfully demure and full of vigorous acidity. Lightly ripe peach and mango come into play midpalate, with a squeeze of lemon emphasizing the wine's vibrancy on the finish.

This is a blend of 53% Merlot, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 2% Malbec. Somewhat lighter in color, the aromas show notes of wet penny, raspberry, wheat, herb stalk, cherry and spice. The flavors are light but juicy, tapering on the finish.
Dried herb and lavender highlight a smooth, rich and round palate of wild strawberry and blueberry in this well-made light-bodied wine.

This small fringe appellation, around the corner of the hill from Santenay, produces accessible wines at good prices. This wine from old vines is rich while also soft and open. It has generous tannins and delicious acidity, red-cherry flavors and just a touch of dryness at the end. Drink this wine from 2020.

This blend of 55% Grenache Blanc, 36% Roussanne and 9% Picpoul starts with broad aromas of Asian pear, tinges of Meyer lemon and tangerine rind and a lot of chalkiness. It's tightly wound on the palate and quite reserved in flavors, until a ripe yellow-pear element starts to come through toward the finish.

This blend of Negroamaro and Malvasia Nera offers aromas of dark cherry, bramble berry and leather. Medium in weight, with a grip of fine, sandy tannins, the palate is carried by a core of ripe red- and black-berry flavors.

A brilliant pink in color, this wine tastes crisp and light despite rather full body. It's well balanced and mouthwatering. Good acidity and light cherry and raspberry flavors give it a refreshing aspect.

Brambly, wild-berry aromas and generous plum, maple and milk chocolate flavors make a delicious combination in this full-bodied plush-textured wine. It's soothing on the palate and has an almost-sweet finish.

There's a barnyard funk to this wine that blows off after some time in glass. Still, this is a Pinot Noir for those who dig the variety's earthy and savory characters. While bright strawberry and black pepper notes abound, they're riding under soy sauce, mushroom and hay. The palate is light-bodied and savory, backed by soft, sandy tannins and crisp acidity.

This blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon opens with wild berry, blue flower and baking spice scents. On the juicy, enjoyable palate, polished tannins lightly support mature plum, black cherry and toast notes. Drink through 2019.

This pliant, savory red opens with fruity aromas of crushed red berry and a whiff of dark spice. The bright, supple palate doles out succulent red cherry, crushed raspberry and a hint of clove alongside soft, supple tannins. This is delicious and enjoyable in the near term.

Game and black plum aromas lead the nose of this wine while the dense palate offers prune, licorice and toast notes. Assertive, somewhat astringent tannins and the heat of evident alcohol provide the backdrop. Drink 2022–2027.

This producer, unlike most Champagne firms, does not let its wines go through malolactic fermentation, ensuring that the acidity remains intense and fresh. The policy results in crisp, mineral-driven, dry wines like this, which also age well. This prestige cuvée offers great citrus fruit, a strong tight texture and aging potential. Drink from 2020.

A rich and spicy take on the grape, this bottling combines dried red plums with juniper, forest moss, spice cake and a fascinating mushroom-laced umami kick on the nose. The palate is taut with raspberry flavors and well integrated exotic Middle Eastern spices. The acidity is lively and the mouthfeel is soft yet grippy on the finish.

Thick and concentrated in baked blueberry, cherry and strawberry, this wine has substantial tannin and weight to it, a powerful backbone that's balanced by bubbling, nuanced acidity and mineral earth tones that linger gingerly on the finish.

Golden Delicious apple is the star of the show in this beautifully oaked, aromatic and lushly textured white. Caramel and nutmeg rise on the nose, leading the way to fleshy full-bodied concentration and richness, tamed by bright bursts of quince and Meyer lemon.

Made from 100% dried Zibibbo grapes, this iconic dessert wine opens with enticing aromas of apricot jam, acacia honey and tangerine zest. The savory, balanced palate doles out mature fig, date, lemon jam and a touch of bergamot on the long finish.

This wine is bright in acidity, with a wealth of freshness in tones of Meyer lemon and lime. Quenching on the midpalate, it develops more and more complexity in the glass, where a stony texture meets crisp green apple and fennel.

Very light on the nose, this bottling offers aromas of wet cement, apple, lime skin and a hint of flint. There is decent acid and texture to the sip, where light flavors of pome fruit and tangy lemon show.

This is a fruity and fresh-tasting wine that's light to medium in body, very aromatic and has flavors like a fruit salad of apples, melons and peaches with a dash of lemon juice. All that fruitiness verges on sweetness, so dry-wine stalwarts beware.

From vineyards located in the east of Corsica, this blend of Vermentino and Chardonnay is floral and crisp, with an attractive perfumed character. The wine is easy, soft and fruity and ready to drink now.
winery: Union de Vignerons de l'Île de Beauté

description: Showing just a trace of copper color, this Sangiovese rosé displays aromas of Muscat gummy and tangerine peel. It drinks dry but the rich fruit flavors give the perception of sweetness.

Cabernet Sauvignon (43%) and Cabernet Franc make up equal percentages of this wine, with the balance Petit Verdot. The aromas provide notes of vanilla, baking spice, fresh herb, cherry, pencil lead, dill and anise, with the oak far out front. The fruit flavors are lighter styled, not seeming fully able to stand up to the oak. Coffee notes linger on the finish.
This wine is intensely earthy and big boned, with a shock of tart acidity. It flourishes in the appellation's herbal mint and pomegranate.

A white peach aroma meets hazelnut, lemon cream, brioche, whipped butter and salt on the lavish and yet restrained nose of this bottling. An iron grip immediately seizes the palate with chalky tension and flavors, then smooths into tones of lemon preserves on toast, tangerine zest, vanilla dust and sea salt caramel.

Oodles of black cherry and sour cherry fill the aroma and flood the flavors of this full-bodied, concentrated and deeply fruity wine. The ripeness is balanced by good fruit acidity, making the wine both seductive and refreshing to sip. Made from Ferrington Vineyard and the old-vine Beaujolais Vineyard, it has the structure to age and improve. Best to drink after 2023.

The 2016s are Chad Melville's first total-control vintage since longtime winemaker Greg Brewer departed, and they show how much he knows his family's ranch. Bright and buoyant aromas of bursting pomegranate, cranberry, lavender and cinnamon lead into a palate of tart cherry, hibiscus and lemon rind, with thyme and sage dusted throughout.

This drop-dead gorgeous sparkler is all about finesse and fragrance. It opens with enticing scents of Alpine wildflower, pear, flint and a whiff of pastry. The savory, elegant palate has an airy, weightless character, doling out ripe apple, creamy white peach, minerals and a dollop of vanilla before the dry, juicy finish. A silky perlage gives it a polished, irresistible texture.

Always one of the more compelling bottlings from the region each year, this single-vineyard expression shows smoked thyme, roasting game, light raspberry, tea leaves and dried purple flowers on the nose. Rose petal, Chinese five spice and cardamom pod flavors make for an exotic palate, set against a tart red-fruit backdrop.

Brilliantly fresh and snappy black raspberry aromas lead into a savory streak of mulberry-laced pork fat, hickory and tobacco smoke, with a hint of crushed slate on this wine's fascinating and shape-shifting nose. Peppery spice grips the palate immediately, then splashes fresh red plum and pomegranate flavors around, finishing on white pepper, cracked nutmeg and unrelenting tension.

A departure for this producer who tends to focus on its single-vineyard sites, this wine combines the best of several sites, with longevity and complexity in mind. It showcases the best of the coast's savory qualities, offering muted spice, firm tannins, orange, currant and a velvety midpalate.

Juicy, grippy and expansive in red and black cherry, this medium-bodied wine is smooth and seductive, an ideal representative of its reasonably warm site. It finishes on tones of black tea and rose petal.
designation: Winery Block Estate Grown Estate Bottled

description: Made from grapes grown at 1,000-foot elevation, this wine is velvety thick and concentrated, with a decadence and grip to it that intrigues. Black licorice, black cherry and blackberry dance around each other with intent, providing a warm, full-bodied explosion of flavorful beauty.

This Adelaide Hills Shiraz shows its cooler climate roots with its restrained nature and medium-body. A bouquet of plum pudding, mint jelly and dried green herbs is knit together by dusty, savory tannins.

Fresh tangerine and apricot aromas juxtapose slate and mineral tones on the nose of this easy-drinking but elegant Kabinett. Semidry in style, it's loaded with sweet-tart tangerine and grapefruit flavors. Zippy lemon-lime acidity and a pleasantly salty tang mark the finish. Enjoy now–2023.

Taut flavors of fresh strawberries, along with a gentle squeeze of grapefruit, introduce this young, snappy wine. Firm tannins support the overall structure, and the balance suggests that this should continue to improve over the next three to five years, and keep for another five after that.

Heady aromas of peach, pineapple, white pepper and jalapeño pepper lead the way in this wine. It leads into a slippy-textured palate that displays lots of fruit concentration and a long, pineapple finish.

Blueberry and baked plum aromas are dusted with cinnamon on the nose. More blueberry on the palate is joined by blackberry, black plum and vanilla. The tannins are boisterous and gritty, offering structure and lingering through the finish with soft blue fruits and spice.
A warm and rich wine with yellow fruits and hints of pineapple, this is generously textured. Its ripe character and layers of fruitiness show that it is ready to drink.
This opens with aromas of ripe dark fruit, tilled soil and a whiff of dark spice. The straightforward palate offers dried black cherry and clove alongside round tannins.

With a nose of brioche and smoky oak, this is a well-made, light-bodied version of the variety with 3% Syrah blended in. Dried cherry, leather and black pepper all appear along a high-toned, tannic texture.

Tight aromas of dark berry, cedar and wet lumber show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard in the southern reaches of Paso Robles. Twiggy, herbaceous flavors meet with red fruit on the palate, which is framed by chunky tannins.

A whole profusion of apple notes assails the nose. There is freshly cut Red Delicious alongside dried apples and baked apple tart. Indeed, there are notions of bitter almond and frangipani paste. While this suggests aromatic richness, the palate remains dry and acts as the perfect foil for these riches. A textured seam of freshness guarantees that this will continue evolving. Drink now through 2028.

Wet stone and rounded yeast define the nose. The palate conveys a picture of utter harmony: the finest fizz conveys pure lemon freshness that sets off the creamy autolytic notes to perfection. This is grown up and serious, offering glimpses of both tart and ripe apple freshness and lasting appeal with its long fresh finish. It's pure class.

Elegant and silky, this medium-bodied wine is carried by aromas of cinnamon and dried currant. The palate brings tones of mineral, plum and black tea, with a lightly tannic texture and a good dose of acidity. The wine has a distinct personality and showcases the high-elevation El Dorado appellation's suitability for Rhône varieties.

Greengage, Granny Smith and lemon on the nose suggest ample vivid freshness. On the palate, the fine mousse amplifies that fruity citrus-dominated freshness into a palate of fruity expression and lively creaminess. The entire wine seems to be a playful interaction of fruit, quintessential freshness and yeasty richness that, at least for now, hides its serious pleasure behind almost frivolous ease. Do not be fooled, this has real depth and deserves to be sipped slowly. It will develop. Drink now though 2025.

Clean, pure berry aromas come with earth and smoked meat notes. This is a full, bold Malbec from old vines. Spicy, lightly herbal plum and blackberry flavors finish pumped up, juicy and fresh. This is ready to drink or can be held for years to come; enjoy through 2028.

A savory herbal note clings to more mellow hints of ripe apple and wonderfully spiky lemon freshness on the nose. The palate reveals more of that wonderfully clean-cut apple with a tart edge and a cool precise lemon brightness. This is taut and textured, with a slight citrus pithiness against which the fruit flavors can play. The finish is mouth-watering, dry and completely refreshing. Drink now through 2035.

Made from organically farmed Sangiovese and 10% Canaiolo, this opens with earthy dark-skinned berry, tilled soil and leather aromas. The juicy, easy-drinking palate offers ripe black cherry, vanilla and cinnamon notes alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2023.
Baking spice and black plum aromas lead the nose of this wine. On the linear palate, firm tannins support dried black cherry, black pepper and cinnamon touches. Drink through 2021.

This wine's delicate dark-skinned fruit and underbrush aromas emerge from the glass. The straightforward palate offers raspberry, star anise and white pepper flavors alongside rounded tannins. Drink soon.

Fairly dark in the glass, this Grenache rosé, which includes 19% Cinsault, shows raspberry and orange oil on the nose. There is persistent acidity and a tactile grip to the sip, where orange skin and red pear flavors ride a chalky texture.
Juicy, this affordable red is high-pitched in acidity, with soft simple layers of red currant and strawberry buoyed by chocolatey oak.
A pretty Sauvignon Blanc that's easy to like, this shows a bright nose of limes, blossoms, stone fruit and a hint of jalapeño pepper. Drink this crisp, zippy sipper on a hot summer's day.

This broad, inviting Tempranillo offers ripe, robust blackberry, cassis and smoked meat aromas. Its blackberry and fig flavors blast at full volume, persisting into the thick finish with just the right amount of chocolaty oak. Drink through 2032.

From the producer's own backyard site, head-trained and planted a century ago, this wine is from the lowest yielding of all their sites. Earthy forest, leather saddle, fennel and a whiff of meatiness highlight a dense brightly layered wine, offering structure that is lifted in red-berry flavor with a spicy tobacco finish.

Bold dark-fruit aromas and mouthfilling flavors make this full-bodied wine taste generous and concentrated. A deep core of black plum and black cherry fills the palate and lingers nicely on the finish. It is both ripe and savory but doesn't go over the top, maintaining good balance and a fresh dry aspect.

This bottling from a vineyard at the cool northern edge of the appellation starts with a wildly intriguing nose of dark elderberry, bay leaf, roasted boar and dark violets. The palate throws tons of bay leaf, peppercorn and thyme before settling into boysenberry and game. It could be mistaken for a cool-climate Syrah.

This blend of 55% Chardonnay and 45% Pinot Noir is certainly dry. It is also packed with ripe fruits that balance the dryness. With its acidity and taut mineral texture, the wine is intense and concentrated. This bottling needs to age a few months, so hold until 2019.

A new wine from the producer, this combines 85% Syrah with 15% Viognier, and it is a whirlwind of intriguing flavor. Blackberry, waxy plum, dried herb, cedar, clove and black pepper highlight a rounded dense beginning that evolves to show lengthy tannin structure and complexity. Still, the wine's just fun.

This wine is lean in structure and flavor, starting with a light-garnet color, then followed by aromas like tea and mahogany and flavors like tart cherry. It has a snappy tangy quality due to good acidity and moderate tannins, so it's a good palate cleanser.
This wine's mild citrus and green herb aromas are typical of good but basic Verdejo. It's lean, lemony and light in body, with briny citrus flavors and a salty finish.

This wine's floral, grapy aromas are woody and a touch volatile. It's jammy and mouthfilling, with wiry acidity and soft tannins. Its jammy berry and black plum flavors finish flush, without much structure.

Whiffs of crushed earth and clay on the nose are quiet but this off-dry Riesling's lemon and tangerine flavors pack a zesty punch. It's an easy-drinking, refreshingly composed wine that finishes on a delicate lace of residual sugar. Drink now.

Aged for 30 months in Russian oak, this has reserved aromas suggesting dried and fresh herbs, woodspice, cherries and flowers. The palate is big and brawny, with firm tannins and a green note that persists throughout. It should do well at the dinner table.

This producer, in the Côte de Sézanne, has made a soft type of Champagne. With its lightly zesty texture and creamy mousse, it is a generous style with a relatively high dosage giving a soft aftertaste. Drink now.

This bottling is quite floral on the nose, but there are also strong aromas of juicy red fruits and a pinch of pepper. Tangy black-plum and dark-blackberry flavors show on the sip, where the tannins are still rather stiff.
Dark berry, red-plum and cooking spice aromas emerge from the glass. The chewy palate offers dried black cherry, black pepper and star anise alongside pliant tannins.
Subtle aromas of leather, baking spice and dark berry lead the nose. The linear palate offers raw sour cherry, clove and tobacco alongside close-grained tannins. Drink after 2023.

Principally a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah, aromas of cherry cola, underbrush and anise are followed by sweet rich black-fruit and licorice flavors that finish warm. The tannins bring quite a grip.

Recently bottled, this wine has some faint traces of bottle shock, but offers plenty of potential for further improvement. Crisp apple, iceberg lettuce and wet stone flavors combine. A touch of lemon rind adds interest to the finishing acidity.
Aromas of ripe Marasca cherry, cooking spice and a whiff of blue flower carry over to the juicy full-bodied palate along with crushed raspberry. Fresh acidity lifts the concentrated flavors.

This is a foot-trod, whole-cluster wine fermented like a white, that is copper orange and pink in color. The grapes come from the producer's Fox Den Vineyard and another Dutton Ranch site. Earthy cantaloupe, cherry and cranberry figure into the mix, as does orange peel and watermelon, the acidity tight and tautly stretched across the vibrant texture.

Blackberry and juniper aromas set the scene for cherry, black plum, white chocolate, orange zest and eucalyptus flavors in this wine. Smooth tannins provide the backdrop for its nice mix of fruit and savory characteristics, while the long-lasting finish is marked by a chocolate note.

Salt and pepper spice show on the nose of this bottling by a Texas-based winery, leading into aromas of mulberry, black plum and star anise. Darker black-plum flavors meet with pepper and allspice on the palate, which is rich in style.

This is the first vintage to be released from this vineyard-designate. It originates from Linda Falls Vineyard atop Howell Mountain, which the family has been farming since planting it in 2002. The wine is herbal and high in acidity, offering nuanced layers of tart cranberry, cassis and just-picked blackberry as well as a field-full of violet and wildflower.

This wine's shy, closed nose leads to a subtle palate filled with Conference pear, lemon and creamy yeast touches. It's light bodied but concentrated, and a lovely dash of white pepper spices up the finish.

Very ripe and heady aromas of blackberry, cassis and creamy oak take you back to the time when Mendoza was all about big extracted bruisers. This blend of Malbec, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot is wide, tannic and grabby. Flavors of cola, chocolate and baked black fruits finish chocolaty and oaky to the last gasp.

Cabernet Sauvignon (43%) and Cabernet Franc make up equal percentages of this wine, with the balance Petit Verdot. The aromas provide notes of vanilla, baking spice, fresh herb, cherry, pencil lead, dill and anise, with the oak far out front. The fruit flavors are lighter styled, not seeming fully able to stand up to the oak. Coffee notes linger on the finish.
This wine is intensely earthy and big boned, with a shock of tart acidity. It flourishes in the appellation's herbal mint and pomegranate.

This salmon-colored blend of 80% Tempranillo and 20% Garnacha smells more rubbery and dense than fruity and lifted. A lemony palate is endowed with more than enough acidity, while this tastes strictly of tart citrus fruits.

This is a firm, mineral-driven wine, densely textured and needing further aging. It has a craggy character, its black fruits shot through with tannins. The wine needs to soften, so should be drunk from 2019.

This wine presents vibrant citrus-zest aromas and clean, fruity, almost-sweet flavors on a rich texture. It has more thickness and mouthfeel than many renditions of the grape, and feels low in acidity.
This wine is light, ripe and generous, with attractive raspberry fruitiness and a touch of caramel. It's full in the mouth, crisp at the end and ready to drink.

A gamy meat aroma meets black cherry, black plum, hickory, licorice and peppercorns on the nose of this cool-climate Syrah by Winemaker Nicole Bertotti Pope. Loads of cracked pepper and bright purple-fruit flavors show on the palate alongside rosemary and bay leaf, all wrapped in a taut structure with zippy acidity.

This deeply flavored and silky-textured wine is surprising in the way that rather mild aromas of cigar box and pencil shavings lead to very rich and concentrated fruit flavors and a mouthfilling firmly tannic but certainly not heavy texture. It layers blueberry, black cherry, mocha and mint notes that seem to build and expand with each sip and linger on the finish. Best after 2024.
This wine currently is all about structure. It has power and weight as well as ripe jammy red fruits. The tannins and opulent fruit speaking to the wine's enormous potential. Drink from 2026.

The producer owns just over three acres of scattered parcels of this 123-acre vineyard, one of the iconic sites in Burgundy. Rich tannins and a huge structure are backed by powerful black damson fruit flavors. The wine is still very young and will not be ready to drink before 2025.

From one of the most famous Grand Cru vineyards in Burgundy, this huge wine comes from vines at least 70 years old, some nearly 100. Intense richness and concentration highlight the dark black fruits and acidity. Its weight and power are part of a package that will age. Drink the wine from 2024.

Dense and focused on the nose, this winery's top bottling is built to last, starting with aromas of elderberry, cola, wisteria and jasmine. Those flower elements extend to the palate, where crushed boysenberry, candied violets and black-pepper flavors are just starting to coalesce. Patience will reward with more savory elements, all wrapped in purple flowers. Drink 2020–2036.

Muscular and ripe, this cuvée mixes cranberry and cherry fruit over a lightly earthy foundation. Barrel aging adds textural flavors of halvah (tahini-based candy). It's not at all sweet, but lovely and detailed.

With a slight edge of reduction on the nose, and a leathery, earthy entry, this wine opens nicely into waves of soft, round and rich black-cherry, strawberry and blueberry. It maintains its exuberance through the succulent midpalate and quiet finish.
This wine may still be young, but it already offers rich fruits, creamed pear and hints of peach. These are cut by acidity and the a flinty texture typical of Pouilly Fumé. Drink this wine from 2019.

A field blend from old vines goes into this impressively rich wine. It has acidity of course, but it also has weight and density. Bright red fruits shine through the tannins that are enhanced by the wood aging. Drink this fine wine now.

Fragrant pineapple, peach and even fresh strawberry notes perfume this dry but intensely fruity Silvaner. It's a thirst-quenching wine balanced by refreshing grapefruit acidity. The finish is moderately long. Drink now–2022.
Crisp and perfumed, this wine is bright with apple and citrus flavors that are tense, cut with acidity and a mineral aftertaste. Drink now.

Beautifully aromatic hints of Cox's Orange Pippin apple are surrounded by overtones of orange and lemon on the nose. The palate makes this fruity array even more precise and appetizing. All is drawn precisely due to bright citrus freshness—think ripe lemon, tart red apple and tangerine. There is concentration, ripeness and utter freshness and quite a bit of power. The dry finish lets these notions speak all the more clearly. Drink through 2030.

The merest touch of nettle merges into a supreme lemon freshness on the nose. The palate rounds everything out with a subtle yeasty creaminess that boosts the pure lemon flavor. It never seems overly opulent or tart, holding delicious tension throughout. Drink now–2025.

There's a prominent but relatively restrained sense of cherry juice on the nose of this bottling alongside gamy meat, sagebrush and composting rose-petal aromas. The palate is framed by strong energy, which delivers red fruit, sharp red spice and tinges of spearmint and tarragon.

Lean and light aromas of pomegranate, tart strawberry and sour cherry mix with plenty of clove on the elegant nose of this botting by the actress Challen Cates. There is a strong spice quality to the sip, where loads of star anise and clove play against the darker cherry and mulberry flavors.

A citrus zest headiness on the nose precedes a very concentrated palate where zesty lemon blitzes against the medium sweetness. That citrus zest delineates the juicy pear and peach notes that swirl headily, showing their purity and fullness. This is concentrated, intense, off dry but supremely balanced. Lovely now but it will be even better with age. Drink now through 2028.

A subtle note of reduction still clings to the tender peach notes on the nose. The palate comes in with medium sweetness and paints an alluring picture of peach—of its fleshy, juicy and sweet ripeness, but also of the wonderfully textured bitterness of peach peel. On the finish a bright, lovely streak of ripe lemon zest sets a fresh friendly accent and leaves this with an off-dry moreish finish. Lovely now but it is certain to evolve. Drink now–2028.
Delicate dark fruit and baking spice aromas merge together in this. The straightforward palate delivers juicy black cherry, clove and white pepper flavors alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.

Unusual but intriguing aromas reminiscent of toasted nuts, paraffin and eucalyptus appear in the glass. The linear palate delivers citrus zest, yellow apple and saline flavors while a bitter almond note marks the finish.
Made primarily from estate fruit, this is a full and fleshy wine, with robustly integrated offerings of rich apple, mango and pear. It has a fresh, layered finish that sparks the palate for more.
Ripe strawberry, currant and underbrush carry this lithe, light-footed Pinot Noir. This is well balanced and straightforward in its appeal.

This wine is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon (55%), Cabernet Franc (26%), Syrah (12%) and Merlot. Aromas of huckleberry, plum, fresh herb, green pepper and black currant are followed by lighter-styled, easy-drinking blue- and black-fruit flavors. Green-pepper notes linger on the finish.

A blend of fruit from Klipsun and Angela's vineyards aged in 17% new French oak, cherry, black raspberry, baking spice, anise and dark fruit aromas are followed by focused dark-fruit flavors with a citrusy finish. The tannins give a gentle squeeze.

Like most 2016 reds from Chile, this is not overly ripe and instead expresses herbal aromas and flavors. Mild astringency and pulling tannins make for a tough palate, while herbal plum, berry and currant flavors finish with rubbery tannins and tomato sauce notes.

This rich, ripe wine offers fine tannins and, just as important, plenty of juicy black-currant flavors. The structure of the wine will allow it to age, although it is already attractive and fruity. Drink ideally from 2022.
This rich wine has some firm tannins as well as generous black fruits. It is balanced, with the crisp acidity coming through strongly. Pepper and pure fruit flavors finish this attractive wine.
Firmly tannic with a dusty texture, this wine is also rich in spicy black fruits and balanced with acidity. It has plenty of potential, with rich tannins and good acidity at the end. Drink from 2021.
A warm wine with ripe fruits and rich acidity, this is a blend of crisp Sauvignon Blanc with smoother Sémillon. This fruity wine is now ready to drink.

This fresh, fruity wine from organic grapes offers attractive red fruits and a backing of tannins. The dry core and the attractive fruits are coming together well, leaving a lively wine that will be ready to drink from 2020.

The latest vintage release from this producer is dominated by Pinot Noir, rich and with considerable aging potential. For now, it is mineral, zesty and tightly textured, a concentrated wine offering white and citrus fruits and a lingering aftertaste of fruit and acidity. Drink from 2021.

The tell-tale creamy vanilla of oak is immediately apparent on the nose. On the palate, the smokiness of the barrel dominates right now, but pure, fresh fruit lies underneath. Lemon and pear just wait for integration on the concentrated, bone-dry palate. This wine needs time. Drink 2022–2030.

This lush, compelling wine deftly mixes barrel spice notes with blackberry fruit. The tannins are polished and the flavors dusted with dark chocolate. The finish is long and nicely textured, adding dried herb suggestions to the mix. Drink now–2025.

Pure tangerine on the nose continues as a juicy, aromatic flow onto the palate where more lemon notes unfold. The balanced, vivid freshness shines and makes the mouth water while a zesty, pleasantly bitter edge sets an aromatic counterpoint. The finish is dry and appealing.

The flinty smoke of reduction covers the nose but the palate brims with urgent lemon flavors. Their fine acidity seems to be powered across the palate to create a lovely, tingling mouthfeel. The body is slender, the fruit is pure and the finish is long.

Planted more than 100 years ago by her family, this head-trained vineyard is still looked after by Dina. The wine's tart focused acidity zeroes in on candied-cherry and strawberry flavors. Sumptuous and brightly rich, it has undeniable structure and a lasting mineral element of oyster shell and brine.

Dark plum, red currant and cocoa dust show on the very expressive, quite ripe nose of this bottling. There is thickness to the mouthfeel and the flavors are lush with dark red berries, peppery spice, a hint of sagebrush and a fresh acidity.

Blended with 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, the black-pepper, clove, flower, herb and spice aromas are followed by light plump fruit flavors, with a tart finish. The concentration seems light for the variety but what's there is interesting.

Wild strawberry dominates in this thick, concentrated wine, that is full bodied in mouthfeel and ripeness. The texture and weight is supported by moderate acidity and a finishing touch of Meyer lemon chiffon.

Celebrating Portuguese maritime explorers, many of whom launched from the Vinho Verde region, the wine is ripe and creamy. Its blend of Loureiro and Alvarinho is soft, layering lime, pear and touches of apricot in a rich fruit salad of flavors. Drink this wine now.

Crisp fruit flavors of apple and jicama, along with peppery notes of white radish, come up through this pleasant Chardonnay. It's young, bright, balanced and refreshing—a solid accompaniment to simple seafood dishes.

Subtle aromas of mocha, espresso, cedar and a hint of blue flowers waft out of the glass. The dense palate evokes dried black cherry, licorice and roasted coffee bean alongside grainy tannins that give it a rather astringent finish. Drink after 2022.

Vivacious aromas of underripe blackberry, green peppercorn, cigar box and green olive show on the nose of this bottling from a coastal vineyard that sits 1,700 feet above the ocean. The softly tannic palate is tart with red fruit and loaded with forest spices, showing anise, fennel, green sage, more green olive and chaparral scrub.

Fern, pear peel and moss aromas create wonderfully green freshness on the nose of this wine. The palate adds subtle ripe pear notes packed in a slender, concentrated body that shimmers with white pepper zestiness.

Inviting aromas of toast, spring blossom, ripe yellow stone fruit and a whiff of graphite mingle in the glass. The tangy palate delivers mature golden apple, ripe peach and a citrus note while a hint of white almond wraps up the finish.

Aromas of jammy blueberry and graphite are reduced but solid. This Malbec has a wide palate that's wall to wall with fruit and tannins. Familiar flavors of plum and berry fruits finish with oak spice, cocoa and leftover red-plum notes. Drink through 2020.

Apple and hazelnut aromas lift out of the glass and carry over to the medium-bodied palate along with grapefruit and white-pepper notes. It's elegant and balanced, with fresh acidity. A tangy mineral note enlivens the finish.

Mouthwatering aromas of grilled herb, acacia, ripe yellow stone fruit and hazelnut waft out of the glass. On the round enveloping palate, a honeyed mineral note underscores yellow apple, apricot and almond. A note of unsweetened lemon drop lingers on the close.
This is a lemony oaky white, rich in baked apple and tropical notes. Full bodied and concentrated in powerful ripeness, it finishes clean and big.
This wine's grapy, jammy raspberry aromas are not the stuff of great Ribera del Duero. It lacks direction on the palate, tasting of herbal, medicinal plums and currants with a scratchy finish.
Ripe, grapy, floral aromas introduce this plump, chunky Monastrell. Soft tannins make the palate amorphous. Its baked plum and berry flavors are a touch raisiny, and the finish is heavy.

Ripe Mirabelle plum joins juicy pear notes on the nose. The palate has a similar, fruit-driven ease of rich pear flavors and sunny freshness. This easy, light wine finishes dry, despite a smidge of sweetness.

Intense notes of peach and melon are drenched in honeysuckle perfume on the nose. The palate intensifies these notions with an ample dollop of residual sugar and enticing, contrasting lemon zestiness. This wine is heady and distinctly sweet. Drink while aromas are at their peak.
Notions of very ripe stone fruit on the nose turn into ripe, fresh apple on the palate. Lemon joins in as well on the easy, light and dry body. Drink soon.

Dried grass, ripe red apple and a touch of white peach unfold on the nose of this light and easy white. Straightforward, yet clean and well balanced, tart flavors of green apple, lime and underripe plantain are fresh, easy and lend vibrancy through the finish.

Extremely pale in color with an orange rim, the aromas are presently hard to get at, with light notes of strawberryies, cherries and twigs emerging over time. The cherry flavors are light but juicy with raspberry notes on the finish. There are some good things happening, but it all seems a bit faint.

A wealth of cola, licorice and other sweet spice tones ride over a baked cherry core in this wine. The medium-bodied palate lends a bit more freshness, with ripe cherry and currant flavors showing more integration with the oak tones.

A light scent of toasted apple marries with tones of orange oil and pressed yellow flower on the nose of this value-minded wine. The citrus-forward character carries through to the palate, lifting the richer melon and grilled apple flavors. It finishes clean, with good acidic lift.

This herbaceous Viognier dispalys aromas of tangerine, dandelion, pear and kale. The weightier palate shows ripe tangerine and nectarine balanced by fresh greens and a good kick of acidity flowing into a white peach and white pepper finish.

Ripe fruit flavors dominate this full-bodied but soft-textured wine as it goes from mulled cherry aromas to baked blueberry flavors wrapped in mild tannins and barely a trace of acidity. While not sugar-sweet it has a dessert-like quality.

Savory nuances and a tight, nervy structure distinguish this impressive, potentially long-lived wine. It has all the ripe fruit and full body one could ask for, but also offers accents of sage, black tea and redwood forest in the aromas and meaty accents in the flavors. Great balance from good acidity and firm tannins completes the picture. Best after 2021.

There are simply not enough wines of this variety at this level from the Napa Valley so this stands out in more ways than one. Blueberry, blackberry and cinnamon provide a warmth of inviting and voluptuous layers of flavor that are buoyed by violet and lavender aromas, while softened tannins allow the texture to impress.
This wine brims in sizzling Asian spice and vanilla. Tangy acidity supports the bright, fresh core of cherry, pomegranate, leather and soy, finishing on tones of black tea and white pepper.

From an epic vineyard 1,250 feet above the Carmel Valley comes this bottling by the Bowlus family. It shows aromas of candied red cherry, grenadine and turned earth on the nose. The palate is herbally tinged and tightly wound, offering pomegranate, rose hips, dried flowers, pepper and tree bark flavors that extend deep into the finish.

Made entirely with native grape Aglianico, this stunning sparkler opens with enticing scents of Mediterranean scrub, bread crust, red berry and crushed stone. The dry, savory palate doles out juicy sour cherry, orange zest, strawberry, fennel, wild herb and flinty aromas alongside an elegant perlage and bright acidity. A mineral note reminiscent of oyster shell energizes the tangy finish.
designation: Esse Rosé Dosaggio Zero Metodo Classico

description: Rusty red cherry, wild mint, turned earth and rainbow peppercorns show on the lovely nose of this bottling by Chad Melville from his family's property. The palate is extremely fresh and vibrant, with Bing cherry and plump hibiscus flavors at the core, dazzled by white pepper and olive tapenade on the fringes.

While labeled Willamette Valley, this block selection is entirely estate-grown McMinnville AVA fruit. Spicy blackberry jam, cinnamon and chocolate flavors carry this wine, along with a pretty streak of candied violets. It shows medium concentration and high-toned brightness.
This opens with aromas suggesting blackberry, blue flower and an earthy whiff of tilled soil. On the soft, juicy palate, notes of mint and star anise accent a core of ripe black raspberry.

This blend is nearly a third each of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Merlot, with a deep, dark oak profile and plenty of firm, chalky tannins. The flavors lean toward licorice and cherry, with a bit of coffee and toffee richness.

Made in a Sauternes-like method, this dessert wine is balanced and smooth, its interwoven layers a celebration of salted caramel, green apple and dried apricot. Not too sweet nor rich, it will classically reward with blue cheeses, spiced nuts or on its own.
From a small parcel of vines next to the producer's cellar, this ripe wine is full of rich white fruits that are cut with acidity. It is well balanced and really crisp. Drink now.

This cloudy, unfiltered pét-nat is made from the Puglian variety Bianco d'Alessano. It changes rapidly in glass, morphing from tropical fruit and floral aromas to apple skins and green herbs. It's pithy and slightly creamy on the palate, balanced by a refreshing zing of acidity and a fruity, herbal punch right to the end. A porch pounder through and through, especially considering it comes in at just 10% abv.

Earthy, floral blackberry aromas are spicy and herbal in a way that's familiar to Carmenère. A fleshy palate with tomatoey acidity is strong but not overly tough. Herbal, minty olive and black plum flavors are spicy prior to a rumbling finish.
A perfumed wine from the small region west of Chablis, this is a tropical-fruit-flavored wine. Its light texture and freshness give it a lively, crisp character. Drink now.
Softly textured with ripe red fruits, this wine has layers of tannins as well as spicy wood-aging flavors. But the main thrust is full and generous fruit. Drink from 2022.

Fresh white fruit aromas of apple and pear include a hint of pine needle. This Cava from the Requena section of Valencia keeps it simple on the palate, so this ranks as an easy drinker. Standard white fruit flavors are clean and friendly.
This is a light, floral white that takes on medium-bodied weight and ripeness on the midpalate. Jasmine and apple highlight a viscous finish.

There's a pleasing petrol character on the nose of this medium-sweet bottling, along with grapefruit and orange peels and rainy cement. There's a flash of sweetness on the palate, with pear syrup and orange-blossom flavors.

This is a fascinating wine—one of the few white Pinot Noirs from the region. It starts with beeswax, yeast and lemon rinds on the nose, and then hits the palate both broadly and energetically, offering smoked lemon peels, the slightest hint of vanilla and more wax.
Meaty on the nose, this wine is tart in citrus and tangerine, spritzy, fresh and light bodied. The label is stellar and what's inside will refresh and rejuvenate. This is a fun wine.

This is all Dineen Vineyard (Rattlesnake Hills) fruit, aged in a mixture of neutral and twice-filled French oak barrels—a rare look at this variety in the state without overt oak influence. Aromas of pencil eraser, gummy bear, tobacco and spice are followed by plentiful dried and fresh tobacco flavors that show a reserved styling.

Slender and taut, the nose is pretty and perfumed with bright passionfruit, pineapple, nettles, grass and tomato leaf, with a touch of honey. There's tongue-tingling acidity on the palate to go with a slippery smooth texture and a good lick of citrus and tropical fruit.
Round and creamy, this has enticing scents of ripe apple, white peach and citrus zest that follow over to the savory palate along with a hint of vanilla. Fresh acidity brightens the rich flavors.
Citrus and yellow stone-fruit aromas meld together with a whiff of white rose. On the elegant refreshing palate, crisp acidity accompanies grapefruit, apricot and tangy blood orange.

This wine from the Daou brothers starts with dense aromas of blackberry, gravelly soil, wood ash and violets. The mouthfeel is plush in soft tannins, offering flavors of black currant, asphalt, purple flowers and marjoram.
Lime, kiwi and grass aromas show on the nose of this bottling. There is tremendous zip and a stony, chalky texture to the medium-bodied palate, which is full of grass and lime peel flavors.

Aromas of desiccated black fruits start with blackberry and air out in the direction of raisin. A huge palate is massively tannic, while this tastes of dried plum, cassis and tobacco. Severe tannins make for a rubbing finish. Drink through 2021.

Aromas suggesting ripe Concorde pear, yellow peach and dried herb carry over to the mature round palate along with a hint of hazelnut. It shows remarkable freshness and elegance for the hot vintage. Enjoy through 2023.

Named for the way part of the vineyard is planted, the vines trained on a high wire, this is a dense earthy red. (The site is also field planted to Carignane.) Juicy with plenty of acidity on the midpalate, it oozes blackberry, black cherry and white and black pepper, with a lasting hit of texture and freshness.

Abundantly flavorful and full bodied, this wine has lots of dark berry and black-cherry aromas, a big rich mouthfeel and deep layered fruit flavors sprinkled with spices from cinnamon to bay leaf to black pepper. It tastes extra ripe and has the moderate tannins and good acidity to support that ripeness.

This is a distinctive and detailed wine that starts with floral and spicy aromas, follows with generous fruit flavors and intriguing accents of tea, rhubarb and wet stone. It's ripe but not overly so, and that little bit of restraint gives it an appealing structured mouthfeel and fine sense of balance.

The Henschkes may be better known for Shiraz but their Cabs can be nearly as singular and expressive. Cyril blends small amounts of Cab Franc and Merlot for what is a relatively quiet, gentle wine that seems to glide along to its own beat, completely unaware of its more robust counterparts down the hill in the Barossa Valley. Understated aromas of red currants, graphite, violets, damp earth, and whispers of salt and smoke lead seamlessly into a palate of ultrafine, sinewy tannins, silky texture and an earthy finish. Still in its youth, Cyril should blossom over time.

Loads of chaparral spice, peppercorns and dried herbs dominate the nose of this appellation blend from one of California's cool-climate Syrah stars, but there is also a dark-fruit background of blackberry soda. Buoyant acidity carries the palate through chopped dill, juniper and more peppercorn flavors.
Explosive in succulent layers of fruit, this apple and pear-driven beauty is lightly spiced and well-integrated, with an impressive depth and length that gives it a warmth and welcoming character.

This mature, golden-colored wine is rich, concentrated and intensely sweet. Its ripe marmalade and orange character is balanced by concentrated honey and spice. Made from late-harvest grapes picked in November, the wine is never cloying, its richness balanced by the acidity that underpins wines from this region. Drink this Labasse family wine now.

Dried lemon peel and the rich notes of lemon oil reach the nose. The off-dry palate then comes in with almost a cornucopia of honeyed fruit. There is ripe apple with hints of quince. There are ripe lemons galore alongside juicy pear and aromatic stone fruit. The midpalate is concentrated and crisp, despite the slight sweetness. This is a shimmering plaything hovering between sweet accents and killer freshness. Make most of this potential at the table. Lovely now, certain to continue evolving. Drink now through 2038.

A lovely scented aspect of crushed citrus foliage flits by the nose before ripe pear notes take over. These also dominate the palate but are tempered by a lovely, pleasantly bitter edge that is reminiscent both of fir honey and citrus pith. Something underneath is fine and almost crystalline. Lemon freshness gives precision to the pear notes and brings the wine to a very balanced, just off-dry finish.

A very subtle nose suggests crushed citrus foliage while a hint of zesty lemon goes straight to the head. The palate then comes in with gentle ripe and fresh peach, a wonderfully bitter but pleasant edge of walnut and a gentle sweetness that colors the concentrated midpalate in off-dry pleasure. All the zesty lemon ensures lasting freshness on the off-dry finish.
designation: Furstentum Clos des Capucins Grand Cru

description: Something creamy and generous appears on the almost-closed nose. A little air wakes up the lime-zest notes which become insistent on the palate and counter spicy notes that have something of maple syrup about them. The finish is dry and lip smacking. This has just begun its evolution. Drink now–2030.

Enticingly fragrant, this focused red has alluring scents of rose petal, menthol, woodland berry and a whiff of new leather. The savory linear palate delivers juicy red cherry, crushed strawberry, star anise and cinnamon set against a backbone of vibrant acidity and firm, refined tannins. Drink 2022–2029.
This offers subtle aromas of dark berry, blue flower and underbrush. The juicy palate offers fleshy black cherry, clove and licorice alongside polished tannins.

Aromas of cedar, tobacco and dark-skinned berry emerge from the glass. On the concentrated brawny palate, close-grained tannins support mature black plum, vanilla and a touch of star anise. Drink through 2020.
This lifted, ripe tropical-fruit-flavored wine offers both good acidity and great richness. With its balanced acidity and smooth texture cut with acidity, it is already refreshing. Drink now.

A full nose with coffee, mocha, blackberry and herbal notes carries this blend of Carmenère, Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon. The palate is choppy in feel, tasting of chocolaty berry fruits and tobacco. More chocolate carries the tannic finish.
designation: Gran Reserva Molino de Viento Vineyard Carmenère-Syrah-Cabernet Sauvignon

description: This oak-aged wine is rich, ripe with bold tropical fruits and a lightly mineral texture. Spice and toastiness balance with the up-front fruitiness and the crisp acidity at the end. Drink this wine from 2019.
This is a thick, dense white with earthy floral and herbal characteristics. Stone fruit and vanilla make themselves known on the palate, evolving in the glass to show a richness of tropical flavor.

Aromas of red berry unite with whiffs of Mediterranean scrub, blue flower and exotic spice. Reflecting the nose, the elegantly structured, focused palate delivers juicy red cherry, strawberry, star anise and baking spice accompanied by firm, polished tannins. Bright acidity lends balance. Drink 2022–2031.

This is a structured wine, ripe yet layered with minerality and a full texture. Rich yellow and white stone fruits are cut with steely acidity that shows the wine's aging potential. Coming from arguably the finest of the Grand Cru vineyards, the wine is still young. Wait until 2023.

Located on the terraced hillsides of Gigondas, the vineyard site La Louisiane boasts Grenache vines that are nearly 80 years old. This is a powerful, intoxicating wine meshing rich black cherry and berry flavors against a sheen of crushed-stone minerality. It's voluminous but not dense, finishing on chalky, gripping tannins. Beautiful already but should improve through 2028, hold a few years further.

Subtle and elegant aromas of pomegranate, dried rose petals and a touch of game show on the beautiful nose of this bottling. There's a wide array of flavors on the palate, from dried lilac, violet and rose petals to black plum, tarragon, Earl Grey tea and more game.

Aromatic herb, rose, wild berry and dark spice aromas take shape in the glass. It's savory, elegant and juicy, doling out sour cherry, crushed strawberry, star anise and orange zest alongside a tangy saline note. Fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity provide balance and support. Drink 2022–2031.

Exotic herb and floral tones start off this brawny full-bodied wine. Plum and black currant flavors underscore bristling acidity and a well-built tannic structure, as secondary characteristics of sage, cedar and oak emerge. This should be put away and enjoyed 2025–2030.

Clean and direct red cherry and berry aromas take center stage in this wine's fruit-forward bouquet, sitting atop hints of milk chocolate and raspberry sauce. Fleeting tannins and soft acidity make it an approachable and easy-to-drink selection.
Lightly volatile seeming aromas of raspberry cobbler, barrel spice, vanilla and cherry lead to sweet full-bodied raspberry and cherry flavors. It doesn't all work.

Underripe banana, green plum and lime set the stage of this fresh and inviting Sauvy. The palate offers more of the same, with ample acidity and additional hints of tart lychee and green apple that hang around on the medium-length finish.

With the acidity typical of the grape, this sweet wine is as much about freshness as about a honeyed character. It has apricot and pineapple flavors and great acidity to balance. Drink this attractive wine from 2019.
Cherry candy, raspberry and herb aromas are followed by plump ripe sweet flavors with a warm tangy finish. It comes off as quite ripe.

Aromas of vanilla, char, coffee and dried herb are followed by soft red-fruit flavors, with plentiful barrel accents. The variety seems a bit hard to find, especially compared to their entry-level offering from the same vintage.
Light footed and lemony fresh, this delicately sweet wine offers punchy citrus flavors with subtle notes of pollen and stony mineral. It's easy drinking and refreshing. Drink now.

This wine is 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Cabernet Franc, topped off with 10% Petit Verdot and 5% Merlot. Aged in a mixture of American and French oak, it delivers green aromas, suggesting savory herbs, cherry, vanilla, coconut, dill and spice. The sweet barrel flavors tussle a bit with the fruit on the palate, not seeming entirely harmonious at present.
Mourvèdre makes up 63% of this wine, with the rest 32% Syrah and 5% Grenache. It's quite reduced out of the gate yet shows a ripe mixture of blackberry, raspberry, black pepper and spice flavors.

Almost as clear as water in the glass, this is a very fresh and clean bottling, yet extremely tropical in style. Aromas of guava, ripe papaya and plumeria extract lead into a palate that tightens up at first before unleashing the coconut oil, guava juice and white-flower flavors. Very crisp, yet it is flowery and ripe.

This wine's forward black cherry candy flavors lead to some less appealing stiff tannins. There's a chalky mouthfeel as it finishes. It's a fair value for the price, and more bottle age may soften it a bit.

This follow-up to the winery's excellent 2016 rosé puts more emphasis on bitter herbal flavors as a counterpoint to sweet red fruit. There's detectable residual sugar, and the balance between bitter and sweet components is a little jarring, at least for the moment. Further bottle age may help pull things together.

This wine with an attractive bite is still young, with a tight texture and plenty of ripe fruit. Lemon and spice flavors are shot through with acidity and a strongly zesty character. Drink the wine from 2019.
This stylish Pinot Noir is full of red-cherry flavors that are freshened by crisp acidity. It also has tannins and touches of wood aging, giving the wine both shape and ageability. Drink from 2019.

This 37-acre estate managed by Annick Tinel-Blondelet has produced a juicy wine with open white fruits and good acidity. Called after the original name for the Sauvignon Blanc grape, it has great fruitiness, a taut texture and is ready to drink.

This full, dry Chenin conveys notes of flowers, zesty citrus and crunchy ripe apple. Its acidity is bright and crisp while keeping richness and an open texture up front. Drink this wine now, or wait until 2020 for a more mature character.

Juicy and polished, this offers aromas of sunbaked earth, mature plum, leather and a whiff of Mediterranean scrub. On the dense, full-bodied palate, close-grained tannins give structure to dried cherry, raspberry jam, star anise and a dusting of bitter cocoa before a rather drying finish. Drink 2020–2027.
