This is an extra-rich wine, concentrated with ripe fruits. It is still young with no holds barred in its power and intensity. With its dense texture and upfront fruit, it needs to age. Drink from 2020.
Thick, woody and flavored in anise, mango and pear, this is an approachable, attractively priced and well-made wine that will work well with food or on its own.
Aromas of barrel spice, creamsicle and flower lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors and a warm finish. The oak influence seems a bit overweighted for the fruit in the bottle.

This medium-bodied wine has plenty of plummy flavors and a spicy streak of black pepper and smoke running through it from the aroma to the finish. It's smooth in texture, moderately concentrated and is 100% estate grown, very rare for a wine this inexpensive.
A fruity wine with youthful acidity and bright-cherry flavors, this is simply structured, with just a touch of dry tannin. Drink now.

Tart blackberry and fresh-picked raspberry mix with an undertow of tanned leather and cedar on the nose. Juicy acidity balances the crushed velvet tannins, housing flavors of ripe blueberry, blackberry and plum that are accented by vanilla, baking spice and balsam. The vanilla and blackberry finish is luscious and plummy.
Bright, fresh and crisp, this wine is textured and fruity. It has a strong mineral edge as well as good acidity. Drink this wine now.

This single-vineyard bottling is very full on the nose with tangy red-cherry, fruit-punch, marjoram and sumac aromas. Lively and tart red fruits show on the sip, which also offers carnation and rosewater flavors that lead into a squeaky finish.

Spicy and herbal, this is a full-bodied, lushly plush wine that holds its power and concentration well in firm polished tannin. Sage, peppercorn and leather ride a lengthy midpalate complementing the bolder aspects of dark chocolate and coffee.

Salted apple and white peach aromas meet with a lemony edge, hint of toast and flash of sandalwood on the nose of this bottling. There is strong energy to the sip, where tangy waves of lemon candy meet with warmer flavors of pan-seared apple.

Released after the 2014, this wine is herbal, with polished tannins that give it a softness around the edges. Tart cranberry and currant flavors accentuate its heightened acidity and underlying elegance. Still, time in the cellar could do interesting things. Enjoy 2023–2030.

The nose of this wine hints at black tulip, black cherry and dusky rose petal. The palate presents a smooth, beautifully fine-grained tannic structure that frames fresh, lovely, tart but ripe cherry notes. A light red with lovely depth of fruit and elegance.

Dark, inky aromas of blackberry, graphite and mocha get things going. This Malbec is full, thick and resiny in feel, with overt oak. Flavors of chocolaty oak, mocha and berry fruits finish round and beefy.

Made from 85% Sangiovese and 15% Cabernet Sauvignon, this opens with toasted oak, mocha and dark-skinned berry aromas. The dense palate offers clove, blackberry jam and roasted coffee notes alongside close-grained tannins. Drink through 2021.

Intensely floral aromas of summer rose gardens and lavender fields leap from the glass, with hints of freshly peeled orange peeking through. The palate is equally playful in flavors of lemon juice and orange-blossom honey, kept light by tangy acidity and jubilant bubbles. White peach joins lemon juice on the finish, with just a touch of nuttiness bringing it to a close.

This is a pretty, delicate wine with notes of honey, blossoms, peaches and lychees and tomato leaf. There's a lovely chalky texture, with mouthwatering acidity and a ripe fruit character adding to the wine's charm.

Aromatic green and fresh yellow pear combine to very appetizing effect on the nose. The palate is less overt in fruit but brings bright zesty citrus to the fore. This is refreshing, light, slender and dry.

This blend of 75% Primitivo, 13% Syrah and 12% Cabernet Franc is starting to show its age, offering rustic dried red-cherry, dust and leather flavors. There are hints of clove and cinnamon decorating the candied red fruit of the palate, but it's time to drink up on this bottling.

Sweet grass, peony, sweet pea and fynbos aromas lead the nose of this floral white. They're grounded by tones of white peach, Meyer lemon and white melon rind, though the fruity core seems secondary to the abundant herbal tones. Medium acidity lends enough cut to keep the mouthfeel vibrant and the finish fresh. Drink now.
This opens with earthy aromas of leather, charred underbrush and dark berry. The ripe, chewy palate delivers black currant jam, vanilla and star anise alongside rounded tannins.
Strong flavors of crunchy apple with hints of cured meat ride along an unctuous texture in this estate-grown wine that holds its acidity well.

This is pure Arinto whose freshness has been softened and given an extra dimension by the wood aging. It is still a fruity wine with plenty of apple flavors. But the toast and peppery edge give the wine richness and a full texture. Drink the wine now.

Also known as Fernão Pires, the Maria Gomes grape is widely planted in the center and south of Portugal. This interpretation comes from a single vineyard in hills close to the Tagus river valley. It is a delicious soft easy wine with lively apple and ripe green-plum flavors that have an edge of minerality. Drink the wine now.

Part of a limited production range from consultant Luis Duarte, this wine is ripe, gently structured and made to be drunk young. With red fruits, layers of acidity and with delicious juiciness, the wine is ready now.

Something honeyed, something mellow plays on the nose of this lemony Riesling. The palate is bone dry and concentrated, yet there is a creamy richness which lends a sonorous aura to the lemony core. All this stems from fermentation in new wood. The dry finish has a touch of maple syrup and resin. Wonderful and unusual. Drink now through 2035.
designation: Altenberg de Bergheim Addict 1.23 Grand Cru

description: Edgar Torres tapped Zotovich Vineyard for a stunning cool-climate Syrah in this bottling, which starts with aromas of elderberry, tar, charred beef, pepper dust and dark violet. The palate is firmly structured, showing white pepper, black currant and more beef and purple flowers. Drink 2020–2035.

Ripe red-cheeked Mirabelle plums and peach fringed with rose petals on the nose promise juicy full-fruited expression. The palate keeps that promise with a flowing, almost creamy and evolving picture of peach, peach skin and wonderful lemon freshness. At six years of age, this wine has only just began its trajectory of development and, while lovely now, will continue maturing. The off-dry finish is long, balanced and zesty.

Ripe red and yellow apples, juicy apricot and sunny Mirabelles on the nose are all framed by lemon freshness while something floral, almost like jasmine hovers. This same fruit-driven concentration appears on the dry but very textured palate. There almost is something like apple crispness that is mellow at the same time. The lemony brightness keeps everything precise. The finish is dry and lasting and packs a wonderful, almost salty punch. Drink now–2030.

The ethereal lift of dried lemon peel on the nose is followed by lemon-tempered mellowness of ripe pear, ripe peach and golden Mirabelles on the palate. This is honed and lifted, slightly sweet but balanced by the glistening freshness of that pervasive lemon. A field blend of Riesling and Gewurztraminer, this is a wonderful synthesis of sunshine, soil and grape. The finish is off dry and subtle. It is lovely now but sure to evolve.

Ripe but wonderfully tangy notes of orange zest on the nose transmute into a wonderfully high-toned palate of citrus depth. Mandarins and tart oranges create a vision of utterly juicy but always tangy fruit. The palate is dry but it is the tingling freshness, countered by ample fruit, that sets the exciting moreish tone. Drink through 2030.
High-toned acidity and spice combine with great intrigue in this beautifully quaffable wine, marked by complex texture and bright layers of orange and grapefruit.

Smoky, flinty reduction still envelopes the nose. Underneath, however, a wine of great purity and freshness stretches its fruity-fresh balance from ripe pear to vivid lemon. The palate is rich but taut, attaining honeyed overtones but remaining chiseled and bone dry. Intriguing now, it's full of promise. Drink now–2028.

Aromas of Mediterranean scrub, wild berry, blue flower and crushed herb aromas take shape in the glass. Elegant and delicious, the polished palate delivers ripe morello cherry, raspberry compote, licorice and tobacco alongside taut fine-grained tannins. A salty mineral note lingers on the close while bright acidity provides lovely balance. Drink through 2029.

While subdued on the nose, ripe rich yellow-peach and nectarine flavors burst from the palate of this sun-kissed spätlese. It's a juicy, almost tropical sip, but maintains a racy acidic edge and lingering phenolic finish. Delightful now but likely to improve further well through 2030.

Bracing lime acidity and earthen notes of crushed stone and salt mark this complex spätlese. Bracing white grapefruit and lemon flavors abound on the palate, softened by a honeyed sweetness and hint of caramelized sugar on the finish. This taut racy wine that should improve through 2030, hold further.

While dry in style, this intensely ripe Riesling offers a deeper concentration of white grapefruit and yellow-plum flavors than the producer's kabinett trocken. It's richer and fuller on the palate while maintaining its zesty lime-tinged acidity and crisp mineral backbone. This lavish but elegant wine finishes on a hint of orange blossom.

Powerfully structured and brooding in dark fruit, this velvety red (named for the winery's founder) is exotic and savory in nature. A succulent midpalate gives way to highlights of white pepper, cardamom and black tea as the ripeness grips the tongue.

Hugely concentrated and a touch reduced, this is a lovely, generously full-bodied wine, rich as a dark-cherry cobbler in flavor. The barrel oak is pronounced and supportive of the wine's seasonings of black pepper, violet and plum. The ripeness and richness are profound, met by a structure that suggest further cellaring; enjoy best 2025–2030.

The winery has been working with this same block since 2005, and its experience shows, starting with aromas of rugged thyme, bay leaf, peppercorn and wild cherry. There's an earthy core to the palate, with forest floor, moss, wild mint and thyme flavors, but quite a lot of raspberry fruit as well. Extremely energetic throughout.

Smoke, crushed stone, underbrush, aromatic herb and wild berry aromas lift out of the glass. Structured, focused and loaded with finesse, the savory palate delivers juicy Marasca cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice, ground pepper and a flinty mineral note alongside taut, refined tannins. It's balanced, with bright acidity. It already has a great depth of flavors but will develop even more complexity over the next several years. Drink through 2026.

Always impressive and powerful in its richness, this Grand Cru has produced a full-bodied, rich and generously fruity wine. Wood aging has added some spice as well, giving a fuller, richer character. The wine needs to age and should not be drunk before 2022

Rich and juicy, this youthful, structured wine is from one of Volnay's top vineyards. It is heading towards ripe opulence and dense black-cherry flavors as it matures. Concentration and fruit characterize this impressive wine. Drink from 2023.
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Les Santenots Premier Cru

description: This rosé, which is from Tempranillo, shows strawberry and red-plum skins on the nose as well as some sharper rose-petal scents. The texture is tightly wound, offering raspberry and wet stone flavors.

Leather and pine needle scents compete with blackberry fruit in this wine. The mouthfeel is soft and rounded, and the fruit is annotated with dried rosemary highlights. That leathery note continues through the finish.

This opens with strawberry and cherry candy scents and flavors. It's front-loaded and fruity, the flavors fresh but fading quickly. Though it spent 14 months in 40% new French oak, the barrel influence is muted.
After just three years, this wine has developed maturity. Its red cherry fruit and tannins remain but are balanced by the secondary, undergrowth character of mature Pinot Noir. Drink now.
Briny and oaky, this wine offers a sweetness of vanilla, peach and pineapple, with a bite of apple pie at its end.
This wine's herbal plum and berry aromas are dry and subtly green. It's tight and racy, with raw tannins, currant and red plum flavors and a dry, herbal finish marked by lemony acidity.

The aromas of apple and pear seem difficult to access at present. Dry medium-bodied flavors follow. It's a pleasant if somewhat innocuous offering of the variety, with the concentration at times seeming a bit light.

Very ripe and overextracted aromas of berry and grape meet with a touch of vanilla bean on this rustic bottling, which includes 12% Viognier. The palate explodes with extreme amounts of acid, which carry candied boysenberry and lavender flavors.

Fruit forward black currant, plum and green pepper aromas are followed by plump, pleasant, lightly sweet fruit flavors. There's not much complexity, but if you want to know what Cabernet looks like unadulterated by oak, this wine is it.

Shy notes of lemon peel, white flower, peach fuzz and clementine zest are slowly revealed on the nose. This has a round mouthfeel with gently tingling acidity. Flavors of nectarine and grapefruit are tinged with endives and are neutral in character, leading to a ripe lemon finish dusted with white pepper.

Aromas of yeasty citrus, fresh corn and lanolin announce a softer, warmer-climate Albariño than what most fans of the grape are used to. A solid but bland palate lacks lift and snap but isn't flabby. Peachy yeasty flavors are limited through the finish but never problematic.

Mocha, dark fruit and coconut lead the nose. The extracted palate offers prune, roasted coffee bean and star anise alongside evolved, but rather astringent tannins. You can feel the evident alcohol as it lacks fruit richness.
This opens with delicate aromas of acacia flower and toasted almond. The aromas carry over to the linear palate along with citrus notes and white peach. Drink soon.

This affordable wine is a little obvious in terms of oaky spices in the aroma and flavors, but it backs them up with good cherry and berry flavors to complete the package. It's medium bodied and smooth in texture.

Earthy berry aromas are matched by spicy oak and vanilla notes. In the mouth, this warm-vintage crianza feels snappy, sappy and sinewy. Oaky red plum and currant flavors finish spicy but basic. Overall, this is a good but standard Rioja, nothing more.
Obvious oak spices including cedar, clove, cinnamon and wood char fill the aroma of this medium-bodied, extroverted wine and continue in the flavors, giving a sweet edge to the fruit component.
This is an earthy brawny red wine with bold ripe characteristics of leather, espresso and black cherry. It broods intensity and big flavor.

Aromas of French oak, vanilla and a whiff of paraffin lead the way. The aromas carry over to the rather lean palate along with butterscotch, vanilla, bitter almond and a note of candied tangerine zest but not much fruit richness. Drink soon.

Extremely concentrated fruit flavors and full body make this wine impressive and memorable. It has spicy, floral, slightly smoky aromas, and deep dark black-cherry and blackberry flavors that are unusually intense and delicious. The mouthfeel is moderately tannic and helps support all that fruit.

A touch of ripe Mirabelle plum joins the pear fruit on the nose. The resolutely dry palate holds them tight on a very concentrated, fresh but also earthy body. Taut and clean, this needs a little more time in bottle. The finish is whistle-clean.

Loads of green peppercorns, juniper, dried violets and charcoal show on the nose of this extremely cool-climate Syrah. That pepper spice powers the palate, where thyme, forest moss and firm tannins frame background boysenberry flavors.

Skeins of wax and pollen, lemon and lime collide in this taut, elegantly composed dry wine. The palate is bold, offering penetrating citrus flavors marked by hits of steel and an airy white-blossom perfume. It is a juicy, pristinely fruity wine that finishes on lingering notes of honey and lime.

This blend of Mourvèdre, Grenache and Petite Sirah is big and brawny, with aromas of roast beef, black pepper and wood smoke. The palate is concentrated and layered in flavors of blackberry, coffee bean and blueberry, framed by fine-grained, gripping tannins. Made by the Bekeris family, who emigrated from Lithuania. Best after 2021.

Rich blue fruit is the star of the show in this 100% varietal wine, from grapes grown on this hillside site. Enticing in crushed rock and dusty earth, the fruit is contrasted by tones of leather and black pepper. A powerful tannic structure underlies it all.

Dark in color, this wine tastes of strawberry leather with an expansive taste of biscuit, lemon zest and Bing cherry. Medium bodied, it remains fresh in acidity, with a bite of body that gives it a nice mouthfeel that's complex but never weighty.

This wine has cherry and violet aromas, with a note of talcum powder. It's smooth on the palate, with soft tannins and flavors of blackberry, cassis, licorice and lavender that culminate in a spicy, cranberry-laced finish.

With aromas of cherry, cranberry and chocolate, this wine offers similar notes on the palate, along with a hint of eucalyptus. Its strong and slightly grippy tannins are kept in check by vibrant acidity that triumphs on the mint and orange finish.

Soft red plum, rose petal and raspberry aromas are cut by tangerine rinds on the nose of this rosé. There's a zippy structure and grippy texture on the palate, which carry fresh flavors of strawberry, lemon pith and the pop of bubblegum.

Acacia, beeswax, crushed herb and yellow stone-fruit aromas align with a whiff of oak. The elegantly structured savory palate has apricot, tangerine zest, ginger and toasted nut. A hint of coffee lingers on the close.

From the first vintage aged in a new cellar, thsi wine is precise, dense and full-bodied wine. Rich black-currant and black-plum flavors contrast with the wine's young structure and acidity. It will age well and should be drunk from 2022.
From old vines, this rich wine is beautifully concentrated and fruity. Apples and crisp green plums go with citrus to give a wine that has delicious potential. Drink from 2019.

Relative to the rest of Fullerton's 2016 Pinots, the Croft seems the most tannic, with a thicker presence in the mouth. Blackberry, black cherry and cola components are the defining flavors, with black olive and dark chocolate highlights running through the tannins.

Excellent fruit concentration and very good balance make this full-bodied wine a winner. Minty cedary aromas accent the vivid black-cherry and pomegranate flavors as moderate tannins and fresh acidity add appetizing structure.

Crisp waves of cherry vanilla are complemented by citrus-driven acidity in this light bright wine that's well made and memorable. Textured, it is lengthy and has ample body to work on its own or with food.

Red-cherry compote, balsamic-glazed berries and a pinch of dried sage show on the nose of this bottling from a new label that's made by a secret group of winemakers. It's relatively light on the palate but full of flavors, from sour cherry and cranberry to pepper dust and dried marjoram.
Deep, dark and lush aromas of blackberry, black plums, lilac and smoked meat show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is well rounded and cohesive, showing berry, plum and espresso-bean flavors.
This opens with cedar, mocha and dark-skinned berry aromas. The firm palate offers tobacco, licorice and black plum flavors alongside close-grained tannins. Drink through 2022.
This vineyard-designated rosé brings aromas of strawberry, orange blossom and sweet herb. The palate is packed full of broad-feeling fruit flavors that deliver enjoyment.

This unusual blend of Pinot Grigio, Gewürztraminer and Riesling opens with heady aromas of dried apricot and white rose. Those aromas carry over to the syrupy palate, along with mature yellow peach, Golden Delicious apple, candied nectarine and bitter almond hints. Fresh acidity gives the rich flavors a much-needed boost.

Made from organic grapes grown in a single vineyard, this wine is light, with deliciously pure red-currant and berry fruits. It has a lively palate, enhanced by the crisp acidity and juicy fruitiness. Drink now.

Years into its existence and this varietal Garnacha Blanca still smells like raw oak and turpentine, although those aromas are more ingrained than superficial. A well-balanced mature palate with lively acidity is helpful, while this tastes of fino Sherry and dried white fruits. A long finish with salt and pepper notes references oak as its final chord.

Initial notes of struck flint and crushed vitamin subside with aeration, revealing crisp tones of watermelon and strawberry here. Full bodied and dry, it's an understated and mineral wine with a bright, raspberry-inflected finish.

Ripe, chunky and slightly static is how to describe the nose on this prime gran reserva from a benchmark year. A flush lush palate shows no gaps and is full from side to side. Baked plum and berry flavors are ripe to the max without tasting sweet, while this darkens up and tastes more savory on the finish. Drink from 2020–2035.

Almost black in color, this blend of Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro and Tinta Roriz is complex and intense. Its big tannins are nowhere near softened, suggesting rich fruit behind the structure. This wine has considerable aging potential. Drink from 2022.

This rich wine is dense with dark, black fruits and layers of tannins. Wood aging for 18 months still shows in the toasty character, although this will go as the wine ages. This powerful wine will age for many years. Drink from 2020.

Perennially delicious, this vintage holds up tradition by offering fresh, strong flavors of strawberry, raspberry and vanilla cookie. Blending 70% Chardonnay and 30% Pinot Noir from several vineyards, including Tognetti and Hyde, it's floral and softly interwoven—a fresh, focused delight. A portion of proceeds goes to Napa agricultural land preservation.

The fresh and lemony nose creates notions of haystacks and beautifully dried hay flowers. There is something ripe and rounded here, and the warm vintage turns the usual herbal tinges of Sylvaner on their heads. The palate is concentrated and remains sinuous, even if aromatically this is richer than usual. This is a lovely, unusual and wonderfully gastronomic wine, with a lovely textural element on the midpalate. The finish is dry and fresh.

Ripe, fresh and almost lifted pear notes stream from the glass. In the background is a touch of honeycomb. The honey and beeswax notes take over on the medium-sweet palate where their richness also lends a viscous texture to the rounded and concentrated midpalate. Candied lemon zest acts as a counterbalance but this finishes with honeyed sweetness. Drink now through 2028.

Aromas of yeasty citrus, fresh corn and lanolin announce a softer, warmer-climate Albariño than what most fans of the grape are used to. A solid but bland palate lacks lift and snap but isn't flabby. Peachy yeasty flavors are limited through the finish but never problematic.

Mocha, dark fruit and coconut lead the nose. The extracted palate offers prune, roasted coffee bean and star anise alongside evolved, but rather astringent tannins. You can feel the evident alcohol as it lacks fruit richness.
A very pretty pale-salmon color, apple and cherry aromas are followed by broad-feeling fruit flavors that taper on the back end. It seems a bit weighty.
Lime, yeast and spiced apple aromas combine to make a good impression. This brut is plump, with mild acidity. Bread and yeast flavors end clean on the finish.

This wine is light bodied, very fresh in aroma and reasonably crisp in texture, showing green-apple flavors and subtle herb and citrus notes. It is very clean, well balanced and should be perfect for a crowd.

Baking spice, fresh herb, blackberry, orange peel and cranberry aromas are followed by flavors that mix equal parts fruit and barrel, with orange peel notes on the finish. Grainy tannins provide support.

Generous aromas of wild berry, sage and spice shine through in this fruity, bold and well-balanced wine that was fermented with native yeast. The palate offers tangy raspberry and sour-cherry flavors, firm tannins, lively acidity and, most importantly, an appetizing character that keeps you coming back for more.

This is a thick, layered and leathery wine, with ample spice and complexity. Cinnamon, toast, clove, red currant and black cherry tones highlight a full-bodied robust experience of impressive integration and tamed tannins.

Firmly structured, this young and generous wine has power and concentration. Its rich tannins and solid texture are good auguries for the future, balanced with red-plum and berry flavors. Drink this wine from 2024.

Made from equal proportions of Syrah and Grenache. Fleshy plum and cherry notes juxtapose savory hints of bramble, smoked meat and earth here. It's full bodied and lavish yet anchored by a grip of firm, fine tannins on the finish. Silky yet invigorating and mineral. Enjoy now–2030.

Crayon wax, pencil shavings and red currant highlight this brightly structured and powerfully ripe wine, a worthy representative of the mountain site. The earthy fruit is complemented by a light sprinkling of clove, sage and cedar, while strong, chalky tannins provide a substantial mouthfeel of graceful concentration.

This blend of 81% Merlot, 5% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5% Cabernet Franc, 5% Petit Verdot and 4% Malbec bursts forth with aromas of ripe blackberry, boysenberry, baking spice and pencil shavings. The palate is tightly wound with firm chalky tannins and bright acid giving poignance to fruity flavors of exotic red plum and baking spice.
Aromas of dark-skinned berry, tilled soil and a whiff of carob carry over to the easygoing palate along with a note of bitter almond. It's a simple but well made Nero d'Avola, with round tannins.
Green apple and fresh gooseberry aromas lead to a palate of star fruit, apple and peach. The finish is pleasantly sweet.

Gritty aromas of road tar and burnt wood share space with herbaceous berry fruit scents on the nose of this wine. It's rough in feel, with dark, spicy flavors of berries and chocolate. The finish is herbal, peppery and consistent with the rest.
This opens with vanilla, dill and fiery black fruit aromas. In the mouth, it's linear, with tomato, plum and oak spice flavors that finish with lively acidity and some alcoholic heat.
This is yet another very hard 2014 Ribera del Duero, devoid of elegance Its cherry, berry and herbal aromas lack focus, and its black fruit and toast flavors finish with scraping tannins.
Peppery, beefy aromas and rich deep berry flavors highlight this full-bodied and firm-textured wine. It is bold and mouthfilling, with a touch of ripeness on the finish.
From a new dry-farmed site, this is fleshy and expansive in complex waves of flavor and texture. Mocha, coconut flakes and blueberry combine around a rich and rounded body that boasts power and grip.

This project from Doug Shafer and Elias Fernandez continues to impress, showing the beauty of this variety in California when in the right hands. The nose offers an undeniable wealth of violet and lavender while the palate exudes smoked cherry, juicy blueberry and an underbelly of garrigue.

Peach, apricot and intense notions of blood-orange zest make for a perfumed, alluring nose. The palate holds on to these enticing aromatics, wrapping them gently in rounded sweetness balanced with candied-citrus liveliness. It's a rounded, medium-sweet but very balanced wine.

Aromas of black-skinned berry, Mediterranean scrub and toasted almond lead the way on this 100% Nero d'Avola. The structured balanced palate doles out ripe blackberry, raspberry jam, white pepper and a touch of cinnamon alongside bright acidity and fine-grained, elegant tannins. Enjoy through 2025.

Vibrant white grapefruit and gooseberry flavors in this Weissburgunder, or Pinot Blanc, are highlighted by zesty lime and lemon acidity. It's dry and full in body, but boasts a racy citrus lift on the midpalate and a lingering chalky finish. Its fresh fruity appeal is ideal now but should hold well through 2023.

This wine's heady coffee and mocha aromas come at you off the bat, followed by roasted black fruit scents that scream of many months in new oak. Its cedary berry and cocoa flavors sizzle with lemony acidity, framed by firm tannins. It finishes ripe and hot. Drink through 2040.

This is a vegetal style from the bottom of New Zealand's South Island. Snow pea and bell pepper notes lead the way, with passionfruit in the background. The palate is creamy in feel, but it's balanced by lifted acidity and more fruit-driven flavors.
White rose and strawberry aromas carry over to the dry, softly sparkling palate along with hints of culinary spice and blood orange. Tangy acidity lifts the juicy finish.
Bold tannins are the dominant character of this wine. Its weight comes as much from its structure as from the fruit that is still suppressed and needs time. Drink from 2022.

In the warmer climes of Hawke's Bay on the North Island, much of New Zealand's (a k a Marlborough's) classic green vegetal notes are gone. The wines exhibits more tropical fruit characters, displaying ripe mango, peach, and lychee notes that are balanced by lifted acidity.

Produced from Gamay Noir grown on both sides of the Columbia River, this bursts with scents of apple blossoms and cherries. The deep color and slight bitter-skin flavor suggest that it spent some time macerating prior to fermentation. What it lacks in finesse it makes up for with fruit power.

This is reductive at first, masked by onion and plastic aromas. It does blow off with some with time in glass to reveal peach, pear and floral notes. The palate is less weighty than the nose suggests although there's some viscosity to the texture that's nicely balanced by tingly, citrusy acidity.

This bold, black-colored, black-fruit-flavored wine also offers rich tannins, layers of toasty spice and acidity. The 15 months in wood have given a ripe, full-bodied wine that will age further. Drink this powerful wine from 2022.

Plumeria, honey and poached pear aromas show on the rounded, ripe and yet somewhat reserved nose of this blend of 75% Roussanne and 25% Viognier. The palate is both tropical and extremely fresh, with pear flesh and light guava flavors wrapped up in a bountiful acid and grippy texture.

This is an open, juicy wine, full of berries backed by tannins. Produced from organically grown grapes, the wine is an immediately friendly take on Malbec, never letting the tannins stand in the way of its delicious fruit. Drink from 2020.

This blend, which is dominated by Syrah along with Touriga Nacional and Aragonez, brings out bold tannins and ripe black fruits. Perfumed and richly textured, the wine is packed with fruitiness, backed by a solid structure and a smooth aftertaste. Drink now.

This delicious, elegant white opens with aromas of ripe white stone fruit, fragrant yellow flower, Mediterranean brush and a whiff of honey. The tangy juicy palate delivers yellow pear, nectarine, ginger and toasted hazelnut alongside fresh acidity.

This wine expresses bright yet dainty lime zest, floral and talc characters. The palate is fine and focused, with crisp, bright, citric acidity and a wet stone minerality. Watch this little beauty morph with time. Drink now–2033 at least.

With lower than the standard dosage in the Jacquart range, this wine shows off its rich, maturing fruit. A strong line of minerality comes from the 52% of Chardonnay in the blend of grand and premier cru wines. Drink now, or, even better, wait until 2020.

This is a tense, tart and crisply mineral-laden white wine, thick on entry in peach and melon flavor. The midpalate finds peace and balance, allowing a slight bit of reduction to linger and the finish to focus in acidity.

Pure Moscatel, aged in old wood, gives a luscious, raisin and spice flavored wine. It is sweet, unctuous and rich, smoothly textured to be ready to drink. Orange peel and honey come through strongly at the end. Drink now.

This vineyard used to be called the Floodgate Vineyard and has been a consistent source of grapes to the producer. Soft, plush and brimming in dark rustic cherry and cardamom, this wine is also plenty earthy, a mix of turned earth and dried herb. The tannins are thick and strong.
This stylish wine balances crisp fruit with a mineral texture and well-structured acidity. The wine is still young, with a tight, zesty texture and crispness. It should be better from 2019.
designation: Cuvée Royale Brut Blanc de Blancs

description: The front label picture of Sigmund Freud underscores the punny name for this new entry into the winery's lineup. The wine was treated to 18 months in 30% new French oak. Its generous, fruit-driven flavors of raspberry and cherry come with a streak of cola, while the tannins are lightly dusty and proportionate.

Beautifully floral in jasmine and apple blossom, this is a dry, mineral-laden expression of the variety that shines in wet stone, peach and lemon, while delivering sticky, refreshing acidity. Well integrated and light in approach, it will work beautifully on the table as a white with body and elegance.

Rounded, creamy notes of ripe and mellow apple stream from the glass. The palate is equally mellow and creamy, with an inherent bright freshness and a wonderfully creamy midpalate. Notions of freshly baked shortbread pastry join the apple notes and make for a very balanced, textured and rounded palate, vivid with apple freshness. This is lovely now, but sure to evolve in bottle. The finish is dry and creamy. Drink now through 2025.

There is a hint of wet chalk stone on the nose, along with crisp apple and a touch of lemon. The palate then amplifies both the chalky impression and the creamy mellow richness of the apple and the autolysis. This is restrained but very classic, understated but deeply satisfying with its creamy mousse, a hint of stone and the fruit-accentuated backdrop. The mousse is fine and the finish is wonderfully dry.

Both juicy Mirabelle and pear entice with their fresh fruitiness on the nose. On the palate it is residual sweetness which amplifies their charms. This generosity and juiciness is tempered with bright lemon freshness. Underlying this is a fine crystalline stoniness which keeps this on light feet despite the medium sweetness and inherent generosity. Drink through 2028.

A touch of wet earth joins lemon zest and green-pear peel on the nose. It is the lemon that gets ever more pronounced in its zestiness on the dry, vivid and concentrated palate. This is taut and compact but has an utterly refreshing impact of ripe lemon zest. The finish is dry and utterly refreshing.

Cracked white and black pepper meet with elderberry and violet on the stunning nose of this blend, which is at once savory, juicy and floral. The palate picks up that savory touch with strong pepper spice, then come the black plum-skin flavors, all riding into a long finish.

Juicy hints of strawberry on the nose are as pretty as the pink glints in this joyful rosé. The palate complements the strawberry notes with earthy lemon and presents a light but rounded, refreshing summer wine with a dry finish.

There's a focused-by-intense-smoke quality to the nose of this bottling, which wafts over the fresh Meyer lemon spray and inviting roasted Gravenstein apple aromas. It grips the palate right away, showing roasted apples, a bit of butter and prominent oak.

Earthy and floral, this is not your average Sauvignon Blanc. This displays lots of floral, lemon balm, melon and warm spice notes on the palate. A delicate line of tannins from 18 hours of whole-cluster skin contact offers balance to the weighty juicy fruit.
This wine's white spring flower and Granny Smith apple aromas follow over to the palate, along with a citrus note. Tangy acidity lifts the juicy flavors.

Fragrant spring flower and white stone fruit aromas lead the nose of this blend of organically farmed Vernaccia (90%) and Chardonnay (10%). On the rounded palate, bitter almond accents back up juicy white peach and citrus rind flavors.

Deep flavors of black cherry and cedar give this wine good focus, while moderate tannins and good acidity add welcome grip in the texture. The body is medium to full, and the palate sensation is dry and appetizing.

One of three de Gaye family estates, this small 17-acre proprerty has produced an intense wine, black with dark tannins and black-plum flavors. There is no doubt about the weight of the wine and it has plenty of fruit to balance the big tannins and dark-coffee flavors. Drink from 2023.

Dried strawberry and red-cherry flavors are plush and soft in this unctuously rich wine. It's juicy and approachable, accented by hints of nut, spice and caramel. Firm but ripe tannins and moderate but fresh acidity lend structure to the midpalate. Drink now–2028.

A year in wood has given this wine great richness as well as ripe spice flavors. It is smooth textured, hinting at toast but much more about ripe lemon, apricot and youthful acidity. This Domaines Rodrigues-Lalande wine, like all the whites from this appellation, needs to age. Drink from 2020.

The vines of this Domaines Rodrigues-Lalande estate grow around the village of Martillac, neighboring some of the area's top classed-growth estates. The wine, well balanced between Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, is rich while well structured with spice and tannins. With its great fruit and ripe character, the wine will age. Drink from 2022.

This sumptuous wine is generous and packed with fruit. Behind the swathes of ripe black-plum flavors lie firmer tannins and a dense structure that will allow the wine to age. Drink this rich wine from 2022.

This inky purple wine has a bouquet of blackberry and juniper. Although its profile runs a little cool, strong raspberry, cassis and orange zest flavors keep the baking spice and menthol notes in check. Strong yet pleasant tannins coat the gums through the espresso-laced finish.

This wine is a blend of half Dolcetto and half Sangiovese. Salmon colored, the aromas suggest notes of apple, sour cherry and pear. The palate brings tart dried apple and cherry flavors that finish short.
A rich style of wine, this offers plenty of ripe peach and creamed-apple flavors. The acidity is held at bay, giving a full, ripe texture that will be better from 2019.
designation: Lua Cheia em Vinhas Velhas Maria Bonita

description: Subdued aromas of toasted oak, baking spice and graphite guide the nose. The dense palate delivers raw sour cherry, clove and vanilla while assertive tannins give it an astringent finish.

Aromas of baking spice, vanilla, green herb and dried cherry are followed by ripe, quite sweet seeming fruit and barrel flavors. The tannins bring a fair amount of grit and dryness. It doesn't all come together.
This wine is soft and rounded, with ripe but fresh fruit. Citrus dominates although bright pear and green-fruit flavors give some extra ripeness. Drink now.

There's a slightly lifted character to the liquorous cherry and blackberry aromas on the nose of this Pinot, with a subtle hint of minty herbs in the background. The palate is surprisingly gripping, with astringent tannins that frame the pithy plum-skin and black-cherry flavors.

Unctuous in anise, apple and Asian pear, this wine is beautifully layered, fleshy and lushly complex. A twist of ginger rises on the midpalate as a backbone of acidity refreshes and lingers on the finish. This is balanced and lovely.

One of the winery's single-block series, which benefit from extra bottle aging, this wine is still fresh and lively, with lots of time to grow. Aromas of red currant, raw meat and tea leaf lead into a zippy palate where buoyant acidity carries flavors of tart red-plum skins and cranberry. The energy will last for years, so drink now through 2034.

Fresh persistent acidity drives this vineyard-designate with energy and buzz—a tension that buoys a fragrant, flavorful palate of forest floor, black tea and citrus. The tannins are strong and structured, a worthy companion to the delicate layers.

This impressive new bottling for the Jackson Family starts with fresh aromas of preserved limes on toast, rounded nectarine, chalk and lemon syrup. There is a strong tension to the palate, where racy flavors of kumquat and lemon sorbet lead into a grippy, tense finish.

It's magical how Talley Chardonnays pack both subtlety and richness into the same package. This bottling starts with light aromas of honeysuckle, golden apple and brioche before intensifying into cashew, peach and tangerine. The palate surrounds caramelized peach and apple flavors yet is cut with lemony acidity and a chalky texture, finishing with light caramel and butter.

Walking a tightrope of grace and power, this wine from Actor Sam Neill speaks of drying flowers, red currants, leather, olives and wild herbs. The palate has focus and tension, fine, powdery tannins, lifted acidity and a herbal tonic finish. It's a delicious drop now but could see 10 years in the cellar. Drink through 2028.
Packed with crisp acidity, this is a refreshing wine. Its fruit and the lively character of the texture make it bright and buoyant. Drink now.

A step up in quality from the previous vintage, this delivers sweet berry and milk chocolate flavors from first whiff. It's appealing but stops short on the midpalate, finishing with hints of Graham cracker and mocha.

There's little ripe fruit here, as the wine is dominated by tea leaf, earth, granite and pepper flavors. That said, it's a style that wouldn't be out of place among inexpensive Burgundies, best enjoyed with a hearty stew.
Yeasty pear and citrus peel aromas introduce this crisp, quaffable white. Its saline and stone fruit flavors hold steady through the finish.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: This delivers fresh but generic apple, pear and stone fruit aromas. It's soft on the palate, with saline-rich flavors of apple and lettuce that finish steady.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: Aromas suggesting medicinal herb, adhesive bandage, lime zest and Mediterranean scrub appear in the glass. The aromas follow over to the palate along with tangy acidity.

You'll find intriguing, earthy aromas of scorched soil, underbrush, leather, ripe plum and a whiff of game on this structured red. Full-bodied, the palate reflects the nose, evoking dried black cherry, cranberry, licorice and a gamy note alongside fine-grained tannins.

From Winemaker Jean-Michel Jussiaume, this sparkling wine is produced entirely from Chardonnay sourced from the Del Rio Vineyard. It offers concentrated lemon, grapefruit and pineapple flavors, with a fine bead and impeccable overall balance.

A 100% varietal wine from a one-acre vineyard site, made in small amounts, this impresses in waxy cherry and vanilla flavors dipped in toasted clove. Soft, round and pleasantly approachable, it offers a touch of grip on the finish.

This is a delicious mix of earth, rock, leaf, cherry and chocolate notes, with some pretty orange peel highlights. It reflects the earthy characteristics of the AVA and nicely integrates its one third new French oak.

A rich expression of the grape, this single-vineyard bottling shows hearty aromas of black currant and concentrated violets. There is a chalky structure and turned loam minerality to the palate, with Indian spice, pepper and cardamom enhancing the black plum core.

Elegantly soft and succulent, this wine is polished in tannin and integrated oak, with dark brooding flavors of black cherry and sage. Powerfully concentrated, it impresses from first sip, with a length of black pepper and clove.

With a high percentage of reserve wines from older vintages in the blend, this is a rich and maturely ripe wine. It has touches of red fruit along with acidity, but its main pleasure is the yeasty edge and the depth of flavor. Drink this wine now.

Jim Barry's premium Cab is a good example of the elegance that can be achieved with this grape when its grown in cooler climes. Aromatically, there's a lot going on here: savory soy-sauce notes and smoky ones, too, fuse with green leafy herbs, red currants, violets and pencil lead. It's full bodied but age has been kind to it thus far. The powerful savory tannins and oak characters are still prominent, but crunchy red fruit keeps things bouncy. Harmony seems to have been found. Drink now–2028.

From the producer's estate-grown site near the coast in Freestone, this shows soft, structured waves of citrus and wild strawberry met with hints of wood and pine. Bolstered by quenching acidity at its core, this is light in feel and delicately crafted.

Kay Brothers's top wine, made from over 120-year-old vines on this historic estate, is a dense thicket of ripe bramble berries still on the bush. There's also a strong exotic savory element: soy sauce, raw beef and Chinese 5 spice. Earthy eastern spices carry through to the palate which is supported by chewy, tight-grained tannins. Everything is in place for this to age with grace for many years to come. Drink now with a rare salt-encrusted steak or cellar for the next 20 years.

Light in the glass, this bottling is redolent with carnations, hibiscus and pomegranate on the nose, which is sprinkled with oregano, marjoram and black-pepper spice. It's lighter bodied on the sip, which is full of energy and layered with texture, showing cranberry and minty flavors.

This is a rare style of wine. Made from 100% Pinot Meunier grown in the Marne Valley, it has a ripe, rounded and easily accessible character. At the same time, minerality comes through the white fruit and floral citrus flavors. Special Club is a grouping of independent growers who taste and approve each other's wines before release.
This is a good wine that balances ripe berry flavors with lively acidity and medium body. It tastes like sour cherries and raspberries and has a lightly tart mouthfeel.
A structured wine, still on the young side, this has the potential of rich black fruits and ripe tannins. Made with nearly 60% Merlot, this jammy, generous wine will be ready from 2019.
This round, smooth wine shows a good balance between acidity and ripe apple fruits. It is an easy wine, fruity, touched by caramel and ready to drink now.
It may have no added dosage, but this wine is so ripe with warm fruits it doesn't need it. The texture is soft and open, full of white fruits and attractive acidity. Drink this wine now.

Aromas of raspberry and cherry compote along with baking spice lead to somewhat lighter styled red and black fruit flavors, with the concentration not always seeming to be there. The tannins are a bit wound up at present.
Light aromas of herb, cherry and raspberry are followed by full-bodied, dark fruit flavors backed by lightly chalky-feeling tannins and a warm finish. The fruit seems a bit desiccated.

Cranberry, white pepper, dried herbs and wet gravel make for a complex aromatic entry to the nose of this bottling. Bright flavors of red cherry, oregano and rose petals give depth to the lighter-bodied style and make it quite easy to quaff.

Ripe berry aromas are suggestive of raisin, baked plum and pastry. In the mouth, this Crianza is chewy and solid, but not too heavy. Plum, raspberry and wood-spice flavors are lasting and steady across the finish. Drink through 2022.

Amped up in gritty texture and a big tannin profile, this is robust, richly concentrated red wine, able to deliver expertly on its style. Rich dark cherry, toasted oak and a thick thread of earthiness combine effortlessly and with a tenacity that's impressive.
White spring flower, ripe orchard fruit and white almond aromas take center stage. On the round, fresh palate, a light mineral note adds depth to mature yellow apple, juicy pear and tangy lemon zest.

Earthy aromas of underbrush, scorched soil, leather and a whiff of game follow over to the enveloping palate, along with juicy Marasca cherry, crushed raspberry, licorice and tobacco. It's already delicious and velvety, so no need to wait to enjoy. Drink through 2022.

The tasty fruit flavors ring clear as a bell in this berry- and cherry-drenched and mouth-filling wine. It's grapey in a good way, very open and generous in character, and there's little or no oak to mask the fruit.
This big wine is hugely fragrant in strawberry, cherry and a slightly reduced hint of oaky tar. Dense rich layers of flavor etch themselves against a backdrop of tobacco, cedar and ripe black cherry.

Concentrated aromas of grenadine and sumac are almost too intense on the nose of this bottling. The palate is also quite thick, with extracted cherry and raspberry flavors lifted by sage oil and wood spice.

Charcoal and mushroom aromas give this blend of Malbec, Cab Franc and Petit Verdot an earthy outlook. A saturated palate with hard tannins and heat is breathing every bit of this wine's 15.5% alcohol volume. Toasty blackened berry and pepper flavors finish with a note of dark chocolate and heat.
Apple butter and creamed corn tones give this Chardonnay a warm, inviting start. Medium in weight and rounded in feel, lemon-butter and melon flavors are met with a cleansing mineral vein.
This opens with underbrush and black plum aromas while the dense palate shows coffee, vanilla, and prune notes. Tightly wound, astringent tannins provide the framework. Drink 2020–2027.

Cabernet Sauvignon (67%) makes up most of this wine, with the rest Malbec (22%) and Petit Verdot. The aromas bring notes of cherry, raspberry, cinnamon, vanilla, green wood and spice. The palate shows a sense of ripeness and appeal, still seeming bunched up.

Subtle notes of tart berry mingle with richer creaminess. The subtle palate with its superfine fizz colors the fruit notions in shades of tart strawberry and aromatic raspberry against a more sonorous, gently yeasty backdrop. This all seems very fresh and will benefit from some more bottle age. All the potential is there. Creaminess and fruit just need a little more time. Drink 2019–2025.

There is a hint of creaminess amidst the dried lemon zest and baked apple on the nose. The palate, despite its dryness and pervasive lemon freshness, also has hints of this creamy mildness which creates a wonderful contrast to the regal bearing of mature Riesling—like a disciplinarian with an indulgent smile. Be charmed and enjoy the wonderfully long lemony dry finish. Drink now through 2028.

Rich and round with underlying notes of wet stone, apple and lemon peel, this beautifully made wine benefits National Geographic's Ocean Initiative, helping to support sustainable fishing and establish marine protected areas. It finishes crisp and dry with lasting elegance—as good to drink as it's doing good.
designation: National Geographic Ocean Reserve Blanc de Blancs

description: This wine is vibrant, elegant, and abundantly flavorful while maintaining a lean nervy mouthfeel. It has very expressive black-cherry and cranberry aromas, almost-tart cherry and raspberry flavors and a combo of firm tannins and fresh acidity that give the texture a nice grip.

Opulent notes of ripe peach and pear jump from the glass. On the palate they are beautifully tempered by the zesty freshness of ripe juicy citrus. Think mandarin and clementine peel and flesh. This is off dry but very well balanced, striking joy with its exuberant, expressive fruit notes. A touch of peach peel and stone bitterness sets a lovely pleasant counterpoint to the richness and colors the off-dry finish.

A golden hint of Mirabelle plum precedes the lemon notes on the nose. The palate also has a gentle side of ripe stone fruit that softens the tangy zestiness of lemon. The palate is dry and concentrated but also vividly and generously juicy. On the dry zesty finish the fruit shines in all its purity. Drink until 2028.

Offering almost as much elegance as its bigger Mount Eden sister at a much lower price, this bottling shows plump red cherries, thyme, vanilla and savory tones on the nose. There is a taut tension to the dry palate, where mulberry, elderberry and cranberry flavors vie for attention against the rocky earthy minerality.

Dark cherry liqueur and marzipan leave an impression on the nose before a grippy structure and a stemmy earth tone join on the palate. This is balanced yet concentrated in feel, with blood orange and black cherry on the midpalate that lead to spicy clove and nutmeg on the finish.

A full-bodied, tannic and powerfully built wine from a great site, this is rich and warm in baking spice, ripe black raspberry and classic cherry cola. Tart and tangy acidity provides a wall of freshness and structure to meet its brooding, brambly tendencies.

Mint, cardamom and tea contrast well against a voluptuously built core of succulent raspberry and strawberry in this lovely, memorable and lightly ripe wine. Lasting acidity enlivens and then energizes a velvety texture of gorgeousness.

Beautifully interwoven acidity gives this wine a lift of freshness and viscosity in this lovely, 100% varietal white, sourced from several sites, including Stagecoach on Atlas Peak, Hyde Vineyards in Carneros and the Spottswoode Estate. Fresh peach, apricot and wild vanilla are met by textured richness that's balanced and measured in approach.

This single-vineyard expression by winemaker Eric Johnson is very supple on the nose with aromas of white peach, lychee, toasted almonds and lime sorbet. Voluptuous flavors of baked pear, cinnamon and light butterscotch are wrapped in a silky smooth palate, hitting all of Chardonnay's notes.

Dusty yeasty aromas are more out front than any particular fruit scent. This Viura-Malvasia blend is linear feeling as it toes a single line. Narrow stony flavors of white pineapple and lime don't do much on a limited finish.
Light and dry, this straightforward wine has a pale-garnet color, mild aromas of cherries and baking spices and restrained fruit flavors. The texture is rather lean and slightly tannic.

Just a touch of Moscatel has created a well-perfumed wine. This character is lifted by the crisp fruitiness and fresh acidity of the Rabigato and Viosinho in the blend. Together, they make an attractive, refreshing and very fruity wine to drink now.

Firm and tannic, this blend of Syrah, Castelão and Aragonez is solidly textured and still young. It sees no oak, which brings out the potential of both the black fruits and the young tannins. Let the wine sit for a few months and drink in 2019.

Sauced cranberry and cherry aromas carry a slightly spiced edge on the nose. Firmly medium in weight, the palate is a mix of savory fruit and fresh herbs that are supported by a delicate frame of tannins.

A wealth of ripe cherry and strawberry aromas carry an undercurrent of smoke on the nose. Made with organic grapes, this red is light in concentration on the palate, with a juicy red-cherry flavor leading the way. Soft acidity and light tannins give this an easy-drinking appeal.
Vines between 40–70 years old form the basis of this ripe, juicy and deliciously fruity wine. With its refreshing acidity and zesty lemon character, it's rich and packed with fruitiness. Drink now.
designation: Les Vénérables Vieilles Vignes Sur Lie

description: Rich and fruity, this has straightforward apple and citrus flavors. It is packed with fruitiness, a zesty character and flavors of almonds and spice, finishing with great acidity. Drink now.

The winery's first reserve-level wine, this shows some reduction out of the gate, making it a challenge to perceive its blackberry, smoke, incense and herb aromas. The palate brings a sense of elegance and restraint despite the warmth of the vintage. Perhaps some time in bottle will serve it well.

A touch of moss joins the tender mandarin notes on the nose of this wine. The palate is still subdued and needs time to unwind, but its citrus purity and lightness promise wonderful, summery, weightless refreshment and poise. The finish is dry, lemony and very moreish.

Brightly perfumed and inviting in dark, brooding cherry and blackberry, this mountain wine is moderate in structure and powerfully ripe, with forceful, persistent tannins and plenty of complementary oak. It finishes in sage, dried herb de Provence and black pepper.

This big and beautiful wine has a dense dark color, classically minty black currant aromas, a dry, appropriately tannic texture and good sense of concentration. It is medium to full bodied, ripe but not overripe, and deserves a place at the table with a lamb or veal chop.
This well-balanced wine is medium to full bodied, has modest fruit and spice aromas and a clean, straightforward fruit flavor.

This Shiraz offers all the plush plum and cherry fruit, coffee, chocolate and toasty oak that we've come to expect from Barossa Shiraz, but there's also an earthy wet-leaf funk at its core that adds interest. The palate is more on the medium-bodied side with a decent line of dusty savory tannins to balance that plush fruit.

Kilikanoon's take on mid-level Barossa Shiraz is rich, fragrant and oaky. If you're into this style, you'll dig the luscious raisiny fruit, black licorice, olive and dusting-polish oak notes. You'll also be into the opulent, almost sweet-fruited, palate with its muscular chunky tannins and lashings of oak. For this taster, it's all a bit over the top.

This wine presents as oaky upfront before making room for layered flavors of melon, baked apple and peach, the grapes sourced from a multitude of locations within the appellation. Round and approachable, it offers great value.

A cheap and cheerful Cab with lots of sweet oak jutting out over rather nice varietal characters: cassis, eucalyptus, pencil lead and dried herbs. There's a nice balance of savory tannins, cassis and herbal notes on the palate, it's just a shame the oak is so overpowering.
Similar to the more pricey Jimmy's Section but with less oak influence, this wine is warm and luscious in notes of cherry, chocolate and cola.

This is a ripe and concentrated wine, full of white and citrus fruit. With layers of wood-aging toastiness, the wine has a smooth, polished character while keeping its crisp edge. This is a young wine still and worth aging. Drink from 2019.

Lightly wood aged but with its fruitiness intact, this ripe wine conveys yellow-fruit flavors. Acidity and minerality dominate the touches of toast and the creamy, vanilla texture. This rich, intense wine needs to develop. Drink from 2019.

With delicious fruit and rich tannins, this wine offers great potential. Bold black fruits and spicy flavors are lifted by the good acidity and crisp aftertaste. The wine was fermented in open-top stone lagars, which always gives a smooth, rich texture. Drink this wine, made under the supervision of South African winemaker Wouter Pienaar, from 2020.
This delivers rich, ripe and concentrated fruit flavors of cranberry and raspberry purée. The fruit pushes deep into the finish. It's clean and generous, without obvious oak influence.

Strawberry and raspberry sorbet meet with sweet wood, cherry blossoms, earth and leather on the nose of this reserve bottling. Herbal tones of oregano and marjoram frame the sip, surrounding the framboise and root beer core.

Made predominantly from Wallula vineyard fruit (40%), with equal parts Upland, Destiny Ridge and Hedges, this has generous boysenberry, mountain blueberry, flower and dried herb aromas, along with kisses of spice. Ripe, silky fruit flavors lead to a lingering, olive- and meat-filled finish. A charmer.

Taking advantage of the natural richness of this vintage, this wine is ripe and soft, hinting at yeastiness as well as retaining plenty of attractive acidity. This balanced wine is powerfully rich and ready to drink now.

With its voluptuous figure and lavish lychee and rose petal perfume, this is a textbook Gewürztraminer. It's lusciously bold and complex offering concentrated stone-fruit flavors and subtle notes of potpourri and musk. The finish is edged by delicate tea tannins and a hint of warmth. Enjoy now through 2024.

Ethereally earthy and forested, this appellation wine is succulent and supple in fleshy blackberry, huckleberry and a freshness of cardamom spice. The full-bodied density exudes fruitiness supported in rounded tannin.

Haart's Piesporter Kabinett is a smokier, more linear expression of the Mosel than the sunnier Goldtröpfchen, offering tart lime, lemon and green-plum flavors offset by a glaze of honeycomb. It's a laser-edged penetrating wine finishing on a reverberating mineral tone. Enjoy now through 2030.

The fresh nose almost has a hint of salted lemon. On the palate both lemon and tart, red apple take over but the lemon streak of bright freshness dominates for now, creating drive. The concentrated body is bone dry and comes to a mouthwatering, superclean and long finish.

This wine's berry aromas are unencumbered by toasty oak. The palate is saturated and fruity, with well-formed blackberry and dark plum flavors. It's steady, firm and long on the finish. Drink through 2030.

This offers aromas of brown sugar and gingersnap tinged with blackberry. The palate echoes the nose, showing more brown sugar and wild blackberry notes joined by vanilla and sweet baking spice. The tannins are soft and velvety, with plenty of acidity for balance. Drink now–2025.
Wood aging shows strongly here with toasty flavors and spice. At the same time, the wine also has hints of its fruity potential. Put the two together and the wine will be ready from 2023.

Aromas of wild rose and red berry follow over to the bright, light-bodied palate along with raspberry compote and crushed strawberry. A note of candied tangerine zest and vanilla close the finish. It's fun and refreshing.
Spring blossom and orchard fruit aromas lead the nose. On the bright, linear palate, vibrant acidity offsets notes of white peach, pineapple and citrus.
This delicate, light-toned rosé offers up red berry and watermelon characters. It's dry, crisp and refreshing—everything you'd want on a hot summer's day.

One of Chile's most classic Carmenères is about as ripe as you're going to find from 2016, a year with severe weather issues at harvest. This is reasonably structured, with spicy, peppery plum and red berry flavors matched by fully toasted oak. Raw intensity on the finish is more demanding than usual.

This is the first release from a new winery from Willamette Valley Vineyards that will be located on the Oregon side of Walla Walla Valley. The aromas bring a sense of purity, with notes of black currant, raspberry, plum and fresh tobacco. The palate offers a sense of delicacy and restraint. There's structure here, but it relies less on overt tannins than most Cabernets. It's a unique offering of the variety.

The latest version is more widely available through expanded production and offers a price drop as well. In fact, it's a fine value in a sappy, sexy style. Raspberry, blueberry, blackberry and cherry fruits are here in abundance—the whole spectrum, reflecting a variety of top vineyard sources. The tasty fruit is backed with fine-tuned tannins—and 42% new French oak.

Two-thirds Touriga Nacional and one-third Cabernet Sauvignon create a perfumed structured wine that still has firm tannins. Toast from wood aging shows through the rich black fruits adding to the richness of this fine wine. Drink from 2020.

This wine is made from a single vineyard that is situated between 1,200 and 1,600 feet in elevation. It is poised between structured black fruits and firm tannins, which gives the wine fine potential. Drink from 2020 to allow for the fruit to broaden out.

This is a plump, fruity Shiraz that many a rich red wine lover can get behind. Plump, bramble berry, black licorice root, violet and cedar lead the way, while the palate is supple and velvety in texture. Finely knit, spicy tannins hold the wine afloat,. Drink now–2028.

Pristine lemon, lime and grapefruit aromas perfume this semidry Riesling. Light-footed yet boldly concentrated in citrus flavors, it's an invigorating wine that finishes with reverberating minerality on the finish. This is irresistibly quaffable yet elegant.
Smooth, thick and meaty, this appellation wine is robustly built to coat the palate and stick to the ribs. Chocolate, blackberry jam and smoky char give it weight and richness.

The nose is rather closed but the palate gives glimpses of a soft lemon freshness on a light fluid body. This is easy and fresh. It is on the finish that more lemon and some salty yeast become apparent.
Only the merest glint of lemon meets the nose. Lemon also is the keynote on the light, dry and very refreshing palate. This is simple but summery and very fresh.
The aromas are light and a bit difficult to tease out, with notes of red and blue fruit, tire rubber, herb and spice. The palate is lighter in style with a tart blue-fruit-filled finish.

Cedar, oak, leather and vanilla dominate the nose and carry over to the palate, where vibrant cranberry and pomegranate flavors pop with a wash of fresh acidity over attractive peppery notes and grippy tannins. Tangy fruit lingers on the finish with a pinch of pepper.
winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey

description: This is a sturdy palate-gripping wine with a good lean texture and firm tannins. The aromas capture forest floor, black pepper and earthy nuances and the flavors are tart and tea-like.

Initial notes of smoke and char fade with aeration revealing layers of decadent black plum and cherry flavors here. This is an intoxicatingly fruity, luscious wine that's balanced pertly by fresh acidity and a crisp mineral undertone. Nuanced by spice and garrigue, it's drinking beautifully already but should improve well through 2030.

This annual white blend by Jim Clendenen is always fascinating, and this vintage's 55% Pinot Gris, 35% Pinot Blanc and 10% Aligoté combination offers warm rich aromas of hazelnut and crème brûlée that are cut by crushed chalk and lemon rind. It lands on the palate with a baked pastry warmth but then proves quite textural and taut with lime spray and herb flavors.

Freshly squeezed lime and orange aromas meet with hints of apple and lemon blossoms on the nose of this very vibrant and zesty Chardonnay. There is an intense grip to the palate, where kumquat and grapefruit flavors meet with chalk, white flowers and Asian pear.

This is one of the rare Zinfandels that needs time in the cellar to reach its most enjoyable stage. The concentration and depth of fruit is apparent, but it's currently wound up with tight tannins and bright acidity, needing time to unravel its complexities. Best after 2022.

Bold cherry flavors dominate this ripe wine. With a touch of smokiness as well as spice and acidity, the wine is already showing its good potential. Full bodied and dense, it will need time. Drink from 2024.

Juicy and impressively structured, this wine hits all the right notes in its complex grasp of blueberry cobbler and graham cracker richness. The denser aspects are skillfully complemented with a length and breadth of additional elements like clove, cedar, sage and graphite, the tannins appropriately robust.

Ripe, juicy yellow pear and honey carry the nose. The palate hits with a touch of sweetness that boosts the ripe pear fruit but, it is countered by zesty lemon and a pleasantly bitter streak of phenolics. The result is a rounded, powerful and concentrated wine. Drink now–2028.

Earthy aromas of underbrush, new leather, crushed herb and eucalyptus take center stage while a floral note arrives later. On the structured polished palate, you'll find strawberry compote, dried Marasca cherry, star anise and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity. Drink 2020–2030.

This wine is not too fat and not too lean, finding a great balance point between vivid fruit and black-pepper flavors and firm tannins and acidity. Little or no oak comes through in the taste, but an engaging earthy, funky, sage-like element does, making it unusually complex and interesting to sip.

Ripe berry and graham cracker aromas are bold. A fleshy, fruity palate benefits from bright acidity as flavors of blackberry, wild herbs and pepper roll out. A racy finish with blasting acidity means this Altamira-grown Malbec will hold steady and could improve over the next three to five years. Drink through 2023.
designation: Terroir Series Edición Limitada Finca El Milagro Single Vineyard

description: This is from a prime site in the Sebastopol Hills and it shows plenty of cool-climate provenance. Earthy pine needle, sage and mushroom are complemented by savory strawberry, tangerine and tart cherry—the flavors blending well with fresh sparks of acidity and spice.

A saturated dark-purple color and aromas of pure grape juice and stout berry fruits amount to an impressive opening. Blackberry, cassis and natural peppery flavors fill out this cement-fermented-and-aged Malbec from the highest part of Tupungato. A steady, focused finish is clean and powerful, and overall this is a racy muscular wine to drink through 2024.

Crisp, herbal Sauvignon Blanc is given an attractive perfumed character by a small proportion of the fashionable Sauvignon Gris. It is a fruity wine full of squeezed citrus, with bright acidity at the end. Drink now.

Coffee, herb and cherry aromas are at the fore, with an ever so slightly burnt note in the background. The palate is light but flavorful, showing a sense of elegance. The concentration seems to be missing in the middle.
A pretty blend of the two Cabernets, this wine is fruity and fragrant. With bright, balanced acidity and fruit, it's ripe while still fresh. Drink now.

From the largest privately owned vineyard in France, this wine is crisp, cool and delicious. It is light and bright, with citrus and refreshing lime and lemon flavors. Acidity cuts the wine, leaving a bright, clean aftertaste. Drink now.
Aromas of char, coffee bean, vanilla and berry are followed by light but creamy feeling flavors that dip in the middle, showing a mixture of fruit and barrel. It doesn't all come off.

Punchy citric aromas are fairly sweaty and green, like Sauvignon Blanc or a Verdejo from Rueda. A racy citric palate is tangy and zesty. Lightly salted orange and lime flavors include a hint of green cactus, while this basic Viura holds firm on a minerally finish.

Black cherry, cedar oil, forest spice, savory meats and a hint of vanilla show on the nose of this bottling by John and Helen Falcone. The palate offers lots of roasted black plum, lively thyme and more of that cedar-like forest spice.

Ripe yet elegant black-plum and cherry flavors are marked by complexities of earth, mushroom and dried herb. It's full bodied and richly concentrated, but balanced by vibrant acidity. The finish lingers with ripe yet firm, persistent tannins. Drink now–2030.

An unusually floral hint precedes this wine's pear and cream aromas. The palate remains light and fresh, with a sonorous backdrop of yeasty texture. Bright lemon notes follow through to the dry finish.

This wine's ripe pear fruit and leesy yeastiness make it seem like a raw tank sample. On the palate, the yeastiness expresses itself as savory texture, framing fresh lemon notes and peppery highlights. The finish is dry and long.

Candied blackberry fruit gives way to elegant purple flowers, a slightly sour tar and hints of roasted meat on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from a property planted in 2002. The palate is firmly structured and laden with acid, offering flavors of dried black currant, more purple flowers and roasted coffee.

This wine is nicely dry, firm in texture and offers a very good mix of ripe-to-bursting blackberry and blueberry flavors along with moderate tannins, good acidity and a welcomed sense of freshness despite full body. It will make a hearty pairing with many kinds of beef, pork, and cheese.
This soft, fruity wine is just dry while certainly ripe and open. Its citrus flavors are set against crisp apple notes and fresh acidity.
This medium-bodied wine has a smoky aroma, good blackberry and black-plum flavors and a smooth non-tannic mouthfeel. It's showing a lot of heavily-toasted oak that comes off as char and black pepper.
Although this has a slight, resin-like bitterness on the nose, the palate presents lots of ripe, bright and sprightly lemon. The finish is dry and fresh.

This wine offers subdued aromas of almond skin, yeast, light oak and peach. It's medium bodied but a touch resiny, with good acidity. Flavors of melon, tropical fruit and mild oak mark the palate, leading to a lightly creamy finish.

While demure on the nose, this off-dry wine offers rich, slightly overripe flavors of white peach and guava accented by hints of dusty slatey mineral. Creaminess on the palate feels a touch clumsy but tightens up with hits of lime acidity on the finish. Drink now.
This wine offers aromas of clove, cinnamon and black cherry. The palate brings soft tannins and flavors of cherry, black raspberry and plum.

Made predominantly from Wallula vineyard fruit (40%), with equal parts Upland, Destiny Ridge and Hedges, this has generous boysenberry, mountain blueberry, flower and dried herb aromas, along with kisses of spice. Ripe, silky fruit flavors lead to a lingering, olive- and meat-filled finish. A charmer.

This wine is a blend of fruit from Destiny Ridge, Stillwater Creek, Boushey and Upland vineyards. Fragrant aromas of flower, cherry and green herb lead to a focused, flavorful palate. With the oak influence pleasantly dialed back, it's a superb value.

This dark ruby-colored wine has a nose of cassis, black cherry and violet. It is full in the mouth, with flavors of blackberry, plum, vanilla, coffee bean and lavender. Smooth tannins continue into the soft, floral finish.

Dazzling acidity leaves just a hint of sweetness on the palate of this racy kabinett. Green melon and lime flavors are lip smacking and tart, brightened by hints of honey and hibiscus nectar. It's delicate in body yet piercing and punchy through a long finish.

This powerfully rich blend of classic Douro grapes aged in wood for 12 months. It is spicy and smoothly textured, with a strong undertow of ripe tannins. The perfume and floral character of the Touriga Nacional in the blend comes through strongly. Drink now.
This vintage showcases strong mineral tones and brambly fruit. Its cranberry and raspberry flavors are sharply etched,  with the youth and precision to age another decade or more.

While subdued on the nose, exuberant white-grapefruit and green-apple flavors penetrate through this dry full-bodied white wine. It's a richly textured wine offset by zesty crushed mineral tones and vibrant lime acidity. The finish is long but crystalline. Enjoy now through 2021.

Subtle aromas of cashew, smoke and green apple belie the honey-drenched tangerine and stone-fruit flavors in this medium-sweet spätlese. It's piercing and concentrated but nuanced by hints of spice and earth. A ripe but sprightly delight that should improve through 2030 and hold further.

Thrilling nervous tension abounds in this vibrant, juicy wine full of pink grapefruit, lime and honeydew flavors. It's a forward, lip-smacking wine yet taut and bracing in acidity. The finish is long and intensely steely. Lovely already but should improve through 2023, hold further.

Sweet-tart grapefruit and melon flavors are fragrant and pure in this spry, profoundly mineral kabinett. Zesty lime acidity and cutting shards of slate and salt accentuate its ethereal, weightless mouthfeel. It's lovely now but concentrated enough to improve through 2026, and hold further.

This is a rare style of wine. Made from 100% Pinot Meunier grown in the Marne Valley, it has a ripe, rounded and easily accessible character. At the same time, minerality comes through the white fruit and floral citrus flavors. Special Club is a grouping of independent growers who taste and approve each other's wines before release.

This wine is elegant and finessed, with aromas of bright red current, cedar, smoke, pencil lead, rose, bay leaf and baking spices. The medium-bodied palate offers tobacco and red berry flavors ensconced in ultrafine, leathery tannins. There's oak influence, but it is well integrated with the fruit. Drink now–2028.

This has a shy nose that eventually reveals whiffs of underbrush, bread crust and the barest hint of woodland berry. The racy palate offers strawberry, peach and a somewhat bitter note suggesting powdered sage and medicinal herb alongside a firm perlage.
This easygoing red has aromas and flavors of Marasca cherry, grilled herb, eucalyptus and a hint of star anise. It has lithe tannins and lively acidity.
Slightly earthy aromas lead to good fruit, black-pepper and smoke flavors, solid structure and a firm moderately tannic texture.

Full of blackberry flavors, this strong, firm wine is just setting out on its development. Big spice, plenty of smoky wood-aging flavors and a juicy aftertaste all point to a good future. Drink from 2022.

This wine comes from an estate owned by the same family for four generations. Dark in color and rich with generous fruit and spicy tannins, the wine is open, smoothly textured and likely to develop quickly. Drink from 2020.
This wine has fine tannins, rich berry flavors and a juicy aftertaste, an indication of the vintage. Structured and with some good potential, the wine will be ready from 2021.

This wine comes from the small premier cru that was possibly once part of Grand Cru Romanée Saint-Vivant. It certainly has depth and structure as well as rich black fruit. Approaching maturity (although not there yet), it is a dense wine with tannins, a smoky character and sophisticated acidity at the end. Drink from 2020.

This is a poised, elegant wine, balancing ripe fruits against a perfumed and textured character. It is young, with bright fruits still to the fore. Acidity and minerality play their part in giving this wine its structure and aging potential. Drink from 2022.

There is a focused intensity of black plum, elderberry and black-cherry pie on the nose of this blend of 82% Cabernet Sauvignon, 9% Merlot, 5% Cabernet Franc and 4% Malbec. A ripe black-cherry flavor meets with licorice, vanilla and fudge on the palate, where polished tannins provide ample structure.

Opulent fruit and savory, earthen complexities combine in this voluptuous Gigondas. Intensely concentrated black cherry and plum flavors are muted by savory shades of dried thyme and bay leaf, crushed earth and bramble. It's a bold, densely fruity wine framed by ripe but persistent tannins. Enjoy now–2030.

Reduced and strongly aromatic in coffee, this wine offers generous helpings of tannin and dark brooding blackberry, tar and dark chocolate. Its powerful concentration doesn't detract from the overall structure, which suggests aging. Enjoy best 2025–2030.
