This wine offers warming layers of cinnamon, anise and vanilla juxtaposed to fresher notes of pear and honeysuckle. It's a full-figured wine with a decadently creamy mouth feel but crisp lemon and tangerine flavors lend lift on the finish. It drinks well already but should improve through 2026.

Shaved apple and nectarine aromas meet with a white-flower touch on the nose of this bottling, which comes from a backyard vineyard in Solvang. There is lots of zip on the tightly wound sip, which is laser-focused from the front to midpalate but opens a bit toward riper pear and apple on the finish.
Crisp and fruity, this light, bright young wine has lively acidity, layers of citrus and a touch of honey. Drink now.
A blue fruit aroma bursts from the glass. The palate offers inviting juicy blueberry and plum, bolstered by gritty tannins. The fruit flavors finish spicy and tannnic.
Aromas of lemon peel, crushed chalk and Golden Delicious apple lead to the dry chalky palate. The pithy finish offers hints of white pepper and river rock.

Licorice dominates the nose of this Texas Merlot, with additional notes of plum, rhubarb and black pepper. On the palate, black raspberry and cherry flavors give way to a licorice tone, bolstered by gravelly tannins. The finish is spicy and tannic.

Muted aromas of red berry and cedar can be coaxed from the glass but are very faint on the nose. Ripe cherry and raspberry are juicy and lip smacking, with tart red-apple acidity supported by fine-grained tannins. Some oak flavors appear on the finish alongside cranberry and a touch of peppery spice.

Extracted black-plum aromas meet with tangy balsamic vinegar and blackberry on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very rich and thick with boysenberry-jam and spice-cake flavors that eventually find some tannic structure.

This blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Colorino opens with dark berry, tilled soil and thyme hints. The round palate offers dried black cherry, clove and licorice notes alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.
Held back in bottle a bit, this reserve wine is juicy, herbal and possessed of sharp edges. Despite that, it is succulently soft, approachable and ripe in its jammy red-cherry fruit.
Aromas of cream, mandarin orange, custard, clarified butter, toast and spice are followed by lightly creamy fruit flavors that dance across the palate. It shows a nuanced touch.

Heady notes of roast chestnut, smoke and cinnamon suggest generous oak on this cherry-like wine. The palate indeed mingles these notions with ripe juicy flavors of red cherry on a light, fluid and easy body. Drink soon.

Crushed black cherry, cherry pits and snapped sage stems show on the woody nose of this bottling. There is an extreme chalky texture to the sip, where black-currant and licorice flavors lead into a minty finish.

Dark and brambly on the nose, this Pinot Noir is carried by crunchy dark berries, cocoa and cranberry skins on the palate. This is medium bodied, with a soft grip of tannins and a refreshing balance of acidity.
Light aromas of cherry, blueberry and wood spice are followed by lighter-styled fruit flavors. It falls a bit flat on the finish, not coming together. Tasted twice with consistent notes.
This perfumed wine dominated by Moscatel is light, bright and intensely fruity. Its acidity is matched by lychee flavors, crisp freshness and a light, dancing aftertaste. Drink now.
This refreshing, cool wine comes from the mountainous interior of Portugal. It has crisp apple and lime acidity along with a tight, mineral edge that gives extra freshness. Drink now.

Lemon in color, the mild nose displays white peach, lemon zest, cashew and white toast. White peach, joined by lychee, carries to the very palate before the 50% new French oak flexes and brings almond and vanilla. The finish turns bitter, settling into a lemon pith tone.

A ripe, tropical-fruit style of Sauvignon Blanc, this wine is perfumed with pineapple balancing the pink-grapefruit flavors. A crisp, zingy texture makes the wine refreshing and deliciously fruity. Drink now.
Colombard, Gros Manseng and Ugni Blanc go into this bright, fruity and herbal wine. With its crisp citrus and gooseberry acidity and extreme freshness, the wine is light and delicious to drink now.
This is a burly ripe red, with small amounts of Merlot, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc blended within. Dried herb meets substantial concentrations of baked plum and possessive tannin.
Aromas of cherry, vanilla and freshly baked brioche carry the nose. The palate is smooth in feel, with soft tannins supported by flavors of tart cherry and plum.
Ruby in the glass, this wine has aromas of freshly baked cherry pie and red plum. On the palate, there are flavors of cherry preserves and black plum.

Orange blossom, key lime syrup and a botanical quinine kick show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is sweet but not treacly, with sweet apple and a touch of citrus rind. It lacks a textural complexity and acidity.
This opens with wayward jammy berry aromas. On the palate, it's hard and tannic, with intense medicinal plum and berry flavors and a black olive note. That note infiltrates the finish.

Traditional notes of black currant, plum and blackberry abound on the nose and mouth of this straightforward yet tasty Cab. It's medium in weight, with approachable tannins and a fruit-forward palate that's ripe and juicy.
designation: Made with Organic Grapes Elegantly French

description: A 100% varietal wine made in magnums only, this is the owner and winemaker's amusing ode to his own position within his large family, choosing winemaking over grape growing, the choice of all his brothers. It is brightly layered and brooding in berry and spice, with lovely soft grooves of cinnamon, nutmeg and black pepper. The tannins are polished and supportive.

This wine opens with a gorgeous, memorable nose of biscotti and hazelnut before unleashing a palate of defined tension and acidity. Light and bright, it has focus and an endearing freshness amidst a powerful embrace of tannin that amplifies its structure.

Robustly layered in crisp apple, lime and wet stone, this wine offers an intensity on the midpalate of grit and grip before easing into a thirst-quenching fistful of acidity. Complex and structured, it shows potential for aging; enjoy best from 2021–2031.

This remains one of the most impressive wines at its price point—a varietal wine blended with small amounts of Merlot, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot, from both the producer's estate and other pedigreed sites. Tense acidity buoys a brawny tannic profile that settles into lushness texture, highlighted in black fruit, butter, gunpowder and plum.

While not classified as a Premier Cru, the vineyard, wholly owned by this producer, performs seriously with bold tannins and ripe black fruits. This wine is structured with a black core and the potential for rich fruits. The wine needs to age, so drink from 2023.
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Clos des Ursulines

description: This wine is nervy in a good way, showing good acidity to match generous alcohol and a fine mixture of complex aromas and flavors ranging from mineral and dried herb to cherry, iron and beef juices. The color is in the natural lighter end of the garnet range, the aromas bring a wide variety of nuances, and the fruity threads weave in and out of savory ones on the palate and finish.

Aromas suggesting underbrush, toast, dark spice and camphor slowly take shape in the glass. The taut palate offers red cherry, pomegranate, clove and pipe tobacco framed in refined, rather austere tannins and vibrant acidity. Give this time to unwind and fully develop. Drink 2022–2035.

With its pale, orange-pink hue and delicately tannic fringe, there's a firmness of structure in this full-bodied wine, that the producer attributes to old vines. The palate is exotic and complex, melding flavors of ripe pear with hints of raspberry, forest floor and spice. Dry and intently mineral, it's a fascinating wine to enjoy now through 2030.

From a coastal site overlooking the Pacific Ocean near Annapolis, this is cool-climate yet brawny in its grasp of cherry cola, black pepper and black licorice, that is wild and densely packed with power. Wild blackberry and blueberry come along for the ride, adding to the succulence of the midpalate, a nice contrast to the underlying gaminess and tobacco.

Cola, blueberry and red fruits meet with sweet tobacco and peppercorn-crusted beef on the nose of this foot-stomped bottling. Though young, it's very accessible now, with smashed berries, tar and savory flavors of black, white and green peppercorn riding a strong acidity.

Ripe pear notes have a mellow aura that takes in both baked apple and gentle vanilla spice. The rounded palate has a lovely texture and some residual sweetness that makes the pear and apple notes even rounder. This is as much balanced by gentle freshness as by concentration. The finish is off dry and long. Drink now–2028.

Deep aromas of caramelized black plum, elegant lilacs, brown sugar and roasted beef show on the nose of this blend of 50% Syrah, 30% Mourvèdre and 20% Grenache. The palate blends rich boysenberry with beef char, smoke and savory herbs, wrapped in a brilliant acidity that drives long into the finish.

Aged in wood, this perfumed wine with eucalyptus aromas and spice and black-fruit flavors has the potential to be well balanced, poised between berry fruits and wood flavors. It is all set for aging, so drink from 2021.

Saussignac is a small appellation in the Bergerac region noted for its sweet wines. This honeyed wine, with its layers of dry botrytis as well as rich sweetness, is a fine example from a top producer. Made from organically grown grapes, it is full of marmalade, orange and spice, rich while still having crisp acidity to balance. Drink from 2020.

Properly dark in color, as befits a wine made from a red-juice grape, this is rich and wonderfully dense. The smooth texture is sustained by integrated tannins and powerful black fruits and acidity. This is a wine to age; drink from 2020.
This cofermented 50-50 blend is full bodied and built of lush apple, apricot and peach flavors. Touches of fruit skin flavors add depth and texture. It spent four months in 20% new French oak.

This wine celebrates its ancient Gaillac vineyard region with a Braucol and Syrah blend of Southwest and Mediterranean grapes. Red-berry and currant fruits intertwine with tannins, wood-aging flavors and a rich structure. Drink this terroir-driven wine from 2021.

This wine, from a tiny mountainside vineyard, has an especially deep gold color, bold aromas of orange zest and peaches, and rich but bright fruit flavors shaded by mineral and spice notes. It feels full in body and viscous in texture, giving a lot of palate impact.

Named after Pierre-Henri Gadais whose family also owns Domaine Gadais, this is a bright, lively wine, rich with layers of ripe fruit, minerality and tight acidity. It is intense, with great fruitiness and a cool edge of final acidity. Drink from 2019.
designation: Cuvée Pierre Henri Saint-Fiacre Sur Lie

description: This one-time cuvée blends a single barrel from each of the winery's six vineyards. Perhaps more symbolic than anything, it's a good wine but somewhat unfocused. The flavor mix includes red fruits, citrus, a hint of mint and tea leaf tannins.

Aromas of raw wood and stem make this wine seem younger than it is. There's raspberry fruit with ample acidity, but these initial flavors lighten and thin out through the finish, giving an impression that the wine is somewhat dilute. With a lot of breathing time, the wine fleshes out considerably, adding bright cherry fruit to the mix.

Thick, inky and almost chunky in the glass, this is a powerful wine, starting with aromas of tar, charred meat, oak and blackberry paste. The roasted and charred elements of the palate are balanced by blackberry jam, white pepper and dried herbs, with tarry, sticky tannins coating the entire sip.

Smoke plays a large role in this wine, starting with the oak and hickory aromas that decorate the sour cherry elements of the nose. Baked cherry shows on the sip before the smoky aspects take hold, which are pleasing and would make a great pairing for a barbecue.

Quite dense on the nose, this well-priced county-wide blend offers aromas of black currant, roasted berries, charred meat, and lilacs. It's thick on the palate, where the creamy mouthfeel reveals coffee and charred berry flavors.

This wine could be the centerpiece for a great dinner due to its combination of vivid, concentrated fruit flavors and good structure. Bold black-cherry and blackberry aromas lead to layered fruit and light spice flavors backed by moderate tannins and good fruit acidity that add grip to the mouthfeel.

The nose is subtle but sends some heady pear-tinged heat. The palate comes in with perceptible sweetness which boosts an array of juicy russet and yellow pear. An earthy phenolic backdrop provides some counter measure to this generous rounded ripeness, while freshness gives precision to this evolving, powerful but balanced wine. The finish is off dry. Drink now through 2028.

Intense and rich, this wine is named after the former monastery that dominates the village of Saint-Mont. It is full of dark fruits, with rich tannins from the Tannat in the blend perfumed by the Cabernet Franc and Pinenc. Ripe, intense and structured, the wine is just coming into full maturity. Drink from 2019.

The merest hint of pink grapefruit adds delicious raciness to the idea of strawberry and cream on the nose. The palate takes these notions and merges them into a seamless vision of toned richness, fuity depth and sonorous joy. All this is underpinned by an electric fault line of freshness—a guiding light that lasts beyond the long, clean and expressive finish.

The nose on this single-vineyard expression combines ripe red fruits of pomegranate and raspberry with spicy Red Hots cinnamon candies. Bright red currant and more raspberry flavors explode on the palate, where nuances of Earl Grey tea, potpourri and rose petal flavors make for a fresh sip.

This wine tastes bold and assertive, pushing smoky oak and vanilla flavors close to the edge but rescuing them with attractive ripe flavors of blackberry and black cherry. The wine is full bodied, layered and mouthcoating, supported by moderate tannins that melt into the bold flavors.

The aromas are lightly reductive out of the gate, followed by notes of slate, citrus and herb. The palate is lighter styled and bone dry, with a zing of lemony acidity on the ever so slightly bitter finish.

Jammy berry and gaseous aromas require a lot of patience to sift through. This heavyweight Syrah-Garnacha blend feels wide, grabby and tannic. Blasting oak, chocolate and extracted berry flavors are expansive on a hot finish that reflects 15% abv.

Cedar and cigar box aromas dominate the nose of this reserve Tempranillo that spent one year in American oak. The palate is more fruit-driven, offering flavors of cranberry, blackberry and raspberry. A juicy finish lingers on a pepper note and a grip of tannin.

Aromas of raspberry meld with cedar and baking spice. The palate echoes the nose adding tart cranberry, white pepper and tobacco leaf. Vibrant acidity and velvety tannins linger through the finish that's filled with a tart berry flavor.

Flabby berry aromas include an earthy note of compost. This Carmenère is dense and monoline, with sucking tannins. Stewed plum and berry flavors finish without much more than rubbery residual tannins. Drink now or never.

This red blend consists of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot and Petit Verdot. There are aromas of black cherry, coffee and espresso and flavors of black plum and blackberry in the mouth. The finish is juicy and fruit filled.

This deep violet-colored wine has blackberry and violet aromas. It's soft and fruity on entry, with wild berry, toffee, anise, nutmeg and ginger flavors. Ever-present but not overpowering tannins build as spice notes take over, dropping off towards the notably soft finish.

Dark red-violet in the glass, this wine has cherry and orange rind aromas. It fills the palate with flavors of black cherry, pomegranate, orange and aniseed, offering velvety tannins and a smooth finish.

A touch of yeast still swings alongside the lively Meyer lemon aromas on the nose of this wine. The palate then presents full-blown lemon zestiness and ample tangerine notes. It's dry, brisk, enlivening and zippy and packs a zesty citrus punch.

This brings roasted coffee bean, char, leafy green herb, spice and cherry aromas, and the oak (75% new French) plays a prominent part in the show. The palate is rich, textured and supple, with plentiful black cherry and barrel flavors that linger on the finish. It hits the gong hard, feeling totally hedonistic.

The subtle citrus hints on the nose of this wine turn into juicy tangerine tanginess on the slender, dry palate. The body is concentrated and bold, brimming with zesty verve. The finish is dry and long.

A single-varietal Sémillon bottling is hard to come by in California, but this bottling shows that it fits somewhere between Chardonnay and white Rhônes. Crushed hazelnuts, saffron, preserved lemon and canola oil show on the intriguing nose. Bright lemony acidity drives the palate through nutty flavors and a grippy texture.
Berry and plum-skin aromas lead to a direct palate with energy but also a sense of rawness. Rough rooty berry flavors are lasting on a tough grabby finish.
Mild dusty aromas lack kick. This has a lemony mouthfeel and flavors of orange peel and lemon. This Txakoli airs out and quickly loses its fruit character and intensity on a pithy-tasting finish.

There's a subtle chalkiness to the nose of this wine, grounded by a core of white peach, apple and clementine aromas and flavors. The medium-weight palate is round and ripe in feel, with a slight lime-rind pithiness that hangs around on the close.

The nose seems a bit disconnected from the palate, showing aromas of overripe lemons and stinky steamed vegetables. While the palate shocks with searing acidity, fresh squeezed lemon and lime and a pervasive grassy note, ending on a tangy lemon note.

Rather tropical on the nose, this bottling shows pear, plumeria and ripe apple aromas on the nose. It's a bit viscous on the palate but with some energy, carrying flavors of apple soda, honeydew and candied pears.
Herb, coffee, green tea and wood spice aromas lead to light coffee and chocolate flavors. The wood seems to get in the way of the plum flavors.
Fresh notes of pear drop mingle with tender strawberry hints on the nose. On the very light and dry palate, the berry notes become more playful and expressive. This is totally summery and refreshing.
Pale pink in color, this wine from the extremely consistent winemakers at K-J is delicate without being wimpy. It offers fresh cherry and raspberry aromas, crisp acidity and modest red-fruit flavors.

Leafy berry aromas are heavily oaked, and hint at volatility. A sticky palate is grabby, while this tastes dark and sappy, like spiced berry fruits mixed with savory but strong oak. A roasted flavor sticks out on a medicinal finish with burnt oak notes.
Red berry, tilled soil and dried herb aromas lead the nose of this wine. The brisk palate offers sour cherry, licorice and white pepper notes alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2021.

This fresh snappy Torrontés shows the upside of this often underwhelming variety. Lime and tropical-fruit flavors come with a note of agave. Tight acidity gives energy to finishing flavors of lychee and green peppercorn.

Alluring aromas of blue flowers and wild red berries lead the nose of this wine, along with a whiff of tilled earth. On the round, approachable palate, soft, supple tannins frame fleshy Morello cherry and star anise flavors. Drink now.

This is a lovely, barrel-fermented white that sources widely from Stagecoach Vineyard, a mountainous site that provides structure and balanced power in this case. Strong varietal aromas of pineapple, peach and anise ride a fleshy midpalate that refreshes in complex layers of lasting flavor.

Very fruity, very pretty in flavor and elegant in texture, this well-balanced wine tastes fresh and cherrylike, slightly floral and lightly spicy too. It seems to glide across the palate with ease and leave a lingering aftertaste of cinnamon and cherries.

Rich blackberry fruit and layers of tannins are a great combination for this wine that has profited from the quality of the Cabernet Franc in this vintage. It has plenty of fruit and acidity, as well as firm, still-toasty tannins. The wine needs to age. Drink from 2023.

A 100% varietal wine, this shines in its full embrace of woody succulence, driven by a core of balanced red and black cherry. Tightly woven tannins provide structure without distraction or dominance, allowing an earthy thread of leather and clove to close things out.

Smooth and supple, but with a strong heart of dark and ripe fruit flavors, this is a big wine in terms of flavor that still comes off elegant and well balanced despite its power. It's also full bodied, not overtly oaky, and seems to get better with each sip.

A blend across a number of grand cru vineyards, this young wine is packed with fruit and rich with minerality. It already shows a good poise between acidity and richness, fruit and structure. The wine needs to age to bring out its density. Drink from 2020.

Lemon oil and Mirabelle plums have a honeyed aspect on the nose, with a whiff of honeysuckle. The sweet palate boosts the yellow plum and pear notes with residual sugar. The finish is rounded and sweet.
This wine is buttery in aroma and flavor and has a generous mouthfilling texture. Being medium bodied and rather low in acidity helps the feeling of richness but keeps the balance a touch too soft.

Stiffly structured, this wine holds tight to its blackberry and black-cherry flavors with very firm tannins that leave a drying sensation. It has a good core of ripe black cherry and black pepper but will need to pair with a fat juicy piece of meat to tame its astringency.

This is a full-bore, heavily oaked, big and tannic wine from the charred cedar aroma to the cinnamon and black-cherry flavors that are held tightly by strong dry tannins. It will need an especially indulgent fatty dish to pair with.
Somehow this reserve, which presumably received extra care and attention in the winery, falls short. It's quickly drying out, the fruit close to disappearing. Drink up.
Very ripe and roasted in character, this full-bodied wine smells smoky, tastes meaty and brings some heat to the midpalate and finish. It is big and a bit rough around the edges.

Exotic spice, red berry, blue flower and a whiff of French oak aromas emerge in the glass. Youthfully austere, the firmly structured palate delivers raw sour cherry, pomegranate, star anise and powdered sage. Tightly knit fine-grained tannins grip the finish while vibrant acidity lends balance. This will benefit with several more years of aging. Drink 2021–2033.

This full-bodied wine brings richness and ripe opulent flavors to the fore. Tobacco, cedar and black-plum aromas come before blackberry and dark-chocolate flavors while firm tannins and good acidity wrap around the palate for support.

Enticing scents of Spanish broom, acacia and honey follow over to the subtle, restrained palate along with ripe yellow-apple skin, dried herb and unsweetened lemon drop. A hint of nut closes the finish. It's still a bit austere and needs a few more years to fully develop.

This wine offers a lovely balance of dry, oaky substance on a well-framed, light body. The palate is fresh and fruity, with an exotic core of papaya, lemon and butter that's bolstered by succulent freshness and a lush backbone.

Tasty and toasty, this young wine is drinking quite nicely now. It's spicy and fresh, with pleasing creaminess. Citrus, lime and melon flavors are married to wet rock and a streak of butterscotch. It was aged for 10 months in 40% new oak.

Made with organically grown Sangiovese, this has aromas of red-skinned berry, new leather and a whiff of mint. The juicy polished palate doles out fleshy red cherry, cinnamon, clove and a touch of vanilla alongside fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. Enjoy through 2025.

Here's a wine that puts Counoise in the driver's seat to great effect. Bolstered by 36% Mourvèdre and 19% Grenache, the wine starts with candied cherry, tangy cranberry, red flowers, white pepper and potpourri on the nose. Exotic spices, familiar herbs and bright red fruit shine on the lively palate.

Juicy black cherry, crushed rock and dried herb combine with ease in this site-specific wine blended with 11% Cabernet Franc. Grainy oak and powerful concentration on the palate make it hard to forget. Enjoy 2020–2025.

Called Cuvée 7 because it is aged for seven years after bottling and before disgorgement, this wine is beautifully mature. It has a tight texture that is rich. The fruit is relaxing into almond and yeast flavors, with some toast as well as considerable minerality. The bottling is ready to drink.

Strong aromas of flint and crushed chalk meet with hints of hazelnut and preserved lemons on the nose of this extremely coastal bottling. There is a tremendous tightness to the palate, where a grippy texture presents racy flavors of lemon, grapefruit rind, nectarine and sea salt on the finish.

This sensational 2016 release is packed with juicy blackberry fruit dappled with hints of bitter herbs. With excellent definition and length, the multi-faceted flavors unravel into layers of highlights—orange peel, cinnamon, espresso and more. The tannins are ripe, and the overall balance calls for putting a few bottles away for further aging. Drink now–2030.

Ripe red apple and lemon are recalled on the nose. On the concentrated palate, aromatic citrus takes over with mouthwatering juiciness suggesting tangerine, lemon and tart orange. The finish is dry, vivid and utterly moreish with its citric refreshment.

Underbrush, blackberry, menthol and a whiff of smoke lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the tightly knit palate along with dried cherry, blood orange, tobacco and licorice. It's youthfully austere, with assertive tannins and firm acidity, so give this time to fully develop. Drink 2022–2029.

Aromatic and interesting from the first sniff on, this blends flavors of red berries, brown spices, and threads of cola and iron. The tannins are soft and supple, beautifully rendered. The ferment included 30% whole clusters, and the finished wine spent almost a full year in one quarter new French oak.

The nose of this wine is ripe and fruity in notes of plump ripe strawberries, red cherries, flowers and spices. The palate gets a more serious, with a fine line of savory tannins balancing bright red fruit. A long, spicy, mouthwatering finish has you immediately reaching for a second sip.

Fleshy and full bodied, this wine shows a pronounced toasted-oak character, with swirls of pineapple and caramel contributing additional richness. Still, it retains enough acidity to offer a juicy core and lasting freshness amidst the fruit.

Aromas of stewed prune, chopped herb, pressed blue flower and nail polish remover lead the way. Reflecting the nose, the palate offers raisin, blood orange and clove set against firm acidity and tight, drying tannins. Give this plenty of time to unwind. Drink after 2022.

Layers of ripe apples and crisp citrus mark out this blend dominated by Chardonnay with some Pinot Noir. Light wood aging has filled out the wine and softened the intense acidity, giving a Champagne that is rich while still tight. Drink now.

An engaging spice-rack aroma and fruit flavors so ripe they're almost sweet make this a gorgeous, generous wine that feels wonderful on the palate and warm on the finish. Light touches of earth, black-pepper and new leather flavors meld with blackberry and blueberry while a full body carries them all to a lingering fnish.

A full-fruit nose is lightly toasted, with a flicker of menthol and tobacco coming from the combination of ripe berry fruit and oak. A saturated palate is intense but still a bit rough at this young age. Rubbery berry, plum and spice flavors get clipped on the finish by hard drying tannins. This needs more time; best from 2020–2032.

Orange marmalade and apricot compote are the two chief and highly aromatic notions on the nose. They also appear on the palate with a wonderfully zesty sweetness. There is lovely tension here, alongside a slight but lovely phenolic grip. This already is five-years-old but only just beginning to develop. Lovely now but sure to continue evolving with its medium-sweet and lasting finish. Drink now through 2028.
designation: Kirchberg de Barr Clos Gaensebroennel Grand Cru

description: A touch of baked Mirabelle skin sends both sweet and bitter notions to the nose. The palate takes up this twin charm of fruit and pithiness and lets them play off each other with just enough pear fruit to keep it juicy. The body is concentrated and has a well of real citrus freshness at the core. The finish is still just about dry and beautifully clean. This is lovely now but will evolve. Drink now through 2028.

This light- to medium-bodied wine shows good tension between expressive black currant and damp earth aromas and an almost steely texture. Though richer than the 2014, it's lean in mouthfeel, crisp and lightly tannic, and the flavors are quite enjoyable in a restrained way. Best after 2022.

A vanilla hint of oak is immediately apparent on the nose with its rich creamy streak. The palate adds a tingling saltiness and fine gently frothing bubbles to this smooth generosity, generating a resonant balance between creamy richness and prickling freshness. The finish is defined by pure lemony freshness. This wine could easily take on food. Drink now through 2025.

Aromas of black cherry and nectarine pave the way for flavors of cherry, white peach and toffee with a touch of salinity. Tannins are a tiny bit gritty, a sensation that is washed away by the bright cherry finish.

Heavy oak spices dominate this full-bodied wine giving it plenty of vanilla, cinnamon, wood smoke and black pepper in the aromas and flavors. Beneath the oakiness and firm tannins, the berry flavor that the varietal is known for is rather hidden.
This wine is concentrated and rich, packed with tropical fruits cut with acidity. This ripe and full wine is ready to drink.

This ballerina pink-hued rosé is fermented and aged in oak. The oak influence is subtle, showing not in flavor but in texture, giving the wine a soft, creamy feel that's nicely balanced by crunchy acidity. Bright strawberry, guava and floral notes offer something that's not overly complicated but completely enjoyable.

Damp plum and berry aromas are herbal and a touch murky. A plump, slightly stewy palate delivers herbal berry and mint flavors along with leafy green notes. This is Chilean Cabernet in all forms, take it or leave it.
Bready apple aromas suggest good quality. In the mouth, this is a foamy Cava with bold acidity. Lemon and orange flavors are fine but basic, while this reverts to dry and bready on the finish.

Intriguing aromas of cantaloupe, chalk and crushed gravel make for a very compelling entry to this blend of 50% Marsanne, 44% Roussanne and 6% Grenache Blanc. The palate is tightly wound with grapefruit-pith flavors but also shows a touch of ripeness in yellow-melon and Anjou pear elements.

This is an impressive can of wine, refreshingly complex and lively in acidity. Bright flavors of pomegranate and cranberry come from a saignée of West Block Syrah in the Petaluma Gap and several Pinot Noir sites, stainless-steel fermented and radiant in depth and structure.

Winemaker: Gordon Newton Johnson. A pronounced Thin Mint note greets you on the nose of this Pinot, grounded by just-ripe cinnamon-spiced raspberry and red cherry tones. Soft tannins lend a satiny texture to the light-plus mouthfeel, with more red-fruit flavors that are joined by hints of foliage and whole baking spice that carry through to the medium-length finish. Drink now–2024.

Winemaker: Pierre Wahl. This is rich and concentrated in yellow apple, melon and creamed pear tones upfront, with supporting notes of orange pith, pressed honeysuckle and lightly toasted nuts for added depth and some textural interest. The medium-weight palate offers a roundish mouthfeel, countered by ample acidity and a textural grip of apple skin and citrus peel flavor.
This dry, well-structured wine has firm tannins and persistent acidity matched by ripe and spicy blackberry and black-cherry flavors. It will shine when served with a roast or chop.

This wine's ripe and green pear scents continue their gently-fruited game on the light, easy and dry palate. Pear fruit sets the tone all the way, with a little assistance from lemony brightness. Slender and fresh, it lingers long.
This light and very lean wine smells like fresh thyme and pine needles, tastes very crisp and delicate, has low alcohol and good refreshment qualities.

Delicate peony and pink sweet-pea florals lead the nose of this sweet wine, with supporting fruit tones of white peach and apple flesh on the nose and mouth. It's medium in weight, with abundant peach and apricot flavors that are balanced by just enough acidic lift.
designation: Pyrène L'emoustillant Grains Dorés Gros Manseng-Sauvignon Blanc

description: Raspberry jam and dried cranberry aromas are at the fore, with peppery accents in the background. The flavors are plump and ripe, but don't have the structure to hold them together.

The aromas pop, with notes of raspberry jam, cherry and spice. The cocoa and jammy red-fruit flavors are light and appealing, tapering toward the finish. It's a straight down the fairway offering of the variety.
Dried herb aromas and lemon-lime flavors highlight this medium-bodied and smooth-textured wine. It has considerable richness in the mouthfeel and tastes soft in terms of acidity.

A strong floral perfume leads the bouquet of this wine, with supporting notes of pink apple, just-ripe pear and citrus oil. There's a pronounced roundness to the palate, with some perceived sweetness thanks to rich flavors of peach and apricot preserves as well as ripe lychee. For fans of a filling, decadently styled Chardonnay.

This blend of 85% Sangiovese and a balance of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Syrah opens with dark-skinned berry, underbrush and cooking spice aromas. The straightforward, savory palate delivers black cherry, star anise and clove flavors alongside pliant tannins. Enjoy through 2021.

Cabernet Sauvignon makes up just about two-thirds of this wine, with the balance Merlot and Malbec. Blue fruit, anise, herb and spice aromas are at the fore. The palate boasts soft fruit flavors that linger on the finish.
Ripe yellow pear makes for an appetizing nose. The palate has the same friendly fruit, with a little more green-pear freshness. It is light, dry and easy.

Made from 90% Sangiovese and 10% Canaiolo, this suggests dark-skinned fruit, tilled soil and tobacco on the nose. The savory palate offers dried black cherry, clove and white pepper notes alongside firm tannins. Drink 2019–2023.
This opens with dark berry, leather and forest floor aromas. The medium-bodied palate delivers dried black cherry, star anise and licorice flavors alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2023.

This is a deep, rich and mouth-filling wine from the heart of Zinfandel country in Amador County. It offers an abundance of ripe berries, black pepper and hints of oak spices. It's full bodied, creamy in texture, layered with black fruits and has a soothing, moderately tannic texture. Best through 2024.

This is an immensely fun, fruity and fresh wine, a vibrant display of delicious youth that's ready to glug now. Light in the glass, the wine shows fruit punch and all manner of red fruit on the nose, along with some carnations. The palate offers red apple and watermelon but with tannic grip and ample spice to make it memorable.

Smoky, yeasty aromas are low on fruit but big on autolysis and complexity. Lemony acidity (on a 16-year-old wine) cuts through creamy fullness, while this gran reserva brut nature emphasizes smoky, peppery white fruit flavors akin to a fine Burgundy. A healthy finish is loaded with latent oak character; drink or hold for up to another five to seven years.

There is very playful and buoyant energy to the nose of this blend of 81% Cabernet Sauvignon, 5% Merlot, 5% Cabernet Franc, 5% Malbec and 4% Petit Verdot, with fresh and inviting aromas of ripe black plum, blackberries and spring flower petals. The palate is delicately bodied and full of black-raspberry and dried herb flavors.

This rich wine comes from a vineyard with more clay soil than many in Chablis. Its weight and density are balanced by the perfumed yellow fruits and acidity. It's a fine wine already, but will be richer as it matures. Drink from 2021.

This premier cru is close to the Grand Cru Les Preuses vineyard. Concentration and beautiful richness are apparent in this structured wine. It shares generous yellow fruits with taut acidity and a tight structure. As it matures further, the wine will open out generously. Drink from 2021.

Rounded aromas of black cherry, cola and vanilla meet with more intense expressions of violet and white pepper on the nose of this wine, one of the few Petite Sirahs grown in this county. Black-cherry syrup meets with savory tones of toasted beef and black pepper on the palate, which is framed by polished tannins.

This bottling offers a delicate nose of peach, lime blossom and white pepper followed by a palate that is tight and focused, with mouthwatering acidity, chalky minerality and a long lime and apple finish.
This is a chunky, spicy, agreeable wine, with a brambly mix of red fruit notes. It's all power on the midpalate, while the oak aging—one year in 30% new barrels—brings toasted hazelnut highlights.

Hugely concentrated and ripely fleshy, this big broad-shouldered wine features rustic and robust flavors of leather, black pepper and clove wrapped in black fig and berry. The tannins are thick but supportive, youthful in their integration.

As part of Osmin's series celebrating the many rare grapes of Southwest France, this wine comes from the small area of the Marmandais close to Bordeaux. Abouriou is the local red grape producing a well-structured, perfumed wine with balanced tannins and ripe acidity. Poised and elegant, it ready to drink now.

Fragrant tones of lavender and licorice accent black plum and cherry in this ripe full-bodied red. It's juicy and primary yet nuanced by savory notes of moss and dark herb. The finish is moderately long, lingering on fine-grained velvety tannins.

Earthy, smoky notes inform the ripe russet-pear fruit on the nose. The palate comes in with real power and concentration but also shows a taut, linear freshness. This big but elegant wine is destined for the table with its concentration and presence. It shows lovely balance and purity throughout, and is sure to develop. Drink now–2028.
designation: Clos Lisser Monopole Grand Cru Kirchberg de Barr

description: A touch of smoke plays about the nose but lemon is just underneath. Lemony notions take over the palate and show both zesty freshness and the golden fluidity of candied peel. This wine is slender but full flavored, with ripe, aromatic lemon. The finish is dry and vivid.

Old World Syrah aromas of olive, animal hide and grilled beef power the nose of this primal wine. The palate is firm with tannic grip, tasting of black olive tapenade, beef jerky and briary black fruit. On the finish, complex notes of chocolate, spice and bacon make it even more interesting. Drink now–2024.

Tasted alongside the producer's other 2016 Riesling, there's clearly an extra layer of oomph in this dry full-bodied bottling. It's ripe and rich, offering plump white grapefruit and green-plum flavors that linger in silky pools on the palate. Punchy lime acidity and a fringe of grapefruit bitter lend structure to the finish.

Very savory and dense on the nose, this bottling by Adam Lee shows smoky roast beef and smoked-pork-shank aromas as well as concentrated black currant and dried purple flowers. The palate is fresh, lively, tense and dense all at once, and needs a bit more time for the black-plum flavors to unfurl and acidity to mellow. Drink 2020–2035.

Powerful and earthy, this rich and concentrated wine is full bodied, broad in texture and has envelope-pushing spice and leather aromas backed by well-concentrated wild-berry and plum-compote flavors of significant depth. It's seductive and lavish in character.

Caramelized aromas of oak, vanilla and concentrated cherry show on the nose of this bottling with butterflies on the label. The palate is a bit sweeter and simpler than in vintages past, with oak, caramel, vanilla dust and red-cherry flavors.
This wine's mushroom, mint, cranberry and spice aromas seem a bit muddled, and the flavors suggest more of the same. It finishes tart.

Heavy oak and modest fruit aromas give this wine an oily, walnut-like bouquet. Salty, nutty flavors mix with citrus and popcorn notes on its full, chunky palate, revolving around a core of acidity. Early oxidation is apparent on the finish, hinting at white mushroom.

This hearty wine is an unusual blend: half Pinot Noir and half Syrah. It's spicy and smoky in aroma, tastes meaty, coffee-like and dense, and has a moderately tannic texture. Oaky flavors dominate the blackberry notes underneath.

This is a simple, citrusy stone-fruited sipper with something a little chemical, like lemon-scented furniture polish, swirling around. Nevertheless, the palate is balanced and dry with crisp acidity and very slight fruit weight.

A rather obvious but likable wine, this has heady aromas of ripe peaches and pears, apple skins and flowers. The palate shows a little residual sugar but overall it's a mostly dry style with a slightly waxy texture. Knock this back with Chinese egg rolls and lo mein.

This producer with vines in the Aube has made a specialty of pure Pinot Noir Champagnes. Rich yet dry, this wine is full of generous white fruits cut with toastiness. Now mature, it is ready to drink.

The aromas start out high toned, with notes of bittersweet chocolate, black cherry and spice. There's a pleasing sense of structure to the elegantly styled fruit flavors. Give it some additional time in bottle or a short decant.

Made from 85% Pinot Noir and 15% Chardonnay, this brilliant brut rosé offers bright and snappy aromas of red currant, strawberry hull and fresh-cut apple. The palate offers more of the same, the tart flavors and mouthfilling mousse cut by citrusy acidity and nervy tension. Drink now–2022.
designation: Twee Jonge Gezellen Vintage Rosé Cuvée Brut Méthode Cap Classique

description: A blend of Chardonnay from the Montagne de Reims and the Côte des Blancs, this is still young, with a soft fruitiness that contrasts with the mineral texture. Its acidity is cushioned by the relatively high dosage. Drink this perfumed wine now.
designation: Blanc de Blancs Grand Cru Brut

description: Lanson's big seller remains crisp and fruity, with a tight, bright character and a mineral texture. Without any malolactic fermentation, the wine retains freshness and delicious acidity. Drink now.

A yellowish shade of pink, this rosé, which is 95% Counoise and 5% Cinsaut, starts with fresh aromas of pluot and bubblegum. The palate is very grippy, slowly releasing flavors of red plum, tangerine and a flash of bubblegum.

This rich, full wine is firmly anchored in ripe tannins. It has concentration and a dense texture, layered with black fruits and acidity. Partly fermented in clay amphoras, the wine has a particularly juicy edge. Drink from 2020.

Calm and pure blackberry and cassis aromas feed into an intense palate with freshness and rubbery tannins. While not loud, this goes heavy on the gas and features edgy dark-berry flavors. A rock-solid finish confirms the structure on this cement-fermented-and-aged Malbec from Paraje Altamira in the Uco Valley. Drink through 2025.

Max level full-toast oak gives this brute an almost burnt nose, but with subtler leathery berry and crude oil notes it's not just about the oak. To no surprise, this is intense and powerful on the palate. Flavors of maple, chocolate, toast and blackberry are pressed into a stocky whole that doesn't dissipate on the finish. Drink from 2020–2032.

This wine explodes with apricot and apple aromas. It's one of the purest expressions of the grape variety to be found in California, and brings excellent depth, concentration and personality to the table. Crisp acidity helps the texture to be lively, and despite light alcohol, it's rich enough to create a lingering finish.

Fresh clear pure notes of green and red apple have the merest hint of lemon, creating a most appetizing nose. The palate is restrained in its clear fruit, but very fine creamy bubbles lend freshness and disperse the lovely creamy apple aromas. This most elegant sparkler has a grown-up, dry and classy finish. Lovely depth shows in the umami finish.

The nose on this bottling from a vineyard first planted in 1970 starts with woody sagebrush, forest floor, mushroom and moss aromas, but leads into ripe cranberry and rose petals, with the slightest hint of game. Bay leaf, marjoram and tangy cranberry touches complete the palate.
Ripe red fruits dominate this creamy, bubbly wine. Its acidity is balanced by the smooth, soft texture with red-currant flavors and an zesty edge. Drink this festive wine now.

Herbal aromas of blackberry, mint, cocoa and oak spice lead to a palate with astringency and wiry acidity. Olive, oak spice and briny red plum flavors are a touch raw, as is the finish on this blend of Carmenère and Syrah.
Powerful in structure and quite ripe and monolithic in flavor, this full-bodied wine tastes like black cherries and light oak spices and has a firm texture backed by moderate tannins.
Light and fruity, this wine has layers of attractive acidity along with a mineral texture that keeps it on its toes. The wine's freshness makes it attractive and ready to drink.
A pale-colored blend of Cabernet Franc and Merlot, this is soft and just off dry. It has plenty of ripe raspberry flavors and a crisp, yeasty aftertaste. Drink now.
Bright and fruity, this crisp blend of Chardonnay and Gamay is soft and packed with apple flavors and acidity that are lifted by an orange-zest aftertaste. Drink this wine now.

The nose of this wine is full of lemon and lime zest, sea salt and stone notes. Its fresh citrus flavors are hemmed in by zesty minerality, offering complexity and a lingering finish. One of Santorini's best whites, hands down.

Ripe berry and cassis aromas exhibit clearer notes of mocha and herbs the longer this breathes. A tight palate is anchored by a grip of tannins. Plum, currant and tobacco flavors precede a finish with lifting acidity and integrated oak. Drink through 2022.

Tangy lime-skin aromas meet with yellow pear flesh and a touch of honey on the nose of this bottling, which gains nuance from the acacia wood treatment. There is grippy texture on the palate, where citrus acidity cuts through the Pink Lady apple flavors.

A Port-like ripeness in the aroma leads to lush, chocolaty flavors that range from superripe black plums to blueberry syrup. The wine is full bodied, rich and viscous in texture, with mild tannins and soft acidity for balance.

Intense varietal aromas of tropical fruit, tomato vine, aromatic herb and citrus jump out of the glass. Reflecting the nose, the expressive, mouthwatering palate doles out juicy grapefruit, honeydew melon and grilled sage alongside tangy acidity.

Tantalizing oak and rich fruit flavors vie for attention in this full-bodied, firmly tannic and well-structured wine. It has plenty of concentration with, boysenberry jam aromas, lush fruit and chocolate flavors.

Tight aromas of dark berries, wet earth and tobacco mark the nose. Firmly medium in weight and bolstered by dusty, grainy tannins, the palate offers tart red-plum and blackberry flavors that lead to an oak-spice finish.
Crisp and grassy although with some hints of tropical fruit, this wine is all about fruitiness. Acidity, citrus and a refreshing character are all part of this attractive wine. Drink now.

Heavy berry fruit and oak aromas are low on depth and complexity. This thick Tempranillo is choppy and impermeable. Saucy flavors of herbal plum and tomato finish equally herbal and with saltiness, much like a meat sauce for pasta.
Black currant, blueberry and tar aromas lead to lightly sweet blackberry flavors. It shows a fair amount of sugar but largely pulls it off.
Quite light in color, the aromas are elusive, with notes of citrus and cherry. It drinks dry, with a lightly smoky finish.
An assertive oaky streak covers ripe apple and caramel flavors in this full-bodied wine. It shows pronounced aromas of charred wood and smoke in the aroma that continue on the palate.

Intense, lifted aromas of black cassis and plum are tinged with earth tones in this full-bodied, penetrating wine. A blend of mostly Grenache and Syrah with a small proportion of Mourvèdre, it's rounded on the palate but firm in minerality and tannins. A rich, densely structured wine that's approachable now but should improve through 2028.

High-altitude vineyards lend a distinct freshness and minerality to ripe black cherry and plum notes here. It's supple yet pure and restrained, marked by integrated acidity and a fine fringe of chalky, elegant tannins that lengthen the finish. An elegant, enjoyable wine already but should improve through 2030.

Enticing scents of rose, woodland berry, wild herb and pastry dough shape the nose on this lively sparkler. The elegant palate shows polished maturity but is still fresh, delivering sour cherry, pomegranate, tangerine and a dollop of ginger alongside bright acidity and a silky mousse. An almond note lingers on the close.

This extremely energetic and zippy bottling offers grassy elements on the nose that are balanced by hints of passion fruit, wet stone and lime rind. The palate is extremely textural and grippy, delivering pear and apple flavors along with pink-grapefruit pith and a chalky finish.

Toasted almond, lemon peel, grapefruit pith, ash and a waft of smoke show on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from the Brack Mountain Winery family. The palate is broad with lemon, pluot and hazelnut flavors, proving equal parts fresh, fruity and savory with every touch point needed in a Chardonnay.

Elegant and savory, this lovely sparkler hits all the right buttons, starting with an enticing fragrance that recalls wild berry, Alpine herb, bread crust and a hint of baking spice. On the creamy, weightless palate, bright acidity lifts strawberry compote, ripe Rennet apple, citrus zest and a ginger note while a silky perlage lends finesse. A flinty mineral note energizes the finish.

This wine is clean and focused on the nose in notes of citrus rind, crushed stone and grassy, blossomy floral tones. The light-bodied, dry palate offers pithy lemon-lime flavors, with a wealth of white flowers and minerals that linger on the finish.
This wine's cedar, vanilla and dark-skinned fruit aromas emerge in the glass. The firm palate offers dark berry, mocha and star anise flavors alongside polished tannins. Drink through 2021.

Ballet-slipper pink, this rosé boasts aromas of cherry blossom, watermelon and crushed stone on the nose. The palate shows good texture and grip, with flavors of cranberry skins and strawberry met with a citric backdrop and a delicate peach-fuzz finish.

This wine is ripe, soft with rich apple and pear fruits. With balanced acidity and a youthful zesty character, it is full, rounded and will pair well with food. The aftertaste adds a perfumed character. Drink this wine now.

Crisp, cutting gooseberry and white grapefruit notes are shaded by smoked nut and fresh herb hints in this medium-bodied white. Dry and intently mineral on the palate, it finishes on an invigorating lemon-lime flavor.

Still closed when tasted in March 2018, this delicate rosé's earth and smoke notes give way to concentrated raspberry and strawberry flavors after hearty aeration. Full bodied and richly textured, it's calibrated by refreshing acidity and a firm, mineral finish.

This blend of 44% Grenache Blanc, 38% Roussanne, 11% Viognier and 7% Picpoul is tightly wound on the nose, offering soft aromas of ambrosia melon and a hint of daffodil. The wine is clean and easy on the palate, with delicately ripe flavors of stone fruit, melon and honey dust.

This red blend offers aromas of dried earth, cinnamon, spiced cherry and cassis. Its palate is oversized and mildly syrupy in feel, recalling medicinal cherry and spice cake tones, with grainy tannins on the finish. Drink through 2030.

Fresh violets and rose petals make for a florally dominated nose, but there's also blackberry sorbet on this bottling. Crisp flavors of violet, blackberry paste and blueberry make for a fulfilling sip.
This lovely, full-flavored and fruit-driven wine needs no special occasion to enjoy. It's a delicious mélange of strawberry preserve, raspberry purée and black cherry cola notes.

Sourced from own-rooted Pommard clone vines planted in 1979, this starts out with a tannic grip and pomegranate and brambly berry flavors. Its underlying, astringent minerality drives the palate forward into a buttery finish. While all Bethel Heights Pinot Noirs are ageworthy, this one will notably benefit from another year or two in bottle.

This elegant medium-bodied wine has everything in place, from fresh plummy aromas to warm layered flavors to an appetizing and moderately tannic texture. It has excellent balance, with a sense of freshness and depth that is compelling.

Crushed stone minerality and zesty tangerine, pineapple and mango aromas abound in this ripe but delicately framed spätlese. Sunny citrus flavors are lip-smackingly honeyed but balanced, offset by spine-tingling acidity and a long crystalline finish.

This wine is bold but nuanced, too, showing a blend of very ripe black-fruit, oak-spice, black-pepper and roast-beef flavors on a firm structure of moderate tannins and good acidity. It turns creamy in texture on the palate and lingers on the finish.

Dark cherry, sweet sage, rust and moist earth aromas show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard just miles from the coast behind Cambria. Dried cherry and pomegranate show on the sip, but that earthy kick carries through, with more sage, juniper and bay leaf. The finish is lively and mouthwatering.

This Right Bank-inspired blend allows Merlot to take the lead at 60%, combined nicely with 25% Cabernet Sauvignon and 15% Cabernet Franc. Sanguine, its richness muted and well-integrated, the flavors lean into black currant, clove, leather and black licorice, with a softness to the texture.

Wet stone and fresh lemon are faint but distinct on the nose. A pure lemon flavor streaks across the slender, taut palate, with a comet-like spray of freshness. This wine is dry and, if it weren't for juicy glimpses of ripe lemon, would be almost austere.

Earthy berry, tobacco and leather aromas announce an old-school Ribera wine with brett in the bouquet. On the palate, this is chewy and meaty, with a full complement of tannins. Its blackberry and cassis flavors are supported by baking spice notes. They lead to a ripe finish loaded with chocolaty richness. Drink through 2034.
This has a carbonic, stemmy energy to its overall earthiness. It also offers an exploration of forest floor, spicy dried herb and baked raspberry.
This Nero d'Avola opens with dark fruit and tilled soil aromas. The simple palate offers suggestions of black plum, star anise and a touch of cocoa alongside pliant tannins. Drink soon.
This soft, ripe wine is packed with black fruit. It has juicy acidity, perfumed berry flavors and hints of its 12 months of wood aging. Drink this rounded wine now.
Aromas of acacia honey, lemon blossom and Granny Smith apple carry the nose. On the palate, there are flavors of custard and baked apple that lead to an off-dry finish.

A salmon-pink color in the glass, this opens with scents of bruised peach, melon and strawberry that follow through to the medium-weight palate alongside brighter notes of pineapple core and grapefruit peel. Medium acidity helps to keep the palate lifted and the finish bright. Drink now.
This smooth, ripe wine has raspberry flavors that are lifted by attractive acidity. Its texture is soft, rounded, rich and lightly textured. Drink the wine now.
This wine is aromatic in tones of red and black berries, cedar and tobacco. The palate brings plum and black cherry flavors, with drying tannins that leave a lingering taste of black tea.

White spring flower, acacia and tropical fruit aromas lift out of the glass. On the smooth, rounded palate, tangy acidity and a mineral vein energize ripe yellow apple, juicy pear and a drop of honey. A hint of toasted almond signals the close.

Aromas of bread crust, field flower and yellow stone fruit lift out of the glass. On the silky palate, bright acidity lifts peach, chopped herb, toasted almond and citrus zest alongside a refined perlage.

Toasted oak, sandalwood, pine, lemon peels and dried apple show on the nose of this bottling from the appellation's northernmost stretches. The palate starts with the freshness of cut lemon before dwelling back on the intense and savory qualities of aged wood and sea salt.

For those who like a hint of sweetness and a ton of dark jammy fruit flavors, this wine is a no-brainer. A blend of 50% Zinfandel plus Barbera, Syrah and Petite Sirah, it smells and tastes chocolaty, berry-like and superripe, and has a velvety texture that soothes the palate.

This well-funded new effort has released its first wines, from a vineyard planted in 2012. The wines show plenty of potential, though young vines cannot fully express all the secrets of the land in which they grow. Light berry flavors and highlights of toast and breakfast tea are in focus. Consulting winemaker Tony Rynders has used one new and one neutral barrel for this limited offering, keeping flavors in balance. Off to a good start, this is a winery to watch.

Ripe juicy apple notes have a slight edge of heady kerosene. On the palate, the apple flavors take over with their juicy but tart ripeness that holds a wonderful crunch despite a smidgen of residual sweetness. This is concentrated, zesty and exuberant. The finish again majors on apple and is just about dry. Drink now through 2028.

This is a powerful wine, rich and dense. Aged for one year in wood, it is a complex blend of 70% Tannat with some Cabernet Sauvignon and Fer Servadou. Its richness with layers of black fruits, acidity and spice from the wood aging are just now coming together and the wine is ready to drink.

Because the Bianco Gentile and Genovese grapes in this blend are not authorized for a Corsica appellation, this wine is a super Vin de France. Produced with natural yeasts in egg-shaped tanks, the wine is rich and warm with a lightly oxidative character that adds complexity. The wine is generous, full of ripe baked apple and apricot flavors. Drink this impressive wine now.

This is a big, seriously rich wine with both great tannins and layers of black-currant fruit. Cabernet Sauvignon in the Douro may seem an odd combination but here it works. Mint and rich fruit combine with a firm texture finished with acidity. Drink from 2022.

Notes of ripe peach have an edge of Damask rose to them on the nose. The palate comes in with an almost viscous roundness, carrying both sweetness and pleasant phenolic bitterness that sets off some of the richness. This is medium sweet and full-on, brimming with the ripest aromatic fruit. Great now but certain to develop. Drink through 2028.

There is a hovering hint of something deeply aromatic, almost of bergamot, that flashes on the nose. The zestiness appears once again on the slender palate where superfine mousse tingles and dances. This is wonderfully refreshing, slender and harmonious, vibrating all the while with its zesty rich perfume, pitched fittingly against its slender palate. This is the way to go. Drink now through 2025.

This small enclave of Sauvignon Blanc in the north of Burgundy has much, tastewise, to do with Sancerre. This wine offers crisp acidity and white-currant flavors cut with lemon juice and filled out with hints of white fruits. Drink the wine now.
This light-pink-colored blend of Pinot Noir with a touch of Gamay is soft and fruity. Red-berry flavors shows against a background of perfumed acidity with a soft, ripe aftertaste. Drink now.
Scents of wildflower and orchard fruit lift delicately out of the glass. On the palate, bright acidity accompanies yellow pear and citrus zest.

Red berry, orchard fruit and bread crust aromas lead the nose. On the lively palate, steely, continuous bubbles and bright acidity provide the backdrop for sour cherry, strawberry and a hint of toasted hazelnut.

A blend of Carricante and Catarratto cultivated on Mount Etna, this has aromas of Spanish broom, orchard fruit, acacia honey and crusty bread. The aromas follow over to the lively palate along with toasted almond and yellow apple. It's edgy, with vibrant acidity and vivacious beading.
designation: Mon Pit Balnc de Blancs Metodo Classico

description: Aromas of jasmine and white peach emerge from the glass. The easygoing palate offers Golden Delicious apple and pink grapefruit, while a ginger note marks the finish.

After a few swirls of the glass, you'll find whiffs of dried wild flower, baked apple and toasted almond, while the round full-bodied palate offers mature yellow apple, white peach and candied lemon slice. A vanilla note lingers on the close while just enough fresh acidity brightens the rich flavors.

Heady scents of beeswax, wild herb, Spanish broom and yellow stone fruit float from the glass. Bright and balanced, the linear palate doles out apricot, yellow apple and lemon zest alongside crisp acidity.

From a 17th century estate, this wine is rich and generous in its ripe yellow fruits and balanced acidity. Hints of wood aging, spice, white fruits and a structured texture will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2020.

From a 17-acre estate close to Pomerol, this wine is powerful and dense, summing up the richness of the vintage. It is opulent, already juicy and densely ripe with black-currant fruits. It has concentration and a dry core that will soften as the wine develops. Drink from 2022.

Plump, sun-kissed blackberry and dried-strawberry flavors abound in this deeply fruity, forward Grenache. Full bodied and plush on the palate, it's lifted by savory hints of bramble and spice as well as firm, finely edged tannins that grip on the finish. Drink now–2021.

Sourced from four vineyards across the county, this white offers concentrated aromas of jasmine and honeyed oak. Fully lush and high toned, it is robust in texture and grit on the midpalate, with a lasting taste of vanilla oak.

This is a soft-textured, medium-bodied wine with floral, earthy aromas and butterscotch flavors that come off as candied and a touch sweet. It's well made and should appeal to people who don't like their wines bone dry.
This is a fairly rich and moderately fruity wine that has peachy aromas and flavors and light to medium body.

This wine spent 30 months in only 40% new French oak. The aromas are lighter in style and don't seem to be fully delineated, with notes of cranberry, cherry and herb, along with a strong anise note. The palate is dry, with scratchy, slightly astringent seeming tannins.

A blend of Castelão and Aragonez, this is fruity, ripely textured and still young. Its fruit comes through the mineral and tannic character but still needs to shine further. The aftertaste has promise with its juicy and fruity flavors. Drink from 2019.
Aromas of yeast, flowers and green melon carry the nose. The palate brings pear, apple and melon flavors in front of a steady finish.
A quiet nose of citrus and tonic leads to the light-bodied, streamlined palate. Wet stone and blossoms linger on the finish.

There's intoxicating power within this lush, concentrated wine full of blackberry and mulberry flavors. But it's a polished, elegant wine, too, edged by fine-grained tannins and hints of earth, bramble and spice. Enveloping and silky through a long finish, it drinks well now but should develop its savory complexities through 2030.

Cinnamon-covered cherry and black currant highlight this beautifully layered, spicy and complex example of the variety—a well-made, full-bodied effort that finishes in a dusting of cocoa powder and coconut.

Light raspberry and strawberry aromas mesh with star anise and close on the pleasing if somewhat mellow nose of this single-vineyard expression. Riper, richer flavors of vanilla, oak, baking spice and cooked berries show on the palate, which is powered by strong acid.

Framboise, sweet dill, moss and dewy herbs show on the nose of this bottling from the Sta. Rita Hills. A grippy texture grabs hold of the palate right away and won't let go, allowing pungent and underripe strawberry, cinnamon and all spice flavors to grab the attention.

Reduced and brimming in barrel oak, this is a full-bodied, concentrated and ageworthy wine, flavored in strong layers of baked plum, cinnamon and soy. As it opens, generous helpings of blueberry and fig figure into the mix, adding to the complexity. Enjoy 2025–2030.

This Syrah from Winemaker Greg Brewer is dynamic and built to last, starting with aromas of crushed peppercorn, tapenade, twigs, ground pepper, tar and elderberry fruit. The palate combines black currant with tart black-plum skin, thyme, bay and peppercorns, ending on flashes of tar and mocha.

This reserve-level wine is priced at the high end of the winery's substantial lineup of Rieslings and sourced from unspecified old vine sites. It offers a fruity mix of Meyer lemon, apricot and peach that's ripe enough to carry the impression of sweetness yet finishes (and is labeled) dry. Drink now and over the next half decade.

Leather and barnyard aromas add complexity without taking over this rich, earthy, smooth-textured and full-bodied wine. Complex flavors like tobacco, rhubarb, black pepper and wild blackberry fill the palate and moderate tannins provide some needed grip. It's on the wild side, for adventurous drinkers.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas suggesting black-skinned berry, underbrush and a whiff of eucalyptus. The juicy savory palate delivers Marasca cherry, white pepper and tobacco alongside chewy tannins. Drink through 2024.

Made entirely from Sangiovese, this opens with enticing aromas of iris, black-skinned berry and Mediterranean herb. The structured, savory palate offers juicy wild cherry, star anise and black pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2025.
This wine's mountain blueberry, huckleberry and flint aromas leap out of the glass. Its blue fruit flavors are rich, saturated and hedonistic. It's unabashed in its appeal.

This wine has pleasant floral and spice aromas, a velvety-soft texture full of fine-grained tannins and generous black-plum and dark chocolate flavors that verge on sweet. It's full bodied, mouth-filling and delicious.

Muted on the nose, this blend of 52% Petit Verdot, 44% Malbec, 2% Merlot and 2% Cabernet Sauvignon is hearty and thickly extracted, the fruit red and highly strung, with herbal components taking on prominence as the wine opens.
This lightly structured wine is crisp and refreshing. Strawberry and citrus come together harmoniously, given dryness by the mineral texture. A touch of spice at the end gives a bite. Drink now.
This Sauvignon Blanc offers up peach and pear juice, tropical fruit, tomato leaf and green bell pepper on the nose. It's silky and slippery, with an approachable, easygoing vibe about it.

Appley floral aromas meet rich ripe apple and pear flavors in this generous mouthfilling and smooth-textured wine. It is medium bodied, fragrant and easy to enjoy, especially with an appetizer like smoked trout.

Hints of lemon zest and moss on the nose signal appetizing freshness. On the light palate, this freshness is helped along by a bit of spritz and more zestiness and a hint of yeasty pepperiness—very moreish.

Mostly Syrah (82%) along with pinches of Grenache (12%) and Mourvèdre (6%), the aromas leap up, with notes of boysenberry pie, herb, fresh flower and raspberry. The flavors are lighter styled, missing in the middle, with a blue-fruit-filled finish.
Crisp red-currant fruits have given this wine an attractive perfumed character. It has lively acidity and a bright aftertaste. Drink this zesty wine now.

A 50-50 blend of Inzolia and Catarratto, this simple white has intense floral aromas evoking jasmine and hawthorn. The floral aromas carry through to the fresh palate along with green apple, ripe white peach and a citrus note.
Here's a bright simple white that evokes mature yellow-apple and citrus flavors. A saline note and fresh acidity give it a crisp clean finish. It's ideal for everyday enjoyment.
This wine is all about the red fruit that gives it its soft, ripe character. A blend of seven grapes, it has spice, lifted acidity and soft tannins. Generous and warm, it's ready to drink.

A touch of earthiness accompanies a peach aroma on the nose. The palate follows with juicy sweetness, boosing peach and a counterpoint of earth and lemon freshness. Drink soon while aromas are at their peak.

A touch of wet hay joins the lemon notes on the nose. The palate has the same wet-hay notions that seem to dull the lemon notes, creating a strange kind of fennel-tinged savoriness. The finish is dry and fresh.

Not your average fruit bomb, this medium- to full-bodied wine blends generous earth, game and leather aromas with raspberry, beef and savory flavors on a smooth, broad and moderately tannic texture. It's very engaging and concentrated. Don't let the nonvintage status scare you off.

This is a seriously delicious wine that's packed tightly with fruit, floral and spice flavors and has a firm but velvety texture that makes it a pleasure to sip. It has a deep dark ruby color, expressive aromas, generous black-cherry and dark chocolate flavors and a lingering finish. Best after 2022.

The aromas in this 100% varietal Cabernet Sauvignon from Cold Creek and Stone Tree vineyards rise out of the glass, suggesting scorched earth, dried herb, graphite, flint, cassis and cherry. It has bright but balanced acidity to support its fruit flavors, with green pepper and cherry notes that linger on the finish. It's flat-out delicious and exceptionally balanced. Put it on the dinner table and watch it shine.

This multi-clonal selection is lushly endowed with a bright mix of red fruit, recalling cranberry, pomegranate, raspberry and cherry. It's annotated with orange peel highlights and orange blossom scents. The detail and subtlety are impressive.

Gentle pear fruit has a touch of herbal tisane. The same gentle purity of fruit is amplified on the streamlined, dry palate where freshness and ripeness seem to flow from a deep well of pear and lemon. Taut and balanced, this is utterly moreish and perfectly dry. Drink until 2030.

This newcomer to the appellation is boldly styled and hearty in blue fruit and baked cherry, the experience on the palate warming and complete. Concentrated and powerfully built, it shows a wealth of cola spice and vanilla on the lengthy finish.

Very ripe and concentrated fruit flavors are framed by light oak spices in this full-bodied and round-textured wine. It has a generous mouthfeel, deep black-plum flavors and a good sense of richness, partly due no doubt to a hefty alcohol level.
Aromas of woodland berry, new leather and forest floor lead the nose. The savory palate offers red cherry, star anise and white pepper alongside polished tannins and fresh acidity. Drink 2020–2027.

This is a sweet rich style of LBV, full of ripe plum fruits as well as raisins. The luscious texture of the wine is nicely lifted by acidity at the end. This style of Port, with its tannins still there, can be aged further. So either drink it now or wait until 2022.

Woodland berry, tilled soil, dried rose, new leather and aromatic herb aromas come together in this fragrant, racy red. It's rather light in body and ethereal for Barolo, already accessible, offering flavors of tart sour cherry, clove and chopped dill. Firm acidity and polished tannins provide lithe support. Drink through 2025.

This fruity style is immediately attractive, ripe with dusty tannins and blackberry fruit. It is not a powerful wine although its tannins do promise longevity as well as a fine sense of structure. Drink the wine from 2028.

Made with 90% Moscato and 10% Grecanico, this racy sparkler opens with aromas of citrus, crushed herb and a whiff of yellow stone fruit. Reflecting the nose, the vibrant palate delivers dried apricot, flinty minerality and lemon alongside an elegant, continuous perlage.

Creamy notes of ripe Golden Pearmain on the nose immediately hint at a winning combination of apple freshness and yeasty creamy autolysis. The palate delivers with a mouthful of creamy fizzing bursting bubbles, dispersing both apple ripeness and freshness with hints of crumble topping and shortbread. The finish is dry and lip smacking with fresh lemon. Simply lovely.

A vanilla lick aligns with the ripe pear notes on the nose. The palate shows the rich, rounded and ripe fruit of juicy pears and a hint of marzipan but also lots of lemony freshness that corrals fruit, oak and all of that juiciness into a concentrated, dry and lingering wine. With the oak notes still fresh this will benefit from time in bottle. Drink 2020–2030.

Ripe pear peel has a lovely touch of grapefruit zestiness. The palate comes in with a subtle, autumnal and demerara sugar sweetness that adds a touch of caramel to the fruit. The palate is smooth and juicy but also harmoniously sonorous. The finish is medium sweet but also zestily fresh. Drink now through 2028.

A tropical touch of mango hovers above the zesty lemon notes on the nose. The palate melds this tropical citrus allure into a smooth fresh fruit-driven palate with wonderfully zesty concentration. Mango notions keep appearing alluringly. The finish is dry and long.

Earth, dried lemon zest and crushed chamomile flowers send their ethereal notes from the glass. The palate comes in a rounded, almost emollient fashion that adds dried and baked apple and notions of mildly clear blossom honey. This lovely evolved Riesling is at a wonderful point in its development. Drink until 2028.

Loads of savory aromas, from cracked black pepper, tar, game and beef crust, mesh with roasted black-currant and coffee tones on the nose of this bottling from the historic vineyard. The palate combines black fruit with coffee cream, savory lamb and more cracked pepper.

This blueberry-colored wine features black cherry, orange zest and black pepper aromas. Its spice notes are stronger than its fruit, suggesting anise, allspice, black currant and stewed plums. Smooth tannins make way for a citrus note on the finish.

Aromas of orchard fruit, bread crust and spring flower take shape in the glass. The savory medium-bodied palate delivers juicy citrus, pistachio, mineral and a hint of ginger alongside bright acidity. Drink through 2020.

This inky violet wine has blackberry, espresso and smoke aromas. It feels good on the palate, with soft tannins and cassis, cherry preserves, pomegranate and baking spice flavors. It offers a bright splash on the finish.

This wine's allspice and black cherry aromas are followed by balsamic, pepper, vanilla and red fruit flavors. Good acidity and a touch of subtle oak give it structure and ageability. Look to beef stew, lamb or aged cheeses as a pairing.

Dark ruby in color, this wine has a fruit-forward nose full of raspberry and strawberry scents. It's soft in the mouth, with blackberry, dark plum and cocoa powder flavors that wind down into a spicy finish.

Prominent notes of barley, nut and spice add a smoky tone to plush blackberry jam and preserved-plum flavors. Made from 100% Grenache grapes, it's a richly extracted, warming wine with bold alcohol and mouthfilling but lush tannins. It needs a few years to meld but should drink well from 2020–2030.

This is a rich, smoothly textured wine. Acidity and a crisp edge indicate how close these vines are to the Atlantic Ocean, adding a lift to the ripe apricot and pear flavors. Drink this lightly perfumed wine now.

Grapey aromas are reduced and meaty, with gaps. This feels hard, tannic and blocky, while dense flavors of blackberry and mint don't rise above the “good” level. A thick heavy finish is saturated in feel but tastes a touch herbal and green.

Barrel aromas are at the fore, with notes of vanilla, green wood, dill, menthol and char, making it a challenge to get at the fruit. The fruit flavors are lighter styled, not bringing the heft to stand up to the oak.

A direct set of stone-fruit and citrus aromas feeds into a round balanced palate with firm acidity. Minerally citrus and red-plum flavors are salty, while the finish is lasting but doesn't taste like much.

A subtle warmth graces the nose of this bottling, lifting the rich black-raspberry and boysenberry characteristics. Earthy scents of peat and pepper unfold in the back, while the medium-weight, satiny palate returns to rich, plush black-fruit flavors dusted in clove.

This salmon-colored rosé of Monastrell smells vaguely of cantaloupe and citrus. A plump citrusy palate features good acidity, while this tastes a little like orange. Accept this as highly basic and enjoy it for what it is.
Fresh apple and pear aromas lead to rich, ripe pear and vanilla flavors in this medium-bodied and lushly textured wine. It has a mouth-coating thickness that's soft and full.

A rare Gamay to appear outside Beaujolais, this wine is soft, with the lightest of tannins and the friendliest of red fruits. The result is a wine with attractive acidity and a ripe aftertaste. Drink now.
This well-balanced, ripe wine offers big tannins and layers of bright acidity. Black fruits and freshness give the wine a perfumed start in life, the tannins coming in behind. Drink from 2022.
The entry-level wine from this estate, this is soft and full of ripe strawberry flavors. Its light tannins and fruitiness go with a succulent texture to make a wine that is ready to drink.
This ripe wine is still very young. Spice, toast and dark coffee flavors still dominate, although there is plenty of fruit weight behind this dry facade. Wait to drink this wine until 2022

This wine is typical of Bordeaux whites in this vintage. It has ripe, almost tropical flavors of rich pear, pineapple and lime over a core of tangy, zesty fruit. The wine is lively, generous and ready to drink.

From one of the estates owned by this negociant firm, this wine's potential and richness are considerable. It has weight along with solid tannins and dark fruits that are waiting to burst out. It will be a very fine wine as it matures, but wait until 2022.
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Les Epenottes Premier Cru
