description: This is 93% Cabernet Sauvignon and 7% Sangiovese—a tense, focused and structured blend that's full bodied and rich. Black currant, mocha and dusty crushed rock provide a complement of fruit and mineral characteristics that work well together and while supported by toasted oak.

Broad and fleshy aromas of white melon and sliced pear are cut with a lime and kumquat edge on the nose of this single-vineyard expression from the Watsonville area. There is decent tension and acid on the tip of the sip, with fresh and penetrating flavors of Meyer lemon, key-lime balm and light almond on the finish.

This is a distinctive wine with memorable flavors of rhubarb, wild berries and black cherries, an expansive mouthfeel and full body. The effect is very ripe and opulent while backed by mild tannins and good acidity for a tasty sense of balance.
Brambly aromas and wild berry flavors give this wine a classic profile, while a full body and moderate tannins help firm up the texture. Hints of olive and sage offer added complexity.

This wine comes from a remote patch of earth that Garrett Boekenoogen farms without irrigation, which concentrates aromas of Bing cherry, herbs, turned earth and barbecued meats. The palate combines rounded red fruit with wild thyme, crushed slate and balanced acidity.

Whiffs of dusty mineral and smoke introduce this dry, medium-bodied white. The palate offers delicate apple and pear flavors accented by hazelnut notes and fresh white grapefruit-like acidity. A spry, neatly balanced wine to enjoy now–2020.

Shy at first, this reveals acacia, dried herb and white stone fruit aromas as it opens. They carry over to the palate, along with white peach and ginger notes. A hint of bitter almond backs up the finish.
This wine's delicate spring flower, citrus and yellow stone fruit scents lift out of the glass. On the medium-bodied palate, a white almond note underscores yellow peach and juicy pineapple flavors.
Dark berry and scorched earth aromas lead the nose of this wine while the savory palate offers black plum, star anise and black pepper flavors. It's easygoing, with smooth tannins. Drink soon.
Earthy aromas of tilled soil, game and dark fruit lead the nose of this wine. The dense palate offers black plum, clove and white pepper notes alongside firm tannins. Drink through 2022.

An aroma like ginger cookies and generous fruit and spice flavors make this full-bodied wine hard to resist. Clove, ginger and nutmeg fill the aroma, while black-cherry and black-currant notes coat the palate and linger on the finish. It's a fairly big wine that's delicious and well-balanced.

Pronounced aromas of earth and smoke subside to reveal delicate yellow-apple and pear notes here. The palate is dry and vivacious, marked by crisp apple and lime flavors. The finish is zesty, ending on a revitalizing shower of crushed minerals.

This bottling is lively on the nose in touches of caramel, red cherry, Chinese five spice and crème brûlée. The palate is fruit forward in a candied cherry note, but cut by ginger spice and framed in a chalky, tannic structure.

There's quite a bit less of the De Ponte bottling available this vintage, but it's well worth seeking out. Fresh, tight, clean and concentrated, it's packed with raspberry and cherry fruit. The acids prevail over the tannins, which only furthers the pleasure.

More approachable now when compared to some of Penfolds's other top wines, Bin 389 is an almost 50-50 blend of Cabernet and Shiraz. A fireside sipper built to woo big red lovers, the nose is a comforting mix of dark berries, chocolate cake and dusting polish, while the palate is rich but structured, with flavors of plush cherries and dark chocolate nibs. A dusting of spicy tannins marks the close.

Full bodied and rich, this wine is structured and classically aromatic in cedar, pencil and sage brush. The herbal, earthy elements are well developed and seasoned further in toasted oak, black pepper and clove. Cellar through 2034.

This wine is powerful and incredibly rich. Honeyed, musky notes of candied and dried citrus dominate the nose with their lifted headiness. That same intensity envelopes the viscous and concentrated palate. Candied mandarin and peach still have a damask-rose perfume. Drink 2025–2035.

Made from Pommard clone vines planted in 1973 and 1984, this subtle and yet commanding wine fills the palate with lush strawberry jam flavors. It's smooth and textural, and time in barrel has imbued it with just the right touch of mocha.

From a site neighboring Hirsch and Martinelli, this beautifully structured wine is abundantly earthy, savory and spicy in forest floor and cardamom. The blustery spice is contrasted nicely against a wall of crisp, fresh acidity and a finish of black tea.

This wine is an impressive barrel selection of several vineyards across the appellation. It opens with a nose of charcuterie and brined olive, with a palate that is textured and rich in flavors of tarte Tatin and baked mango.

A dried-orange-peel headiness on the nose reveals some development. This orange-peel notion gains more currency on the concentrated palate where a streak of freshness accommodates the slight lick of residual sweetness with ease and charm. Concentrated, layered and intense, it shows what a little bottle age does to Gewurztraminer. Lovely now, it's sure to develop further. Drink now–2028

The nose is rather closed but gives faint notions of waxy honeycomb. The palate is alive with lemon freshness to counter that textural waxiness that creates the backdrop of the palate. This wine has concentation and impact with its lemony power despite the relative slenderness of the body. The finish is dry, long and vivid.
Musty, earthy and taut on the palate, this white is intensely verbose in lemon peel and melon, with a steely character that makes it seem lean.

Dark and inky in color, this 100% varietal wine is thick, dense and simple in approach, with mountain-size tannins. Leather saddle, earth and blackberry dipped in chocolate make up the flavor profile.

This new version is a blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Merlot, 15% Cab Franc and 10% Syrah (replacing last year's Petit Verdot). It's dominated by vanilla, tobacco and tea leaf scents and flavors, making it a potent, serviceable red with immediate impact but little follow-through on the finish.
Subdued aromas suggesting beeswax and citrus come together on this. It's simple, offering hints of apple and lemon alongside bright acidity.

Broad notes of ripe pear also have a hint of bruised apple on the nose. The palate comes in with easy pear notes that lack definition. This wine is easy and dry, with a slightly bitter finish. Drink soon.

This wine is a blend of fruit from Conner Lee (42%), Dionysus (33%), Bacchus (21%) and Stillwater Creek vineyards. Its medicine cabinet, dried cherry, pencil lead and woodspice aromas lead to fruit leather flavors. It seems dried out.

Quite rich on the nose, this bottling from a historic property deep in the appellation shows loads of honeysuckle and gardenia on the nose as well as lemon bar, nectarine, candied apple and a flash of nuts. It lands with ripe power on the palate, carrying hints of mango and pome fruits.

Crisp, cutting white grapefruit and pear flavors lend freshness to this full-bodied but invigorating white. It's silky and expansive on the palate but balanced by zesty acidity and a pleasant rim of astringency on the finish.

Fresh yellow peach and apple flavors are accented with cashew, green plum and lime zest in this dry but intensely fruity Sauvignon Blanc. It's a full-bodied yet zesty wine marked by a fresh, lingering finish.

Dark smoky charred aromas lend a crusty, slightly burnt topping to the nose. In the mouth, this cool-vintage wine is wiry, with magnetic midpalate acidity. Saucy flavors of plum and berry finish savory and tight. Fitting for a 2013, this is never overly ripe. Drink through 2022.

Ripe berry aromas suggest raisin and graphite. A flush palate is full in body and displaying good structure. Roasted berry and plum flavors are meaty in front of a savory finish that tastes of soy sauce and grilled beef. Drink through 2020.

A blend of fruit from Olsen and Kiona vineyards. Brooding dried herb, black cherry and spice aromas are followed by a supple, flavorful palate, bursting with cherry, cedar and plum notes that extend on the finish. This one is all about subtlety and sophistication, and it brings both in abundance.

Black in color, this dense wine has packed tannins from the combination of Touriga Nacional and Cabernet Sauvignon as well as intense dark fruits and a powerful structure. This wine will age further, so drink from 2020.

Ripe blackberry aromas run deep and are supported by earth notes and a hint of buttery pastry. Like most high-end wines from this bodega, this is fully formed and ripe, with correct balance. Savory berry and salty cured-meat flavors finish smooth and with some elegance. Drink through 2026.

Made from equal parts Pinot Noir and Chardonnay, and late-disgorged after seven years en tirage, this is the winery's top-of-the-line bubbly, and it shows. Gorgeous wafts of peach skin tease the nose before dry, layered components of lemon peel, white flower and apple skin shine on the palate, dipped in a strong mineral streak of crushed stone.

The nose is still shy, giving a mere hint of earthy pear but the palate comes alive with juicy fresh ripe,yellow pear. There is a wonderfully poised balance to all of this. There is a fluid medium body and restrained power. All of this gives the impression of understatement since this rounded unobtrusive wine truly delivers with its integral balance and its off-dry finish. Drink until 2028.

A touch of spicy dark fir honey plays about the apple notes on the nose and also makes its dark amber richness felt on the palate amongst baked apple and dried orange peel. The palate is concentrated and dry but keeps this honeyed charm through to the end where it plays with notions of apple, maple syrup and, not least, tangy citrus. Lovely. Drink now through 2028.
designation: Altenberg de Bergheim Vieilles Vignes Grand Cru

description: Ripe red apple flavors have a really zingy lime note about them. The palate shows some pleasant, pithy bitterness and pure lemon freshness tingles on the taut palate. Notes of ripe crunchy apples shimmer all the way to the long, clean and dry finish.

Made from old vines and aged for over four years on its lees, this wine is rich and spicy, with a ripe, smooth and creamy texture. Full and intense with quince and peach flavors, it is ready to drink.
This rich, dry wine is opulent, with an intense spice and mineral texture. It offers ripe quince and green-plum flavors cut with tight acidity. Still a young wine, it needs time. Drink from 2020.

Not at all what most would expect from a Pinot Gris, this wine is rosé in color, has plenty of body despite low alcohol and drinks almost like a Pinot Noir. The watermelon aromas and plummy, earthy flavors accompany a generous texture and nip of tannin. Biodynamic grapes were fermented with native yeast and not filtered.

Toasty blackberry aromas are linear and secure, but fairly basic for quality Malbec. A plump grabby palate is restrained by rubbery tannins, while this tastes of roasted blackberry with a caramel note.

Very cloudy in the glass and exuberant with bubbles, this fun and whimsically labeled bottling from Mission Ranch Vineyard shows crisp apple, poached pear and a slight funkiness on the nose. Ripping acidity frames the wildly effervescent palate, where a steely minerality meets with Asian pear and grapefruit flavors.

Walla Walla Valley white wines remain a rarity, but this blend of 40% Marsanne, 40% Viognier and 20% Roussanne makes a strong case for the category. Vibrant peach, apricot, papaya and mango aromas are followed by a pure, balanced palate with a lingering finish. It shows some pleasing subtleties.

This is a ripe style of wine with tropical fruits and nutmeg spiciness from the fourth matriarchal generation at this site with ancient origins. It is a generous wine, named for a daughter, with its toastiness and perfumes from the unusual 50% Sauvignon Gris in the blend. Drink the wine now.
This wine is still young and shows its wood aging. That will soften, giving the black currant fruits the chance to shine with their stalky edge and light tannins. Drink the wine from 2019.

Firm tannins and strong signs of wood aging mark out this young wine from the Despagne family's flagship property. With intense acidity and black currant fruits, it needs to soften and fill out. Give this structured wine until 2021.
Very ripe, almost sweet fruit flavors pour forth from this full-bodied wine, accented by baking spices like vanilla and cinnamon. It feels very smooth and soft in texture.

Fruity and juicy aromas of ripe blackberry and purple flowers prove lush but with a tang on the nose of this bottling. Candied blackberry, vanilla, sarsaparilla and cigar-box flavors show on the palate.

Simple peach and melon aromas are chunky. Strong acidity cuts through an otherwise plump and melony palate. Short, basic green melon and white pepper flavors lose fruit but not their appeal on the finish.

This wine has a strong new-oak signature easy to detect in the vanilla and cinnamon aromas and the ginger-spice flavors that layer over good red-cherry notes underneath. It is medium to full bodied and highly stylized.

Merlot and Syrah make up the majority of this blend. Aromas of raspberry, plum, blueberry, herb and whiffs of tire rubber are followed by straight down the fairway, quite lightly styled fruit flavors. It's enjoyable but comes off as quite light.
All herbs, citrus and crisp white-peach flavors, this wine bursts with cool fruitiness. Its acidity, light texture and touch of minerality are bright and juicy. Drink now.
This is a fresh blend of four local grapes, giving a bright, crisp texture and great acidity. It is an easy, fruity wine, lightly mineral and packed with juiciness. Drink now.

Something earthy edges the apple notes on the nose. The palate lacks that fruitiness and speaks of more earthiness. The frothy bubbles, however, provide freshness and glimpses of lemon here or there. The finish is dry and clean.

This is all Grenache coming from French Creek Vineyard. Extremely pale in color, looking almost more like a white wine than a rosé, the aromas suggest notes of lees, raspberry and spice, with palate bringing more of the same. It doesn't all seem to come together.

A good 15% Cabernet Sauvignon is blended within this wine, as well as 4% each of Malbec and Petit Verdot. Impressive, it offers rich notions of dark chocolate and graham cracker that present as round and richly soft. A bright streak of acidity contrasts well, refreshing the palate under cover of creamy oak.

This impressive wine is full of black fruits as well as dark tannins. Its structure and density comes from the vineyard that abuts grand cru estates in Saint-Julien. The wine has power while as well as the elegance of the appellation. Drink from 2023.

This is a tiny production wine well worth seeking, savory in forest floor, black tea, sage and mushroom, with a soft, round midpalate that presents as equal parts silky and velvety. Exotic and earthy, it has integrated barrel presence and tamed tannins, with a succulent finish of baking spice.

Succulent in brambly cherry and berry with an effusive, taut and persistent thread of acidity, this is a lovely, memorable vineyard-designated wine, coastal in its bright embrace of freshness and delicate layering. Additional elements of forest floor and black tea provide a nice contrast to the fruit.

This is a gorgeously perfumed wine, wafting of sandalwood, violet and fleshy black plums. It's pliant and round, chock-full of luscious blueberry and blackberry flavors. Chalky, persistent tannins and a hint of crushed earth persist on the finish. Enjoyable now but should drink well through 2026.

There's a delicate blue floral note that persists from nose to finish here, accenting fleshy but pure black plum and berry flavors. It's a smoothly polished, decadent wine fringed by supple, baby-soft tannins. Ready to drink now but concentrated enough to improve through 2028.
This wine's green herb, black cherry, cedar box and woodspice aromas lead to dry fruit flavors with a tart, medicinal finish. It seems slightly dried out.
This wine has a deep well of black fruit flavors and a smooth, slightly tannic texture. Blackberry, cherry and a touch of black pepper flood the palate. This is softly balanced and easy to enjoy.

This everyday Garnacha is racy and energetic, with spicy, leathery raspberry, strawberry and plum aromas. It's brighter on the palate, offering juicy plum and raspberry flavors that linger on the lively finish.
This pale-colored blend of 57% Cinsault and 43% Counoise offers light aromas of raspberry, plum and spice. The flavors are elegant but finish tart.
Fresh and light, this is a delicate wine, light pink in color, showing subtle raspberry aromas, subdued cherry flavors and good acidity that keeps it lively on the palate.
This is a gritty, grippy wine, tannic and showing a touch of herbal underbelly, with a strong sense of sweet compost and mushroomy earth.

Whiffs of cherry blossom, sour cherry and raspberry introduce this pale-pink rosé. Moderately concentrated on the palate, it offers delicate wild strawberry and red currant tones intensified by a clean, mineral backbone. A full-bodied yet refreshing wine to enjoy now.

There are plenty of bright red fruits and secondary earthy complexities, but at the moment the oak overpowers, cloaking the wine in rather soapy toasty and cedar notes. The palate is elegant and restrained, certainly set up for the long haul, this needs time in the cellar for things to settle. Drink 2020–2026.
A light electric pink, the aromas bring notes of watermelon bubblegum, cherry and strawberry. It drinks dry with medium-bodied slightly fat-feeling fruit flavors, with grapefruit notes on the finish.
designation: Beyond the Pale Boushey Vineyard Syrah

description: Rounded and creamy with a touch of citrus, this floral aromatic wine is simple in its approachable layering of lemon zest and tropical pineapple. The oak is supportive and spicy in vanilla bean and nutmeg.

Pale gold in color, ripe tropical and stone fruits, along with bruised apple and guava, white pepper and a smattering of snow peas can be coaxed from the glass after some swirling. The palate is medium bodied and oily in texture, but there is enough acid—along with lemon and herbal flavors—to keep things bright.

This bottling, part of the winery's series dedicated to its labor crew, is a fresh herbally laced take on Cab, with peppercorns, asphalt, smoke and earth decorating the tangy black-plum aromas on the nose. Red cherry and plum start the sip, followed by crushed gravel, more smoke and dried herbs.

Almost spicy notes of pear tingle on the fresh, aromatic nose. On the palate the brilliance of the pear is accentuated even more with vivid citrus zestiness. The palate remains dry and fresh, while the concentrated body has drive, energy and enduring, almost bracing freshness and wonderful length.

Made in homage to Côtes du Rhône, combining 94% Syrah and 6% Viognier, this opens in lavender, violet and garrigue, inviting and smooth. The velvety texture continues, with a spicy savory edginess of white pepper, blackberry and cured meat.

Golden Mirabelle plums and apricots are evoked on the aromatic nose. The palate reprises these ripe notions with added lemon verve. Concentrated, dry, aromatic and long, the body reveals notions of riper citrus among the stone fruit. The flavors last and last.

A relatively light color leads to spicy aromas, a firm gripping texture and very tasty, complex but restrained flavors including red cherry, cardamom and beef tartare. The wine has great balance due to firm tannins and good acidity, and tastes incredibly fresh and appetizing.

Fresh aromas of framboise, hibiscus and rose petals make for a very lively and floral nose on this bottling. The palate is also alive and vibrant with flavors of red-currant sorbet, yet mint and tarragon hold that fruity aspect at bay enough to add intrigue.

This blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Franc from Boushey and Champoux vineyards is bouyantly aromatic, with dark raspberry, leafy herb, cocoa powder and incense notes. On the palate, it's flavorful yet light-footed and exquisitely balanced. Thoroughly captivating.

This powerful wine is richly perfumed and richly structured. Its dark tannins and firm texture are enhanced by wood-aged flavors of the ripe Touriga Nacional. The wine needs further aging. Don't drink before 2021.

This is a thick, dense and structured wine sourced from the Bismark Vineyard high atop the appellation. Juicy and soft, it has substantial tannins up front that resolve and mellow in the glass. Black currant, earthy sage and dried herb hint at its mountainous provenance and higher elevation.

This Tempranillo Mexicano is a wide load, starting with its earthy, stewy black fruit aromas. The palate is scratchy, with full-size, abrasive tannins. Loud peppery blackberry and chocolate flavors finish with a fiery burn and strong black coffee and charred beef notes. Drink through 2024.

Dense boysenberry, black plum and dried teriyaki meet with savory notes of soy and teriyaki on the nose of this bottling. Roasted black-plum flavors show on the smoky sip, which is enhanced by roasted lamb and complex rosemary notes. The tannins are still stiff and young, but this will drink well until at least 2025.

Fermented in stainless steel and aged on the lees for a month, this leads with compelling aromas of sweet herb, melon, citrus, and tropical fruit. The sleek palate bursts with fruit flavors, framed by lively acidity.
Fermented and aged in stainless steel, this offers apple, pear, straw and lees aromas followed by full-feeling, textured fruit flavors with captivating purity. A warm finish caps it off.

Brimming with a sweetness of baked cherry and molasses, this is a soft, rounded and robustly ripe wine that carries its weight well. A touch of structured, high-toned acidity complements the power and outer reaches of excess, allowing the experience on the palate to speak.

This is an estate-grown combination of half Cabernet Sauvignon with 40% Petite Sirah and 10% Merlot. It offers moderation and grace within its juicy core of muted black fruit, cedar and gamy meat seasoned in black pepper.

Bursting in black cherry and a light thread of cola spice, this is from a single block of one site, planted all to Pommard clone. Tree bark and black tea provide seasoning to a soft and lengthy palate of exuberance.

Aromas of Spanish broom, Mediterranean brush, citrus zest and a subtle whiff of oak slowly take shape. On the palate, bright acidity frames ripe lemon, golden apple, coffee bean and minerality. This is a serious white made to be paired with savory first courses as opposed to a simple aperitif.

This delicate, low key sparkler is a blend of three different clones of Chardonnay. The variety shows its many colors with subtle fig, white spice and tropical fruit notes. The palate is creamy but balanced by fine bubbles and crisp acidity.

Hearty and full bodied, this wine is loaded with blackberry, dark chocolate and beef flavors and structured with moderate tannins and a rich mouthfeel. Blended from Zinfandel, Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec, it has good concentration, ripeness and length, and it's easy to enjoy.

A touch of Turkish delight flashes across the nose before ripe bottled peach takes over. On the palate, the peach reigns supreme with its juicy, generous and aromatic sweetness. The finish is off dry, a little warm but also tempered with a streaky tinge of tangy lemon freshness that makes you want to sip more.

A gentle hue of russet pear peel on the nose starts to unfold on the palate. The juiciness and the purity of ripe pear flesh become apparent against a background that owes as much to phenolic texture as to concentrated freshness. These elements are well placed to counter the alcoholic warmth. This is rather powerful but also very well balanced with a dry and sustained finish. Lovely now but with the stuffing to evolve. Drink until 2028.

An almost perfumed hint of hedgerow fruit precedes the richer notes of ripe apple on the nose. This is followed by lovely yeasty hints of autolysis. On the palate, these notions combine in a most convincing joyful fashion. Every tiny bubble that bursts brings some of that rounded, fruity but ultimately fresh vividness. This comes with serious intent but an even greater proportion of charm.

The mellowness of ripe yellow apples is apparent immediately, as is the creamy yeasty depth of autolysis. The palate brims with notes of wet chalk and baked apple and a combination of freshness and richness that is compelling. This is a demi-sec and with its subtle sweet-sour balance, this finds its place with fruity desserts, cheese and Asian, hot spice. These flavors will benefit most from this wine's inherent off-dry balance.

Concentrated morello cherry, packed flower petals, turned soil, light pepper and concentrated watermelon aromas make for an exotic nose on this bottling from Alta Colina Vineyard. Chalky tannins make for a grippy, somewhat sticky entry to the palate, where black-plum and wild animal flavors arise.

The nose is subtle with hints of green pear, but a zesty edge of lemon already suggests concentration and power. The palate follows suit with a wonderful textured where ripe pear notes are boosted by just a touch of residual sweetness. But it is both alcoholic heat and concentrated lemon zestiness that provide structure and convey a sense of power. This is a full-bodied white coming into its own now. Drink now through 2028.
Seared apple, lemonade and lemon-blossom candies show on the steely nose of this fresh twist-top bottling. Tangy orange rinds meet with broad Pink Lady apple flavors on the palate.

A savory nose offers violets and herbes de Provence mingled with vanilla, black currant and wild blackberry. The palate is smooth in feel, with sandy tannins and bright acidity housing flavors of tart cranberry and raspberry alongside vanilla, tobacco leaf and cinnamon. Black plum and leather tones linger on the grippy, tannic finish.
This fat, toasty wine shows touches of spice as well as ripeness. Apricot and peach flavors are just balanced with acidity. Drink now.

Raspberry and cherry aromas suggest red fruit soda. In the mouth, this basic rosé is plump and that's about it. Raspberry, plum and cherry flavors are easygoing, while this stays in the red fruit realm on a generic finish.

Leafy berry and herbal aromas are mulchy and suggest olive. This is medium in depth and cushion, with drying tannins. Smacking plum, tomato and herbal flavors finish hard. The 2013 vintage was a cool one in Chile, and this Carmenère has only moderate ripeness. Drink now.
The nose of this bottling is quite shy, offering hints of black cherry, dark berry and loam with patience. The palate shows simple berry and earth flavors, with a touch of tannic tension.
Fernão Pires and Arinto have produced this floral, perfumed wine that also has crisp citrus and green-apple flavors. A refreshing wine, it's lively, bright and ready to drink.
Fruity with just a touch of spice, this berry-flavored wine also has a good edge of tannin from the Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. Its juicy aftertaste is perfumed and attractively ready to drink.
Light and bright, this wine has delicious lemon flavors enhanced by ripe tastes of apples and juicy green plums. Both crisp and ripe, it's ready to drink.
Floral and characterized by bold stone-fruit flavors, this wine is spritzy in acidity, with a nutty herbal imprint of anise.

Light aromas of soil, dried herb, dried cranberry, licorice, barrel and cherry are followed by anise and cranberry-filled flavors that trail on the finish. It doesn't all seem to come together, with the structure seeming lacking.

This has a shy nose that eventually reveals suggestions of red berry, blue flower and a whiff of dark spice. On the taut, no-frills palate, racy acidity accompanies sour cherry, raw cranberry and powdered sage alongside grainy tannins that leave a dusty, drying finish.

Shy on the nose, this wine opens into beautifully ripe, aromatic pear notes on the palate. It's slender in body, with a juicy and fresh nature resulting from a lovely streak of lemon at its core. The finish is refreshing and dry.
A great value, this wine offers perfumed oak and notes of jasmine and white flowers. Salty caramel pretzel flavors accentuate a bigger, bolder take on fruit-forward freshness and voluptuous texture.

The crushed sage and lemon notes that mark the nose of this wine attain a far riper aspect on the palate. Yellow Mirabelle plum flavors fill the mouth, rounded by yeasty richness and framed by lemon freshness.

This bottling of an obscure grape originally from France shows crushed violets and tart boysenberry on the nose. Best served with a slight chill, it packs black plum skin, potpourri and marjoram flavors onto the palate. It is both refreshing and satisfying.

Lush and expansive, with moderate oak and acidity, this is a big, bolder style of white, mineral in stone and rock, with exotic fruit flavors of apple and pineapple. A trace of green olive lingers on the succulent finish.
designation: Three Sisters Unfiltered Don Miguel Vineyard

description: This combines fruit from Bennett Valley as well as several vineyard designates within the producer's portfolio. Bay leaf, eucalyptus and cool-climate tart red fruit accentuate the crisp focused acidity.

This rich, smoky wine has layers of wood to contrast with rich black-plum flavors. It comes from one of the line of premier cru vineyards on the steep slope right behind the village of Gevrey-Chambertin, Structured and firm now, with the classic weight of the appellation, the wine will take its time. Drink from 2023.

Hints of smoked nut, licorice and wild herb accent sumptuously ripe black plum and wild strawberry flavors here. The midpalate is fleshy and forward, cushioned by delicate acidity and fine, velvet tannins. Its open-knit demeanor is welcoming now but should drink well through 2026.

A full, heavy nose includes graphite, plenty of herbal essence and inky black fruit aromas. On the palate, this Cabernet is rich, thick and saturated. Chocolaty blackberry and cassis flavors come with a strong herbal element, while this maintains chocolaty oak and ripeness on a beefy finish. Drink through 2022.

Delicate scents of field flower, warm bread crust and a whiff of orchard fruit come together in this elegant sparkler. The bright, silky palate offers sour cherry, pear and tangerine zest alongside tangy acidity and a vibrant, refined perlage.

Made entirely with native grape Corvinone, this lovely sparkler opens with aromas of wild rose, red berry and a whiff of bread dough. The savory, excellent palate doles out red cherry, pomegranate, dried herb and a hint of hazelnut. Bright acidity and a refined, elegant perlage provide the backdrop.

From New Zealand's Chardonnay expert, this offers a smokey and briny nose marked by salted nuts and grilled stone fruit. These tones glide to the effortlessly silky, smooth palate, threaded by stoney minerality, pristine acidity and a lengthy tangy, savory finish. Drink now—2024.
This wine's subtle white flower and orchard fruit scents float out of the glass. On the juicy, rounded palate, a bitter almond note underscores yellow pear and ripe apple flavors.

The smoky nose shows aromas of black pepper, tobacco and leather. Ample acidity on the palate is highlighted by juicy blue fruit flavors, alongside green tobacco leaf, black pepper and wood smoke with spicy, gritty tannins. This finishes on strong notes of leather over cranberry and smoked pepper.
winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey

description: This wine is simple in structure and ample in density. It is full bodied and plush on the palate in black cherry, berry and a richness of vanilla wafer.

Very dark in the glass but not thick, this bottling shows roasted black plum, coffee and charred vanilla bean on the nose. The palate is layered with that vanilla flavor and cut by a slow-rising acidity, offering flavors of tangy blackberry and espresso on the finish.

It introduces itself with a hint of passion fruit, a touch of grass. While the nose just teases, the palate gives bright lemon freshness and juicy yellow plum. This is bright, light, dry, fruit-driven and refreshing.
This wine's yellow spring flower, citrus and ripe orchard fruit aromas carry over to the tangy palate, along with a juicy hint of tangerine. A pleasantly bitter almond note signals the close.
Ripe pear and wet river rocks show on the clean nose of this bottling, which invites with the fruit and then intrigues with the minerality. It's a bit ripe on the palate, with poached pear flavors.
This offers the fresh apple and pineapple aromas typical of Albariño. Its high acidity creates tart, lemony flavors that lack body. A sharp finish confirms the wine's pointy profile.

This wine's light tint and equally light tropical fruit, lychee and gardenia aromas suggest Moscatel, but it's 100% Verdosilla, a white grape native to Valencia. The palate is lean but fresh, with briny citrus and salty melon flavors that don't break down on the finish.

This Tempranillo Blanco offers candied melon and lime aromas. On the palate, it has the consistency of apple juice and tastes of Bartlett pear with a hint of salt. Ultimately, it's a good but average wine little character and a dilute finish.

Aromas of underripe elderberry, black currant, sweet smoke and chocolate cake make for an intriguing (if unfamiliar) nose on this bottling from a new producer in Atascadero. Ripe flavors of prune ice cream, figs and raisins show on the sip, which shows decent acid and texture.
This reserve lacks the depth and ripeness needed to carry its dark, toasty barrel flavors. The wood dominates, and as a result, the fruit flavors thin out quickly.

The pear fruit on the nose is not only super ripe but downright honeyed and edged with smokiness. The palate is resolutely dry but holds baking spice, appealingly bitter phenolics and lots of frshness. The result is a full-bodied white with fruit, power and texture. Smoky oak makes itself most felt on the finish. Drink now–2025.

Though this multi-vineyard is blend priced below the winery's vineyard designates, it was given the same exacting care. A substantial wine, it's lush with blackberry, black cherry, lemon peel and orange blossom scents and flavors. Barrel aging has added clove and other spice notes. A stylish effort that outperforms its price.

With a woody nose of toasted oak and dried herb, this impressive wine is structured and bright, with fresh cassis and red cherry. Balanced and well integrated, it shows depth of flavor and complexity.

Toasty aromas of road tar, tea and baking spices accent this wine's blackberry and oak scents. The palate is plush—rich with fruit but just short of syrupy. Its baked berry, plum and spice flavors lead to a ripe, slightly hot finish. Drink now–2027.

Very ripe notions of juicy pear and wet earth combine on the nose. The dry palate is linear with citrus freshness and rich with pear fruit. This has concentration, body and length, always shimmering with ripe pear. The finish is dry and long.

Fermented in neutral French oak, this is a big, spicy and polished rosé. Bright strawberry and cherry fruit is in abundance, dotted with cinnamon spice. It's a full-flavored, full-bodied tour de force, giving rare muscle to a category mostly devoted to light, simple summer sippers.
Aromas of eucalyptus, exotic spice, underbrush and aromatic herb lead the nose. The tightly knit palate offers cranberry, dried cherry, star anise and clove set against taut, close-grained tannins.

This is the standard nonvintage cuvée from this Aube-based producer. With two years bottle age before release, it is still fresh but with smooth fruits that show some maturity. Apples and citrus come well together along with a well-balanced aftertaste. Drink this bottling now.

Tight-grained tannins and oak define this wine's powerful concentration and the heartiness of the vintage. Flavors of black plum, blackberry and leather give it fruit-forward complexity but are held in check by the wines inherent structure.

This smoothly textured, cherry-flavored wine is rich and gently tannic. Ripe fruits partner with a good layer of acidity. It has a crisp edge along with spice from wood aging. The wine is just ready to drink, still fruity, ripe and fleshy.

This wine starts with plush aromas of yellow melon, plumeria, wild lime sorbet and a hint of cream. There is ample zip to the palate, where acidity and a strong floral character keep the honeydew and white peach flavors in check.

Made from 93% Pinot Noir and 7% Pinot Meunier, this is a lovely sparkling wine, rounded and layered with moderate acidity. The flavors dance around aspects of wild strawberry, raspberry and melon, with a lasting tease of hazelnut.

The mother-daughter team behind this wine and the new Petaluma Gap appellation showcases the brawny, boisterous nature of the site, coaxing lush layers of blueberry and black cherry from its thick extracted layers of polished tannin and underlying bolts of acidity.

Achingly pure plum, red fruit, game, black pepper and fresh green herb aromas are followed by textured, seamless red and black fruit flavors in this wine. The finish is long and redolent of cranberries. It's riper than the norm for this winery, but so was the vintage it comes from.

Clean lines of Meyer lemon, hazelnut and vanilla are framed by a smoky oak touch on this first ever Chardonnay from this winery. The wood flavors show prominently on the sip, which offers toast with lime preserves and a hint of forest spice.

Cab lovers will rejoice at the affordability of this tasty, finessed expression of the grape. On the nose, the black currant fruit is on the raisiny side. Notes of licorice, warm stones, dark chocolate, smoke and a stalky, leafiness also abound. The medium-bodied palate is dense yet juicy, with easy-going black fruits and a broody, old book quality, backed by a spine of fine tannins.

This pioneering vineyard still holds vines planted in 1965 by the original owner, Charles Coury. The Coury clone, along with Wadenswil and Pommard from the same era, combine gracefully in this lush, spicy wine. Its tart berry fruit is balanced by firm acidity and generous barrel flavors of toast and buttered nuts. This is a fine value for a rare old-vine Pinot Noir.

This is a hugely tannic, thick and extracted wine that bears further time in the cellar. Within its powerful frame lie layers of leather, tobacco, black currant and dried herb that show richness and power. Enjoy 2024–2034.

A heady lemon marmalade streak on the nose has edges of honeysuckle blossom. The palate sweeps these aromatic notions up in its medium-sweet wake of ripe juicy peach. An edge of lemon and pleasant peach-skin bitterness sets a lovely counterpoint. It is on the finish that the lemon streak triumphs with a final flourish.

Fruit for this wine comes from the winery's vineyard in the foothills of the Blue Mountains. The aromas pop, with notes of nori, black pepper, sea breeze, parsley, black olive tapenade, fresh flower, herb and wet stone, revealing more complexity on each swirl. Smoked meat aromas emerge over time. The palate is elegant yet richly flavorful, with an extremely long, smoked meat finish. This one is all about delicacy and finesse but it brings both in abundance.
designation: In the Hills Estate Foothills in the Sun Vineyard

description: Cola and racy red-fruit aromas are classic Uco Valley. A fresh, zesty palate is a touch choppy, but this Malbec's deep and impressive licorice, spice, espresso and berry flavors carry the show. A fresh finish is full of blasting energy, so no need to rush this. Drink through 2028.

Imagine tobacco, loamy earth and rhubarb mixed together to get a picture of the complexity and different-ness of this beautifully balanced Rhône-style wine. It feels medium bodied and moderately tannic on the palate as the flavors unfold slowly, releasing hints of new leather, sour cherries and mushrooms.

Subtle savory flavors like herbs and mushrooms and consommé meet mellow fruit flavors of Bosc pear and yellow plum in this full-bodied and lushly textured wine. It has a broad mouth-filling presence, and flavors that are at once rich but also show some restraint that encourages more sipping. Save until at least 2021 for an extra treat.

Smoky hints of both ripe and dried pear have a honeyed edge. The palate comes in with that same honeyed sweetness on a rather concentrated powerful palate. Both lemon notes and lovely phenolic grip give structure. The finish is medium sweet and long.

There's a roundness to the nose and mouth of this wine, formed through abundant waves of ripe green melon, peach flesh and white cherry. Ample acidity keeps the medium-weight mouthfeel in check, with final flavors of green banana, citrus oil and melon rind.

This wine is ripe and jammy upfront, with forward aromas of a baked berry crumble, cherry pie filling and vanilla pod. Smooth and easy on the palate, it boasts just enough tannic structure and acidity to lift the plush, decadent fruit flavors.
designation: Pyrène L'inimitable Pays de Cocagne Merlot-Tannat-Syrah

description: Raspberry jam, rose hip and spice aromas are followed by light juicy fruit flavors that finish warm. It doesn't all come together but it still provides enjoyment.

This wine is about two-thirds Cabernet Sauvignon, with the rest Cabernet Franc, Merlot, Syrah and Malbec. Aromas of blueberry, herb, plum, green pepper and spice lead to soft lighter-styled fruit flavors with slightly grainy tannins. The concentration seems quite light.
Lighter styled aromas of peach, apricot and whiffs of lime are followed by sweet, rich stone-fruit flavors. It leans a bit too much on the sugar for its appeal but it still delivers plenty of it.
Right away this is funky on the nose, with briny aromas and a sense of resiny wood. A briny palate is texturally thick, while this tastes of brined citrus and savory notes.

A highly herbal, varietally specific nose contains aromas of olive, eucalyptus, mint and clove. A needly palate is tight, snappy and alert. Roasted, spicy berry flavors dry out on a bold finish with mild burn.
Effusive aromas of freshly peeled orange, floral soap and lychee are followed by just off-dry, slightly oily feeling fruit flavors. It's equal parts intrigue and delivery.
Made from 61% Sangiovese and 39% Cabernet Sauvignon, this is earthy and tannic, with a dry, leathery composition of oaky black pepper and dried cherry.

This is an unusual blend of Grenache, Syrah and Cinsault mixed with Merlot, Marselan, Caladoc and other grapes. It's an intensely rich, fleshy wine with fruit character that's almost pulpy in ripeness. Ripe but persistent tannins lend structure to the finish. Drink now–2023.
Baked red-cherry, vanilla, baking-spice and turned earth aromas show on the nose of this bottling. Strong herbs, from oregano to thyme, show on the sip, alongside tangy red fruit flavors.
The nose is quite shy, but the palate reveals sour cherry, pink grapefruit and white pepper alongside racy acidity. Brisk bubbles provide a lively backdrop.

Based in Pouilly-sur-Loire, this producer also makes wines from across the river in Sancerre. Ripe and rich, this wine is as much bringing out apple and citrus as more herbal flavors. The wine is ready to drink.
This light copper-colored wine is crisp, almost steely, light-bodied and refreshing. It is bone dry, extremely appetizing, and offers lean raspberry flavors backed by good acidity.

Complex aromas, concentrated fruit flavors and a firm structure add up to a very good full-bodied wine. It offers cinnamon and ginger aromas, adds superripe black cherries on the palate and has a lingering, baking-spice finish.

Pressed wild flower, crushed flint and ripe white stone-fruit aromas delicately come together on this medium-bodied white. Ripe and savory, the fresh enveloping palate doles out mature yellow pear, apple and juicy citrus while a hint of bitter almond signals the close.

This is a robustly tannic and powerful wine, its entry laced in peppercorn and crushed rock-like dust. Pencil shavings, dried herb, cedar and clove continue on the savory theme. An underlying earthiness barely tames the cassis-like fruit.

From the producer's home site, this wine opens with a tobacco-laden nose, leading to a palate with moderate structure and plenty of grip. Savory in character, this is defined by tones of dried herb, cassis and toasted oak.

This wine has the power associated with this appellation, giving richness even while it is still so young. Its weight, spice and acidity are there, packed into a tight parcel that will need to age. Drink this powerful, toasty wine from 2022.

Earth and sandalwood greet the nose in this soft, velvety and textured wine that's made in an expansive, succulent style. It is effusive in fruit, a mélange of blueberry and black cherry flavors, with a bright refreshment of blood orange and tart pomegranate.

Rose petals, cranberry and dust show on the nose of this bottling, which grows more intense on the nose as it sits open, offering riper fruit. Dried sagebrush and baked earth flavors show on the sip as the red fruit and floral components arise with grace.

Plum, black cherry and raspberry meet with cardamom, tomato and slate on the dynamic nose of this bottling. It's fresh and taut on the palate, with more raspberry, a hint of charcoal and caramel flakes on the finish. Tightly wound tannins will unfurl with patience. Drink 2020–2035.

This is a classic wine from the appellation, bright, lush and spicy in cola and cardamom. Full bodied and velvety smooth, it offers dense layers of strawberry, raspberry and blood orange with a wealth of rich toasted oak and brioche.

One of the wines that put Lambrusco back on the map, this vibrant, linear wine boasts aromas of wild strawberry, violet, red cherry and grapefruit. The aromas carry through to the slightly sparkling, savory palate along with cinnamon and white pepper notes. Crisp acidity lifts the savory finish.
This rich wine, the classic blend of Grenache, Syrah and Cinsault, is ripe and smoothly fruity, with a bright touch of acidity that gives the wine its great lift. It is ready to drink.
This full, rich wine emphasizes ripe berry fruits rather than crispness. That makes for a wine that is warm, intensely fruity, soft on the palate and ready to drink now.
Smooth and ripe, this rounded wine has a rich character as well as crisper acidity. It is softly textured, full of great fruit and ready to drink.

This crisp, light wine is a blend of 90% of the local Rolle and 10% Ugni Blanc. It has attractive acidity, plus plenty of apple and citrus fruits with a zesty lemon-peel edge. This bright wine is ready to drink now.

Tangy and mineral driven, this bright, crisp and fruity wine holds 70% Sémillon. Its texture is dominant at this stage, emphasizing a herbal character and intense acidity needs to soften. Wait for this Dulon family wine until the end of 2018.

This refreshing, bright wine from the Rochet family is full of acidity and delicious apple and spice flavors. Its balance is just right, hinting at an herbal edge while preserving the pure direct of fruitiness. Drink now.

Serious ripeness and juiciness stand out in this deep-colored medium-bodied wine grown at high elevation. It smells earthy and lightly oaky, and tastes very fruity and generous, flooding the palate with jammy blackberry and black cherry flavors.

This medium- to full-bodied wine offers ripe, almost candied, fruit notes of watermelon, strawberry and rhubarb, along with warming vanilla, chocolate and black olive characters. The ripe, juicy fruit leads the way on the palate, while sinewy tannins and a savory, olivey finish keep things interesting. Drink now–2028.

Sourced from the oldest vines of the estate's La Bohème vineyard, this lush sparkler is made from 100% Pinot Noir. Its pretty strawberry shade matches the scents and flavors. With exceptional concentration and elegance, it seemingly gathers strength through its long, flavorful finish.
designation: La Bohème Estate Grown Brut Rosé

description: Made with organically grown Sangiovese, this offers enticing aromas of iris, wild berry and new leather. The bright palate doles out black cherry, white pepper, clove and a touch of thyme alongside fine-grained tannins. It's balanced, with fresh acidity. Enjoy through 2024.

This mineral-textured wine tastes of wood aging, rich lees stirring and toastiness. Ripe yellow and quince flavors are developing well, but this is a wine for further aging. Its acidity and crisper side show at the end. Drink from 2019.

Under the same ownership as Château Haut-Selve of Bordeaux, this estate produces a structured Madiran. It's a richly perfumed wine, showing great tannins as well as generous, juicy black fruits and acidity. It will be ready to drink from 2020.

Blending 42% Cabernet Sauvignon, 19% Malbec, 19% Merlot, 14% Cabernet Franc and 6% Petit Verdot, this is an elegant, structured red, elongated by silky tannins. Cedar, sage, red currant and turned earth provide an understated savory personality.

Forest floor, plum, baking spice and incense aromas lift out of the glass. It's concentrated, chewy and brooding, doling out blackberry jam, star anise and crushed mint framed in firm, close-grained tannins. Drink after 2024.

The Knudsen vineyard is the source of this reserve-level release. It's toasty and thick with tree fruits. There's a viscous, almost oily quality to the wine, which is long on flavor, though a bit uniform throughout.

This soft, smooth estate wine is forward in tart red fruit, supported by pillowy tannins and well-balanced acidity. There are welcome flavors of cherry and strawberry that flirt with pomegranate and rhubarb.
Silky, sanguine and tart, this wine is defined by tones of strawberry, rhubarb and citrus. It is a delicate, lightly textured wine that holds its ripeness well and has a lingering spice note.
This wine offers expressive tones of strawberry, leather and jam, with a full-bodied, rich approach. A creamy, velvety quality unfolds on the palate, supported by brawny tannins.

Ripe and rich aromas of black plum are cut by savory, gamy and peppery qualities on the nose of this complex Syrah. The cohesive palate is quite delicious, showing roasted plums, pepper-crusted beef and touches of oregano, marjoram and rosemary. Acid keeps it lively.

The nose of this wine is loaded with mocha, coffee and raisinated fruit notes. The palate offers dark, chocolaty flavors of toasted blackberry and oak, framed by ripe tannins. That oaky chocolate flavor carries over to the ripe, slightly hot finish. Drink through 2028.

This has a pretty floral nose, a delicate aspect that is in contrast with the thick integrated tannin and depth of baked cherry tart, caramel and oak. Black pepper and dried herb season the full-bodied density well.

Great concentration, full body and an almost thick texture make a big statement in this no-holds-barred wine that was barrel-fermented in old barrels that don't add oaky flavors. It smells like honey, cream and vanilla, tastes nutty and buttery and coats the palate with a richness that continues to linger even after the last sip.

Creamy and lush, with warmth of baked pear and fig, this wine fully embraces a ripe fleshy style and does it justice. Supportive, integrated oak adds to the full-bodied voluptuousness as jolts of acidity settle things down and make the wine complex in underlying freshness.

This is the top Champagne from this cooperative brand. Based in the Marne Valley, the producer specializes in Pinot Meunier, as shown in this half-and-half blend with Chardonnay. It is a ripe, generous and warm wine that keeps a tight texture and is now showing hints of yeasty maturity. Drink now.

A heavy use of oak pervades this full-bodied wine from the aroma through the finish. It starts with an aroma of freshly cut boards, moves to tight astringent oak and cherry flavors on the palate, and finishes with a lingering ginger and nutmeg spice effect.
This wine's gamy blackberry and raisin aromas struggle to hold up. The palate is astringently acidic, with coconut- and vanilla-laden plum and berry flavors. Those oak accents preside on the finish.
This opens with subtle scents suggesting yellow field flower and yellow stone fruit while the fresh light-bodied palate offers golden apple and tangy tangerine. It's simple but well made.

Cabernet Sauvignon makes up three-quarters of this wine, with the balance Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Its mocha, green herb, blackberry, medicine cabinet and anise aromas lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that have a lightly creamy feel. It seems evolved for its age.

This blend of 60% Merseguera, 20% Sauvignon Blanc and 20% Verdejo features pleasant floral aromas and a racy palate with some inherent creaminess. Its briny citrus, lime and salt flavors don't waver on the finish.

This wine's berry aromas come with strong notes of tobacco and mint. Its tight, drawn palate holds spicy, herbal red plum and cherry flavors. Spicy oak and minty green flavors are more prominent than fruit on the finish.

Lightly herbal and floral aromas of wild flowers, thyme and sage lend complexity and interest to an otherwise berry fruit nose. This is fresh but a bit edgy in feel, seemingly a combination of its Altamira origins and a cool 2016 vintage. Berry fruit flavors are bright and touched up with chocolaty oak, while this is sturdy, spicy and complete on a juicy finish. Drink through 2025.

Lime marmalade and fresh lime zest immediately rise from the glass. These citrus notions become even more concentrated on the palate where their zing finds lovely expression and keeps on tingling. This has quite some power and is taut and bold with all of its lime freshness and its dry finish.

This powerful, rich wine is produced from a vineyard and cellar selection. It's full of impressive tannins and black fruits, with strong flavors of wood aging. Ripe berries are enhanced by spice and a big structure cut with acidity. Drink from 2023.

Intriguing whiffs of smoke, chestnut shells and anise lend savory nuances to ripe black cherry and berry in this wine. Rich and juicy yet elegantly framed, it's structured by fine, persistent tannins and moderate but fresh acidity. Earthen tones and a hint of vanilla linger on the finish. Lovely now it should improve through 2025 and hold further.

The nose suggests embalmed fruit preserved in citrus oil. There are notions of quince, apple and lemon oil. The palate has attained a balm-like viscosity but stays absolutely dry, showcasing the chalky texture and the exquisite purity of apple and lemon. The finish is a triumph of lively, ripe and wonderfully spiky citrus. Drink now through 2028.

Now approaching maturity while still packed with black fruits, this is a rich, dense wine from David Ebert, a Chicago architect who found the property while cycling Madiran's southern boundary. Its tannins are dusty, as ripe as the juicy black-plum fruits and spice. Perfumed and concentrated, it's ready to drink now or keep until 2020.

The vivid, lively lemon zest notes on the nose of this wine stay on course throughout the juicy, concentrated palate. The body is light, dry and very zesty. A lovely summer wine with verve and tons of lemon flavor.

Roasted red-cherry and wet gravel aromas show on the nose of this bottling from the Jespersen Ranch. The palate is soft and mellow, framed by strong acidity and displaying tightly woven tones of red fruits and chaparral spice. It's mouthwatering into the finish.

A peppery hint of ripe, red cherry entices on the subtle, understated nose of this wine. That pepper note spices everything on the translucent, honest, fresh-faced palate. Between gentle grip and mouthwatering freshness, there's tons of straightforward pleasure here.
Mouthwatering and crisp, this medium-bodied wine has bright aromas of kiwi and citrus. It's fresh and vibrant in character, backed by a tangy underscore.
Aromas of grapefruit, tomato vine and a whiff of exotic fruit lead the nose. The tangy palate offers passion fruit, green apple and white peach alongside bright acidity.

This is a compelling wine at a good price point, showing warm aromas of hazelnut and baked bread along with fresh sprays of orange zest and honeysuckle. Toast and blanched almond flavors on the palate are lifted by citrus zest and gardenia.

Lean rubbery berry aromas are raw and pinched, with a hint of vinegar. This Rioja from an average vintage smacks hard with juicy acidity. Standard berry flavors are short and basic, while this is wiry on the finish.

High-toned cherry and plum aromas are aggressive, as is a lean palate. Plum and cranberry flavors are firmly in the red, while this Garnacha offers side notes of peppery spice. This is juicy and spunky more than dark and heavy.
A blend of many of the Douro white grapes, this wine is rounded and crisp while also ripe. It has attractive green fruits, mineral-driven acidity and a lively aftertaste. Drink now.
The aromas offer notes of fresh flower and canned peach, with lightly styled flavors that follow. The concentration at times seems a bit light. Still, it delivers plenty of easy-drinking appeal.
Perfumed aromas of flower, nectarine, lime and herb lead to lightly sweet-seeming fruit flavors. It's a well made example of the variety.
A good weekday choice, this full-bodied wine smells of plums and prunes, has an iron-like tang in the flavors and a pleasant mouth-filling texture.
Maple syrup in the aroma and raspberry jam in the flavor add up to a very fruity, almost-sweet wine that is rich and mouth-filling. It has a soft soothing texture, low acidity and little tannin.

Medium gold in color, this wine is a luscious wine that offers aromas of lemon balm, guava, nettle and bruised apple. It's creamy and slippery in texture, but a good lick of acidity to holds things in place.
This is a good, solid and concentrated wine for everyday occasions. It has ample blackberry and blueberry notes, a light vanilla and cinnamon oak touch, smooth texture and rich finish.

Nice fruit concentration, a touch of spicy oak and a very clean uncomplicated flavor profile make this smooth and almost-sweet wine easy to quaff and enjoy. It's full bodied, soft and not noticeably tannic.
A crisp wine packed with apple and citrus flavors, this is light and immediately attractive. There is no need to age this balanced wine. Drink now.

Wild rose, red berry, dark spice and Mediterranean brush aromas come together to create a delicate, alluring fragrance. The smooth, elegant palate doles out juicy red cherry, strawberry, white pepper and clove alongside polished, silky tannins. Bright acidity gives it tension and energy. It's already approachable, but will age well for several more years. Drink through 2026.

Whiffs of dried strawberry and plum introduce this blend of 70% Grenache and 30% Syrah. It's a gorgeously fruity, fleshy wine with opulent body but also nuanced by hints of crushed earth, leather and violet. A supple wine with soft tannins to enjoy now–2023.
winery: Domaine du Roucas de St Pierre

description: This is made from the spectacular coastal vineyard farmed by the Martinelli family, showing the cool-climate grip of tart, tangy acidity. Flavors or apple blossom and Meyer lemon custard give it an unctuous quality that's hard to resist.

Owned and produced by José Sanfins, who is the manager at neighboring classed growth Château Cantenac Brown, this wine balances the elegance of Margaux with the richness of the vintage, giving swathes of black-currant fruit that has been lifted by the new-wood aging. Drink this wine from 2023.

This is a sophisticated, complex and smooth-textured wine that has a mellow, spicy, moderately oaky character and lots of ripe berry and black cherry to fill the middle. The body is full, the tannins are abundant but soft and the mouthfeel is rich and plush.

Though already five-years-old, this bottling is still very fresh, showing aromas of honeysuckle, toast, lemon balm, gardenia and sandalwood. There is a flash of tart lemon on the sip but it's leveled immediately by smooth nut-butter and brioche flavors that power into the velvety finish.

Yummy is the word that comes to mind with this wine, its ripe, round, slightly candied fruit flavors on full display. Orange, tangerine, blackberry and sour cherry flavors create a sweet/tart effect that's held in check by just a touch of barrel toast.

A promising new project out of Temecula, this bottling, which includes 15% Merlot and 5% Cabernet Sauvignon, offers dense aromas of dried strawberry, red plum, vanilla and baking spice. Cooked cranberry, strawberry and pomegranate flavors show on the sip, which is framed by a chalky texture and lifted by hints of rose and carnation.

The color of tanned leather, this limited production Palo Cortado from the almacen Cayetano del Pino is backed by dusty apricot and honey aromas. Classy from first pour, it's is refined but also full bodied on the palate, with integrated dried white fruit and roasted nut flavors that take a long ride into the finish.
designation: Almacenista Cayetano del Pino y Cía Palo Cortado de Jerez

description: This rosé, by the team at Chamisal, is a superstar in the category, offering a little bit of everything for all palate preferences. Perfumed aromas of peach, strawberry and wet gravel combine fruit with minerality, while the palate is framed by a compelling texture. Flavors of red apple and plum sail into the finish.

Copper-yellow in hue, this is a dry blush wine made from barrel-fermented free run juice. Its boasts papaya, plum and melon flavors in a softly fruity and open framework. Ripe and accessible, it should be consumed over the next two years.

This wine's dense fig and raisin aromas are more subtle than loud. It's thick and lush on the palate, but a jolt of acidity lends balance. The usual suspect flavors are here: caramel, toffee, honey. On the finish, a chocolaty flavor takes over.
Juicy, crisp and fruity, this is an immediately refreshing wine. It has an herbal edge although the wine is really more about apple and pear flavors. Drink now.

The engraving of Saint-Tropez on the bottle sets the summer scene behind this wine. Its fruitiness and light acidity evoke warm days while the rich berry flavors give a rounded texture. This wine is ready to drink.
This wine's tilled earth, leather and cassis aromas emerge in the glass. The ripe, rather evolved palate shows mature black plum, roasted coffee and licorice flavors alongside close-grained tannins.

Understated black cherry and blackberry flavors are marked by pert, sour cherry-like acidity in this Grenache-based blend. It's a bold, full-bodied wine kept elegant by delicate earth and dried herb tones. Firm, persistent tannins frame its moderately long finish.
A touch of honeysuckle, a hint of crushed citrus foliage and grass are hinted at. They also shimmer on the light palate where vivid freshness leads onto a fragrant dry finish.

Apple freshness hovers above the glass. Richer pear fruit appears on the resolutely dry palate where midpalate texture does as much to frame the concentrated fruit as lemon freshness. It's a real mouthful, but vivid with freshness.

A hint of earth wafts above ripe pear notes on the nose. The palate is resolutely dry with a streak of lemon brightness running through the earth- and phenol-tinged palate. This wine is lively, fresh and serious, with a long, bone-dry finish.

A shy nose gives little away. The dry palate, however, is a picture of pure, fresh pear, both ripe and tart. Streaks of lemon make the pear even more precise and refreshing on a concentrated but agile body with lovely tension and a refreshing, dry finish.

Almost honeyed pear shows on the nose. On the palate the pear attains a fresher aspect, just as ripe but brightened by lemon. The palate is concentrated, rich but dry with a textured mouthfeel. Lovely now, it promises more. Drink now–2028.

Juicy mandarin on the nose has a touch of maple-syrup spice. The palate has gentle sweetness but much of that mandarin freshness, too. There is a lovely interplay of freshness and richness on a body that remains svelte despite its roundness. The finish is off dry, zesty and long.

Blended with 15% Mourvèdre, this hails from Stoney Vine, Stone Tree, Olsen and Red Heaven Vineyards. Its generous raspberry, black pepper, herb and orange peel aromas are fresh and pure. The palate is rich and ripe, with a smoked meat-filled finish that carries into the distance.

This is a solid, if rather oak-laden, example of Barossa Shiraz that shows notes of plums, violets, red cherries and plenty of sweet, vanillin oak. The palate is plush and plummy with a decent lick of acidity and yet more slightly clunky oak influence.
A light caramel flavor gives this wine a smooth texture. It has acidity along with red-currant and raspberry fruits to bring out the ripeness. This attractive wine is ready to drink.
Lively, fresh and with crisp fruitiness, this intense wine has good acidity balanced with perfumed fruit. Drink this attractive, juicy wine now.

This wine is well-balanced and easy to like, with pleasant notes of toasted apple skin, pie crust and peach pit throughout. It's medium in weight, with a lingering note of orange zest for a final pithy kick. Enjoy now.

Ripe pear notes have tinges of cream and earth that carry through on the palate where they broaden what should be defined. The body is fruity and dry but the earthy element adds bitterness. Drink soon.
From vineyards at 1,200 feet elevation, this cool, fruity wine has fine acidity, black currant fruit and a fresh character that gives a lift to its spice and light tannins. Drink now.

Made with the addition of 9% Viognier grown in Bennett Valley, this is a pleasing white layered in lushness and strong flavors of pineapple and mango. The tropical nature doesn't preclude brightness and balance, ending in a flourish of white flowers.

Underbrush, crushed mint and dark-spice aromas lead the way. It's juicy and savory, doling out dried red cherry, licorice and tobacco alongside bright acidity and firm, refined tannins. A salty note marks the close.

This is a hearty red, completely characteristic of its rough-hewn, mountain appellation, a study in crushed rock and elusive mineral elements. The fruit is a mix of blackberry and black cherry dipped in chocolate, with seasonings of black and white pepper.

This is among the finest Bordeaux blends at its price point, from estate-grown fruit, and consisting of a majority Merlot. A dusty, oaky nose gives way to soft fleshy black fruit, cedar and black pepper, offering length and breadth with ease.

Well rounded aromas of red cherry, wood smoke, cowboy leather and earth make for a very accessible entry to the nose of this affordably priced wine. There is a strong snap to the palate and an impressively chalky grip, offering flavors of dark cherry, cranberry and, on the finish, some vanilla.

The bulk of this wine is 85% Cabernet Sauvignon, which is finished off with Syrah. Aromas of moist earth, funk, black currant and herb lead to soft, smooth cherry and green pepper flavors. It possesses a lovely feel.

Black-currant sauce, concentrated violets and lilacs, milk chocolate and a hint of Dr. Pepper show on the nose of this bottling. The fennel spice extends through the palate, where candied Concord grape and blackberry-syrup flavors also arise.
From a vineyard best known for its Cabernet Sauvignon, this offers blackberry, mineral, smoked meat and toasty spice aromas and full-bodied red and black fruit flavors. It delivers a lot of appeal.
Inviting aromas of peach, green apple and tropical fruit jump over to the round, juicy palate. Tangy acidity lifts the fruity flavors and gives it a refreshing, savory finish.
Granny Smith apple, exotic fruit and nectarine aromas lead the nose on this juicy white. The aromas follow over to the succulent savory palate along with tangy acidity.

This wine's raspberry, strawberry and peppermint aromas set the scene for ripe summer cherry, blueberry, white chocolate and mint tea flavors. Velvety tannins carry it through a zesty, orange-inflected finish.

Aromas of ripe key lime and nectarine meet with edgier elements of pomelo pith and tangerine rinds on the nose of this single-vineyard expression. There's a clean, stony note to the palate, which also offers lime rind and lemon-cream flavors as well as a tense texture.

Bright lemon aromas meet with toast and sweet oak on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling. The palate is aggressive in flavor, with bright citrus, buttery brioche, sea salt and a vanilla finish, all wrapped in grippy structure with well-integrated oak flavors.

This vibrant, almost ethereal Barolo opens with aromas of wild rose, woodland berry, crushed mint and camphor. On the exquisitely elegant, impeccably balanced palate, taut refined tannins and vibrant acidity support crushed red cherry, pomegranate, star anise and a hint of aromatic herb. Although some may find it almost too delicate, others will be enchanted. Drink 2020–2026.

Fairly tart and juicy on the nose, this bottling from one of the region's oldest vineyards offers raspberry, baking spice and a hint of wild boar flesh on the nose. The flavors are full of barely ripe red fruit and more gamy qualities, and there is plenty of acid cutting through the rounded mouthfeel.

Ripe, primary black-cherry and blackberry flavors are direct and concentrated in this balanced red wine. Approachably juicy and edged by soft, feathery tannins, it drinks satisfyingly already but should improve through 2020.

Dark aromas of black cherry, wet slate, loam and strong baking spice show on the nose of this bottling, which comes from some of the more neutral barrels in the winery. It's crisp and juicy on the palate, with rich flavors of wild cherry and cola, all cut by strong acidity.

Elegantly structured, this focused red opens with delicate enticing scents of rose, woodland berry and star anise. The lithe polished palate delivers strawberry compote, red cherry, licorice and white pepper alongside taut smooth tannins. It's balanced, with bright acidity. Drink 2020–2029.

This has underlying smoke and char that works well to bring out the lithe, cool-climate silkiness of texture and tart high-toned fruit. Cranberry, pomegranate and a squeeze of citrus appear on the intriguingly bright, delicate palate as white pepper develops on the finish.

An intense elderberry aroma meets with an equally powerful scent of toasted oak on the nose of this blend of 63% Malbec, 23% Petit Verdot and 14% Cabernet Franc. The elderberry-oak combination carries into the palate as well, where it also picks up blackberry jam and pastry flavors, layered with polished tannins and light acidity.

Sensuality abounds in this voluptuously ripe, plummy wine full of concentrated black cherry and berry flavors. It's a fleshy, hedonistic wine accented by notes of anise, toast and vanilla. Ripe but persistent tannins frame a long finish. It's ready to drink now but should improve through 2028.

This is an expertly delivered steak house Pinot Noir, with big, booming aromas and flavors. Concentrated, intense tones of Bing cherry and boysenberry are lifted by star anise and a strong floral character on the nose. The palate brings flavors of boysenberry pie and vanilla, with bright acid and smooth but hearty tannins.

Apricot aromas and a generous texture are balanced by the crisp freshness of this ripe wine. With that easy contrast between the rich vintage and the natural minerality of the wine, this poised bottling is ready to drink.

Warming notes of cedar and spice mingle into juicy blackberries and plum in this potent, penetrating wine originating from the sun-drenched plateau of Gigondas. A bold proportion of Mourvèdre accentuates its deep, concentrated character, but sunny acidity and a clean mineral backbone lend balance. Approachable already but should improve through 2026 and hold further.

Grown on the plain below Saint-Émilion, this open, gently fruity wine is young. Its blackberry flavors still show the wood aging, giving spice as well as attractive fruitiness that will soften and integrate. Drink from 2020.

Baked plum, licorice and lavender aromas and flavors define this jammy wine, which takes on a sweetness of oak. Thick on the midpalate, it has substantial weight from the tannins and powerfully ripe fruit.

Toasty, resiny aromas make for a nose that's more oaky than fruity. A round palate with a resiny texture holds oaky white fruit flavors of apple and melon that carry over to the finish. This is in its last stages of health; from here on out this will only lose clarity, structure and flavors.
Pomegranate and light baking-spice aromas show on the mellow nose of this bottling. The palate is clean with fruit punch and spice-cake flavors wrapped in a fairly mellow texture.

The product of a troubled El Niño vintage, this has more qualifiers in its name than any wine of this quality should have. Despite all the “estate” and “gran reserva” designations, this Cabernet Sauvignon is a wiry, woolly smelling wine that's rough and raw on the nose. Hard-smacking acidity creates a clipped mouthfeel, while this tastes of buttery plum and currant, all propped up by wiry acidity.
designation: Envero Gran Reserva Estate Grown Tricao Vineyard Selection

description: Cool, herbal aromas of spicy black fruit and tobacco are solid for Carmenère from a tough, rainy year. In the mouth, this shows pumped up acidity and grating tannins. Angular red plum and cranberry flavors are wiry and dry on the finish.
Dry and medium bodied, this wine has appley aromas, apple-skin flavors and a tangy, edgy texture. It tastes rather low on the ripeness scale but has refreshing qualities.
Really light in the glass for a Cab, this bottling shows hints of green herbs and exotic red plum on the nose. The palate is a bit thin and minty, surrounding a light cranberry core.

This full-bodied wine has assertive smoky oaky aromas and flavors that nearly overwhelm the jammy fruit flavors underneath. The roasted toasted character gives a little spine to the otherwise soft impression on the palate.
Black-plum and black-currant aromas are a bit shocked. In the mouth, this is tight and tannic. Jammy black-fruit flavors are the definition of generic, while this settles in bumpy fashion.
Sweet is the name and sweet the taste of this soft wine. However, the crisp acidity typical of Vinho Verde gives the wine a lift. A fine aperitif wine, it's ready to drink now.

Thick aromas of earthy truffle and sweet oak spice create a sheen over a quiet dark-berry tone. The palate is extracted and dense, yet shot through with sharp acidity. Despite that, there's a bit more fruit expression on the palate, with flavors of tart dark berries under a dollop of vanilla and clove.

This funky Oloroso has a coffee color and cheesy prune and dried fruit aromas. It's less than polished but quite honest, with a tight, drawing palate filled with nutty, salty flavors, acidity and power.

This leads with smooth, ripe and pure aromas of honeyed raisin. That richly honeyed note carries onto the palate, which is thick to the point of cloying. Its corn syrup, candied pecan and caramel flavors are rich and confected, even on the finish.

This wine balances ripe fruit flavors with oak spiciness. Aromas of mahogany and cedar start it off, followed by cherry and black currant flavors that are shaded by chocolate and linger on the finish. It boasts an appetizing and moderately tannic texture, with supportive acidity that keeps it fresh and compelling.

Crisp white melon, grapefruit and gooseberry are cutting and spry here, nuanced by dusty chalk and salt. It's gorgeously fresh and fruity yet maintains a steely tension that's invigorating. Ready to drink now but it should hold well through 2026, likely further.

The fruit for this 100% varietal wine comes from top sites Seven Hills (51%) and Klipsun (46%), with a dash from Scooteney Flats. Its barrel spice, dried herb, cocoa, black currant, pencil lead and dark cherry aromas are locked up at the moment, but the palate is well balanced and full of fruit and crunchy tannins. It needs time to unwind. Best after 2020.

This inaugural release from Ben Paplow, assistant winemaker at Gorman Winery, is a blend of 67% Grenache, 10% Syrah, 10% Mourvèdre, 9% Cinsault and 4% Viognier—all cofermented and aged in neutral oak. Its blackberry jam, white pepper, flower and orange rind aromas are followed by smooth, polished fruit and meat flavors. It displays a lot of purity and finesse.

Only faint hints of ripe stone fruit reach the nose. On the palate these become fully, ripely drawn and edged with lemon. This is fresh and concentrated with a zesty, lemony tang informing the long, dry finish.

This is a light, floral red, aromatic in rose petal and white pepper, that evolves to show a wealth of balanced red fruit, from rhubarb to strawberry. A hint of cola is contrasted nicely against a plushness of cola and sweet tannin.

Lower in elevation yet slightly cooler than Giant Steps's other single-vineyard Chardonnay site, Sexton, this is nonetheless cut from the same delicious cloth. Bright lemon and pineapple swirl with flint and buttery brioche. The palate has an appealing and surprising lightness, with slippery acidity, a chalky texture and a spicy, citrusy and stony finish. Drink now–2022.

Lifted hints of chamomile and petrol hint at ripeness of fruit and some maturity. The palate, however, is still fresh as a daisy and does not yet show signs of evolution with its sprightly, ripe lemon notes. This is compact and dry, with a wonderful streak of lemon freshness. Lovely now, it's sure to continue evolving. Drink now–2025.

An aggressive smoky earthy tobacco aroma precedes rich berry and chocolate flavors that drench the palate in this full-bodied, concentrated and almost feral wine. It's an adventure to drink and far from boring.

Earthy, mellow richness shows on the nose and blossoms on the palate. Rounded, ripe pear fruit fills the mouth with sunny generosity while a phenolic edge grounds the richness. Lemon freshness ensures balance. It finishes dry.

A thick, rich and oak-laden white on entry, this coastal-influenced white is crunchy in green apple, melon and mango. Ultimately balanced and medium bodied in ripeness and body weight, it finishes in a pleasing note of Meyer lemon.

An estate wine made entirely from the Swan selection of the grape, this is a delicately layered high-toned red, stratified in rhubarb, strawberry and a burst of dried herb. It is light bodied and coastal in influence and style.

From the Heintz Estate, this is a floral, herbal wine with an edge of carbonic brightness and acidity to it, which works well in its light-bodied frame. Lithe on the palate, it offers a subtle take on pomegranate, rhubarb and black tea.
