Crushed mint, pressed rose, wild red berry and dark spice aromas appear in the glass. On the juicy linear palate, licorice and savory mineral notes back up ripe raspberry and Marasca cherry. Polished tannins provide elegance and support. Drink through 2021.

Made entirely with Pinot Nero, this bright red opens with aromas of rose petal, red berry and baking spice. The linear, light-bodied palate evokes juicy raspberry, cooking spice and a touch of cinnamon alongside vibrant acidity and polished tannins. Drink through 2022.
Crisp and floral, this wine has mid-tier structure and is ultimately clean, focused and unfussy in style. Restrained ripeness allows room for lemon zest, grapefruit and persistent acidity to shine.
Perfumed, flavored with thyme as well as crisp red fruits, this fragrant wine also has a zing of tight acidity. It has plenty of fruitiness, refreshing and tangy at the same time. Drink now.
From a 24-acre vineyard, this wine is a blend of Grenache, Syrah, Mourvèdre and Cinsault. The perfumed wine is rich with strawberries and ripe with caramel, spice and soft acidity. Drink now.

Sour cherry, bramble berry and a bit of pepper carry the nose of this wine. The medium-bodied palate is soft in feel, with juicy red cherry and strawberry flavors that meld with a floral lilt. This is enjoyable for its immediate easydrinking appeal.

Lemon and green pear make a very slight appearance on the almost neutral nose. On the light palate, their image is clearer and refreshing with a hint of Grüner's herbal tang before ending in a zesty finish.
Aromas reminiscent of mature yellow stone fruit and yellow spring flowers lead the way in this. The tangy palate evokes apricot, citrus and yellow apple. A bitter almond hint signals the close.

When Tannat, Madiran's bold red grape, is fortified with brandy, its tannins and spiritous edge create a contrast. The result: rich, jammy red fruit flavors and potent tannins. It will be ready to drink from 2019.

A heavy blanket of oak accents this wine's earthy berry fruit aromas, making it smell a bit like marshmallow. The palate is thick and resiny, with wood and black fruit flavors. An oaky finish confirms its one-dimensional character.

Ripe plum, chocolate-covered cherry and boysenberry flood the nose and palate of this straightforward but easy-drinking wine. It's rich in sweet-fruit flavors, but not overdone, with soft tannins that lend a touch of texture.

Faint scents of yellow apple, lemon verbena and lime pith tease the nose of this light, easygoing wine. The palate offers good acidic lift, while notes of bitter melon rind, mâche and white peach linger on the pithy close. Drink now.

This is a good middle-of-the-road wine with sufficient fruit flavors and fairly crisp acidity that will make it quite food-friendly. It's light to medium in body, and has light lemon and herb flavors.

This wine is half Syrah and half Cabernet Sauvignon, aged 30 months in new American and Slovakian oak. It delivers copper penny, wet herb and baking spice aromas, seeming unready to reveal its charms. The palate shows a mixture of fruit and barrel notes that continue through the finish.
Balanced, crisp and fruity, this lively wine offers raspberry fruits, touches of red currant and a perfumed aftertaste. Drink this attractive wine now.

A compact nose does its best to support the weight of heavy yet savory aromas of beef jerky, soy sauce and black tea. A choppy tannic palate sizzles more than it simmers, while this is toasty and blackened in flavor. Additional toasty oak, baking spice and chocolate flavors seep onto a long generous finish. Drink from 2020–2035.

Freshly smashed lemon aromas meet with yeast and sourdough on the nose of this excellent bubbly bottling. The palate's bubbles are soft and inviting, with flavors of yuzu, fresh bread and the slightest hints of smoke and ash.
designation: Blanc de Noirs Bien Nacido Vineyard

description: A very subtle nose gives hints of ripe yellow apple and a gentle creaminess. Lively but fine fizz on the palate brings out more of the vivid enlivening freshness, now with nuances of green apple and ripe lemon pitched against a gently autolytic background of shortbread. With its long dry lemony finish this is all about subtlety, freshness and restrained elegance. Lovely now but it will evolve. Drink though 2025.

Aged for 18 months in wood, this wine shows its tannic structure, but that is balanced by the hugely ripe black fruits and acidity. Despite its power and richness, it has elegance, balanced well between concentration and fruitiness. Drink this wine from 2019.

A nose of vivid citrus and red apple is most appetizing. The palate is fresh and a wonderful compromise between rounded, rich autolysis with its shortbread notes of buttery pastry and the fresh green and red-apple briskness. Lovely creamy bubbles disperse the full-flavored freshness across the entire palate, filling the senses with freshness and fruit. The finish is full, fresh, dry and long.

This bold, flavorful wine offers well-integrated tones of red currant, dried cherry, dusty leather and clove. Savory and profound in elongated tannins, it holds its powerful ripeness and structure with pride, showing the stuffing to age well. Best 2024–2029.
Winemaker Bryan Kane of Vie and Sol Rouge is behind this wine, which succeeds in offering fleshy, savory cranberry and Asian spice around a light delicate core that's balanced in acidity and style.

This Mavroudi/Syrah blend has a spicy nose of plum, cocoa and strawberry rhubarb. On the palate, cherry, plum and raspberry flavors are interwoven with an herbal rosemary character that's very appealing. It's elegant, with a crisp profile that should pair beautifully with a variety of foods.
This wine's lemon and ripe, yellow Mirabelle plum scents smile from the glass. The palate follows with ripe freshness and a slender yet juicy body. This is lovely and light, with a dry finish.
Floral and brimming in citrus-laden acidity, this is a creamy, lush example of the variety, with a strong peachy flavor and aromas of apple blossom.

The 94% Cabernet Sauvignon and 6% Merlot were sourced from the producer's Chiles Valley estate and organically grown. Dried herb and olive present first around full-bodied notions of crisp cassis and red currant, finishing in a swath of nutmeg oak and firm tannin.

Almost a mustard yellow in the glass, this viscous, age-worthy bottling shows extremely nutty aromas of toasted walnut on the nose, along with dried lemon peels, beach sand and caramel cream. There is richness to the palate but the acidity holds it in check, offering flavors of crushed cashew, macadamia nuts and lemon rind.

Dripping with sun-drenched blueberry and plum flavors, La Colline is Bosquets' expression of pure Grenache. It's a fleshy, opulent wine marked by earthen tones of crushed clay and smoked herb and a delightfully clingy texture. Its soft tannins and juicy constitution make it ready to drink now, but it should gain depth well through 2028.

This full wine is well structured and offers rich red fruits. It is still young, but its concentration and ripe red-berry and cherry flavors are all there. Let the wine age for a few years and drink from 2024.
designation: Clos de l'Ecu Monopole Premier Cru

description: While subtle on the nose, fleshy black plum and smoky violet perfume intensifies throughout this silky, full-bodied wine. It's richly composed yet finessed, finishing on fine-grained, firm tannins. Approachable already but should gain complexity though 2030.

Anise and black pepper lend spice and fire to gorgeous black cherry and plum flavors in this supple red. It's a potent yet plush, generous wine framed by yielding acidity and a subtly earthen finish. Lovely already but should improve through 2028.

From a blend of iconic sites, like Rochioli, Hallberg and Martaella, this opens with thick, dense and concentrated tones of dried cherry and cola before unleashing a wealth of white pepper and black tea. It finds a balance between the fruit and the forest elements on the midpalate, finishing in silky brilliance.

This mature wine comes from one of the finest premier cru vineyards in Gevrey-Chambertin. While light in color, it has richness along with red-berry acidity. The tannins have softened to broaden this ripe wine that is ready to drink.

A blend of Procanico, Malvasia and Drupeggio, this opens with subtle aromas suggesting ripe orchard fruit and spring wildflower. The simple but juicy palate offers Bosc pear, candied lemon slice and a hint of raw almond.

Butter and vanilla notes dominate the jammy fruit flavors in this rich and seemingly sweet wine. It is medium bodied, lightly tannic and heavily influenced by oaky aromas and flavors, including baking spices and maple syrup.
This wine has potential, bringing together ripe fruits and soft tannins. Its acidity and dry core will allow it to age. Drink from 2021.
A ripe Pinot Noir from the Mâconnais region, this offers plenty of red-cherry flavors and balanced firm tannins. The wine is fruity, rich and likely to soften quickly. Drink from 2019.
This aromatic wine with fine fruits and rich tannins is still at an early stage in its development. It shows dryness as well as richness and needs a few years. Drink from 2022.
Light and fruity, this wine is dominated by fresh Sémillon flavors. Citrus and a hint of potential creamy richness balance the wine between a smooth texture and a fresh aftertaste. Drink now.
Generic berry and plum flavors lead to a pulling palate with clamping tannins and high acidity. Plum, black-fruit and olive flavors are choppy prior to a tight-as-nails finish.

Forced oak aromas are gritty and strongly suggest clove. A tannic palate is resiny in feel. Oak-based clove is the key flavor on this oaky one-dimensional Malbec that comes across as being more worked than natural.
Aromas of dusty apple, mature peach and pollen carry to the oily, rounded palate. A mild backbone of acidity offers some balance yet ultimately flattens out on the finish.
This is a soft wine, light and gently fruity. Acidity, green fruits and a touch of herbal flavors give the wine a gentle, open character with a twist of honey. It is ready to drink.

Solid red fruits, cherry-pie filling, cinnamon and carnation dance in the nose of this bottling. The palate shows a bit more herbal, stemmy presence, with medium tannins that lend support to the cherry-dominant fruit profile.

Scratchy plum and berry aromas are a bit gummy. A jammy palate with strawberry and raspberry flavors shows off the fruity red side of Garnacha, while a raspberry flavor lingers on a finish with mild heat and burn.

This is a fruity wine that overflows with cherry, plum and raspberry aromas and beautifully ripe pure flavors along with some rhubarb and herbal accents that add complexity and interest. It's full bodied, and has a silky-smooth texture.

This spring-flower-perfumed wine is crisp with citrus while having a soft backdrop of ripe apples. It is an intensely textured wine, mineral and zesty. Those elements contrast with the rich fruitiness and good acidity. The wine could be aged longer, and will be better from 2020.

A lifted touch of chamomile precedes lemon notes on the nose. The palate comes in with concentration and freshness of both fresh and dried lemon rind. This is dry, mouthwatering and refreshing with its sinuous, light body and brisk, lasting freshness.

Mac Forbes is a leading light when it comes to championing the Yarra Valley's diverse terroirs through traditional winemaking methods. His 2016 Chardonnay starts reductively, but those onion-skin aromas blow off, replaced by subtle and integrated aromas of waxy lemon, white pepper and melon rind. The palate is the star in the show, with a taut and focused line of lemony acidity, stony minerality and long lingering salty and citrusy finish. Extremely food friendly but it is also delicious on its own.

While initially soft, this wine then develops a crisper side that comes from the red-currant flavors. It also has some toasty touches and hints of maturity. Taken together, these elements have produced a rich wine, ripe and ready to drink.

Rubbery pencil eraser scents accent this wine's blackberry and menthol aromas. It's a heavyweight, with chunky blackberry and fig flavors swathed in chocolate notes from aging 30 months in French oak. It remains oaky and thick into the finish. Drink through 2032.

This wine is a complex—and a tad woody—combo of lemon verbena, pineapple cake, wet hay and lavender soap. Slightly slippery in texture and sitting firmly in the medium body spectrum, the integrated herbal and wet stone flavors finish with lick of toast and a salty tang.

A blend of 70% Nero d'Avola and 30% Syrah, this opens with aromas of dark berry, Mediterranean scrub and cooking spice. The full-bodied, chewy palate delivers blackberry jam, licorice and black pepper alongside dusty tannins. Enjoy through 2022.

As Devona wines are still produced in Walla Walla, its single vineyard efforts bear only the generic Oregon AVA on the label. The blend here is principally Pommard clone and spent time in 30% new French barrels. Light berry fruit flavors, annotated with herb and stem highlights, finish with stiff tannins and suggestions of cedar and tobacco.

Named after a legendary oak tree, this wine is full of ripe tropical and spice flavors. Its rich character is balanced with sophisticated acidity. Densely textured, the wine could do with a few more months, so drink from 2019.

This wine leads with a broody nose of plum, earth, coffee, warm stone and baking spice. The palate is woven together by tight tannins, but the acidity keeps things firmly in the medium-bodied spectrum. It finishes with a savory soy sauce note. Drink now.

From a single vineyard in the cool climes of Victoria's Pyrenees region, this offers heady notes of cherry, meat, tree bark, chocolate, ground black pepper and spice. The palate is silky and savory, with earthy tannins and a slightly bitter oak note on the finish. Drink now–2023.
This wine's generic white fruit aromas are innocuous. Its tangy, citrusy palate deals salty flavors of orange and lemon. It feels fresh on the finish but never rises above basic, good Albariño.

This full-bodied wine is surprisingly soft with a very smooth texture carrying ripe black-plum and milk-chocolate flavors. The acidity and tannins are way in the background and the seemingly sweet flavors take center stage.

It may be one level up price-wise from the Red Silk, but frankly, there's not a huge difference between the two wines except for more oak on the Jimmy's Section. Plush and ripe, and oozing plum and blackberry jam, the oak here is sweet and slightly sweaty. Structurally it's soft and round with just barely enough acidity and tannins to hold things together.

This wine's heavy oak aromas bring a smoldering campfire to mind. It's dense and soupy, with low acidity and soft tannins. Its baking spice and black fruit flavors finish hot, with a roasted character. It was tasted twice with consistent findings.
A slight mealiness on the nose suggests bruised apple. The palate pulls this back with fresh lemon flavors on the light, easy and dry palate. Drink while lemon notes are at their peak.
This wine's mild citrus and grape skin aromas suggest chewing gum and yeast. It's salty on the palate, with quick-fading citrus flavors bolstered by punchy acidity.

This is a blend of 65% Viognier, 28% Chardonnay and smaller amounts of Rousanne and Marsanne. Aromatic in jasmine, it's medium bodied with fresh, vibrant layers of fresh acidity built around strong flavors of apricot and apple.

Concentrated aromas of red currant, alpine strawberry and carnation show on the nose of this bottling from one of the region's Zinfandel pioneers. The palate follows suit, with a juicy blackberry sorbet flavor and a gravelly minerality that are upheld by firm tannins and solid acidity.

Smoky, spicy and rich, this dense wine is full of firm tannins that keep it structured and concentrated. This limited-edition wine brings out berry fruits and final acidity that gives a juicy character to the aftertaste. Drink the wine now.

Swathes of Alicante Bouschet with its firm tannins and dark color give this wine great power. This is balanced by another structured grape, Syrah. Together, the two make a darkly tannic wine with bitter chocolate, perfumed black fruit and tannins. There is nothing subtle here, just density and richness. Drink from 2021.

This rich wine is a blend that includes 10% old field-blend vines. Firm and structured, it is layered with bold black fruits and great acidity. With wood aging and minerality, the wine is complex and set for some good aging. Drink from 2021.

Medium bodied and well-crafted, from a tremendously well-farmed site, this white is crisp and acid-driven with a lightness of being that surprises. Asian pear and crème brûlée both play a part in intriguing the palate.

This blend of 90% Sangiovese and 10% Ciliegiolo offers delicate black-skinned fruit and earthy underbrush aromas. The straightforward, enjoyable palate offers crushed plum, green tea and white pepper flavors alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2021.

Crushed mineral and delicate rosemary and sage notes are at the forefront of this elegant, dry rosé. Its crisp red cherry and dried strawberry flavors are understated and lean, with vibrant, balanced acidity. The finish is moderately long, with lingering mineral freshness.

Cottony plum and berry aromas are a touch soapy. This is plodding and on the heavy side. Saturated stewy berry and spice flavors are chocolaty and oaky on the finish, as well as herbal. This offers a lot, but it's coarse, jumpy and suffers a bit under its own weight.

Ripe tropical and passion fruit along with wild mint, butter and a flinty minerality are slightly hidden in this gold-hued wine. The full-bodied palate is round and rich, with just enough acidity to keep things refreshing. A salty herbaceousness is present right through to the finish.
This has a shy nose that eventually reveals pressed acacia, Spanish broom and beeswax aromas. On the ripe, round palate, bitter almond underscores mature yellow apple and citrus rind flavors.

A touch of fir honey, lifted lemon oil and dried orange and apple peels create a most enticing, complex nose. The palate is soft and pliable, with a flavor of sweet Mandarin orange flesh, yet the finish is dry. This is sinuous, dry Riesling with tons of charm. Drink through 2028.

While full bodied, this wine also has more than enough fruit, spice and savory nuances to give it plenty of flavor. The aroma exudes sour cherry, wild berry and underbrush while the flavors reveal ripe black cherry, rhubarb and light tea notes for an appealing and complex mix. It's called Rescue Block because the grapes are from a block of 1,000 old vines that Lula's owners nursed back to health.

Subtle Williams pear on the nose has a lovely earthy saltiness about it. The palate comes in with gentle sweetness that accentuates the pear but also with vivid freshness and a phenolic backdrop that enhances that earthy pity salty feel. This is balanced, elegant and finishes very harmoniously on an off-dry note. Drink now through 2028.

Ripe notes of russet pear are tinged with lemon freshness on the nose. The palate comes in with concentrated and generous juiciness. Lots of pear fruit swirls and is amplified by spirited warmth, but both these elements are framed with lemon freshness, pulling it all into a balanced, even and just off-dry finish. Drink until 2028.

French oak, blue flower, underbrush and wild berry aromas escape the glass. On the smooth, full-bodied palate, firm fine-grained tannins frame juicy black cherry, crushed raspberry, espresso and star anise. Fresh acidity keeps it balanced. Drink 2024–2034.

A soft touch of mandarin with a little zesty lemon zing on the nose leads onto a very full-fruited palate made up of juicy tangy mandarin notes. With a little air, they become ever more aromatic and fragrant. Concentration and freshness accommodate the smidgen of sweetness well and the zesty flavors make sure this reaches a dry finish.

This wine shows the richness of the appellation in this vintage. It is opulent, full of ripe fruits and with just the right amount of acidity. Textured and still young, it will be ready to drink from 2019.

From a sloping hillside at 1,000-feet in elevation, this is a beautiful vineyard-designate and ambassador for the variety: shy in fruit at first, which only allows its floral, earthy aspects of ash and rock to shine. Black pepper and leather boost an array of tangy cherry, raspberry and plum that remains tart and fresh.

Spicy blackberry and cassis aromas are dense yet subtle. A power-packed palate is pulpy and fruity but also tannic. Blackened berry flavors dominate this Bordeaux-style blend, while richer oak-aided flavors of chocolate and root beer settle at the top of a long finish. Drink through 2026.

Aromas of red-cherry reduction sauce meet with mud, clay, purple flowers, peppercorns and herbs on the dynamic nose of this single-vineyard bottling. The palate is quite dry and herbal with flavors of fennel frond, anise, and thyme, but there's a solid mulberry and exotic red-fruit core.

Notes of salt, baked earth and crushed stones act as base notes to this succulent but restrained Gigondas. Aged entirely in concrete tanks, it's subtle and nuanced, suggesting a transparency of black fruit flavors and a deep earthiness that lingers. Ripe, integrated tannins ring the finish. A lovely wine to enjoy now–2030.

With an addition of 5% Petite Sirah, this wine is brooding in a berry fruit tone that mingles with brown sugar, baking spice and coffee. Lifted acidity does a good job reining in the fundamental power and concentration at its core.

Winemaker: Carel Nel. A true Port-style wine, this is made from 80% Touriga Nacional, 10% Touriga Franca, 6% Souzão and 4% Tinta Barocca. It boasts intense, rich black-berry and -cherry aromas and flavors that are coupled with decadent notes of milk chocolate, all-fruit preserves and baking spice. The palate is warm, slick and full, the sweet fruit flavors just lifted by the alcohol and structure.
designation: Cape Winemakers Guild Cape Vintage Auction Reserve

description: Winemaker: Carl van der Merwe. Soft aromas of white flowers, peach-white tea, melon rind and orange blossom delicately dance on the nose of this surprisingly dainty wine. The palate is fruit forward, with fresh flavors of guava, melon flesh, apricot and orange peel that carry through to the medium-length finish. It's easy to like, well balanced, clean and tasty.

Winemaker: Jan Coetzee. Light in character, this "swansong" bottling opens with fresh, snappy scents of small red berries and currants as well as a touch of rhubarb. The palate boasts a smooth, satiny texture, with fine tannins that lend a subtle texture to the red berry and cherry flavors. Hints of sweet spice and mocha develop on the close. A magnum bottle, this is still quite young and primary, needing more time to gain depth and additional complexity. Try after 2023.

Delicious cherry and plum flavors are accented by touches of black tea, rhubarb and forest floor in this complex, medium-bodied wine. It's slightly soft in feel, but has light tannins and enough acidity to give it some snap.

Still showing its wood aging, this wine is packed with black-currant fruits, firm tannins as well as layers of acidity and fruitiness. The high proportion of Merlot gives the wine a delicious juicy character that will develop further as it ages. Drink from 2022.

This wine's ripe green pear, yeast, miso and arugula notes on the nose reappear on the light but aromatic palate. Subtle hints of yeast and salt accent its gentle pear fruit. It's light bodied and dry, with a totally refreshing finish.
This soft wine conveys pineapple and ripe white-currant fruitiness along with citrus acidity. Warm, open and rounded, it is ready to be drunk now.
An aroma like toasted almonds and wood smoke meets spiced plum and red-cherry flavors in this medium-bodied wine. It's an oaky version that maintains pretty good balance.

Plum skin and pomegranate lead the nose while white pepper and raw oak take on an earthy edge. The soft-bodied palate is awash in silky tannins, with intense flavors of vanilla, oak and green tobacco leaf over black cherry and plum. There is a spicy kick on the finish, with more vanilla and baked black plum.
This is a big ripe red wine moderate in structure that offers fleshy mouthfuls of cola and black cherry.
A bright, fresh and crisp wine, this is totally ready to drink. It has good acidity as well as minerality.

Aromas of scorched earth, ripe yellow apple and a whiff of toasted nut lead the nose. On the medium-bodied palate, fresh acidity offsets dried yellow peach, a hint of citrus zest and bitter almond. Drink soon to capture the remaining fruit flavors.
region_1: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore

description: Ripe and darkly fruity, this open, red-berry-flavored wine is made to be drunk young. It is lightly perfumed with violets and full of balanced fruits. Drink now.

This is a ripe and fruit-forward wine, offering notes of berry preserves and cherry flesh on the nose and mouth. Hints of sweet spice, powder and carnation lend some added earthy depth, while moderate tannins and bright acidity provide structure to the rich fruit core.
Maraschino cherry, anise and vanilla aromas lead to lightly sweet-seeming fruit flavors. It doesn't all work.

Church incense, Asian spice, fennel and green tea add spicy depth to the red currant and plum core. The tannins are taut and astringent on the palate, and they linger through the green, tightly wound finish.

Funky white-fruit aromas come with scented-soap notes. This is foamy and less than smooth on the palate, with briny citrus flavors that don't amount to anything specific. An innocuous finish is appropriate for an average Cava such as this.
Quite light in color, aromas of caramel and red fruit are followed by light fruit flavors. The concentration doesn't seem all there, with the variety hard to find.

Juicy notes of canned mandarin segments suggest utter ripeness on the nose. Measured richness continues on the palate where a good dollop of residual sweetness lets this mandarin fruit shine, while zestiness never lets this slip beyond freshness. The palate stays toned but full. This carries off a lovely balance with its medium-dry finish.

Light in color, this bottling of the Wente clone from a historic, wind-whipped, hilltop vineyard shows soft aromas of white peach, creamy melon and key lime, all dusted by ample sea salt. The palate starts with a touch of toast and caramel, but then grabs the palate with a grippy texture and flavors of lemon and lime juice.
Nobly reduced on the nose, this is a savory, leathery red, tart in cherry and cassis. Full bodied, it imparts elegant seasonings of cedar, dried herb and woody tannin that grip and structure.

Intense, wild red-berry, Mediterranean scrub and dark spice aromas mingle together on the nose. The elegant palate mirrors the aromas, evoking juicy red cherry, crushed raspberry, camphor and star anise, while a mineral note wraps up the finish. It's well balanced, with fresh acidity and polished tannins. Drink through 2021.

From the relatively cooler climes of the Clare Valley, this is a dense and broody, yet multifaceted wine expressing red current, menthol, licorice, cola, black pepper and sweet oak on the nose. The palate is full bodied to be sure but it's clear that this wine is in it for the long haul. Everything is in place, from ultrafine tannins to a silky texture, all held together with plenty of plush fruit and savoriness. Drink 2010–2022.

Tart, focused and bright in acidity, this unoaked wine doesn't hold back in richness, allowing the fruit to speak freely for itself in lemon, Mandarin orange and melon. Asian pear and peach play supporting roles as lingering aromas of jasmine weigh in.

From 40-year-old vines comes this semisweet wine by young winemaker Natalie Darr, full of aromas of honey, honeysuckle, chamomile and fortune cookies on the nose. The sweetness is subtle on the palate, as it surrounds a chalky core and grippy texture.

From 40-year-old vines in Los Alamos comes this crisp, lovely wine, which shows nectarine, Meyer lemon spray and grapefruit peel aromas on the nose. The palate is crisp and grippy, with light stone-fruit flavors alongside crushed white rocks and a slight citrus tang.

There's a core of pristine, cutting red-cherry and raspberry flavors here nuanced by earthen hints of beet root and crushed stone. Delicate and airy in texture, it's a lively nuanced wine with juicy red fruit framed by feathery tannins and a pleasant bite of dried herbs on the finish. Drink now through 2023.

A combination of spicy, fruity and savory flavors, as well as a suave texture, make this wine quite impressive. Subtle nutmeg and vanilla aromas lead to fresh pear and white peach flavors, with a touch of minerality for a tasty but not extreme personality.

This is a nicely put together, complex red, brimming in smooth layers of integrated black fruit, plum, cinnamon and clove. The robust ripeness is well-managed and in check, with a welcome smoky touch to the lengthy finish.

Estate-grown, this wine is juicy and expansive, with an approachability that makes it instantly pleasing on the palate. Black currant, graphite and dark-chocolate flavors meet brushy dried herb and toasted oak, integrating into a lengthy finish.

Initial aromas of wet cement, baking spices and creamy oak are as prominent as red-berry scents. This old-vines Carignan from Terra Alta is full to the brim on the palate, with no wiggle room. Saucy, oaky plum flavors come with a full dash of cocoa, while this is warm, oaky and savory tasting on the finish. Drink through 2021.

Enticing scents of field flower, orchard fruit and a whiff of bread crust waft out of the glass. On the creamy palate, bright acidity lifts ripe yellow apple, white peach and candied citrus slice alongside a silky mousse.

Candied citrus and pineapple aromas juxtapose bramble and crushed mineral in this dry, medium-bodied white. Crisp quince and green plum flavors are tart and crunchy but balanced by riper tones of melon rind and grapefruit. The finish is invigorating and mineral. Drink now–2023.

This wine seems to be holding itself back, even after some hours of breathing. There are well-woven suggestions of blackberry, fig, smoke, black tea and charred wood, supported with ample acidity. The tannins are tongue-dryingly astringent. Give this a few more years of bottle aging, and drink in the early 2020s.

A reserve selection that blends Coury, Pommard and Wadenswil clones, this is a full-bodied, fleshy wine with berry and black cherry fruit. Barrel aging adds notes of cola, coffee and black licorice, and the wine is buoyed nicely by a seam of citrusy acidity. It's still pulling itself together, and this vintage is one that should cellar well. Drink from 2020 on.

Well integrated with a subtle fist of power, this wine is fleshy and fruit forward in apple and lime with a stony mineral edge. A twinge of fresh grapefruit flavor brightens the glass and adds to the overall complexity.

Alluring scents of Spanish broom, beeswax and wild herbs mingle with orchard fruit aromas in this wine. On the round palate, a honeyed note underscores mature yellow apple and citrus rind flavors. A bitter almond note signals the close.

Fleshy black cherry displays its ripeness on the nose. The palate has the same ripe juiciness but also a dollop of freshness to counter it. This is easygoing, utterly-fruit-driven and for immediate drinking.

Grassy herbs, gooseberry and slate make for an atypical aroma for a late harvest Riesling. The palate brings more familiar melon and chalky apple flavors, with a mild vein of acidity carrying to a peach-fuzz finish.

Coming from Dutchman Vineyard in the Yakima Valley, aromas of muscat, dried orange peel, honeydew melon rind and citrus are followed by full-feeling lightly spritzy tropical fruit flavors. It delivers appeal.
This organically grown wine's white spring flower and orchard fruit aromas form in the glass. The bright palate offers yellow apple, Anjou pear and nectarine flavors alongside fresh acidity.
Boysenberry and chocolate flavors flood the taste buds as this full-bodied and broad-textured wine fills the mouth with richness. It tastes lush and ripe, feels smooth and almost soft.

Ripe mango and guava notes are a bit confected but tasty in this juicy, easy-drinking Riesling. Medium sweet in style, it's balanced by zesty lime acidity and a hint of earthen minerality on the finish. Drink now.
Heady aromas of fragrant spring flower and orchard fruit leap out of the glass. On the bright, simple palate, fresh acidity accompanies green apple and citrus notes.
This wine has an earthy, walnutty aroma, sparse fruit flavors improved by a white-pepper and mineral streak, and a very crisp, dry mouthfeel.

This wine's combination of oak and oily aromas makes for a nutty nose with stone fruit notes. On the palate, it's fresh and racy, with citrusy acidity and nectarine, scallion and sea water flavors that play out on a lasting finish.
Honeydew and rainwater make for a nicely restrained nose on this bottling. It's a bit soft and broad on the sip, with mango, guava and more tropical flavors. The texture is a little flat.

This wine starts off softly, with faint aromas of yellow apple, lime peel and hay. The medium-weight palate shows low acidity, though it's enough to keep the warm apple-pie flavor in check. Drink now.

Spicy aromas of toast, tobacco, fine oak and ripe but subtle berry fruits combine forces to create a classic Rioja gran reserva bouquet. The ripe palate is full but hasn't stalled out, while this tastes of oak-enriched mocha, coffee and spiced berry fruits. A ripe, malty finish tastes mostly of tobacco. This is a Tempranillo-based blend, with 30% Graciano, 15% Garnacha and 5% Mazuelo. Drink through 2035.

The zestiness on the nose is undeniable but subtle. There is a hint of stone and earth, too. With air, an aromatic edge of pear and apricot appears. The palate comes in with smooth generous fruit. Serene ripe notes of apple and pear are tempered by gentle, but distinct, lemon freshness. This has a fluid, generous and harmonious body and a just off-dry finish. The lemon notes linger long. Drink 2028–2030.

At first the nose is clouded by earthy funk but then rather pure notions of dried mandarin peel and ripe apple appear. The palate is very concentrated and also pulls this aromatic coup from earthy smoke to mandarin-scented marvel. This is unusual, but has real impact. The finish is dry and utterly lemon fresh. It's lovely now. Drink through 2028.

Rose, crushed herb, balsamic notes and exotic spice aromas float above the glass. The smooth savory palate offers juicy raspberry, wild strawberry, cinnamon and star anise alongside supple tannins and fresh acidity. It's already delicious but will age well for several years or more. Drink through 2024.

On slopes of up to 50% gradient leading to the Tua river, this north-facing vineyard produces well-structured wines like this. The tannins are very present along with the potential of the rich black fruits and acidity. This complex, concentrated wine needs to age. Drink from 2020.

A pale-pink color and an appetizing aroma of baked red apples make this very appetizing. There is a certain creaminess on the nose, too, which also pervades the wonderfully tart but ripe red-apple fruit. In the background is a hint of patisserie as a proof of subtle autolysis. This is fresh with pristine flavors and tiny fine bubbles. It's a real joy.
Dust and sage accentuate the oak and depth of flavor in this wine, which is soft and supple on the palate. Succulent flavors of black cherry, plum and anise carry well through the finish.

Made by freezing the grapes prior to extraction, this dessert wine shows candied red apple, dried honeydew and a hint of tuberose on the nose. The palate is viscous but balanced by zesty acidity that penetrates deep into the finish, offering flavors of lime spritz and apple syrup.

Earthy, slightly damp black-plum and black-currant aromas include notes of tobacco and graphite. A round plump cushioned palate is toughened by slightly rough tannins. Blackberry, dark plum, coffee and toasted flavors finish with spicy notes of black pepper.

Jasmine, hawthorn and white stone-fruit aromas lift from the glass. On the bright palate, refreshing acidity balances creamy Granny Smith apple and tangerine zest, while small continuous bubbles lend finesse. A beeswax note signals the close.

Elderflower, tomato leaf and citrus aromas delicately float out of the glass on this fragrant white. On the elegant linear palate, bright acidity accompanies juicy grapefruit, white peach and honeydew melon alongside a hint of wild herb. A tangy mineral note signals the close.

This deep violet-colored wine offers an enticing whiff of cherry pie on the nose. Strong acidity balances its heavy tannins while cherry, strawberry, orange zest, violet and vanilla flavors power on into a bright, lingering finish.

Bright and energetic aromas of pomegranate, light thyme, marjoram and rose petals show on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard that lies near the Santa Ynez River. Strong herbs show on the palate, from oregano to wild mint, giving depth to the mulberry flavors. It's all framed by persistent, well integrated acidity.

Enticing aromas of ripe dark-skinned berry, new leather, mocha and a hint of pressed violet emerge from the glass. The structured, savory palate offers black cherry jam, espresso, star anise and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2025.

This is a rare look at the original vines planted by Richard Sanford and Michael Benedict in the 1970s. Aromas of candied strawberry and red currant lead into a dry palate, where cranberry, rose petal, thyme and dried sagebrush arise. The integrated acidity and tannic structure are most compelling, along with the lingering hint of dried flowers.
designation: Founders' Vines Single Block Estate Grown

description: This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot opens with aromas of black currant, star anise and a whiff of incense. It's savory and elegant, doling out flavors of dried black cherry, raspberry jam, white pepper and licorice. Fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity provide balanced support. Enjoy through 2027.

Brawny in generous fruit and tannin, this 100% varietal wine is from a low-yielding vineyard at elevation. Soft layers of black cherry, clove and a welcome helping of dried herb combine effortlessly on the full-bodied palate to offer complexity and concentrated flavor.

This elegant, savory sparkler opens with inviting aromas of dried wildflower, mature orchard fruit and a yeasty whiff of bread dough. On the creamy palate, a soft mousse accompanies yellow apple, white peach and citrus zest alongside accents of dried herb and a hint of ginger.

This wine is a blend of 48% Cabernet Sauvignon and 38% Merlot, with the balance Malbec and Petit Verdot. Aromas of mushroom, dried herb, wet gravel, spice and cherry lead to ripe cherry and soy flavors. The palate brings a sense of elegance and appeal.

This Pinot Noir-based rosé offers ripe notes of almost candied strawberries, raspberries and watermelons, with a strawberry leaf finish. The fruit sweetness on the palate is weighty but the acidity keeps things under control.
Honey-dipped pineapple and guava, with a touch of fig give this wine a fruity midpalate. This has a moderate structure and a lingering note of anise.
Thick and oaky, this estate wine evokes caramel and pineapple-upside-down cake—its texture lushly unctuous and rich.
This wine is something of a disappointment for such a prestigious appellation. A red fruit flavor, gentle tannins and spice contrast with a tough, extracted texture that lingers.
designation: Laurent Dufouleur Aux Vignes-Rondes Premier Cru

description: A touch of spice gives an edge to the bright, crisp texture of this wine. It offers freshness, lively acidity and immediate drinkability. Enjoy it now.
designation: Domaine des Coteaux du Val Lamartinien Les Charmes

description: This 100% varietal wine hails from Olsen Brothers vineyard in Yakima Valley and Upland vineyard on Snipes Mountain. The aromas leap from the glass, suggesting satsuma orange peel, jasmine, green herb and plum. They lead to plush red and purple fruit flavors, with prominent satsuma peel notes on the finish. It shows delightful purity.
Brawny and full bodied, this earthy wine shows a generosity of forest floor, cardamom and cola, before unveiling integrated layers of bright strawberry and citrus.

This spent 18 months in French oak and another three years in bottle. Yet despite its age, it looks and drinks quite young, perhaps because it is sealed with a glass cap. There's even a whiff of yeast on the nose, and the tart, fresh fruit includes blood orange, cranberry and raspberry notes. It's firmly tannic and may hold its youthful freshness considerably longer.

Rambling hints of caramel and smoked nut accent zesty wild strawberry and bramble berry in this invigorating light-footed Trollinger. It's a thirst-quenching fruity wine, elevated by hints of dark granite and ripe finely edged tannins. Drink now through 2023.

Smoky earthen notes of crushed stone and salt accent crisp pineapple and nectarine notes here. While dry and lean in style, a kiss of residual sugar accentuates its juicy, mouthwatering feel. Bristling lime and tangerine acidity leads a long, lip-smacking finish rimmed with salty minerals.

Deep garnet to the eye, this wine offers aromas of raspberry, blueberry and smoked meat. Soft and silky tannins provide the setting for flavors of cherry, pomegranate, roasted meat, coffee bean and white chocolate, with a whiff of smoke on the finish.

This is a compelling take on a sometimes simply fruity and lively varietal from risk-taking winemaker Kevin Luther. It's medium bodied, well balanced and has a complexity in the aromas and flavors that is fascinating to taste. It blends tasty cherry and raspberry notes with accents of tamarind, black tea and clove.

Whiffs of honey and saffron accent boldly concentrated flavors of apricot and grapefruit in this pristine dry Riesling. While medium bodied in style, it's silky and expansive in mouthfeel. Bracing lime acidity lends a nervous tension to the finish. Enjoy now through 2023.

This bottling comes from what was once Verna's Vineyard, whose new owner employed Drake Whitcraft for this bottling. Quite dark for a Pinot Noir, it shows very concentrated blackberry sorbet, strong mint, cola and vanilla bean aromas on the nose. The palate is lush and thick with boysenberry paste, clove, star anise and vanilla dust flavors.

Fleshy, almost tropical notes of honeydew and papaya are offset by stony minerals and fresh grapefruit acidity here. An excellent value for such an elegant wine, it's a voluptuously textured yet deftly balanced Riesling. The finish is lean and intently mineral. At peak now through 2022 but should hold further too.

Part of a range of limited-edition Champagnes created for artist André Saraiva, this is a deliciously crisp and dry wine. It still has freshness, although hints of yeast add complexity. Drink now, or let it age until 2020.

Although not labeled as such, this is a Blanc de Blancs. It is a rich while intensely mineral wine, aged for four years after bottling. That gives the wine richness and enhances the texture, producing a well-structured, taut wine that is ready to drink.

This stainless-steel fermented wine is monumentally light in profile and easy to love. Refreshing waves of watermelon, strawberry and dried rose petal will conjure happy memories of footloose and fancy free days at the beach.

Partially fermented in wood, this wine dominated by Chardonnay is crisp, taut, tense and very mineral in texture. It is obviously young, emphasizing freshness and tart citrus flavors. However, it will soften to give a rounder and richer wine. Drink from 2020.

A touch of honey lends delicate sweetness to crisp white grapefruit in this easy-drinking off-dry wine. It's juicy and fruity but accented by savory notes of earth, dried thyme and lemongrass, too. The finish is moderately long, marked by bitter orange zest and a touch of green herbs.

This big, robust wine blends spicy oak aromas and flavors with saturated blackberry and blueberry for a concentrated and layered effect. Made from Cabernet Sauvignon, Petite Sirah and old-vine Zinfandel, it is full bodied, moderately tannic and quite mouthfilling in texture.

From a site first planted in 1915, this is a tiny production of wine that's well worth seeking out. It speaks to old-vine dusty spice and dried sage, its texture softly beguiling and boldly full-bodied. It offers plenty of vigor and power.

Get ready for a different take on Chardonnay in this earthy, layered wine. It has an unusually deep golden color, mature aromas like baked apples and a nutty, honeyed flavor akin to that of a late-harvest dessert wine. The flavors develop nicely with each sip and reveal subtleties of fruit and mineral that linger on the finish.
Cherry and strawberry aromas carry a warm spice undercurrent. The palate is lean and simplistic in its racy red-currant tone, with a mild grip of grainy tannins offering support.

Pumpkin, root beer and creamy berry aromas are frankly a touch less than fresh. This vintage rosé is narrow and wanting, with an oxidized character infiltrating sour plum and cherry flavors. A skins-like feel and mild oxidized flavors control the finish.
This wine epitomizes the crisp, herbal and grassy whites of Gascony. Cool with apricot and pineapple flavors, this blend is instantly refreshing and ready to drink now.

Rather light in the glass, this bottling shows cherry juice, smoke, caramel and mint on the nose. The palate delivers acid, but in a slightly weird way, carrying flavors of extracted cherry and berry along with dark spice.
This fruity wine has easy tannins and plenty of acidity to freshen the ripe Syrah and Touriga Nacional. The wine is softly textured and ready to drink.

A tad cloudy in the glass, this proprietary blend shows smashed blackberry, crushed thyme and grape-seed aromas on the nose. It's quite tangy and chalky on the palate, with strong black-plum-skin flavors.

Made entirely with organically cultivated Nero d'Avola grapes, this opens with aromas of dark berry and underbrush. The simple palate offers black-cherry jam and star anise alongside velvety tannins. Drink soon.

This wine's fresh asphalt, oak and green berry and plum aromas lead to a dense, chewy palate full of peppery, baked black fruit flavor. The finish is marked by gamy notes, heat, herbal berry flavors and a hint of chocolate.
Vivid cherry and strawberry flavors give a cheery personality to this generous wine. It smells bright and fruity, and tastes more ripe, showing light spicy accents and a good focus on fruit.
Softly ripe, this warm wine is rich in spice as well as red-berry fruits. The texture is zesty, crisp and clean, with a lively aftertaste. Drink now.
Dark in color and showing sediment, this white is austere on the nose—a combination of steely and floral, with subtle flavors of green apple and potato.

Vila Santa is the name of the Portugal Ramos winery in Estremoz. The wine is soft and rounded, with apple and ripe Bartlett pear flavors. It has zesty lime notes and a fresh, crisp aftertaste. Drink now.

Toast, butter, lemon spray and a hint of smoke show on the nose of this widely available and reliable wine. It's fresh and zesty on the palate with lime peels and Meyer lemon juice, yet there are also creamy butter and blanched almond flavors to round out the palate.

With a bold purple color and aromas of dark berry fruits and cassis, this is a lusty Bonarda with a jammy palate bolstered by firm acidity. Roasted peppery black-fruit flavors are beefy and a touch hot on the finish.

Lemongrass, grapefruit peel and tonic are refreshing and clean on the nose. The lithe palate shows a bit more ripeness, with juicy peach on the fore that turns more lean and tart on the finish. Overall, this is quite enjoyable for its short burst of power.

Producer Jean-Bernard Larrieu describes this unfiltered wine from organically grown grapes bottled without sulfur as libre or natural. It has a certain oxidative character with a touch of honey and smooth yellow fruit. Drink now.
The high proportion of Syrah (55%) in this wine has given it intense acidity and a tight, crisp and perfumed character. It is refreshing, lively, packed with fruit and ready to drink.

Bright lemon and crisp green apple immediately appear on the nose. The palate takes up the lemon theme and adds extra zestiness, while also hinting at a richer riper more generous and juicy fruitiness. This is clean cut, dry and utterly refreshing, with a kind of stony precision. Lovely. Drink now through 2028.

A crisp texture and rather full body carry subtle spice and lean dry fruit flavors in this nicely reserved and complex wine. Apple skin, lemon zest and hints of toasted almond carry the palate and linger on the finish.

Made from a family estate in the eastern wilds of Napa Valley, this small-production red is fermented in a concrete tank and aged in neutral oak. It retains ebullient freshness and focus, its fruit a mix of grape, cherry and plum. Around the edges are floral aromas and superb mineral characteristics.

Concentrated black-fruit aromas are dark and meaty. A tight, pure, sinewy body is home to lightly salty flavors of plum, blackberry and natural spices. A direct focused finish is what Zuccardi is seeking from Poligonos, a line of cement-made wines with zero oak. This one hails from San Pablo, one of the highest vineyard areas in the Uco Valley. Drink through 2026.
designation: Poligonos del Valle de Uco San Pablo

description: Ripe and round, this generous semisweet wine is quite different from the average Grigio. It has ripe apple and pear aromas, concentrated fruit and light spice flavors, a broad, almost thick texture and lingering finish.

Deeply layered spice-rack aromas of clove and star anise lift the mulberry fruit on the nose of this bottling from a vineyard on the appellation's westernmost point. Tarragon and marjoram flavors give depth to elderberry and black-plum-skin backdrop, which proves rather elegant.

Pronounced in perfume, this supple red offers intense aromas of ripe black cherry and berry offset by a crush of stone and earth notes. It's full bodied, powerful and mouthfilling but framed by crisp red cherry acidity and chalky, persistent tannins. Delicious already but should improve through 2030 and hold further.

Whispers of toast, smoked garrigue and earth juxtapose luscious black cherry and plum in this potent red. Made from 98% Grenache with just a splash of Syrah, it's rich and velvety on the palate but has a spicy kick and touch of minerality that lend balance. Finishes long on firm but chalky tannins. Ready now but should hold nicely through 2026.
designation: Domaine de Longue Toque Hommage à Gabriel Meffre

description: Despite the crazy round-based bottle that you can't really put anywhere, Kripta continues to rank as one of Spain's most consistently excellent Cavas. In this vintage, vanilla and yeasty aromas are mature and heady. The palate offers white fruit acidity offset by notes of toasty bread, spiced apple and pear. These tones linger on the supremely smooth finish. Drink now.
designation: Kripta Gran Reserva Brut Nature 40 Anys

description: While intensely ripe and rich, there's a delicate lift of minerality that freshens this blend of Grenache and Syrah. Blackberry and cherry preserve flavors are rounded and densely concentrated but finessed by silky tannins and accents of spice and olive. This is a polished but powerful wine to enjoy now–2028.

Bright and radiant aromas of cherry, strawberry and raspberry meet with rose petals, spice cake and a touch of bubblegum on the nose of this bottling by winemaker Angela Osborne. There is firm structure to the palate at first, then comes tart cherry and hibiscus flavors—altogether quite refreshing.

Juicy black fruit meets powerfully structured tannins and concentrated flavor in this wine, blended with 10% Petit Verdot, 5% Cabernet Franc and 3% Merlot. Sizable oak supports layers of black cherry and currant, along with tense, underlying acidity. Enjoy 2025–2030.

This elegantly structured white offers aromas of spring flower and ripe orchard fruit. Savory and enveloping, the polished palate offers baked apple, mature pear, toast and vanilla alongside a candied-lemon-zest note.
Aromas evoking grapefruit, tropical fruit and tomato leaf flow over to the full-bodied enveloping palate along with green melon and steely mineral. Fresh acidity lifts the finish.

Full of balanced fruit, this wine is rich with plenty of underlying dry botrytis. Apricot, white peach and spice flavors partner with a warm, generous structure. The wine will develop well and will be ready from 2021.

With 90% Merlot, this is a rich, dense wine. Its alcohol shows in the pepper and rich spice character and in the dark, extracted flavors. Happily, plenty of ripe black-plum fruit from the 130-acre organic estate gives the wine potential balance. Drink from 2021.

This ripe, spicy wine shows indications of wood aging. At the same time it offers plenty of fruit, bright acidity and forward black-currant flavors. Made from two-thirds Merlot and one-third Cabernet Sauvignon, the wine has good potential. Drink from 2021.

From the young vines of this Graves classed-growth property, this wine shares some of the impressive structure and aging potential as the Grand Vin of the estate. It is ripe, juicy with grapefruit and tropical flavors balanced with spice from wood aging. Drink from 2021.

Made in the traditional method, this 100% Pinot Noir is a bright straw color, dry and tangy, with excellent length and precision. The flavors and color don't suggest Pinot Noir but might actually be mistaken for a blanc de blancs, except for a light lick of dark chocolate that trails the finish.
designation: La Cantera Vineyard Blanc de Noirs Brut

description: Almost all Pinot Noir, with just 5% Chardonnay, this méthode Champenoise wine was barrel fermented and spent 20 months en tirage. It's a tawny gold and opens with a slightly earthy aroma that evolves into a complex mash-up of toast, butter, coffee grounds and tart fruits. The color and flavors suggest it's in a prime drinking window.

Aromas of fresh stone fruit and sea breeze waft from the glass in this Chardonnay that see time in 85% second- and third-use French barrels, with the reminder new. It's silken and luscious on the palate, with ripe fruit tones held in check by a current of tangy crushed minerals and delicate vanilla.
Underbrush, red berry and leather aromas unfold in the glass. The taut palate shows cranberry, clove, star anise and a crushed sage note alongside firm tannins that grip the finish. Drink 2021–2028.

Made entirely with Aglianico, this savory rosato delivers aromas and flavors of wild raspberry, creamy white peach, Mediterranean brush and a stony mineral note. Tangy acidity gives it a clean, fresh finish.

Rich aromas of blackberry jam, roasted meats and gravel are very well integrated on the nose of this bottling. The palate deftly balances pepper and charred meats with a strong black-currant core, adding touches of gravel and tobacco leaf toward the finish.

Cidery apple aromas come with a hint of barrel smoke. A medium-to-full palate offers adequate acidity, while this older-vintage Chardonnay tastes of generic white fruit, bitter oak and honeyed sweetness. A slight sticky finish is less than fresh.

This wine is initially a bit reductive. It veers towards the green spectrum, showing notes of bell pepper, tomato leaf and grapefruit. There's a biting, slightly underripe quality to the acidity and that is ultimately balanced out by a slightly rounded texture. It finishes on a citrusy tang.
With an ashy undercurrent of char and smoke, this wine offers medium-bodied layers of dried cherry and leather, finishing with a lasting note of black pepper.

Fruity but not bombastically so, notes of apple, guava and peach lead into a palate that is creamy-textured thanks to some time spent on lees. The palate is back by enough acidity to remain refreshing yet the finish is abrupt.
This wine balances loads of peach and pineapple tones with a touch of green bell pepper. The palate is a bit disjointed, with the ripe fruit and bright acidity not quite gelling.

Slightly oxidized berry and prune aromas include overt oak and a more vague hint of asphalt. A full, chunky, sticky palate delivers a mix of herbal berry flavors and oak-based clove, and that's more or less how this finishes.

Honeyed richness is immediately apparent on the nose. The palate continues in the same rich, golden and almost viscous vein. Musky flavors recall dried fruit such as sultana and dried apricot, but a spike of fresh lemon balances this sweet wine that veers far into dessert territory. It's still developing but will drink well until 2025 at least.

From one of the founding Margaret River estates, Cape Mentelle's wines tend to be ultrapolished, classy specimens with nary a hair out of place—unsurprising considering they're now owned by luxury brand Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy. The 2013 Cab exemplifies this finesse while also starting to show how well Margaret River Cab can age. The currant fruit is getting a little raisiny, and there's vegetal leafy tones, charred wood, black licorice, dusting polish and a soy sauce-seaweed salinity. Texturally this is still tightly wound, bordering on austere, with crisp acidity and ultrafine tannins. Drink now–2025.

Technically dry yet with enough residual sweetness to round its sharp edges, this is a juicy and delightful wine. Fresh, tangy citrus, peach and melon flavors are all in play—ripe and beautifully melded. The acidity is clean and refreshing, with no chalkiness.

Aromas of cherry kirsch and framboise meet with star anise, allspice and a welcoming French toast element on the nose of this bottling from a new producer based in Monterey. The palate is very fresh and spicy, with ginger snaps, tart pomegranate and cranberry flavors, riding an acidity that simmers low and long.

This beautifully pale-pink-colored wine is crisp and dry, very much in the house style. Raspberries and tight acidity are part of a cool, tangy wine that is zesty and mineral textured. This bottling is still young, and will be better from the end of 2018.

This wine shows touches of passion fruit, bitter fir honey andripe peach. These elements unite on nose and palate of this luscious, sweet wine. Ripe lemon freshness and citrus oil set a balancing counterpoint that defines the purity of the fruit even more. Lovely now, it will develop further. Drink now–2028.

As with all this winery's reds, there's substantial extract here, giving deep color, dense flavors, and chewy tannins. Its blueberry and black cherry fruit is accented by earthy mushroom notes. It makes a strong case for growing Malbec in Southern Oregon, where Tempranillo and Cabernet Franc also shine.

No one in Oregon is more dedicated to this grape than Leah Jørgensen, and nowhere does it pay off better than in her entry-level bottling. A baseline of deep, saturated blue fruit carries the taster into a lush mix of coffee, pepper, tobacco and dusty tannins. The depth and concentration put most $25 reds to shame.

A muted nose of toasted oak and brioche leads to an expansive and fleshy midpalate of apple and peach in this moderately structured, medium-bodied and balanced wine. The finish is lingering and vibrantly bright in acidity.

In keeping with the style of this domaine, the emphasis here is on fruit rather than the tannins associated with this appellation. This wine comes from a two vineyards and is packed with red-cherry fruit. Its tannins are there but gentle and right at the core of this perfumed wine. It is young and will need plenty of time, so drink from 2022.

This is made from 82% Merlot, with the balance Cabernet Franc (14%) and Petit Verdot from Southwind, Stone Tree and Dionysus vineyards. Raspberry compote, fresh flower and barrel spice aromas lead to full-bodied, no-holds-barred fruit flavors that coat the palate from end to end, backed by lightly grainy tannins. The style is ripe and rich, but so is the vintage it comes from.

Honeysuckle, orange blossom, pear, wild herb and apple aromas follow over to the palate along with tangy nectarine and beeswax. It's refreshingly crisp in bright acidity, with a savory mineral note that lingers on the close.
This medium-bodied wine has an earthy, smoky aroma followed by tangy lemon flavors and figgy, earthy accents. It has a crisp mouth-cleansing texture.

Papaya, yellow melon and orange cream aromas are front and center on the nose of this rich, abundant Chardonnay, with a hint of fresh hay in the background. The palate is similarly rich and ripe, with low acidity and a weight to the midpalate that lingers through to the soft close.

Aromas of road tar, blackberry and rubber are a touch chemical but not bad. A raw palate with rubbery tannins is home to generic plum and berry flavors. A dry rubbery-feeling finish is appropriate for this everyday Tempranillo.

This ruby colored blend opens with aromas of poblano pepper, followed by black raspberry, red currant and old, dusty wood. The tannins are present and astringent on the palate, just barely balanced by lazy acidity. Ripe cherry, vanilla and nutmeg flavors turns tart on the cranberry finish.

Powdery, slightly soapy aromas lack fruit and freshness. In the mouth, this rosé of Bobal is round and in decent shape, but with only mild acidity. Nonspecific orange and nectarine flavors finish short, without cleansing power.
designation: Hoya de Cadenas Bobal Single Estate

description: Earthy plum, cherry, spice and tobacco aromas are familiar to Rioja. A high-acid medium-bodied palate is austere and hard as nails. Tart red-fruit flavors finish racy and fiery, with excess gas in the tank.
Jasmine, white peach and chamomile hints merge together in this. The linear palate offers grapefruit and Bosc pear notes alongside bright acidity that leaves a refreshing finish.
region_1: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico

description: Made from 90% Sangiovese and 10% Colorino, this has violet and kitchen spice aromas. The medium-bodied palate shows red cherry, raspberry jam and clove notes alongside fresh acidity and lithe tannins. Drink through 2020.

Subtle black-skinned berry, baking spice and white pepper aromas come together in this. The savory palate doles out ripe black plum, star anise and tangerine zest notes alongside pliant tannins. Drink through 2021.

This smartly named rosé is a beautiful shade of pink, and sports aromas of raspberry, melon and flint. The flavors are subtle and soft, with watermelon, strawberry and tangerine touches, proving easy to like and mellow.

The aromas pop, with notes of green flower, bountiful citrus peel, fresh herb, kiwi and scooped honeydew melon. The broad feeling but lighter styled kiwi flavors bring appeal, with a pink-grapefruit snap on the finish.

A deep purple color and beefy berry aromas give this Malbec up-front strength. In the mouth, this is alert due to prodding acidity. Cherry, plum and berry flavors are textbook, while this is saucy tasting on a direct finish.
This Garnacha's jammy aromas of prune and raisin suggest overripeness. It's full bodied but short on acidity. And it tastes like it smells: raisiny, with cassis notes.
This wine's game, baking spice and Band Aid aromas are followed by cherry and medicine cabinet flavors. It doesn't all come together.

This wine's generic berry aromas are earthy and a touch baked, with clove and chocolate notes. The palate is dense and blocky, with leafy berry and chocolate flavors that finish with a residual minty note.
Sweet spice and potpourri grace the black plum core of this accessible wine. It's medium in acidity and soft in tannin, with a clean, fruit-forward finish. Drink now.
Made with organically grown grapes, this opens with aromas suggesting jasmine and tropical fruit. On the fresh simple palate, bright acidity accompanies candied citrus and ripe green melon.
This soft, off-dry, fruity wine has the typical light prickle of a young Vinho Verde. It's crisp and clean, with attractive apple and lemon sherbet flavors. Drink now.

Butterscotch and hazelnut aromas make for a very creamy and yet not overblown nose on this bottling. It's zesty on the palate with strong lime and lemon-rind flavors, yet the core remains the clarified butter, hazelnut and cashew flavors, leading into a crème brûlée finish.

A good deal of oak is notable on a nose with savory aromas of beef soup along with berry-fruit scents and a hint of prune. A full chunky palate shows rubbery tannins, while this tastes of plum, savory berry, prune, salt and spice. A steady finish doesn't deviate from this Tempranillo's core flavors. Drink through 2035.

Ripe aromas of blackberry, prune, raisin and oak spice come together with aplomb. A full-bodied palate with controlled weight is the vessel for toasty flavors of oak, vanilla, mocha and baked black fruits. A solid finish with latent acidity is a worthy conclusion to this fully oaked Tempranillo. Drink through 2027.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: This is a delightfully delicious and immensely quaffable wine, made from a majority of whole cluster-pressed, estate-grown grapes that were fermented in stainless steel. It is light in body and lively in a dried herb tone, with crisp, inviting flavors of tangerine, white peach and watermelon.

This blend of Petite Sirah, Petit Verdot and Merlot is aged in new French and American oak two times (once before blending, and once after) to produce a whopper of a wine. Aromas of black cherry, toffee and vanilla are leveled by gravel and fresh raspberry. The rich sip reveals scorched caramel, roasted coffee beans and charred black-currant flavors.

Gentle notes of peach float from the glass. The palate follows that with a soft, pliable, gentle peachiness, couched in medium sweetness and countered by some lemon freshness. The finish is surprisingly sprightly and also tinged by that lovely lemon zestiness.

This blend of 80% Grenache, 19% Syrah and 1% Mourvèdre is easygoing, likable and fit for many occasions and meals, just like a good Châteauneuf-du-Pape. Inviting aromas of plump cherry, macerated strawberry and vanilla lead into a palate loaded with cherries and vanilla ice cream flavors, finishing on a touch of caramel.

Fruit purity and power combine in this opulent but elegant wine. Ripe black plum and boysenberry flavors are buoyant, but shards of crushed mineral and a crystalline freshness abound as well. The finish extends on fine, persistent tannins. Ready now but should improve through 2028.

This powerful, dense wine is currently dominated by its rich tannins. It has weight both from the structure and the ripe berry fruits that are developing. With the weight of the vintage, it will turn into an opulent wine. Drink from 2023.

Hints of green olive, balsamic and soy sauce allude to the 30% Syrah in this supple, savory marriage of Grenache and Syrah. It's a full-bodied, unctuously concentrated wine plush with blackberry flavor. Fresh acidity and ripe, sinewy tannins extend the finish. Drinks well already but should improve through 2028.

Initial notes of smoke and crushed earth fade with aeration revealing prettier tones of summer blackberry and cherry. A blend of 80% Grenache and 20% Mourvèdre, this is a rich, voluminous wine marked by deep fruit character and a smoky, meaty, umami undertone. Fresh but moderate acidity lends lift on the finish. Enjoy now–2028.

This vineyard-designate shows off the ample richness of the site and appellation, offering fulsome, exotic flavors of guava and fig. The ripeness of the fruit finds its complement in equally ample acidity that refreshes and lingers on the finish.

The d'Arfeuille family, also owners of vineyards in Saint-Émilion, have produced a richly juicy wine from this 20-acre estate. It's a rich wine with fine tannins, a smoky character, strongly structured and with excellent potential. Drink from 2023.
Perfumed in lavender and sage, this is a richly supple Kosher wine, exuberantly laced in dried herb and dark chocolate with a full-bodied background of polished tannin.
This wine's light aromas suggest lemon curd, apples, pears and white flowers. The palate is full bodied, bringing both weight and grace, with stone fruit flavors that linger on the finish.

This powerfully extracted Syrah-dominant wine is full of rich, ripe black-cherry and blackberry flavors. It's a muscular, almost ruddy wine but balanced by sharp, angular hits of acidity and brambly, spicy complexities. The finish is long, marked by firm, taut tannins. Enjoy now–2025.

While full bodied and richly concentrated, this wine's brambleberry and plum palate has a crisp, cutting character. It's silky and luscious yet balanced by fresh acidity and ripe but grippy tannins. The finish lingers on hints of sweet spice and crushed granite. Drink now–2025.
Aromas of menthol, oak-driven spice and dark-skinned berry slowly take shape on this. The chewy savory palate doles out plum, steeped wild cherry, licorice and mocha alongside fine-grained tannins.
Plush and textured, with tasty, crushed berry-like fruit, this has hints of stems but finishes with richer notes of chocolate wafer and toasted almonds. It was aged in 30% new French oak.

Sea salt, preserved lemons, pan-seared apples, plumeria and honeysuckle show on the engaging nose of this bottling from a preferred block in this historic vineyard. The palate plays to the savory side of Chardonnay, offering an oily texture that carries flavors of cashew and marmalade.

In Hentley Farm's characteristically muscular style, this Shiraz dominant blend shows notes of ripe dark fruit, dusting polish, vanilla and notable oak-driven spices. The rich, full-bodied palate comes with firm, chewy tannins, juicy fruit and a savory finish. In it for the long haul, this wine needs to be cellared for the next few years at least. Drink 2020–2038.

From a three-block section of the vineyard, this wine is high-toned in rhubarb and pomegranate. The texture is grainy and complex, layered nicely with a lasting note of plush, velvety black cherry and fresh acidity.

There is a honeydew rind tightness and a lemon curd opulence to the nose of this bottling from a vineyard planted in 1997, along with chalk and lemongrass aromas. The palate starts with strong grip and then opens with tart lime skin and a hint of butter—very refreshing.

Tart cranberry and pomegranate fruit is front and center in this wine, streaked with an herbed butter accent. Barrel aged for a year in 30% new French oak, it's smooth and silky in feel. The tannins are somewhat astringent but should soften in time.

Plum and berry aromas are solid but nothing beyond ordinary for Cabernet. A tannic, pulling palate is drying, while this tastes woody more than fruity. Overall, this is fine but highly generic and overoaked for what it is.

Aromas of yellow apple, toasted nut and a yeasty whiff of bread crust come together on this. The aromas carry over to the lean palate along with a dollop of vanilla and a hint of bitter walnut. Bright acidity and vigorous, steely bubbles provide the vivacious backdrop.

Produced in a vineyard at the base of the hill of Saint-Émilion, this accessible wine is soft, ripe and fruity. It has a generous texture from the vintage and bold black fruits spiced with wood aging. Drink from 2019.

This perfumed wine is full of fruit and with an attractive aromatic character from the Muscadelle in the blend. The dominant Sauvignon Blanc gives herbal crispness to the bright aftertaste. Drink now.
Yeasty, bready aromas include a not-shy note of scrambled eggs. A pulpy palate is balanced but doesn't stir much interest. Stone fruit and mild citrus flavors are highly basic.

This has subdued aromas of chamomile flower, yellow apple and a whiff of toasted bread. On the palate, bright acidity lifts toast, mature yellow apple, bitter walnut and a candied citrus note alongside vivacious bubbles.
Delicate and light, this wine has floral and red-cherry aromas, subtle berry and cherry flavors and good acidity. It tastes absolutely clean and fresh—just what most people want in a rosé.
Mature yellow apple and bread crust aromas carry over to the lively palate along with bitter walnut and a vanilla note. Fresh acidity and an elegant mousse provide the framework.
Broad, clean aromas of melon, mango and guava are cut by a chalky minerality on the nose of this bottling. Bright, tropical flavors on the palate glide along a river of fresh acidity.

A rich and ripe style of Cab, this bottling starts with almost sweet-smelling aromas of black cherry, blackberry and toasted oak. Framed by a chalky mouthfeel, the palate offers tangy flavors of blackberry alongside savory touches of pepper and dried flowers.

Made from 52% Cabernet Franc and 48% Zinfandel from an estate site, this is a burly, pleasingly round and rich wine, layered in dark chocolate, blackberry and leather. The finishing touches include swathes of lingering cinnamon and toasted oak.

This wine comes from a four-acre parcel of stony soil. Closed and tight as is typical of young Pouilly Fumé, it promises rich white fruits for the future. Ripe and well structured, it will be ready to drink from 2020.

A blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon from Cévennes, 30% Grenache and 20% Syrah from Southern Rhône, this opens with a gamy, rustic bouquet of iron, leather, black plum and boysenberry. It's gripping and tight on the palate, with a lingering cured-meat character through the close.
Baked cherry and warm spice tones carry this soft, plush red. There's a bit of midpalate heft to carry it along, yet this is ultimately a straightforward, easy pour.

This is rich and decadent from the start, offering aromas and flavors of rich berry preserves, raspberry sauce and sweet oaky spice throughout. It's smooth and round on the palate, with just enough tannic structure to keep the abundant fruit flavors from feeling too dense or heavy.

This dense, plummy wine looks thick in the glass, with streaky purple legs. Bubble gum spice, menthol and blackberry-jam aromas lead to a tart dark-cherry palate. While slightly thick in feel, bright acidity and enveloping tannins offer a bit of structure to balance things out.

This crisply textured wine with its red-berry fruits is easy to drink when young. Its acidity and juicy character are immediately attractive, with a touch of tannins keeping everything together. Drink now.
Crisp citrus and green pear aromas translate to the light-bodied palate. This is bright and simple, perfect for easy enjoyment.

Earthy aromas of truffle, new leather and underbrush mingle with whiffs of dark-skinned fruit in this wine. The rounded, full-bodied palate offers dried cherry and star anise notes framed in polished tannins.

This is likely to become a very popular wine, thanks to an inviting nose of lemon candy, white peach, pineapple, plumeria and a hint of guava, all leveled by a chalky minerality. The palate is zippy and tense, yet also somewhat crowd-pleasingly sweet with ripe apple and pear flavors.

Juicy, fruity and with a good balance between acidity and crisp apple flavors, this wine is ripe and full of fruitiness. It has a zesty tang as well as some minerality that balances the great fruit. Drink now.
This blend of Grenache and Syrah is soft and bright, with plenty of red-berry and currant flavors. Its fruitiness and balanced acidity make for an immediately attractive, easy wine. Drink now.

This wine is dark and rich but also very approachable for this notoriously tannic varietal. The tannins are moderate and the blackberry and blueberry flavors so concentrated that they balance out the tannins and make the mouth feel velvety.

Made entirely from organically farmed Sangiovese, this opens with dark-skinned berry and baking spice aromas, with an earthy hint of underbrush. The straightforward, juicy palate offers red plum, clove and cinnamon touches alongside polished tannins. Enjoy soon.

Earth, white currant and dried pear notes make for an intriguing nose. A touch of flint creates a smoky edge that carries onto the dry, concentrated palate where pear and currant are joined by bright, tart lemon. The finish is superclean, lip-smacking and dry.

Domaine Drouhin Oregon's new Eola-Amity wine continues to impress. Supple, seductive and rippled with kiwi, apple, citrus and melon flavors, it's nicely ripe and well melded. The barrel influence is modest, which perfectly suits fruit this good.

Ripe, honeyed pear notes on the nose lead onto a palate rich with fruit that is still dry. Lemony briskness frames the rich fruit notes on a concentrated, vivid body. Pear and lemon play off each other all the way on the long, dry finish.

Rich black fruit meets with a touch of roasted lamb and rosemary on the classic nose of this Syrah, which was planted in 1989 as a memorial for Fess Parker's late son-in-law. The gamy qualities are much stronger on the sip, with charred lamb and more savory herbs, yet the backdrop is all boysenberry.

Ripe, juicy apple notes on the nose have an almost spicy tang of grapefruit. The palate adds yellow plum, oranges and lemon to this fruitiness, brimming with freshness on the light but fulsome body. It finishes dry and fresh.
designation: Clos de la Treille Grand Cru Brand

description: Russet-pear peel with earthy and fruity notes dominates the nose. The palate comes in with dreamy sweetness, highlighted and framed with ripe lemon freshness, creating a tension between those two entirely fruit-driven poles. The finish is medium sweet but also refreshing and long.

Sophisticated in flavor and extremely smooth in texture, this high-elevation wine is easy to enjoy while also offering interesting nuances of fig and black pepper in the aroma, and plump plum and raspberry on the palate. It's another excellent wine from the very consistent Cedarville property.

Vibrant, vivid aromas of perfectly ripe dark cherry, blackberry and cranberry are covered in a delicate dusting of wet limestone and fresh herbs on the nose. The palate is all about texture, walking a tightrope between penetrating, juicy lushness and powdered, stony grip.

Ripe, sweet late-harvest fruits are the secret behind this poised wine. It is perfumed, packed with exotic fruits, honey and a touch of lemon marmalade. Acidity shoots through the wine, so it is not cloying. Rather it is well balanced, fresh and sweet at the same time. Drink from 2019.

Well-integrated aromas of clove, star anise, cola and suave black cherry show on the nose of this bottling from the southernmost vineyard currently used by winemaker Coby Parker-Garcia. Dark cherry flavors meet with sarsaparilla and cola on the rich, brawny palate.

Woodland berry, blue flower, forest floor, truffle and menthol aromas take center stage on this polished red.
