Cool, murky berry aromas are gamy. A blast of fruitiness propels a big palate loaded with spicy chocolaty oak. Bold berry flavors are short-lasting on a tight, intense finish. Crianzas are made to drink young, but this will benefit from more aging; drink through 2028.
Aromas of baked plum, fig and mocha lead the nose. The concentrated, full-bodied palate delivers blackberry jam, vanilla, clove and black pepper alongside velvety tannins.
Alluring aromas of ripe dark-skinned berry, pipe tobacco and leather emerge from the glass. The hearty palate delivers ripe black plum, fig, white pepper and cinnamon alongside polished tannins.

An alluring spicy aroma and generous, opulent fruit flavors pack this full-bodied wine with pleasure. It has a velvety, almost-thick texture, blackberry, blueberry and oak spice flavors that are concentrated and deep, plus a good structure of fine-grained tannins.

Otago veteran Grant Taylor's single vineyard wines are an excellent deep dive into Otago's varied terroirs. This vintage of Bannockburn is particularly pretty and approachable, and less rich than the Gibbston. Heady notes of raspberry, vanilla, clove and white pepper envelop the senses. The bright, tart berries continue on the palate where the tightly wound, sinewy tannins are balanced by crunchy acidity. Drink now–2028.

An amazing floral aroma lights up this supersweet and fortified red wine before vivid, ripe and grapey flavors flood the palate and a good viscous texture coats the sides of the mouth. It's ultrarich, decadent and syrupy.
Mature dark fruit, leather and cooking spice aromas come together on this. The full-bodied, polished palate offers blackberry jam, tobacco and clove alongside fine-grained tannins.
Burly yet structured, this robust varietal wine, blended with 3% Cabernet Franc, is supple with underlying grip. Big boned in style, it offers a wealth of bold cassis, dark cherry and sage.

Black olive marks the opening of this soft, spicy and ripe wine, well integrated in its marriage of fruit, acidity and oak. Full bodied, it holds its ripeness well, showing a lasting balance of clove and dark chocolate on the finish.

Fresh aromas of black raspberry sorbet, sage, violets and toasted oak show on the nose of this blend of 55% Tempranillo, 36% Grenache and 9% Petite Sirah. The wine enters the palate quite smoothly, offering lighter bodied boysenberry flavors with touches of marjoram, black pepper and bay leaf.

Young wines from the rugged Chalone appellation tend to be a bit closed in the early stages of life, and this is no exception. Black plum, wet slate, light vanilla and black peppercorn show on the nose, while the palate proves more shy, with plummy fruit and dark spice. Expect more cohesive flavors with time.
With a noble sense of reduction on the nose, this wine is taut and tart in acidity, focused in Meyer lemon and balanced oak. A grainy texture adds complexity to the light-bodied ripeness.

Aromas of tropical fruit, citrus, aromatic herb and a whiff of grilled bell pepper leap from the glass. On the tangy palate, fresh acidity accompanies juicy grapefruit, pineapple, white peach and stony mineral.

One of the few bottlings of this variety in the state, this brings spicy herb, white peach, citrus rind and white pepper aromas. The flavors are light, sleek and acid-driven, with a drawn-out finish. It provides a lot of appeal and versatility at the table.

Although this is pure Malbec, the wine is generous rather than structured. It sings of ripe tannins and warm blackberry fruits. The wine shows off the fruity side of the grape, meaning it will be ready to drink from 2019.

Old vines and wood aging lend structure to this single-varietal wine from the Terrisses estate. It's rich, made entirely from the local Duras grape, giving spice, bright black-currant fruit and good acidity. Drink from 2019.

This 100% Pinot Noir sparkling wine opens with tart fruit flavors of rhubarb, strawberry and sour cherry. It's tight and sharply defined at first but broadens as it opens, finishing with a lick of vanilla.

For fans of a bigger voluptuous style, this wine delivers a lush layered combination of honeycomb and crème brûlée. Dark in color, the oak is pronounced and supportive, while the structure is moderate, opting for velvety texture and rich ripe fruit.

The sister cuvée to Bouza's B6 Tannat, this is rock-solid up front, with heady black olive, balsamic berry and cedar aromas. Its heavy and syrupy on the palate rather than elegant, tasting of prune, blackberry and peppery spice. Its toasty finish includes blackened flavors. Drink through 2023.

A friendly, easy-drinking red blend, this offers pleasant notes of cassis and black plum throughout, hit by decadent accents of cocoa, woodspice and licorice root. It's direct and straightforward in feel, but well balanced and clean.
This wine's bright raspberry and plum aromas are typical of basic Garnacha. Its fresh, racy palate isn't heavily structured, offering a simple mix of plum, oak and chocolate flavors.

This wine's raisiny aromas include smoked meat and chocolate notes. It's intensely tannic on the palate, tasting mostly of chocolaty oak and vanilla. That oak dominates the finish, leaving a carob flavor.
Heavy oak dominates the nose of this wine, creating milky notes of vanilla and carob. The palate is choppy with tannins and herbal red plum and currant flavors. It ends with mint and green notes.
This soft, perfumed blend of Malvasia and Encruzado is ripe, fragrant and made to be drunk young. It has a warm, ripe character, shot through with just the right amount of acidity. Drink now.
This Garnacha Blanca's lime and dusty apple aromas lead to a plump, simple palate with little direction. Its lightly briny white fruit flavors are generic and a bit flat.

Firm and closed, this wine has a way to go. Solid tannins dominate and there is a strong sense of extraction and bitterness. The wine should soften, although the tannins will remain. Don't drink before 2022.

Spicy, foresty, slightly damp black fruit aromas are normal for basic Carmenère. A solid palate with acidic snap is healthy. Generic berry and spice flavors are a bit green, while this is saucy tasting on the finish.
Bright, crisp and ready to drink, this is a lively wine. It has plenty of apple and citrus flavors as well as a more mature edge of almonds. Drink now.
Textured while also rich, this rounded wine is generous and lightly spicy. The smooth texture gives the wine extra weight. Drink now.

Soft and fruity with an attractive blend of cherry fruits and acidity, this wine is perfumed and developing well. Its fruitiness is lightly supported by tannins that are just softening. Drink the wine from 2019.
Red cherry and turned earth show on the simple but clean nose of this bottling. Tart red fruit and more dusty qualities show on the sip, with a hint of vanilla on the finish.

The Alloro vineyard is among the finest in the Chehalem Mountain AVA. Sweet blue fruit is on full display here, delivering a broadside of blueberry and blue plum flavors. It's smooth, supple and perfectly balanced, its 30% new oak well integrated and adding just a light touch of toast.

There's an enticing hint of musk accenting flavors of fresh lemon and grapefruit in this dry medium-bodied Pinot Gris. It's a fragrant fruity wine but structured by crisp acidity and a cool mineral finish. Enjoy now through 2026.

This medium-bodied, steely and austere wine has a pale orange-gold color, citrus and green-apple aromas and crisp, dry flavors like grapefruit. It has light almond and earth accents and is driven by good acidity for a refreshing mouthfeel. Extra brut means truly dry, and this wine shows how appealing the style can be.

Scott Paul's Azana is precise and distinctive, delivering a focused fusion of strawberry, blueberry and spicy cherry flavors. There's a pleasing touch of lightly earthy funk as well, and the overall balance keeps it interesting and on point through the finish.

The famous vineyard is showing well here. Winemaker Ian Burch has a fine ability to provide a distinct focus for each of the winery's single vineyard selections. This bottling is refined, with an intriguing mix of flavors, from grapefruit and Bing cherry, to chicken broth and milk chocolate. As odd as it sounds, it all knits together quite well.

Fresh red currants, rose petals, tarragon and thyme meet with vanilla and caramel on the very pleasing nose of this blend of 70% Grenache, 16% Mourvèdre and 14% Syrah. Rosewater shows on the palate along with fresh cherry and strawberry flavors, wrapped in light tannins and judicious acidity. It goes down easy.

Acacia, Spanish broom, apricot and toasted nut aromas set the tone in this wine. Mirroring the nose, the rounded palate offers ripe peach, yellow apple, orange zest and honey hints while an almond note gives it a pleasantly bitter close.
This opens with subdued aromas suggesting oak, paraffin and thyme. The palate is more expressive, offering dried apricot, citrus zest, grilled herb and bitter almond flavors.

Confected notes of pear drop and strawberry create a very open appetizing nose. The palate has a little spritz to keep things fresh on the zippy easy fruit-driven palate. With its light dry appeal, this is all about easy summer afternoons. Drink soon.

A hint of bramble lends complexity to this wine's understated raspberry and wild strawberry aromas. It's a zesty, mouthwatering dry rosé boasting tart red fruit flavors and a crystalline, mineral finish.

Made entirely from Sangiovese, this opens with iris, underbrush and Mediterranean herb aromas. The youthful, easygoing palate offers raspberry, white pepper and clove hints alongside pliant tannins. Enjoy soon.
This wine's underbrush, tilled soil and dark fruit aromas appear in the glass. The straightforward palate offers black plum, clove and white pepper flavors alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.
This blends 61% Pinot Noir, 35% Chardonnay and 4% Pinot Meunier. Dry and crisp, it offers flavors of Gravenstein apple, stone and lemon peel. It is refreshing, layered and complex.
Bright and fresh in Gravenstein apple, fig and citrus flavors, this full-bodied wine is balanced and well integrated, with a depth of texture and complexity. It lingers gingerly in Asian spice.

This mature Malbec is a throwback to the days when Mendoza was all about big is better. This smells ripe and raisiny, with a cooked-fruit element that some might dismiss as unfresh. In the mouth, this is typically bulky and saturated almost to the point of syrupy. Flavors of raisin, coffee, black licorice, root beer and jerky are sweet and savory prior to a flat finish. Drink now.

The aromas of this wine intoxicate, showing more initial fruit aromas compared to many wines from this region, with strong blueberry and orange peel scents. Those notes are dominated by more savory tones over time, with waves of wildflower, olive, fresh herb, gravel and a whiff of smoked meat. The elegant palate offers a seamless feel that leads into an extended finish, showing a lovely overall sense of refinement.

A hint of nettle plays amidst the green apple and lemon notes of the nose. The palate has very fine fizz that gently exudes even more green-apple and bright lemon notes. This is slender, taut and lively, and makes an ideal apéritif style delivering real, lasting and resounding refreshment.

Aromas of cedary oak, vanilla bean and mocha accent ripe berry scents. This Malbec blend is chunky, blocky and stocky more than elegant or lifted. Savoy, beefy berry flavors finish stout and compact. Drink this well-made Bordeaux-style blend through 2023.
Among an excellent lineup of 2016 Pinots, the Wichmann seems to be the least ripe. Its flavors are tart berry, with lemony acidity and hints of wet leaves. Drink 2021–2025.

Tight and nervy, this mineral-textured wine keeps the fruit in the background. It is very dry, with the acidity showing strongly. Another few months or a year will do this steely wine the world of good.

Jammy berry aromas are forward but inexact. A tight powerful palate is narrow in scope, with peppery red-berry flavors propelled by lively acidity. Finishing notes of oak spice and cocoa are notable through a choppy but bold ending.

Grapy berry aromas are oaky and a touch harsh. A fleshy pulpy palate is sturdy and tannic, while this tastes of airy dark fruits that are more fluffy than tough. Toast and blackberry flavors make for a no-nonsense finish.
A tiny production from a small producer, this wine has a hearty entry and is hugely oaky and bursting in tannin. Its flavor profile is leathery, savory and smoky.

The winery has dropped “Barrel Select” from the label, but this remains a barrel selection. In 2015 the finished wine pushes hard against 15% alcohol, and it's fully ripened and then some, with deep plum and black cherry fruits at the core. The tannins bring black tea, smoke and tobacco notes, with a strongly astringent aftertaste.
Named after the Portugal Ramos winery, this smooth, fruity wine is full of attractive blackberry flavors and integrated tannins. It is ripe, full in the mouth and ready to drink.
Round, authentic Cava aromas of lemon-lime and brine introduce a plump and easy palate that comes up soft. Dried apricot and briny nectarine flavors finish quietly.

Medium-intense aromas of ripe raspberry and sweet spice show in the bouquet, coming off a bit warm. The medium-weight palate shows more of the same, yielding a straightforward yet solid and clean experience overall.
There's a strong metallic and new tire rubber tinge to the aromas, along with whiffs of diesel. The palate falls flat, with abundant canned peach and Nestea Iced Tea flavors. It seems past peak.
A pale-salmon color with an orange tinge, aromas of strawberry, herb and flower lead to a broad palate with plentiful apple flavors. It doesn't all work.
A blend of Malvasia, Síria and Gouveio, this wine is soft, open and fruity. It is rich while still having a crisp edge and a refreshing aftertaste. Drink now.

This deep ruby wine has a nose of pomegranate and white chocolate. Silky tannins provide a rich mouthfeel and offer a backdrop for flavors of black plum, raspberry, anisette and espresso bean that head off into a baking spice finish.

Made with 100% Pinot Nero, this smooth, seductive red delivers juicy raspberry, strawberry compote, white pepper, star anise and cinnamon flavors. It's fresh and elegant, with supple tannins that leave a silky mouthfeel. Drink through 2022.

Rich, mature aromas of brioche reflect autolysis. A full palate with just enough acidic freshness is layered and complex, while spiced apple flavors are yeasty. A mild note of toast melds with a hint of butter and brioche on the lingering finish. As gran reserva Cava goes, this is a winner.

From one of the most famous of the Meursault vineyards, this wine shows a good poise between tight texture and a more opulent character. An edge of minerality draws together the toasty flavors and the warm fruits. Drink this rich wine from 2021.
designation: Domaine du Pavillon Les Charmes Premier Cru

description: Fragrant and refined, this rosato has enticing aromas of red berry, citrus, wild herb and nectarine. A blend of 90% Nerello Mascalese and 10% Carricante, the savory palate doles out juicy strawberry, sour cherry, ginger and peach alongside tangy acidity. A saline note closes the finish.

Focused black-fruit and flower aromas and flavors are wrapped in a lightly tart texture that amps up the volume of fruitiness on the palate. Having been aged in used, neutral-flavored barrels there is little oakiness to interfere with the powerful ripeness of the black-cherry, black-plum, black-tea and violet flavors.
This wine is quiet in a black-cherry aroma. The palate adds sumptuous, ripe, fleshy cherry notes while the body remains toned and juicy. There is crunchy freshness and a long, cherry-laced finish.

A subdued note of rose petal vies for attention with subtle orange hints in this wine. The palate is fluid and fresh, with an oily, orange zest-laced texture. This classic combination of two Austrian white grapes makes for an intriguing, medium-bodied and fresh wine with subtle aromas.
This wine's corn, apple, pear and toasty spice aromas are followed by sweet, rich stone fruit flavors that sail into the finish. It provides as lot of enjoyment.

Inky garnet in the glass, this wine has fruit-filled aromas of raspberry, strawberry and orange zest. Lush, long-lasting tannins provide a framework for its blackberry, cassis, dark chocolate, spearmint and orange rind flavors that culminate in a bright yet velvety finish.

Hints of black pepper, clove and cedar waft from the glass, followed by ripe and generous fruit flavors on the palate. This wine is dry, well balanced and has a mouthwatering texture stiffened a bit by light tannins.

Full of sage and earth tones, this robust, full-bodied wine is brimming in black cherry and cassis flavors that are bolstered by a firm grip of tannins. Toasted oak finishes things out, with lingering notes of clove and vanilla.
Add crispness to bright red-currant fruit and the result is a delicious, fragrant and refreshing wine. It is lively, bright and ready to drink with its zesty aftertaste.
This crisp wine is full of clean, perfumed fruit. It has spice, strawberry flavors and a lively, zesty texture. It's an attractive, fragrant wine, ready to drink.

This wine's generic white fruit aromas are indicative of neither the Sauvignon Blanc nor the Chardonnay in this blend. It's chunky on the palate, with cactus, tarragon and green citrus notes. A texturally solid finish ensures that this leaves a mostly positive final impression.

Aged in concrete and hailing from three different vineyards, this is an extremely ripe and unctuous bottling, starting with aromas of banana Jolly Rancher with a hint of grapefruit juice. The palate is extremely tropical, blending papaya, guava and banana flavors as well as a dominating coconut-oil element.
Very fruity, even jammy in aroma and flavor, this medium-bodied wine is easy to sip. It's low in tannins and acidity, making a very soft texture.

Juicy fruits of red currant and boysenberry meet with tar and musty herbs on the nose of this bottling. The palate is very pyrazine-laden, showing lots of dill and bell-pepper flavors against the red fruits.
Made in a medium-sweet style, this emphasizes strong peach flavors that some might call syrupy. It's nicely ripe, fruit-driven, off dry and should be enjoyed slightly chilled.

Made with organically grown Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, underbrush and leather. The juicy elegant palate gives red cherry, vanilla and a touch of mint alongside velvety tannins. Drink through 2022.

As its name suggests, this wine was aged in clay amphora, giving it both an oxidative character and zesty red fruits. The fascinating wine will need to age, although its structure means that will not be for long. Drink from 2019.
designation: Herdade de São Miguel Art.Terra Amphora

description: This zesty and tangy wine is packed with yellow fruits and citrus. Short oak aging has given a spicy edge that enhances the refreshing fruitiness of the wine. Drink from early 2019.
designation: Herdade de São Miguel Colheita Seleccionada Branco

description: This opens with aromas of Mediterranean scrub, sea breeze and citrus peel. The vibrant savory palate doles out lemon, pineapple, wild fennel and saline set against vibrant acidity.

A saturated, dark purple color and dense blackberry, black olive and chocolate aromas open this firm but nicely balanced Syrah—a grape that deserves more attention in Chile. Its savory plum and berry flavors are stretched a bit thin across its medium, oak-laced finish.

An enticing aroma of toasted oak meets spicy ripe peach and pear flavors in this full-bodied luxuriously creamy wine. It has vanilla, nutmeg and ginger notes and a mouth-coating texture that is also well supported by acidity. Oaky, yes; delicious and balanced, also yes.

This is a dynamic and lovely white wine that checks all the boxes. Aromas of melon and Meyer lemon meet with honeysuckle and wet cement on the nose. The palate is framed by a grippy tension, yet shows welcoming flavors of nectarine and pear. A powerful streak of lime acidity slices through it all.

This features top-heavy aromas of cedar and tobacco. It's ribbed with powerful tannins that frame its cassis and baked plum fruit. Those flavors are infused with cedary oak, finishing smooth and chocolaty. Drink through 2030.

A silky, elegant wine from one of Australia's top Cab producing regions at a great price, this wine shimmers with ripe cranberries and raspberries, dried leaves, florals and a briny, seaweed character. Medium bodied with tight focused tannins and balanced acidity, this wine could be drunk now with protein or cellared through 2028.

A gorgeous array of mineral tones anchor this vivacious medium-bodied white wine. Ripe juicy tangerine and grapefruit flavors are accented by hints of pollen and dusty earth. While creamy and textured, it finishes lean with a bracing hit of lime acidity. Drink now through 2023.

Enticing scents of wild berry, Mediterranean scrub and dark spice abound on this elegant red. The refined palate delivers red cherry, crushed strawberry, white pepper and licorice alongside bright acidity and savory mineral. Firm polished tannins provide silky support.

Cut grass and pungent green-apple slices make for a familiar entry to the nose of this bottling. The palate starts with Granny Smith apple and nectarine flavors, but they are short-lived and the texture is flat.

Minerally citrus aromas break down and veer off toward lanolin and sea-foam. This Sauvignon Blanc (with other white grapes) has grip, but that's fleeting. Briny, salty citrus flavors are crisp before fading fast on a dilute finish.
designation: Fina Reserva La Isla Vineyard Sauvignon Blanc-Chardonnay-Viognier

description: Straw colored in the glass, this Pinot Grigio has aromas of citrus blossom, white flowers and lemon rind. In the mouth, there are flavors of green apple, pear and white peach. It is well balanced and has a crisp finish.

Aromas of black plum, ripe raspberry, violet, bay leaf, fresh thyme and black pepper spice are savory on the nose. The palate shows tart cranberry and black cherry, with an earthy, herbal undertow. The tannins are soft textured but very drying, while the acidity is tangy with an underripe berry flavor. A leathery tone is introduced on the finish, while the tannins hug the tip of the tongue.
A soft, fruity and creamy wine with attractive acidity and a touch of honey, this is crisp and bright. It has a lively, texture and a light touch of minerality. Drink now.

This wine is a blend of Tempranillo (81%) and Syrah. Aromas of pencil eraser, cherry, sweet herb and spice are followed by a tight core of fruit flavors with a smoky finish. Firm, lightly grainy tannins provide support.
The aromas jump up, with notes of lemon zest, cream and white peach that lead to rounded melon and stone fruit flavors. It brings appeal.

This wine is principally Merlot (62%) and Cabernet Sauvignon (20%), with the rest pinches of Malbec, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot. Expressive aromas of huckleberry, jalapeño pepper, cherry and wood spice lead to sweet plump fruit flavors, with lightly grainy tannins providing support. It's enjoyable but comes off as quite green.

Notes of pollen, lemon and plastic carry the nose, with a bit of melon showing on the light-bodied palate. There's mild concentration to the flavors and a pleasing roundness to the feel, balanced by a gentle vein of acidity.
designation: Shared Table Farm Long White Cloud

description: The nose on this very pale rosé is rather shy but the palate presents easy notes of lemon and red currant. This is dry and easy, both very light and very refreshing.

A yeasty aroma is at the forefront on this wine, although there's also plenty of this style's characteristic citrus, pineapple, snow pea and green bell pepper as well. The palate is extra fruity, bright, zippy and crisp, making for an easygoing porch pounder.

Subtle, earthy aromas evoking underbrush, baking spice and dark berry set the tone. The linear palate shows dried black cherry, clove and ground pepper alongside firm, rather evolved tannins. Drink through 2025.

The winery does an East and West block selection, this being the more open and broadly fruity of the pair. Rather soft, rounded fruit flavors of raspberries with a backing of citrus oil keep the flavors fresh and lively. Drink now and over the next half decade.

Dark oaky aromas of minty black fruits are gritty and concentrated. Following that nose, this is grinding on the palate. Acid-pushed dark-fruit flavors come with an offset of oaky vanilla, while this is clipped and gappy in feel on the finish.

The latest release of Oregon Pinot from this Napa Valley producer is done in a lush and creamy style, with flavors of raspberries, cherries and vanilla in abundance. It's forward and tasty, though rather lightly ripened throughout, and best consumed 2021–2025.

Crisp, dry and full of red-currant fruits and tight acidity, this is a delicious, young Champagne. It is textured and zesty, with layer of acidity vying with the perfumed fruit. This bottling really should age, so drink it from 2019.

Cocoa, cinnamon and oak aromas are more prominent than fruit on this ripe, full-bodied Pinot Noir. A hard-driving palate is not about elegance, acidity and restraint. Flavors of black cherry, mocha and chocolate are tasty but atypical of most Pinot Noirs. A peppery finish with heavy oak spice seals the deal on this uniquely Rolland-style wine.

This wine offers a depth of aromatic intensity and is expansive in velvety tannin. Spicy cherry, strawberry and a compelling thread of cola highlight a succulence on the midpalate that lingers leisurely on the finish.
Tart in complex acidity and subtle flavors of strawberry, pomegranate and orange, this is a light-bodied, lightly ripe wine, that's angular and elegant.

Baked red cherry, star anise, gingersnaps and purple flowers show on the fruity but elegant nose of this bottling. Those strong fruit and hearty spice flavors show on the sip as well, which is framed by powerful acidity. That acid needs more time to mellow, so drink 2020–2030.

This wine offers a fruity core of plum and dark-cherry compote, with elements of spicy clove and forested earth. It has a backbone of acidity that contributes freshness against a powerful backdrop of ripeness and intensity. The finish is dusted in chocolate.

Candied lemon-zest notions are heady on the nose. There are some earthy hints, too. On the palate, the lemon notes are toned down and appear as fluid, concentrated lemon oil impressions with inflections of ripe peach and pear. Their lovely zestiness dominates the palate and leads to an off-dry finish.

Pure Alvarinho from one of the top producers in the Monção and Melgaço sub-region of Vinho Verde, this wine is ripe, full of fresh green and white fruits, and is well structured. There is a zest of minerality going through the palate which adds intensity. Drink from 2019.
Tart plum and green gooseberry immediately greet the nose on this bottling. Nervy and taut, it's light and zippy on the palate, with an abundant lime flavor and mouth-puckering lift on the close.

Brambly berry and cherry aromas are hit with subtle cocoa and forest-floor accents. The palate boasts fine yet astringent tannins, which are just countered by the fleshy, concentrated flavors of red plum and cherry flesh.

Very floral and aromatic from the start, this opens with enticing scents of ginger-peach tea, jasmine and rose water. It's medium in weight, with a slight viscosity that lends a slick texture to the palate and final notes of muddled peach flesh.
The aromas are quite reticent and hard to get at. The palate brings plentiful red-fruit flavors and grippy tannins, with a tire rubber note that distracts.

This wine is a blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon, 25% Cabernet Franc, 7% Syrah, 6% Merlot and 2% Malbec. Blue-fruit aromas are at the fore along with notes of green pepper and green herb. The concentration is quite light, not able to deliver.

Creamy peach and orange aromas are a bit like a Creamsicle. In the mouth, this is chunky and citrusy, but far from elevated or elegant. Salty briny citrus and nectarine flavors finish flat, yeasty and oxidized.

This is a smooth, balanced and lovely dessert wine, moderate in sweetness and heat, with lovely aromas and flavors of rose water, fresh and dried apricot and honeycomb. It will do well on its own, or as an accompaniment to a wide range of cheeses and spicy desserts.

There's a rugged and burly quality to this single-vineyard expression, starting with aromas of roast pork in a pan sauce of cranberry, mulberry, dried herbs and cracked pepper. The hearty palate layers pomegranate and plum alongside chai spice, bay leaf and sage.

This wine is thick and reduced, with sizable tannins and a generosity of black and red currant. Leather, clove and pepper round out and season the fruit, contributing to its overall complexity and intrigue. This wine is structured and bursting in power. Enjoy best 2023–2033.

Properly bold and tannic, this is a concentrated wine. The rich fruits and powerful tannins will allow this generous wine to age. Black fruits, intense acidity and dark tannin mean it will take time. Drink from 2024.

Under the same ownership as the Rothschild property Château Clarke in Moulis, this estate predominately grows Merlot. This wine comes from a selected parcel that gives rich, intense and concentrated fruitiness and dense tannins. It shows a lightly burnt character from the wood aging but the blackberry fruits are dominant and ripe. Drink from 2021.

Swathes of dark tannins and a dense texture introduce a wine that needs to age. The black fruits, rich structure and concentration are part of this firm wine made under the direction of cellarmaster Géraldine Lussiez. With layers of rich wood from 12 months in 400-liter barrels and black-currant flavors, it is still developing. Drink from 2022.

This estate-grown Chardonnay leads with elusive aromas of toast, vanilla, cream, corn silk and spice that emerge over time. The flavors are light but have lovely texture, with barrel notes speckled throughout.

Dust, sage and crushed rock show well in this appellation wine, inviting in its opening aromatics of dried herb and violet. Chalky tannin and pronounced oak accentuate its ultimate power, evolving to reveal plush chalky tannin.

Sticky tannin and a thickness of blackberry, sage and herb are the defining characteristics of this full-bodied youthful wine from a great site and great vintage. The hearty presence of fruit and weight give it a density and length on the palate.

Lavender and licorice tones give this wine a savory touch. The fruit comes from Oak Knoll and Coombsville, relatively cooler appellations within the Napa Valley, and includes the addition of 20% Petit Verdot. Rich, thick layers of blueberry, blackberry and cigar box meet dried herbes de Provence and sweet spice.

This excellent wine has tempting aromas of new leather, sandalwood and dried earth, plus complex, savory flavors like dried herbs, prosciutto and green olives complemented by dried cherries. It captures the varietal characteristics very well and avoids being oaky or overly ripe.

Delicate wet stone, white flower and tart red-berry aromas mark the nose of this wine. The medium-bodied palate boasts crunchy strawberry, tangy mineral and pepper tones, with vibrant acidity and a fuzzy, phenolic finish.
Orange peel and dust aromas open this basic Chardonnay. The palate is chunky, with stone fruit and papaya flavors that lack definition and show little evolution on the finish.
This is the current release, though well past its vintage. It seems flat on first sip but recoups itself with a lingering finish that reflects well-aged Viognier. Drink up.
This is ripe and round with lashings of ripe dark berries, coffee and toasty oak. It's a soft-bodied wine that's seen plenty of South Aussie sunshine.
This straightforward wine offers notes of blackberry jam, mint and sweet spicy oak. The palate is juicy-fruited, with soft tannins and a rather clunky oak finish.

A Grenache- and Cinsault-based rosé, this pours a pink-peach color with initial aromas of strawberry hull, white currant and a hint of rhubarb. The palate follows suit, with sprightly berry and cirtus flavors that finish with a tart twang. Drink now.
This ripe, strawberry-inflected wine has attractive, balanced acidity. It has a touch of spice, lively fruitiness and a crisp aftertaste. Drink now.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of violet, underbrush and white pepper. The bright savory palate has juicy red cherry, clove and star anise alongside polished tannins. Enjoy through 2022.
This blend of Petit and Gros Manseng has both the intense freshness of Jurançon and its great sweetness. Apricot and honey contrast with acidity and a zingy bite. Drink this wine from 2020.

Showing strongly spicy wood flavors, this is still a young wine. However, the bold fruit and blackberry and plum-skin flavors hold promise for the future. Age this wine with its rich fruits, firm tannins and acidity. Drink from 2021.

Dating to the 15th century, this estate is on the eastern side of the Lisboa region, away from the ocean influence. That gives rich wines like this structured Syrah. It is perfumed, full of berry fruit and with great tannins and acidity. Drink this wine from 2019.

This limited-production Chardonnay comes from high-altitude vineyards in eastern Portugal. It is soft, but a cool, crisp line of acidity gives a zesty aftertaste that shines through the wood aging. Drink this wine now.

This wine's plum, crushed flower, blackberry jam and wet rock aromas are followed by concentrated purple and black fruit flavors that persist on the fruit-filled finish. A big wine, it pulls no punches.
This is a showy brash wine that smells smoky and oaky, has medium body and tastes like wood char, cranberries and vanilla. Not much varietal character comes through but it will please oak lovers.
This wine opens gritty in texture and tannin before softening on the midpalate. Black fruit, cedar, dried herb and black pepper combine for a forceful experience of power and serious ripeness.

This is a sweet but light-bodied dessert-style wine that will taste great with cheese, desserts that aren't too sweet, or on its own. It has floral aromas and flavors like apricots and tutti-frutti ice cream, but it also has good acidity to keep it balanced.

Toast, plum, herb and cherry aromas are followed by light, slightly sweet seeming fruit flavors. The tannins seem quite bunched up, not appearing to have fully ripened, and the fruit concentration a bit light.

The nose shows ripe black plum, blackberry, herbs and stale pepper, while the palate offers blueberry, raspberry, oak and cocoa powder. The cranberry-laced finish displays the easygoing grip of crushed-velvet tannins.

This Texas Sémillon offers a chalky nose that blends with fresh clementine, lime and pine needles. The light palate is somewhat creamy due to rounded acidity, presenting flavors of lemon juice, crushed stone and a touch of lemongrass. There is some mineral-driven astringency on the finish alongside citrus and white pepper.

Subdued notes of sun-ripened pear and russet-pear peel on the nose are pervaded by fresher hints of tangerine peel. The palate is a balanced synthesis of juicy pear and peach alongside Mirabelle plums. These notions are boosted by medium sweetness but balanced by texture and freshness. The finish is dominated by a surprisingly pure note of rose petal.

Smoke and candied tangerine zest appear on the nose and make for an appetizing opening. The palate is juicy and off dry, favoring tangerine and peach notions pervaded by the intriguing smokiness that was first encountered on the nose. A lovely act of balance lets very ripe but also very fresh fruit speak. Lovely now, it's sure to develop.
designation: Signature de Colmar Grand Cru Florimont
winery: Domaine Viticole de la Ville de Colmar

description: Floral, tender notes of honeysuckle blossom have an aromatic edge of mandarin peel. These fragrant notions carry onto the palate where they are boosted by residual sweetness that enhances accents of ripe peach and juicy mandarin. There is freshness as a counterpoint as well as a textured midpalate. Mandarin notes dominate the finish.
designation: Signature de Colmar Grand Cru Hengst
winery: Domaine Viticole de la Ville de Colmar

description: Appetizing notions of juicy mandarin dominate the nose and ripple through the palate with energetic juiciness. This wine is ripe, fresh and mouthwateringly zesty. The palate is completely dry and recalls ripe red apple on the finish.

This wood-aged, vintage-dated Champagne is the top of the range from this producer. Blending Chardonnay and Pinot Noir, it is rich, just hinting at toast and certainly at nutmeg and cinnamon. The wine is intense, with a strong mineral edge. Still young, it will be better from 2020.

Rounded aromas of Meyer lemon and white peach are quite plush, and there are hints of butter and oak also slipping into the nose of this bottling. There is great zip to the sip, where rich flavors of pan-fried apples are cut by strong acidity.

A touch of white blossom on the nose makes way for hints of honey and white mushroom. The palate is streamlined and fresh, fizzing with a fine but lively mousse that flashes highlights of blossom honey once again amidst a crisp lemony note. The finish is dry and wonderfully brisk.

Incredibly vivid aromas of dark cherries and wild forest berries seamlessly meld with highlights of pepper, damp earth, blood-orange rind and stone. The plush yet persistent palate is equally vibrant and complex, offering loads of juicy berry flavors offset by delightfully grippy berry-skin notes.

An earthy, figgy sur lie character sets this wine apart from the crowd, while a supple texture and good balance make it easy to sip and enjoy. Plenty of cherry and raspberry flavors emerge on the palate, seeming to fill the mouth and then lingering on the finish.

Earthy and floral with an inviting nose of cherry and tangerine, this is a deft, lithe, focused and fresh wine with a lasting thread of tangy acidity. It is delicious in its understated elegance and delicate fruit.
This rich, wood-aged Encruzado is ripe, packed with toastiness plus apple and yellow-fruit flavors. With spice and lovely acidity, the wine is opulent, elegant and ready to drink in 2019.

Loads of earthy aromas of thyme, cracked pepper, rosemary, lavender and loamy soil add intrigue to the dark elderberry core of this blend of 60% Syrah and 40% Grenache. That array of savory herbs also decorates the black-plum flavors of the palate, which is bolstered by pepper spice and tea leaves.
This offers grilled herb, citrus rind and exotic fruit scents. The ripe, forward palate shows grapefruit, baked apple and mature peach flavors.
Vibrant pink in color, this offers bright tones of crushed strawberry and watermelon, with a bit of tart currant. Light in body but with a pleasing roundness, this is a well-balanced summer sipper.

Aromas of ripe stone fruit, lemon curd and green beans are backed by appealing secondary characters of melon rind and dried herbs. The palate feels a little more forced and lacks the pretty fruit found on the nose, but there's pleasing textural weight, crisp acidity, and an interesting salty, melon rind finish.
Made as a white wine from dark Pinot Noir grapes, this medium-bodied wine has earthy aromas and savory herbal flavors that give it a rustic character. It has a tartness like grapefruit on the finish.

Spicy aromas of cedar, baking spice and green peppercorn hover above notes of vanilla, blackberry and blueberry on the nose. The powdery tannins are well balanced on the straightforward palate, with more notes of cedar and pepper alongside additions of leather and raspberry. The fruit is left behind on the finish but oaky tones persist with a grip of tannins.
This wine's honeysuckle and tropical fruit aromas leap out of the glass. On the fresh, linear palate, a mineral hint accompanies grapefruit, pineapple and tomato leaf notes.

While this producer's style is for dry Champagnes, this one is perhaps excessive. Even the ripe fruit can't quite take away the shocking acidity and intensity, making it best for those who like their Champagne to be seriously dry and tight. A few months more might help reduce the shock.

As the name suggests, this wine is from some seriously old, low-yielding vines. The liberal use of American and French oak, however, does mask the character of those old vines somewhat. It's dense and chocolatey, with plum, black pepper, vanilla and a dusting polish note throughout. The palate is plushly textured and warming, with soft, dusty tannins and a lingering peppery spice.
Delicately layered and earthy, this wine takes on power as it opens in the glass, ending up in a full-bodied style of robust forest, cardamom and pomegranate. The structure is moderate in acidity.

The best of the winery's 2016 vineyard selects, this well-defined wine has flavors of mulberry, sour plum and a touch of lemon. Aging in one-quarter new oak adds some pretty spices, and the overall concentration is enough to carry it for another half decade or so.

This offers aromas of dark-skinned fruit, eucalyptus and espresso. The concentrated palate delivers raspberry jam, Marasca cherry, roasted coffee bean and licorice alongside youthfully assertive tannins. Drink 2022–2026.

Inky, concentrated aromas of black fruits are mildly spicy and granular. High acidity along with a grape-skins texture defines the palate, which tastes of grapy blackberry. A compact, narrow finish is flush but lacks expansiveness.
Soft and fruity, this blackberry-flavored wine is rich and smoothly textured. Ripe fruits are laced with hints of tannins and pepper, with plenty of acidity to give the wine a lift. Drink now.
A slight prickle gives this wine a zingy character to go with the freshness of its citrus flavors. It is fruity, fresh and lively. Drink the wine now.
Firm tannins shoot through this structured wine. The fruit is there, blackberry flavors that come with acidity and a crisp texture to balance the dry core of the wine. Drink now.
Light in color, the aromas provide notes of black currant and herb, with the oak dialed way back. The palate is elegantly styled, with the concentration seeming a bit lacking.
The apple, spice and custard aromas take some time to tease out. The palate is medium bodied, shortening up on the finish.
This very fruity and slightly sweet wine has a hot-pink color, bold aromas of cherries and strawberries and a simply fruity flavor.

Vibrant and elegant, this has aromas of white stone fruit, acacia and a whiff of bread crust. The silky palate doles out white peach, yellow apple and honey alongside bright acidity. It closes on an almond note.

Enticing aromas of ripe dark-skinned fruit, pipe tobacco, leather and incense emerge from the glass. The savory, full-bodied palate delivers dried black cherry, star anise and licorice alongside fine-grained tannins.

Oak-based maple and spicy black fruit aromas include notes of wild herb and espresso. A sappy, tannic palate is round and full, but with a modest midpalate. This blend of 70% Cabernet Sauvignon and 30% Merlot tastes of blackberry and cassis, with a touch of chocolate. A steady finish brings nothing new to a settled panorama. Drink through 2025.

Hints of sweet spice, anise and cacao meld into ripe black cherry and mulberry flavors here. It's voluminous and penetrating yet finessed, freshened by sunny acidity. The finish lingers on ripe, integrated tannins. Enjoy now–2028.

Fragrant whiffs of black-tea leaf, bramble and sandalwood accent this opulent Grenache. It's intensely fruity, offering generous layers of ripe black plum and cherry flavors. Fresh acidity and fine, integrated tannins lead a long, supple finish. An open-knit yet complex wine to enjoy now–2028.

Made primarily from Grenache vines on average 50 years in age, this is intensely ripe but elegantly balanced. Flavors of ripe black cherry and raspberry are tinged with crushed stone and dried mint notes. Its soft, pliant mouthfeel is accentuated by ripe yet persistent tannins. Enjoy now–2023.

This is a beautifully balanced, medium-bodied wine that goes beyond the basic black-fruit flavors and adds hints of dried earth and bay leaf on the nose and light wood smoke and black pepper flavors. Moderate tannins and persistent acidity complete the picture.

All of the fruit for this wine comes from Block 10 of Evergreen Vineyard in the Ancient Lakes. The aromas are exuberant, with lime, pear, mineral, tangerine and white peach notes. It drinks a hair off dry, with stone fruit and citrus flavors brightened by vivid acidity. Precise and detailed, it has a long finish.

A 100% varietal wine from estate-grown grapes, this impresses in its soft supple texture and rich red fruit, while a note of crushed rock underlies the fruit. The structure is impressive and well able to support the power.

This offers generous black cherry, black raspberry, fruit leather, mineral, spice and herb aromas. The fruit flavors are obviously there, but like most offerings from this appellation, it's very much about structure, framed by firm, juicy tannins and crisp acidity.

From a vineyard planted to three clones of the variety, then blended with 12% Petite Sirah, this sees 18 months in oak, a mix of new American and neutral French. It works in its bramble of wild berry and banana, the body softly layered, rich and sumptuously lush.

This medium-bodied wine is made from Pinot Noir grapes grown on a single-vineyard hillside site. It has a light-pink color tinted with salmon, fresh peach-skin aromas and nicely dry, crisp yellow-plum and white-cherry flavors that sit on a smooth, substantial texture.

Mild white fruit aromas lead the nose of this La Mancha Verdejo. It feels round and plump, with moderate acidity and a standard mix of stone fruit and citrus flavors that grow increasingly bitter on the finish.
This wine's leesy, lightly oxidized nose leaves an impression of oak, although none was used. Its powdery, yeasty melon flavors land softly on the rather lifeless finish.
This soft and fruity wine has ripe strawberry fruit and attractive acidity. It has a light, crisp texture to balance the ripe fruitiness. Drink now.

A pale, coppery pink color, this value-minded rosé shows some flowery, earthy elements to the pineapple, peach and cantaloupe fruit tones on the nose and mouth. There's just enough acidity to keep that fruity richness in check, finishing fresh but quick. Drink now.
This low-alcohol wine is pink with a hint of peach color and has mostly ripe and slightly sweet fruit flavors like peaches and pears. The texture is smooth and rather thick for a rosé.

This wine's jumbled aromas of coffee grounds, burnt oak and berries lead to a tight, pulling palate with hard tannins. Its heavy oak and soupy berry flavors are accented by carob and green notes. On the finish, it's overtly tannic.

Made with organically grown Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of mulberry, iris and underbrush. The bright juicy palate offers black cherry, black pepper, clove and star anise alongside polished tannins and fresh acidity. Drink through 2023.

This wine shows a classic, generous style with the waxy aromas and rich texture typical of the grape variety. Melon, walnut and lemon zest flavors make it interesting to sip, and the mouthfeel is broad and inviting.

This pretty, affordable Oregon Pinot Noir brings purple fruit character and plenty of appeal. Soft on entry, it loosens up on the palate to deliver a blast of blueberry jam and French oak flavors (though its oak aging is unspecified), finishing with a chocolate note recalling a Hershey's kiss. This is a good candidate for immediate summertime enjoyment.

Old vine is an unregulated term, and the bottle gives no indication of what it signifies here. The wine starts out toasty and a little hot, improving as it opens, with black cherry, coffee and toasted walnut flavors. The finish brings a lingering taste of chicken stock.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of ripe black-skinned berry, underbrush and baking spice. On the dense palate, velvety tannins support black plum, mocha, vanilla and a hint of tobacco. Drink through 2023.

There's plenty of concentrated, tangy fruit here. The wine bursts with juicy cranberry and raspberry flavors, bolstered by ample acidity. It spent just under a year in barrel, 7% new. Another year in bottle would be a good idea before pulling the cork.
designation: Not One iOTA Pelos Sandberg Vineyard

description: Fresh but prickly aromas of citrus fruits include a green note of cactus. This doesn't have much stuffing, but it's round on the palate. Briny flavors of lime and green salad with vinaigrette are common to a basic Rueda Verdejo like this.

Creamy oak and heavily ripe berry aromas make for a milkshake kind of nose. A heavy, viscous palate is no surprise given the nose and black color on this Syrah. Black fruit and heavy oak flavors finish thick and chewy.
This has delicate aromas of mature apricot and grapefruit that carry over to the forward, simple palate. It closes on a bitter, nutty note. Drink soon.

Vanilla and pear aromas are about as basic as you will find from good Cava. A flat palate tastes of briny white fruits and sea-foam, while this is soft on the finish. Overall this brut nature is highly regular, with nothing special about it.
A rather deep copper color and a combination of savory and fruity flavors make this medium-bodied wine a little more serious and substantial than many. It's made from red Rhône varietals.
This vineyard-designate has a sweet nose of oak and corresponding thick ripe richness on the palate—a full-bodied take that's generous in tannin and flavors of vanilla and coconut.
This easygoing red has subdued aromas suggesting red fruit and baking spices. The simple, light-bodied palate offers raspberry and white pepper touches alongside smooth tannins. Drink soon.
High-toned cherry and cranberry aromas carry the nose, with a slight menthol kick in the background. There's a pleasing roundness to the soft palate, bolstered by more red-berry flavors.
Pale-peach colored, the aromas bring notes of herb and cherry candy. It drinks off dry, with broad-feeling fruit flavors.
Intense berry and black-cherry flavors give focus to this full-bodied, smooth and not-very-tannic wine. Touches of raspberry and leather in the aroma add complexity to the core of dark fruit.

This is a mineral-driven wine, still young and very textured. It has a tight character, more structure and texture than fruit at this stage, but it's sure to open up as it matures. Drink from late 2018.
This well-balanced, ripe wine has an herbal edge that contrasts comfortably with the grapefruit and apple flavors. It has a tangy texture, hinting at minerality as well as fruitiness. Drink now.

This is a field blend of Gewürztraminer, Trousseau Gris, Riesling and other mixed whites that invites in its perfumed aromas of green apple and lychee. With a grainy texture and lifted acidity, it refreshes in a lingering taste of lime zest with an oomph of body.
This powerful and dense wine has aged well. With its fruit now blending into dusty tannins and hints of prune and licorice, this wood-aged wine is well balanced and rich. It is ready to drink now.

This wood-aged blend of Touriga Nacional, Touriga Franca and Tinta Roriz, the classic Douro grapes, has density, ripe black fruits and a fine layer of juicy acidity. Still young and full of the firm tannins that will allow it to age, it likely will be ready to drink from 2020.

Smashed red currants, rose petals, roasting pork and baking spice make for a very inviting nose on this appellation blend. There is great tension and freshness to the palate, where cranberry, raspberry and pomegranate flavors meet with rosewater for a lively experience.

Strong flavors of lemon, lime and salty oak permeate the opening of this dense concentrated wine, which retains moderate acidity and freshness. The brightness comes from a lingering sensation of wet stone and citrus that intrigues.

A very subtle nose is promising with its hints of ripe red apple, gentle shortbread and lemon zest. The palate presents that very same harmonious and fresh picture, enhanced by the finest fizzing creaminess of the mousse and the integrated yeastiness that can only stem from sufficient time on lees. This is a paradigm of balance and understated elegance.

Tropical melon and guava notes are offset by zesty grapefruit acidity in this ephemeral wine. Light bodied and refreshingly mineral, it's a frisky, perfumed spätlese with integrated sweetness that lingers on the finish. Enjoy for now through 2022.

There's a note of barrel influence on the nose, a heartiness of oak that weaves within the greater whole as the wine develops. Smooth, rounded richness, a mix of baked apple and hazelnut, provide a textured balance of flavor within lovely highlights of lemongrass and ginger.

This blend of 50% Grenache and 50% Syrah expertly employs the best of both grapes, blending beastly brawn with floral beauty. Aromas of composting rose petals, forest underbrush, rustic berries and gamy animal hide lead into a savory, complex palate of salted plums, lamb hide and marjoram.

Ripe, heady blackberry aromas lead the nose of this wine, touched up with graphite, wood smoke and menthol notes. It's a lush and extracted mouthfiller, with black plum and cassis flavors, scratchy tannins and lasting intensity. Drink through 2025.

As the name suggests, this wine comes off a rocky part of the estate vineyard, creating a sturdy platform for its rich array of blueberry and brambly cherry fruit. There's a whiff of chicken stock also, and it's still tight with youthful tension. Give it plenty of aeration or an extra year or two in bottle before popping the cork.

Herbal in brushy sage, with thick determined tannins, this is a complex worldly wine, leathery and full of black and white pepper. Soy, meat and tobacco also figure in, speaking loudly back to the spine of acidity.

Subtle cedar and tobacco aromas are smooth and mature. This Gran Reserva from a notoriously tough and cold vintage feels tight, firm and rubbery. Savory, slightly stewed berry and plum flavors are lightly herbal and finish with gritty tension.
This beautifully balanced, perfumed wine offers both red fruits and tangy acidity. The dosage fits its fruitiness. Drink now.

Made in the méthode traditionelle, this is lightly toasty and quite dry. The pale tawny gold hue and dried apple flavors suggest that it be consumed in the near term, between now and 2020. There's a touch of pepper adding a bit of welcome spice to the finish.

Wines from this small AVA are often marked with a strong minerality, but here it's only mildly evident. The grapy fruit flavors suggest it was sourced from young vines, and the ample acidity puts that fruit front and center, with little indication of time in new barrels. Enjoy it for its youth and freshness, and drink now–2022.

Part of the winery's AVA Collection, this new release is the first of the 2016s. An unusual streak of pine sap enlivens the aromas, not harsh, but definitely present on the palate. There's blueberry and fig fruit as well, and the fig comes with a Newtonian crunch. Though not typical of this AVA in the heart of the Willamette Valley, it's an interesting and compelling wine nonetheless.

A light Pinot Noir, this is soft, full of red-cherry flavors and silky tannins. The wine has a fresh feel while also offering plenty of ripe fruitiness, acidity and a refreshing, crisp aftertaste. Drink this gently structured, balanced wine from 2020.

Savory notes of crushed earth, bramble and dried mushroom juxtapose sun-kissed plum and berry in this opulent blend of 50% Grenache and 50% Syrah. It's plump and fleshy on the palate but anchored by firm, lingering tannins and a fresh mineral finish. Powerful yet stately, it should improve through 2030.

Plump and mouthfilling, this blend of 80% Grenache and 20% Syrah offers bold blackberry and boysenberry flavors accented by hints of crushed violet and thyme. It's soft and rounded in constitution but has a glimmer of crushed mineral that lends freshness. Smooth, comforting tannins linger on the finish. Enjoy now–2025.

Plush blueberry and black cherry flavors penetrate deeply on the palate of this warming, generous wine. A blend of 75% Grenache and 25% Syrah, it calibrates richness against an earthen freshness. It's a forward, intensely fruity wine to enjoy now–2026.

While not from the producer's oldest vines, this bottling is comprised mostly of fruit from 40-year-old Grenache planted on the lower terraces of Gigondas. Its black fruit flavors are plump and round, smoothed over by yielding acidity and a luscious, mouthclinging texture. Fine, grippy tannins lend structure to the finish. An approachable but deeply satisfying wine for now–2026.

Elegant and fresh, this lovely rosé sparkler opens with delicate scents of bread crust and orchard fruit. The savory palate offers Rennet apple, ripe cherry, ginger and a hint of tangerine zest set against a soft, continuous mousse.
Lush and exotically spiced in nutmeg and rose, this wine is expansively complex and beguiling in its big-boned, full-bodied richness. It displays bold flavors of dark cherry and cola.
Soft and fruity, this wine with juicy Castelão in the blend is an easy drink, full of red-berry fruits, acidity and an attractive touch of spice. Drink now.
designation: Casa Ermelinda Freitas Monte da Baía Tinto

description: Aromas of orange blossom and mandarin pith show on the somewhat flat nose of this bottling. There's a burst of acid on the tip of the sip, but it quickly fades into dried apple and orange-rind flavors.
Fruity Merlot and spicy Duras go well together in this soft, warm wine that was made to drink young. Lightly textured, it is all about easy, ripe fruit. Drink now.

A strange aroma of multi-grain bread and caraway rides underneath vanilla, black cherry and anise. The palate is stuck on ripe raspberry and cherry flavors, with touches of vanilla and sweet spice and pummeling tannins that lack structure. There is a sour candy tang on the finish, with mildly grippy, sandy tannins and a sprinkle of pepper spice on the end.
This blend of Syrah, Tinta Roriz and Touriga Nacional is open, fruity and ripe. Its tannic structure gives it just enough shape to sustain the red-berry fruits and acidity. Drink the wine now.
Six grape varieties go into this crisp and herbal wine. It is perfumed, packed with fruitiness that's fresh and cool at the end. Tangy, zesty and lightly textured, it is ready to drink.

Enticing scents of white spring flower and yellow stone fruit float out of the glass. Reflecting the nose, the tangy, savory palate offers mature apricot and ripe yellow apple while a white-almond note carries the finish.

Zesty lemon-pith and grapefruit flavors abound in this invigorating blend of Grenache Blanc and Clairette. While dry in style and freshly composed, the midpalate is accentuated by a waxy citrus-peel richness and pleasantly bitter finish. Drink now–2021.

This estate, whose name recalls the Carthaginian general Hannibal who marched this way, has produced a balanced wine. Its richness and generous red-berry flavors contrast easily with the fresh acidity and crisp texture. The result is a ripe and also brightly fruity wine. Drink now.

Ripe and luscious, this wine has a good future. It balances honey and toffee with acidity, smooth but also with a dry core of botrytis. It will develop well into a dense wine, always keeping its acidity. Drink from 2020.

This wine is full of ripe tannins along with dense, juicy black fruits. It is balanced, with tannins and spice on the one hand and great fruit and acidity on the other, promising good aging potential. This is a wine to keep and drink from 2022.

Ripe, spicy and with a good line of acidity, black-currant fruit and an aromatic character, this is a balanced wine. It is poised, with soft tannins that are well integrated into the wine's structure. Drink from 2020.

This wine is super aromatic but in a synthetic way: an unusual combo of lemon, lychee, cardamom and cookie-dough aromas are followed by a rather clunky palate. There's plenty of fruit here as well, but again, it feels rather forced and fake.
This ripe, fruity wine has a soft texture, light acidity and a zingy prickle on the tongue. That gives it an attractive lift. Drink now.

This leads with vegetal aromas recalling celery and lime. The palate is standard, with citrusy acidity and pyrazinic flavors of green bell pepper and peppercorn. Those flavors echo on the finish, losing intensity rather quickly.
This blend of Grenache and Syrah tastes like raspberry purée, with a broad streak of vanilla. The tannins are drying out, and the whole wine is over the top, like a hyper-realistic painting.
This wine's aromas and flavors are outright raisiny. Prune, fig and other overripe flavors feature prominently. And yet, it still has some quality and character despite being out of balance.
This soft wine has a light structure and red berry-like fruit. Its juicy, lightly fruity character carries into its crisp aftertaste. Drink now.

This rich wine is full of spice and cream, with a soft texture. The ripe fruit with its tropical and yellow flavors is generous, cut by attractive acidity and a full-bodied aftertaste. Drink from 2020.

Made from Pinot Gris fermented for weeks on its skins, this is an unusual rosé—and not just because it's technically not a rosé at all, but an orange wine. Unlike most pink sippers that are made to be knocked back, this is a thinking woman's wine. The nose is a heady blend of ripe watermelon, peach, pressed red flowers and shitake mushrooms. The palate is all at once creamy, tangy and salty, with flavors of watermelon rind, ginger candy and cocktail bitters. Geek out with your wine-loving friends on this quirky little beauty.

This is a 100% varietal wine grown on Mount George at the southern end of the valley. Cave-aged nearly two years in all French oak, it's tightly wound and intensely ripe, a bold, boisterous offering of black cherry, black pepper, clove and lasting oak. Let it open in the glass.

This affordable red succeeds in offering full-bodied dark cherry and black-currant flavors among an expansive palate of integrated oak and structured tannins. The finish is an extended mix of cinnamon, toast and chocolate tones.

Crisp and juicy aromas of squeezed Meyer lemon, white peach, honeydew rind and rainy sidewalk show on the nose of this single-vineyard bottling. There is great grip to the palate as well as a light texture, but the flavors are generous with more stone fruit and melon, making it rounded and likable for many tastes.

Extra richness and depth lift this wine to a high level of quality and deliciousness. Its ripe blueberry, blackberry and dark-chocolate flavors seem layered and generous, and it fills the palate with fine-grained tannins and a full body.

Early aromas of tire rubber and compost give way to cheese and white fruit scents. A foamy palate quickly flattens out, while this tastes of yeast and tangy apple. Mild spice notes help out an obtuse and heavy finish.

Rustic berry aromas are herbal and gritty. In the mouth, this is lively, with just enough body to support high acidity. Oaky, roasted berry and plum flavors show a hint of chocolate on an herbal finish with tomato notes.

Resiny oak aromas induce a note of popcorn, while spiced pumpkin scents are savory but not all that fresh. Following the nose, this lacks spine and weighs in as chunky. Woody spiced-apple flavors fade out on a round, oaky finish.

Shy aromas of peach and dust are reserved. A cidery palate has just enough acidity to avoid flatness, but this is not exactly bursting with tension and energy. Mild spiced-apple flavors finish slightly foamy and bitter.

The aromas of cedar and cigar box consume the dark fruit on the nose of this bottling. Similar wood-spice and pine-oil flavors are wrapped around the palate, with flashes of black plum and tobacco trying to emerge.

A deep, dark color and deep, dark flavors steal the show in this extra-ripe and extremely spicy wine. Oak is the star, as cedar, clove, vanilla, cinnamon and smoke notes pervade the aromas, flavors and finish.

Subtle aromas of white peach flesh, crushed limestone and nectarine blossom decorate the nose of this estate bottling from a pioneering family. The palate is loaded with flint, smoke and a plaster of Paris element in the background, all giving depth to the nectarine cream, key lime spritz and hint of chive flavors.

This is a new offering from the producer, sourced from a cool windy site in the Petaluma Gap. A whiff of violet rides atop dense concentrated blackberry and dried herb. The wine offers a brushy dusty character and long polished tannins, showing cool-climate balance and elegance.

A light floral note in the aroma joins up with layered and ripe fruit flavors that are handsomely accented by cedar, cocoa and balsam, for a complex and lasting impression on the palate. Full body and firm tannins provide good structure to balance the rich flavors in this Zinfandel-based, traditional Northern California blend.

This wine's raisin and ripe blackberry aromas include whiffs of cinnamon and nutmeg. The solid, balanced palate pops with acidity and noticeable oak. Vanilla, cinnamon, cassis, tobacco and citrus peel flavors carry into the finish with momentum. Drink through 2026.

A plump candied-blackberry aroma and a touch of wet slate make for a very inviting nose to this bottling, which is bolstered by 9% Petit Verdot, 5% Malbec and 2% Cabernet Franc. It tightens up on the palate thanks to firm tannins, and delivers flavors of black cherry, milk chocolate and toast. Acidity rises into the finish.

This producer gives this style of bone-dry Champagne just the right bottle aging to allow it soften and fill out with ripe fruit. Of course, it still has crispness as well as a tight mineral texture. Together with the fruit, the elements are balanced, right in place, giving a wine that is ready to drink.

Attractively perfumed, this wine is ripe with kiwi and pink-grapefruit flavors. Its zesty acidity and mineral edge suggest that it will age well, certainly over the next several months. Drink from late 2018.

Ripe, tropical-fruit-flavored Sauvignon Blanc dominates this soft, smooth wine. With its young fruits and flavors of lemon candy and quince, it needs a few more months to come together. Drink from early 2019.

The style of this estate is for extra crisp, red-currant-flavored wine, and this attractively named bottling matches that profile. The tight acidity, crisp texture and young fruitiness suggest that it will be better in a few months when it has softened. Drink from late 2018.
Spicy, peppery and with an herbal edge, this wine has a dense texture, rich red currant and rhubarb flavors and intense, spice at the end. It needs a few more months, so drink from late 2018.

Siblings Florence and Philippe Giraud reserve 10% of their red vineyards for white wine. This is ripe, with soft, smooth creamed-pear flavors. Acidity and crispness give the wine balance. The crisp juicy fresh character is refreshing and the wine is ready to drink.

High-toned smoke, char, baking spice, berry and herb aromas are followed by plentiful currant, plum and vanilla flavors, with a crème de cassis finish. The tannins are surprisingly soft for the variety.
Dark blackberry fruit meets with raw game on the nose of this bottling. Tangy black-plum flavors meet with a funky kick on the palate.

A little shy and straightforward, this offers aromas and flavors of softly baked apple, clove-spiked orange peel and pie crust. It's medium in weight, with enough acidity to keep the palate from feeling too rich, abundant or overdone.
Citrus and pear flavors come comfortably together in this fresh, light and fruity wine. It's open and soft, bright with acidity and crisp at the end. Drink now.
This is a dull tannic red, earthy in dried herb, sage and a lasting note of clove. It is full bodied and presents as duly ripe.

Vibrant, lifted red plum and currant aromas are the star of this wine's bouquet, while the palate boasts darker flavors of black cherry and berry. It's medium-minus in weight, with integrated tannins and a solid finish.
Aromas of green coffee bean, garden herb and flower are followed by elegantly styled fruit flavors. Coffee notes linger on the finish. The concentration seems quite light.

Initial Damask rose notes on the nose are filled out with ripe peach scents, with just a little air. The palate then majors on lemon-tempered, fresh and bottled peach fruit. This is medium sweet and totally juicy but comes with a welcome lemon fillip on the long intense finish.

Beautifully aromatic notions of citrus peel and blossom reach the nose. The creamy fine bubbles that follow accentuate those hints of blossom even more on the slender, fresh, bright and utterly invigorating palate. This is light, floral, and unusual, but totally charming. The finish is dry and whistle clean with another hit of that pure expressive citrus florality.

A very fragrant nose suggests ripe juicy pear and full-fruited pleasure. The palate obliges with gentle, pure and very inviting fresh notes of both green and yellow pear. The juiciness sits well and initially belies the undeniable power at the core of this wine. It wears its concentrated fruit and measured balanced with great charm. The finish is off dry and very refreshing.

The ripe peach notes apparent on the nose are tempered by zesty lemon. The palate picks up this theme where juicy fleshy peach vies with sprightly bright lemon for attention. The result is resounding bright joyful fruitiness on a long, off-dry and fresh finish. Lovely.

One of a series of single-parcel wines, this is rich and full bodied. Dense tannins march with the warm, ripe black fruits. Wood aging shows lightly, giving the wine a spicy character. A blend of local grapes, this herbal wine will likely be ready to drink from 2020.

Gamy berry, herb, mint and oaky aromas open this high-end Prieto Picudo. A firm grinding palate is anchored by muscular tannins and bold acidity. Savory oaky berry and plum flavors are saucy and complex, while this finishes long and choppy, with chocolaty oak flavors and lasting savory notes. Drink through 2025.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: The end of the great line of Premier Crus in Gevrey-Chambertin shares some of the same richness. Just approaching maturity this wine retains beautiful cherry fruits while increasing the depth of ripeness and concentration. It is ready to drink.

Vines up to 80 years in age have contributed to this rich wine. Now in its beautiful maturity, it has an golden character, both in its color and in the way the fruit has developed wonderful secondary flavors, with almonds and spice coming through. Drink the wine now.

This well-structured wine shows the combination of rich black fruit and tannins that is the hallmark of this appellation. Join that with the ripeness of the vintage, and this is a wine that can age. Drink from 2021.

Juicy, with a medium-built backbone of intense fresh acidity, this wine is savory in spirit and style, with large helpings of black tea, cardamom and forest pine. The fruit component is defined in cherry, cola and vanilla.
Rich while also mineral textured, this wine, produced by Féry et Fils, shows excellent potential. Layers of white fruits, acidity and a taut character promise aging. Drink this tense wine from 2020.

Made entirely with Arneis, this fragrant sparkler offers enticing scents of field flower, white stone fruit, crushed herb and a whiff of pastry. The savory, silky palate doles out white peach, yellow apple, tangerine slice and a hint of nutmeg alongside fresh acidity and a creamy mousse. It has complexity but also remarkable freshness for an 11 year old.?
designation: Faiv Blanc de Blancs Brut Metodo Classico

description: Tropical fruit, crushed herb, red bell pepper and fragrant white flower are just some of the aromas you'll find on this expressive white. On the juicy palate, fresh acidity brightens white peach and grapefruit while a note of white pepper lifts the finish.

Vines more than 55 years old give extra concentration to this generous wine. White fruits are cut with lime acidity and gently textured. To balance that freshness, the rich, rounded character is immediate and attractive. Drink now.
designation: Clos de la Fontaine Vieilles Vignes Sur Lie

description: The Anjou Villages appellation is warm enough to ripen both versions of Cabernet, Franc and Sauvignon. This rich while balanced wine is good proof of that with its ripe black fruits and acidity. It wouldn't be Loire without the smoky, lightly stalky backdrop that will allow the wine to age. Drink from 2020.
This is a rich, ripe and well-balanced rosé. Made from Pinot Noir, it has hints of red cherry as well as red currants, with crisp intensity and spice. It's ready to drink now.
This rich, intense wine is deliciously juicy and fresh. Its acidity and lemon flavors are balanced by a creamy apple tone that gives a ripe feel. It's a fine wine, ready to drink now.

This is made from grapes grown at Three Palms Vineyard, alongside other valley floor and mountain fruit, including 10% Merlot and smaller percentages of Petit Verdot, Cabernet Franc and Malbec. Smooth, lush and robust in dark cherry and plum, it's fruit forward and full bodied, with considerable ripeness.

Aromas of ripe orchard fruit, oak, toast and coconut lead the nose. On the enveloping palate, you'll find dried apricot, toasted oak, nut and a hint of crushed herb. Enjoy over the next few years to capture the remaining fruit richness.

This limited cuvée includes about one-quarter whole clusters, and saw 30% new French oak. Strawberry, raspberry and a light wash of mocha orchestrate a young, fresh and fruity wine ready for immediate enjoyment.
Aromas of cedar, menthol and dark berry emerge from the glass. The dense palate offers ripe black plum, mocha and clove alongside close-grained tannins. Drink after 2022.

Still tasting quite young, this tight, chewy wine seems to be in the midst of pulling itself together. Components of sour plum, wild cherry and green tea are in place, but the seamless ripeness of past vintages is not, at least for now.
Compact and stubbornly closed, this offers suggestions of plum and cherry, framed with stem and earth. The tannins conjure up black tea, finishing dark and astringent.
Tense and linear, this offers pomegranate, clove, menthol and licorice flavors. Taut close-grained tannins provide the tight framework while fresh acidity lends balance. Drink after 2020.
This is a commercial-style red blend that smells chocolaty and tastes almost like maple syrup. It has noticeable sweetness and a soft mouth-coating texture.
Fruity, crisp and off dry, this is a simple, very drinkable wine. It has a zesty touch and plenty of acidity to go with its red berry and carame flavors. Drink now.
This smells of spices, barrel char and milk chocolate. Its raw, tannic palate shows highly evident oak, tasting of reedy plum and wood. The finish is tough.
This wine's strawberry aromas fall somewhere between jammy and sharp. It's citrusy and lean on the palate, with plum skin, cranberry and salt flavors that lead to a tangy, sour finish.
Candied raspberry fruit along with orange-peel flavors and zesty acidity give this wine a crisp while not quite balanced character. It is fruity and has intense acidity. Drink now.
This wine is soft, giving caramel and spice flavors lifted by candied red fruits. Drink soon for it's easy fruit tones.

Even in dry Jurançon wine, a hint of honey comes from the two Manseng grapes in the blend. Here the honey taste adds to the wine's weight and richness. Yellow fruits, spice and pepper give ripeness and a tight edge. Drink from 2019.

This is a big, dense red, with aromas of cherry, chocolate cake, licorice and a little menthol. The full-bodied palate is savory and herbal, with more licorice notes and fine-grained tannins. This should cellar well through 2028.

While exceptionally light footed and frisky, this off-dry Riesling offers bold yellow-peach and cantaloupe flavors glazed by sweet hibiscus nectar. Briskly composed and refreshingly mineral, it finishes with a delightfully nervous tension.

Lemon cream, peach and mango show on the nose of this top-tier bottling from the historic regional producer. The flavors are light and bright, with lemon juice and apple flesh, though the wine feels a bit more reserved in this vintage.
This wine's black cherry, herb, graphite, woodspice and chili pepper aromas are followed by a palate tightly wound with burly tannins and fresh acidity. It needs some time in the cellar to settle.

This wine's appealing cherry and plum aromas feature an oaky note suggestive of maple. It's medium in body, its spicy, oak-aided flavors of cherry and currant driven long into the finish by lively acidity. It ends with tobacco and chocolate notes. Drink through 2020.
Neutral aromas are largely clean and barely suggest white peach. This boxed SB is plump and citrusy on the palate, with citric flavors that turn a bit green and grassy on the back side.
A heavy oak influence gives this full-bodied wine smoky, charred aromas and flavors that dampen the fruity components that may have been in the grapes. It's bold and spicy.

Aromas of toasted bread crust carry over to the lean, racy palate along with bitter walnut and mature yellow apple skin. It's vibrant and dry, with firm acidity and vigorous bubbles, but it lacks fruit.

Melony aromas are bright and clean, but simple. A fresh, firm palate is blazing with acidity, while this old-vines Sauvignon Gris tastes of grapefruit at first, then more like grass. A pyrazinic finish flattens out quickly, indicating that this is basic more than elevated.

This wine comes from a 160-acre vineyard just east of Bordeaux city. Half-and-half Sémillon and Sauvignon Blanc, it has a mineral edge as well as tightfruits. The herbal flavors, bright acidity and crisp aftertaste are attractive now.
Dominated by 65% Sémillon, this wine is ripe, with a creamy texture and rounded fruits. It's all about green plums with touches of apricot, spice and balanced acidity. Drink from 2019.
Made entirely from Petite Sirah, this is given three years in neutral barrels and was bottled in 2016. Thick, syrupy, soft and sublime, it imparts a heady decadence of blackberry, cedar and tobacco.

Notes of russet-pear peel, ripe peach and earth are pervaded by citrus zestiness on the nose. The palate frames these in gentle sweetness but the concentrated fruit and zestiness provide a backdrop of firm freshness. This wine has lovely balance, great concentration and an extended, off-dry finish.

A blend of the historic Sierra Madre and Bien Nacido vineyards, this reserve wine shows toasted hazelnut, seared lemon rind, salted apricot and a touch of sour cream on the tangy yet smoky nose.
