Aromas of red berry, underbrush and a balsamic note emerge from the glass. The solid palate shows black cherry, star anise and clove alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink 2020–2026.

This Pommard clone bottling showed significant variation during tasting, the first example exhibiting leathery aromas and some bitter tack room flavors. The second bottle merits this score, with juicy cranberry and raspberry fruit, ample acidity and good length.

Sourced from vines planted a quarter century ago, this stainless steel-aged white offers smooth and balanced fresh pear flavors, with refreshing, wet stone-like minerality. Light hints of garden herbs make it a model Pinot Gris with style, length and the ability to age. Drink now–2025.

The appellation shows well in this wine, sharing full-bodied concentration within a cooler-climate personality of woody graphite, chalky tannin and floral, dried herb. Cassis and currant accentuate the burbling acidity. This will do well in the cellar. Best 2020–2030.

This is a crisp, textured expression of pure Chardonnay. Acidity, minerality and shining white fruit and citrus flavors give this wine a pure, direct line of tight fruit and acidity. Let this bottling age a few months, and drink it at the end of 2018.

Racy lime acidity is offset by sunny pear and kiwi in this crisp medium-bodied white. Dry in style and enriched by a hint of cashew on the midpalate, it finishes long with juicy squirts of white grapefruit. Drink now through 2021.
Earthy, meaty, oaky, aromas and rich ripe cherry and strawberry flavors give this full-bodied and plush-textured wine plenty to appreciate. It tastes generous and feels smooth and mouthfilling.

A dark purple color and overripe raisin, berry and clove aromas introduce this Navarran blend. The palate is cloying and overweight, with wood resin and clove flavors. It finishes with that clove note, confirming its one-dimensional character.
Herbal, with green fruit and a zesty texture, this wine is too fresh for its own good. The acidity dominates, leaving a wine that has intense crispness.

This wine has an unusually deep color, assertive aromas like wood smoke and cloves and very concentrated, spicy, charred flavors that don't seem to come from the grapes but probably from oak products used during aging.
This Chardonnay's floral aromas are inoffensive but not very wine-like. The palate is round but hollow in the middle, with briny citrus flavors and mustard- and green herb-inflected finish.
This rich, medium-sweet pink wine is made from the local Padeiro grape. It smells like a candy shop, its sugary and ripe strawberry flavors just balanced with acidity. Drink now.
Very ripe fruit flavors and a hint of sweetness give this medium-bodied wine a resemblance to pear nectar. The texture is soft and mouth-coating and the acidity is low.

Honey, lemon curd, plumeria and white jasmine aromas meet with poached apple on the nose of this bottling. It's subtle on the palate and smoothed out with even flavors of roasted pear, caramelized apple, lemon juice and toast.

A dense plummy nose of milk chocolate and cherry compote is quite unctuous for this dark brooding blend of 62% Cabernet Sauvignon and 38% Petite Sirah. It's very soft and welcoming upon entry to the palate, showing slightly tart yet plush plum and fig flavors. The tannins are still sticky at this young age.

The result of a collaboration between Sonoma-based winemaker/consultant Paul Hobbs and the Bertrand Vigouroux family in Cahors, this wine is packed with fruit, acidity and generous tannins. Without any wood aging, it is all blackberry flavors, with a crisp edge and a dry core. Drink this perfumed wine from 2019.

This Albariño's floral aromas are a bit misleading, because it packs pop. The palate is full and textured, with mature grapefruit and orange flavors that finish in peak condition. It's bold, staunchly acidic and still fresh; drink through 2019.

From vineyards in the Douro Superior, this wine is a ripe example of the rich tannins of the region. It has a dusty texture, firm black fruits and good concentration. It is still on the young side and will be better from 2019.

Blending sizable portions of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot with Cabernet Franc, this approachable mix opens in a succulence of cherry and berry that remain juicy through the fleshy midpalate and finish. The oak is well-integrated and the tannins softened.

Ripe grape and plum aromas fill the nose in this exuberant and fruity wine. The palate brings a rich blackberry-jam flavor that seems to coat the tongue in a velvety texture, ending on a delicious dark-grape tone on the finish.

A bright copper color and citrus aromas are followed by tart cherry and pink-grapefruit flavors in this fruity and crisply balanced wine that is a late release in magnum only. It has a refreshing, vibrant mouthfeel and clean finish and an unusually strong stream of bubbles that keeps going 30 minutes after pouring. In this large format, it will certainly keep improving through at least 2022.

Somewhat reserved for a vineyard that often shows unbound power, this bottling begins with rounded red-cherry and boiled pomegranate aromas on the nose. The palate offers cooked cranberry, oregano and earth, wrapped in balanced acidity and tannins.

Plush but not fat, this subtle and complex wine combines peach and vanilla flavors with fig, crushed rock and bright acidity. The creamy mouthfeel stays well balanced as lemon and crisp apple notes come forward on the midpalate and linger through the finish.

Engaging and nicely oaky but also well structured, this full-bodied wine has dense layers of ripe fruity spicy flavors and almost chewy tannins. It is concentrated, deep and with a lengthy finish. Best after 2022.

Pressed wildflower, ripe white stone fruit and whiffs of baked bread take shape in the glass. The creamy, ethereal palate offers ripe Rennet apple, white cherry, orange rind and a hint of toasted hazelnut alongside bright acidity and a silky mousse. A ginger note lingers on the finish.

The vineyard for this wine lies in the far east of the Entre-Deux-Mers. It has produced a soft, fruity wine with gentle tannins and open fruitiness. The wine has attractive black-currant flavors and acidity along with a dry core that keeps everything together. Drink now.

This medium-bodied wine has good fresh fruit flavors that verge on jammy, boosted by a sweet-seeming oak character that includes vanilla, maple and brown sugar accents. It's smooth in texture and light in tannin content for this varietal.

Yeasty aromas include notes of compost and damp leaves. On the palate, this is crisp but also tomatoey in feel. Flavors of cherry tomato, citrus and green herb settle on a tart, dry, limited finish. This is 100% Trepat.
Beneath a sulfur blanket there are aromas of ripe pear and guava. The palate is slightly creamy texture, but the acidity juts out above it, making the wine seem overworked and a little unbalanced.
Baking spice, vanilla, licorice and dried cherry aromas are followed by dried-out-seeming fruit flavors. Dry tannins and cranberry flavors fill it out. It seems quite evolved for its age.
Overextracted aromas of tangy black plum and blackberry jam show on the nose of this bottling. Ripe flavors of black-plum juice prove too tangy and nearly vinegar-like.

This wine's black-skinned fruit, underbrush and baking spice aromas emerge from the glass. The easy-drinking, approachable palate offers Morello cherry, clove and white pepper touches alongside supple tannins. Enjoy soon.
Very ripe berry flavors and a broad smooth texture propel this full-bodied and mouth-coating wine to a lingering finish. Oaky accents of cinnamon, smoke and vanilla add complexity.

Citrus, creamed corn and butterscotch aromas are enticing on the nose. The medium-bodied palate is bright in flavors of lemon and tart pineapple rind, with lively acidity keeping focus through the crème-brûlée finish.
Ripe, soft and fruity, this is a rich, caramel-flavored wine. Its light acidity and warm, rounded texture are easy on the palate, with a style that is just ready for food. Drink now.

A punchy nose includes aromas of green herbs, scallion, bell pepper and stone fruits. This Verdejo has an oily texture cut by lemony acidity. Salty flavors of orange peel and citrus fruits hollow out in front of a plump finish with lasting citric acidity.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: This wine is earthy and herbal, with a slightly carbonic effervescence that's both fresh and distracting. Cranberry and rhubarb highlight a moderate structure with sparks of forest floor and cardamom.

Reminiscent of running through an orchard in the peak of autumn, this offers nostalgic aromas of sweet hay with ripe apples and pears. The palate is rounded in feel and concentrated in these same tones, with a revitalizing wet limestone streak from start to finish.

Rose, perfumed berry, exotic spice and new leather aromas are at the forefront on this elegantly structured red. On the palate, polished fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity offset juicy Marasca cherry, crushed raspberry and baking spice. Drink 2021–2028.
This tightly wound, dense wine shows a touch of reduction on the nose. It's tart and spicy, with layered flavors of tangerine, mint, cardamom, tobacco and white pepper that intrigue and delight.

A blend of 70% Montepulciano and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon, this starts off with an enveloping nose of baked cherry, hoisin, olive and dried herbs. The medium-bodied palate is well-defined and full of life, boasting fresher cherry and currant flavors speckled with dried tobacco leaf, all floating on a persistent river of acidity and finely meshed tannins. It's approachable now but should hold well through 2023.

A subtle nose of lemon defines the faint nose. The palate then brings a kind of honeyed citrus where lemon zest has an edge of candied richness. The finish is wonderfully clean and citric, lip smacking and juicy in its fruity dryness. Lovely.

Rather boisterous on the nose, this bottling shows fresh aromas of black cherry alongside pencil shavings and milk chocolate. There is solid depth to the palate, where flavors of smashed blackberry and boysenberry meet with tangy black-plum skins and roasted coffee notes on the finish.

The black cherry notes on the nose of this wine are vivid and fleshy. The palate reins them in with a lovely outline of pristine conifer overtones, channelling the cherry notes into lip-smacking freshness. Dry, rustic but very charming.
Menthol, minty eucalyptus greets the nose of this wine, not uncommon for the appellation. A soft midpalate of soy, cherry and cassis meets leather and grippy tannin on the finish.

Silky smooth, this vineyard-designate offers a high-toned streak of acidity within a substantial framework of powerful ripeness. Cherry, blueberry and coffee-cake flavors and aromas play nicely with one another, with a lasting finish of black licorice.

Clean and crisp on the nose, this blend of 42% Viognier, 21% Marsanne, 20% Grenache Blanc and 17% Roussanne shows mandarin pith, sliced apple and Asian pear on the nose. It's tightly wound on the palate, with fresh citrus, crushed granite and Gravenstein apple flavors that ride strong acidity into the finish.
This wine's blackberry and orange zest aromas lead to black plum, pomegranate, chocolate and clove flavors. It's balanced by firm tannins that even out as the long, smoky finish takes shape.
Perfumed in rose petal and cherry blossom, this 100% varietal wine has a chalky grip of tannin and substantial mouthfeel, with dusty spice and leather. The fruit is brightly accentuated in cassis.

This rounded, approachable blend is well-made, blending 51% Cabernet Sauvignon with smaller percentages of Merlot, Malbec, Petit Verdot and Cabernet Franc. Concentrated in big, burly black fruit, it offers accents of tobacco and mocha around a thick midpalate and finishing touch of char.
This young wine still has a stalky character, but the rich fruit and warm tannins hold promise for the future. Drink this ripe, spicy wine with fruitcake flavors from 2020.

Just one barrel was made, and it was aged for 18 months. Oak-driven aromas open into flavors of toasted coconut and roasted cashews. The medium-bodied berry fruit is clean and fresh, with highlights of orange peel and chocolate.

Dark berry, Mediterranean brush and carob aromas take center stage. Made with Nero d'Avola, the smooth, juicy palate delivers ripe blackberry, ground pepper and clove alongside pliant tannins. Enjoy through 2020.

That Cabernet Franc makes fine sparkling Crémant in the Loire is obvious from this red-currant-flavored, crisp-textured wine. It is full of sparkling fruitiness, vibrant with acidity and a fresh aftertaste. Drink now.

Crisp, herbal and apple flavored, this perfumed wine is ripe, full in the mouth and still young. It has great acidity and a tight mineral texture. The wine comes from 25-year-old vines that add concentration to the fruits. Drink from 2019.

This wine is near equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec, finished off with a dash of Syrah. The aromas show some volatility, along with notes of vanilla and dried cherry. The cherry and green-pepper flavors are lighter styled, with tart cranberry-like acidity. Green-pepper notes linger on the finish.

From a hot vintage, this wine shows a baked berry aroma on the nose, doused in tobacco, clove and other sweet oak spices. The palate is simultaneously plummy and ripe, yet harsh, with sharp acids and bitter tannins holding court.

Aromas of leafy red fruits and orange are flaky. This is cloying on the palate, but not without hope. Red-fruit flavors are sugary, while this offers plum and raspberry notes on a finish with notable residual sugar.

This Merlot-Cabernet Sauvignon-Syrah blend is woody and warm upfront, with assertive notes of pencil shavings and sawdust atop some berry preserve and raspberry sauce tones. Full and round in feel, the wood notes continue to dominate the palate, with plush, somewhat medicinal cherry and blackberry flavors in the background.
The dark and rusty color is almost red. Aromas of roasted red fruits, tire rubber and baked beans precede a foamy palate with no smoothness. Cherry-skin flavors finish rough then hollow.
This lively, fruity wine offers attractive acidity and a good mix of creamed-apple and citrus flavors. It is crisp, clean, full of fruitiness and is ready to drink now.

A lovely and affordable example of Margaret River Cab, this displays the style's characteristic red and black-current, pencil lead and eucalyptus aromas with a lick of chocolate and charred wood too. Medium to full bodied, the savory tannins are big and the cedar notes are apparent, but there's still plenty of fruit to prop them up along with a satiny texture. Drink now–2033.

Although this wine was fermented dry, in this forward, ripe year the fruit brings an impression of sweetness. Juicy peach, apricot and papaya flavors commingle, with a fresh acidity that makes it delicious when slightly chilled on a hot day.

From Tasmania's Tamar Valley, this fleshy, medium-bodied Pinot Gris (indicating the Alsatian rather than Italian style) sees 20% fermented with native yeasts, and this make all the difference, adding heaps of interest and layers. The heady nose is a deep well of aromas like honeyed pear, yeasty apple, peach, jasmine and cherry blossom. It's dry yet rich with a fleshy skins-y texture and a long tangy finish that begs for another sip. Drink with buttery shellfish or on its own.

This full-flavored, fruit-powered wine takes off with ripe blackberry and black cherry notes. Barrel aging has contributed brown spice, cola and chocolate accents, which fill out the finish. It's quite tasty and ready to enjoy now and over the next couple years.

From one of a handful of Oregon wineries working with Sauvignon Blanc, this wine focuses on the natural, herbaceous pungency of the grape. The palate is ripe in pineapple, apple and melon flavors, giving an appealing, round feel. Touches of hibiscus and honey trail on the finish.

Part of a range of wines that have been given a low dosage to make them extra dry, this wine is a blend of Chardonnay from the Côte des Blancs and the Marne Valley. It is strongly mineral in texture, with tight acidity as well as intense grapefruit flavors. It needs to age a few extra months, so keep this bottling until 2019.

Aromas of pomegranate and coffee set the scene for flavors of tart cherry, Seville orange, herbs and rose. With stiff tannins and a pervading sense of sourness, this wine never quite comes together on the palate.
Green aromas of lettuce and bell pepper announce a wine with little fruit. Its chunky palate is barely in shape, with vegetal notes of arugula and spinach on the back end.

Minor hints of red apple flesh, creamed orange and straw dance softly on the nose of this direct white. There's some weight to the midpalate despite the low intensity of citrus-based flavors. Drink now.
Soapy floral and tropical fruit notes are pronounced on the nose of this off-dry Riesling. It's a tad sugary and perfumy in style but crisp lemon acidity refreshes on the finish.
This wine's medicinal, roasted black fruit aromas include animal and Band-Aid notes. It's a syrupy Garnacha with overripe plum and blackberry flavors that's at once sticky and acidic on the finish.
Vanilla, baking spice, game, dried cherry, Band Aid and medicine cabinet aromas are at the fore in this wine. Light fruit and medicinal flavors follow. It doesn't come together.

With nine months in wood, this estate-collection wine is rich with spice and has a polished texture. The blend of five grapes works well, giving black fruits, ripe tannins and a juicy aftertaste. Drink now.

This lovely and lingering white impresses from start to finish, showing a wealth of pear and peach flavors within an inviting jasmine aroma. It finishes in swift teases of wild vanilla and subtle oak.

This wine has a feral aspect to it—a mix of wild mushroom and gritty stone, with the grit and grip persistent on the palate. Asian pear, apple and nutmeg highlight a full-bodied concentration nuanced in toasted oak.

Pretty aromas of wild berry, blue flower and tilled soil lift from the glass along with a whiff espresso. Reflecting the nose, the taut, medium-bodied palate evokes blackberry, licorice and coffee bean framed in polished tannins and bright acidity.

Deeply yellow colored, this opens with aromas of Spanish broom, bread crust and mature tropical fruit. On the savory palate, tangy acidity lifts ripe peach, yellow pear, orange peel and wild herb. A smoky mineral note graces the finish.

Planted on original rootstocks, this vibrant linear white shows flair and finesse. It opens with aromas of sea breeze, wet stone and orchard fruit that carry over to the racy palate along with pear and lemon. Crisp acidity provides the backbone while a tangy saline note backs up the finish.

Yellow wildflower and orchard fruit aromas mingle with a whiff of baked bread. On the creamy palate, bright acidity lifts flavors of Golden Delicious, tangy lemon and a hint of hazelnut. A silky mousse lends finesse.

This offers enticing scents of field flower, white stone fruit and bread dough. On the vibrant palate, you'll find ripe Bartlett pear, nectarine and juicy citrus offset by an elegant mousse and crisp acidity.

Fresh raspberry and pomegranate mix with hibiscus, sumac and French toast aromas on this bottling from a vineyard just south of San Francisco. It's very fresh and snappy on the precise palate, with bright raspberry and cranberry flavors leading into dried ginger and all spice.

This is a tightly wound, youthful and still developing, medium-bodied wine, with plenty of beauty to show for it even as it evolves. Dense black cherry, plum and cardamom flavors are complemented by floral aromatics of rose, violet and lavender.

Pure, expressive fruit flavors and a supremely polished texture make this full-bodied wine a delight to drink. It practically oozes raspberry and blackberry aromas, and floods the palate with flavors of berries and peppery spice.

Smoky cherry and tar open the way to well-defined flavors of cola spice and vanilla in this 100% varietal wine from the famous Oakville site. Integrated, it is succulent and fruit-forward with sultry, sensuous texture and heavy toasted oak.

Gamy plum and red berry aromas are true to Pinot Noir but nothing special. A sappy palate goes flat with airing, while this tastes of oak, berries and clove. A woody tasting finish with persistent clove notes remains fairly flat.
This soft, unfocused wine has toastiness and almond flavors but not much in the way of fruit. Drink the wine now.
Caramel and spice flavors give a curious edge to this wine. Dense tannins leave little sign of any fruit. It has too much structure.
Acidity shows strongly in this wine along with the dry tannins. It has weight, suggesting ripe fruits that need to develop. Drink this wine from 2021.
This soft wine is open, ripe and bright with apple flavors. Its softness is underlined by spice and toastiness in the background. Drink the wine now.

This is a dry wine, closed and very firm. Its tannins come from the ripe Merlot fruits that were extracted too much. It should soften to bring out the blackberry flavors, but it is likely to remain austere.

This is a good, reliable unoaked style of wine that will please a lot of different drinkers. It has mild pear and apple aromas, fresh-tasting fruit flavors and a good lively texture that refreshes the mouth.

This is a good, middle-of-the-road wine that should satisfy a wide range of people. It has appealing apple and pear aromas, a fresh but smooth texture and light baking-spice flavors to accent the fruit notes.
Made entirely from Sangiovese, this offers violet, thyme and tilled soil aromas. Supple tannins frame its red plum, licorice and baking spice flavors. Enjoy soon.
This wine's nose is rather shy but eventually reveals a whiff of spring flower. The simple palate offers mature apple, pear and beeswax notes alongside fresh acidity.

Aromas of green wood, green herb, tire rubber, baking spice, mint and cherry lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that dip in the middle. Orange-peel notes linger on the finish. It wants a bit more acid and tannin structure to stand it up.
This opens with red fruit, baking spice and Mediterranean scrub aromas. The easygoing palate evokes black cherry and clove, with supple tannins. Drink soon.

A nose of pure, juicy and very ripe peach makes for a very inviting opening. The palate follows with an even fuller, even riper picture of that peach, supported by sweetness. This is juicy, flowing, expressive aromatic in its peachiness and tempered both by lemon-zest notes and a phenolic backdrop to finish with just a slight sweetness. Lovely.

This medium-bodied wine offers depth and complexity that are unusual for the varietal in California. It has lightly earthy, mineral, figgy aromas, a palate-coating texture and layers of flavor that unfold from apple to almond to fig, giving it the substance to be a main-course wine, not just a pre-dinner beverage.

This nicely balanced wine poses tantalizing, bright fruit flavors against relatively full body and wraps them in a velvety blanket of fine-grained tannins. Red cherry, cranberry and light earthy notes give it welcome complexity.

Pale pink in the glass, this rosé shows very subtle aromas of thin lemon-skin ribbons, raspberry water and a whiff of cotton candy on the inviting and fresh nose. There is extreme grip to the sip, which is all about texture and freshness, showing delicate touches of lime, chalk and pink-fleshed fruit.

A lovely note of mandarin peel hovers on the nose alongside hints of honeysuckle. The palate follows with a fully sweet sweep of ripe peach and pear, edged with lemon freshness. It is the tension between lemony tartness and full sweet flowing fruit that creates tension here. Lovely now, sure to develop. Drink now through 2028.

From the plateau vineyards south of the Douro river around the town of Ervedosa do Douro, this wine is powerful and rich. It has a luscious, Port-like character, ripe with rounded tannins and black fruits. Made from old vines and some Touriga Nacional, this wine is still maturing. It should be ready to drink from 2021.
This is tannic and heavy, made in a big full-bodied style that overwhelms at times. Soy, leather and earth feature prominently.
Muddled red currant and rhubarb greet the nose of this bottling and carry through to the lightweight palate. It's straightforward and direct, with a short finish.
A freshly sawn oak aroma and equally oaky flavors make this wine a one-note song. It is medium bodied and reasonably smooth in texture.
A classic Gascon blend of Ugni Blanc, Colombard and Sauvignon Blanc, this is tight, fruity and intensely fresh. A young, bright, herbal character adds tang to the fruitiness. Drink now.
Aromas of strawberry balsamic and dried hay carry to the tart red-fruit driven palate. This is lean in feel, with sharp acidity, gritty tannins and an astringent finish.
Clean citrus and sea-spray aromas carry to the light-bodied palate. This is zesty and bright, yet simplistic and short.

For the region, this Taïx family property is large at 79 acres. Wood aging has given this wine a smoky, spicy character that contrasts with the juicy black-cherry and blueberry flavors. Its structure is still firm, showing the tannins of the vintage. Drink from 2022.

This rich Domaines Rodrigues-Lalande wine is already well balanced. It has dense, dusty tannins, rich blackberry flavors and a general sense of comfortable ripeness. Its structure and concentration don't detract from its elegance. Drink this full wine from 2022.

Rather light in the glass, this estate bottling shows cooked red currant and cinnamon spice on the nose. The palate is both lightweight and tannic in texture, showing food-friendly flavors of star anise, clove, fennel and red fruits.

This wine's tart cherry aromas lend an intriguing contrast of ripeness and tautness. On the palate, that fresh-faced, crunchy, tart cherry fruit wins the day. It's fresh, snappy and slightly rustic—but all the more alluring for that.

A delicate nose of crushed stone, strawberry and lemon rind scents leads this bright, exotic pour from a single vineyard plot. On the palate, layered and integrated citrus and cherry flavors finish with a zesty spin. A unique pour for grilled meats and fish.

From 60–70 years old, this wine boasts a rich, concentrated backdrop. Its spice and pepper flavors are integrated with the ripe fruitiness, while delicious acidity and a touch of almond grace the finish. Drink now.
designation: Clos des Briords Cuvée Vieilles Vignes Sur Lie

description: This blend of Chardonnay and Pinot Noir is enhanced by the four-years aging. Balanced fruitiness and a toasty character give a creamy, intense wine with hints of tropical fruits as well as great acidity. Drink now.

Very light and airy in the glass, this bottling shows exotic red plums, fresh cherries, rust, bay leaf and wild mint on the lively nose. It's also lightly bodied and energetic on the palate, where tart cherry fruit is enhanced by pinches of red Mexican spices.

This is an earthy wine, funky in rose garden and compost, with a demure entry that develops into a more full-bodied sense of thickness and dense tannin over time. There's a nice flourish of strawberry and rhubarb that takes on a compote-like lushness.

Savory aromas of burnt sage and black pepper along with beef, anise and carbon flavors make this an adventurous wine. It's medium bodied, not overly ripe or rich and has a tight mouthfeel due to moderate tannins and lively acidity.

This wine's black fruit aromas come with road tar, leather and raisin notes. It's intensely tannic, with ripe, savory berry and cassis flavors and integrated oak. Chocolate and baked black fruit notes last on the strong, tannic finish. Drink through 2025.

This wine is warm and welcoming, starting with ripe plum and cherry-compote aromas, then presenting rich cherry-pie flavors that are generous but not sweet and a soothing smooth texture with just a touch of tannin.

Named after the Roman villa that once existed in Pouilly-sur-Loire (and which gave its name to Pouilly), this wine comes from old vines giving concentrated citrus and green-fruit flavors. Bright, crisp and tangy, the wine could do with some aging. Drink from 2019.
This wine comes from a parcel of vines planted on flint soil close to the Loire river. It is tense and mineral, with swathes of rich citrus, lively acidity and a tangy aftertaste. Drink now.

The Dardis cuvée is taut and citric and shows wild berry fruit. Barreled for 10 months in 30% new French oak, it shows little impact of barrel flavors at this point in time; just the slightest hint of caramel streaking through the finish.

This fruity wine is full of ripe red-cherry flavors, with a touch of smoky tannins. It has a delicious, juicy character, very open while also having a balanced structure. From vineyards to the east of the city of Saumur, the wine is bright and ready to drink.

Cola and slightly overripe aromas of raisin and fig are blanketed with oaky mocha and cocoa. This is syrupy in feel, with not much structural or acidic support. Thus you get a rich, creamy set of chocolaty berry flavors all the way through the finish.

With this producer's emphasis on Pinot Noir, this wine is like the brand's signature. Crispness balances with the soft, creamy mousse and light acidity. A blend of five different vintages, it moves easily from freshness to hints of toast. Drink now.

While demure on the nose, zingy tangerine, green apple and yellow plum shine on the palate of this thirst-quenching dry Silvaner. It's an exceptionally spry, feather-weighted wine but feels silky and lavish on the palate. The finish is prolonged by elegant murmurs of crushed stone and grapefruit astringency.

Very pale pink in the glass, this offers a bright, vivacious nose full of bubblegum sticks and watermelon water. The palate is grippy in texture and lively in acidity, showing delicious but light strawberry flavors.

Rusty red cherry, dried anise and a hint of carnation show on the nose of this bottling. A rose petal flavor is strong on the lightly bodied palate, where a firm tannic structure and solid acidity frame soft, welcoming flavors of Concord grape and vanilla on the finish.

What a wonderful value. Smooth and subtle, this medium-bodied wine layers raspberry and light earthy aromas over a smooth palate of ripe plum, tea leaf and baking spices. Soft tannins blend in nicely with a touch of good acidity for very nice balance.
This is an approachable, rounded and likable appellation wine, robustly built and shy in fruit, with soft, smooth layers of clove, red cherry and plum.

Warm spices override a wealth of blackberry crumble in this robust wine, substantial in concentration and richness. Toasty smoky oak plays a background part, allowing the wine to remain fruit forward and soft on the palate.
This wine's orange blossom and yeasty aromas seem confected. It's spritzy but shapeless, with low acidity and candied citrus and creamsicle flavors.
Considering that 2015 was a good, albeit hot, vintage, this is surprisingly edgy, with pronounced acidity. Its tart currant and plum flavors are lean and sour, lacking ripeness and richness.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: Funky compost announce an unusual wine, which Maturana Blanca is. The palate is round and lacks structure; its briny, white fruit flavors finish salty and stalky.
Herbal, jammy berry flavors lead the nose of this blocky-feeling Tempranillo. Its stewed plum and berry flavors finish peppery, gritty and herbal, with little structure.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: Wet clay, clove and lactic berry aromas set this wine up for a sticky, resiny palate. Its oaky, chocolaty, candied berry flavors seem overworked and unnatural. If you're familiar with this type of commercial wine, you can take it or leave it.

This wine's heavy chewing gum-like aromas come with a hint of peach pit. It's a rosé on its last legs: plump and rubbery, without much cut or structure. Its cheesy, salty citrus flavors trail off on the finish.

With this vintage, the former Charles Blondeau-Danne père domaine is under Piffaut family ownership with a new name. Full of white stone fruits and with a tight citrus texture, the wine is still young. Its acidity and fruitiness are matched by the tight texture and nervy character of a wine that can wait. Drink this intense wine from 2019.

Ripe berry and cassis aromas come with richer oak-based notes of mint, coconut and baking spice. A lively, fresh palate holds spicy black fruit flavors along with toast and mild herbal notes. Flavors of black coffee, black pepper and dark chocolate grace the finish on this blend of undefined red grapes. Drink through 2025.

Small proportions of Cinsault and Mourvèdre lend depth and perfume to plush, plummy black fruit flavors in this full-bodied yet finessed Grenache blend. It's densely fruity yet anchored by firm minerality and fine, persistent tannins. Fully enjoyable already but will continue to improve through 2028.

Aromas of ripe dark-skinned berry, exotic spice, espresso and a whiff of Mediterranean brush lift out of the glass. Reflecting the nose, the tense, linear palate offers Marasca cherry, licorice, clove, wild herb and coffee bean alongside taut, close-grained tannins that give the finish grip.

Sweet spice and pepper tones lend fire to fleshy black plum and mulberry here. It's a plush, full-bodied wine with edges rounded out by soft, supple tannins and a silky mouthfeel, but there's grace and balance, too. An open-knit, approachable sip but concentrated enough to improve through 2028.

Ruddy, ripe blueberry and blackberry flavors are mouthcoating and rich in this voluptuous blend of Grenache and Syrah. It's a plush wine with soft, yielding tannins and sunny acidity, but notes of pepper, smoke and herb entice. It drinks well already but should deepen in savory attributes through 2030.
Briny apple aromas are standard. This Godello is full in body and a bit flat, with little acidic edge to the palate. Fairly modest melon and green-banana flavors are understated on a simple finish.
This wine's spring wildflower and orchard fruit scents delicately lift from the glass. The straightforward palate offers nectarine, apple and tangy citrus flavors while bitter almond marks the close.
region_1: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore

description: This is a curious, highly individual Malbec. The nose is briary, with sandalwood notes and a suggestion of blueberry. The palate, however, is severely ripped with acidity, such that this is borderline astringent. Flavors of plum, currant, lemon, spice and leafy herbs finish gritty due to enamel-peeling acidity.

Underbrush, wild berry and grilled Porcini mushroom aromas come together in this straightforward red, along with a whiff of leather. The easygoing palate offers crushed wild cherry, orange zest and clove hints alongside solid tannins. Drink through 2019.

From the Saint-Martin estate, which has been in the same family since 1740, this wine is rich while balanced with herbal acidity and touches of citrus. The ripe berry red-currant and berry fruits are still developing in this young wine, so wait to drink until later in 2018.

Produced from grapes grown within sight of the sea, this wine is light both in color and in flavors. Its delicate texture and light touch of acidity and red fruits are balanced by crispness and immediate freshness. Drink now.
Lightly toasty, this wine is both crisp and fruity It has acidity, touches of apples and a nutty minerality at the end. Drink now.
A blend from a number of different parcels in Primeaux-Prissey just south of Nuits Saint-Georges, this wine is juicy and fruity. Crisp acidity gives a lift at the end. Drink now.
Aromas of soil, violet, herb and cherry lead to medium-bodied fruit flavors that trail on the finish. It seems slightly evolved for its age.
Garnet in the glass, this Cabernet Sauvignon has aromas of black cherry, black pepper and cassis. In the mouth, there are flavors of black cherry, plum and black raspberry.

This is an ultralush wine, harking back to Chardonnay from several decades ago. A buttered popcorn note overwhelms the nose, nearly overpowering the peach and pineapple tones. The palate is rich and opulent, with the oak and malolactic influence sitting heavily on the tongue. Those fans of Chardonnay from the '80s and '90s will find this wine a trip down memory lane.

This is a fairly simple, fruit-forward wine that mixes a tomato leaf quality with ripe watermelons and red berries. There's weight and fruit concentration on the palate but there's a nice balance of acidity as well.

Fermented in granite lagars, this blend holds Touriga Nacional, Jaen, Alfrocheiro and Tinta Roriz—the main red grapes of the Dão. Rich and stylish, it's packed with firm black fruits and firm tannins. Drink from 2020.

Rounded, rich and full bodied, this wine brings out all the great qualities of the white Encruzado variety. It is poised between freshness, ripe white stone fruits, a crisp texture and toasty richness. Drink this wine from 2020.

The aromas are expressive, with abundant notes of smoked ham along with herb, wet stone and olive. The palate has a sensuous soft feel, with fruit and savory flavors carrying on the smoked meat finish. It's all about elegance. Give it some time to open up.
designation: Stonessence Estate In the Rocks Vineyard

description: This wine is exotic on the nose in rose and white pepper, as it opens into a palate of thick rich cherry-cordial flavor and enduring acidity. The freshness complements the lushness of the fruit and maintains a lively aspect of brightness.

Full flavored and rather full bodied, too, this wine exudes vivid and spicy aromas of pears, browned butter and toasted almonds, feels broad and mouthfilling and has softly ripe flavors. Light baking spices add complexity and a nicely viscous texture combines with good acidity for a lingering finish.

Roasted blackberry, soft vanilla and rich milk chocolate aromas start off this suave blend of 75% Cabernet Sauvignon and 25% Syrah. Polished tannins frame flavors of black-cherry and caramel on the palate, resulting in a rich and pleasing wine.
This is an intense, tightly structured wine. Very mineral in character, it is as much about texture as about fruit. It needs some aging to fill out the fruitiness. Drink this complex wine from 2019.

Intense fruit and a strong mineral texture give this wine impressive richness. At the same time, it combines apple and quince fruit, intense acidity and ripeness, making it the sort of wine that could age. Although it can be drunk now, it will be even better from 2019.

Ripe but restrained, fruity yet elegant, this richly concentrated red offers luscious black cherry and berry flavors nuanced by hints of earth, smoke and spice. The palate is rich and fleshy but anchored by taut acidity and a finely edged backbone of tannins.

A concentrated and powerful brew of earthy, roasted berry and plum aromas includes a hint of burnt rubber. This feels thick and blocky, with only modest acidity. Stewy berry flavors come with herbal underpinnings, while this tastes baked on the finish.

This wine has classic rosemary and pine aromas and fresh, lively citrus flavors. Supportive acidity and a concentrated palate helps extend the finish. It's all about savory flavors and a nice tart character.

Brushy sage and a thickness of leather play up the robust ripe nature of this reserve wine, which sources from Mount Veeder, Diamond Mountain and Howell Mountain, and blends in nearly 13% Cabernet Franc. A sweetness of cherry and cassis accent hearty toasted oak and tannin.

Made with Nero d'Avola and Nocera, this boasts fruity and spice aromas of black cherry and white pepper along with an earthy whisper of underbrush. The aromas carry over to the round savory palate along with juicy blackberry and star anise. Supple tannins lend irresistible finesse.

Sourced from vines grafted over to Pinot Gris in 1978, this was wild yeast-fermented in neutral oak and aged another 22 months before bottling. This is fresh on the nose, with lush tones of melon, pineapple, pear and a touch of honey.

Lovely earth, mushroom and leather aromas bring softness to this full-bodied wine. It's packed with black fruit, cola, coffee, smoke and baking spice notes, all well integrated, with impressive length and complexity.

Only three barrels of this distinctive wine were produced. It's aromatically complex, with hints of pear and mushroom, the fruit flavors firmly rooted in citrus and peach, with a touch of mint as well. The texture is impressive, and helps to extend the finish.

At nearly half the price of Vasse Felix's premier-range Cab, Filius is less cellar worthy and more approachable young, but it still carries the winery's classic, restrained, mineral-driven stamp. A nose of red currant, raspberry, dark chocolate nibs and licorice is wrapped in a distinctive graphite and sea-spray character. Tart red fruit and graphite continue on the palate which is tight and focused with fine savory tannins and seemingly effortless elegance and restraint. Drink now–2025.

This new winery is showing lots of promise early on, and this bottling may be the best yet, with elegant aromas of blackberry jam, charred beef, smoke and dense purple flowers. It's lively and fresh on the palate in tones of elderberry and lilac, bolstered by stiff tannins and a chalky backbone. Bittersweet chocolate shows on the finish.
From a single vineyard, this white is given six months to chill in stainless steel. It tastes concentrated and full, with an overt tartness to the underlying acidity.

Old-school Cabernet Franc aromas of green bean and leafy berry fruits are damp. A creamy, chunky palate has an oaky feel, while this tastes of oak resin, mint and berry fruits infused with green tea. The same can be said of a highly herbal finish.
Gritty aromas are low on fruit and heavy on burnt field and hay. A chunky palate is O.K., while this tastes of bitter orange prior to a flat yeasty bready-tasting finish.

Medium-intense scents of red cherry and raspberry are dusted by gentle toasted-oak tones. The palate is straightforward but pleasant, with soft tannins and some fruit-skin flavors that lend a subtle texture through the close.
The aromas bring notes of cherry, exotic spice and whiffs of tire rubber. The cherry and cranberry flavors are tart and tangy, trailing on the back half with the tannins giving a light grip.
Sweet aromas of peach and apple syrup show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is also quite sweet with fizzy lime-zest flavors than fall flat rather quickly.

This adds 12% Malbec and 4% Petit Verdot to the mix, a burly, full-bodied expression of mountain mint, cinnamon and tenacious tannin. Juicy plum and dark cherry compete for attention amidst the strong herbal components and concentration.

Ripe, rich and full bodied, this opulent wine from a San Luis Obispo producer has plenty of fruit aromas and flavors shaded by chocolate and baking-spice nuances. It's all at a reasonable price for the level of quality.
Smooth and soft, this wine has richness and a good balance between ripe white fruits and a zesty, mineral texture. Like all good nonvintage cuvées, it is ready to drink.

Truffle, ripe berry, rose, cocoa and Mediterranean brush aromas shape the nose. The firmly structured palate is a bit on the lean side, offering French oak, sour cherry, powdered sage and star anise set against bright acidity and firm, fine-grained tannins that leave a drying finish.

Made entirely with Nero d'Avola, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry and Mediterranean brush. The juicy, easygoing palate delivers crushed blackberry, black cherry and a hint of carob alongside round tannins. Enjoy soon to catch the fruit richness.

This is a deeply mineral yet refreshingly easy-drinking wine balancing savory notes of crushed slate and honeycomb against pristine pineapple and lemon flavors. It's a zesty sip with just a hint of tangerine sweetness. The finish is brisk, ending on a pleasantly bitter touch of lemon zest.
An appellation wine that impresses with its complexity, this offers earthy tones of bark, cinnamon and wild strawberry within a sultry sleek texture that's spicy and moderately structured.

Earthy compost aromas and notions of forest floor tease the nose of this wine, which shows high-toned spiky acidity underneath strawberry, cranberry and rhubarb flavors. It is full bodied and concentrated in ripeness.

This variety is rare in California, but wouldn't be if they were all as good as this nicely funky, meaty wine. It combines earthy beefy mushroomy flavors with good plummy bass notes on a medium to full body, along with light tannins adding some grip.

Vibrant acidity and zingy grapefruit and yellow-cherry flavors collide in this off-dry Riesling. It's delightfully forward and fruity yet maintains a nuanced undertone of gun flint and crushed minerals. This is an elegant yet approachable wine to enjoy now through 2021.
designation: Nik Weis Estate Bottled Old Vines

description: This Shiraz is plush in notes of plums, currants, flowers, peppery spice and a lovely warm stone quality. The palate is medium-bodied and fruit forward, with elegant, glossy tannins and a tangy finish. It shows its colors particularly well after some time in glass.
This blend of 55% Syrah, 36% Grenache and 9% Mourvèdre offers unctuous flavors of blueberry and blackberry wrapped in sweet vanilla and full-bodied ripeness.
Honeyed apples, creamed pears and pressed buttercups lead the nose of this value white. Flavors of mealy apple and melon unfold on the flat palate, which is low in acid and finished fast.
This wine has a plump nose marked by vague aromas and a spritzy, imprecise palate marked by cidery apple and pyrazinic flavors. It breaks down on the finish, tasting bitter.

This Cabernet Sauvignon-based blend, with 20% Merlot, starts off a touch lean and herbal, with notes of blackcurrant leaf, church incense and violets candies atop the black fruit core. The green tannins and fruit-skin flavors lends a tight, astringent grip to the palate.

This $15 Garnacha is heavily oaked and smells singularly of clove. The palate is sticky and cloying, with artificial clove and allspice flavors. Way too much oak has been thrown at totally average fruit here, and the result is forced and fake-tasting.
Aromas of blackberry leaf, plum and balsamic reduction lead the nose of this direct wine. It's medium in weight, with surprisingly gripping tannins and abundant black-fruit flavors.

This wine's odd, yeasty aromas are the result of a mismatched blend of Chardonnay, Viura and Moscatel. The palate is flabby, with cured ham flavors. A grape skin-like bitterness takes over on the finish.

Whiffs of sun-baked earth, violet and spice lend complexity to sunny black cherry and dried strawberry in this full-bodied, stylish red. It's a rich, mouthclinging wine with juicy, forward flavors but penetrates persistently. The finish is marked by ripe, chalky tannins. Irresistible already but should improve through 2026.

Intensely ripe flavors of black cherry and preserved strawberry abound in this pliant, cream-textured wine. It's plush and juicy with easygoing acidity but hints of crushed mineral, dried lavender and thyme lend freshness. Soft, integrated tannins cushion the finish. Ready now but could improve through 2024.

A 100% varietal expression of this fine grape, in this case from a relatively cool climate, this sings in brambly black-cherry, mocha and graham cracker richness, its texture soft and supple on the midpalate. Tremendous aromatics give it a memorable lift and length, elegant to the end.

This coveted block designation from a historic property combines rich aromas of black cherry and dark berry with gamy hints of roasted pork and composting violets. It's bright and tart at first on the palate before wood spice, roasted cherry and cherry pit show in the midpalate. It's still a young wine.
Rich while also freshly fruity, this is a delicious wine. In addition to fruit, it has a strong texture with minerality and acidity equal components. Drink this wine from 2019

Very dark in the glass, this bottling from a new project based in Santa Barbara County offers aromas of elderberry, blue flowers, dark cocoa and earth, proving both rocky and fruity on the nose. Acid rises quickly on the palate to deliver flavors of blueberry, black rocks and a hint of leather.

This rosé is made from Pinot Noir and has interesting yet pleasant aromas of sweet cherry and fermented apple cider. In the mouth, there are flavors of dark fruits including black cherry and black plum.
Pear and apricot aromas are joined by a soapy gardenia note. The palate is ripe and loaded with peach, guava, lemon and rose. Blood orange acidity moves to a finish of apple and blossoms.
This light-bodied wine is grassy in aroma, has lean veggie and lemon flavors and a fairly crisp mouthfeel.

A floral and herbal nose delivers rose, white pepper and lime. The palate offers plenty of acidity but is gentle and soft in feel, with ripe lime and grapefruit flavors that are rounded out by a blossomy note. A dry, citrus finish shows astringent acidity and a white pepper tone.
An abundance of sweet-seeming, spicy oak fills the aroma and smothers the fruit flavors in this spice cabinet of a wine. It has lots of vanilla, ginger, nutmeg and maple flavors and full body.
Light-red fruit, crushed gravel and a hint of gunmetal aromas show on the nose of this bottling. It's lighter bodied on the palate with lots of turned soil flavors and just a touch of red fruit.

The sunny beachside views on the label sums up this bright, sunshine-filled wine. It is a classic blend of Grenache, Cinsault and Syrah, packed with red fruits, crisp acidity and a fresh aftertaste. Drink now.

Ripe plum, underbrush and leather whiffs lead the nose of this wine. The firm palate renders dried cherry, a touch of clove and a hint of powdered sage alongside astringent tannins. Drink soon to capture the remaining fruit.

Dark-purple fruits meet with deep-violet aromas and loamy soil on the nose of this bottling. There's a powerful and earthy richness on the sip, showing flavors of boysenberry, cut by an acidity that's almost overpowering.

Light aromas of dried grass, savory herbs and lime leaf mingle with fruity notes of green melon and white peach on the nose of this wine. The palate follows suit with more lime and tart melon tones, lifted by ample acidity and finishing slightly bitter and tangy. Drink now–2019.
For a Provence rosé, this juicy wine is deeply colored, which reflects the extra-generous flavors. Soft and fruity, it's ripe with red fruits cut refreshingly with acidity. Drink now.

Named after two grandmothers, one Italian and one Spanish, this yellow and citrus-fruit-flavored wine is ripe while also crisp. Its acidity is embedded in the mineral, tangy texture, giving the wine both freshness and rich fruitiness. Drink now.

Aromas that are slightly earthy at first become spicy, complex and fruity and lead to good red-cherry and rhubarb flavors in this medium-bodied elegant wine. Moderate tannins and good acidity balance it out well.

Wild berry and fresh herb aromas are classic for Tupungato, and especially Gualtallary, where this comes from. A racy acid-driven palate is a bit jagged in feel, while reedy spicy berry flavors are juicy and fresh. Acidity is the fuel behind a hard-driving finish with espresso-like bitterness. Drink through 2028.

Dense compact aromas of blackberry and other dark fruits are what Luján Malbec is all about. This is full and integrated on the palate, while blackberry and oak-based spice flavors finish savory, with a note of graphite. Smooth, grainy tannins help this along.

Gentle hints of ripe green and yellow pear lead onto a dry but very expressive palate. Ripe and juicy pear flavors are clearly delineated. While some alcoholic heat becomes palpable on the midpalate, the pear fruit flavors are pure and vivid with lots of concentration. The finish remains balanced and dry.

This blend of 83% Cabernet Sauvignon and 17% Syrah shows dark, roasted black plums and berries as well as charred beef and green peppercorns, proving both very ripe yet still a tad green on the nose. It's thick on the palate with elderberry and black-currant flavors, wound together by rigid tannins, and finishing on caramel, vanilla and pepper.
This opens with enticing aromas of red berry, baking spice and leather. The savory palate delivers red cherry, tobacco and clove alongside fine-grained tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2021–2029.
This is a layered, full-bodied red, thick in baked bread, cherry and vanilla flavors. It has underlying elegance, with balanced acidity and polish tannins that keep it fresh and succulent.

Great fruit flavors and an especially smooth and creamy texture make this full-bodied wine hard to resist. It smells delicious like black cherries and tastes rich, almost jammy, with blackberry-pie notes. Moderate tannins add some good structure for all that fruit.

Tempting aromas of dark chocolate, wood smoke and black pepper lead to rich, concentrated layered fruit and oak flavors that are hard to resist. The wine has firm tannins to support all that concentration, but not so much as to dry out the otherwise plush, mouthfilling texture. Made from Petite Sirah, Barbera, Tempranillo, Syrah and Grenache.

Babak Shokrian is the new owner of what was once the Melvilles' Verna's Vineyard, and he hired Morgan Clendenen to make this Syrah. It's rich with stewed black currants and black plum, with hints of licorice and cinnamon on the nose. The well-structured palate shows blackened blackberry and just a glimpse of bacon and maple.

Copper orange in color, this is a meaty, complex quencher, with a metallic edge of steely wet stone. Citrus and peach give it a restrained fruitiness that never becomes heavy or anything but refreshing.

This blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon (from Santa Cruz County) and 47% Syrah and 3% Viognier (from Monterey County) is still tightly wound on the nose, with crystalline purple-fruit and lilac aromas. The palate is elegant, energetic and clean, with firm tannins framing the purple-fruit flavors, with a touch of oak and chocolate on the finish.

Initial graham cracker aromas transition to smoked meat, black olive and leather while never suggesting much fruit. This is smooth but thick on the palate. Savory flavors of herbal tea and black fruits are plodding on a meaty dense finish.
This wine's subtle but aromatic note of cut Conference pear makes for a fresh nose. The palate is full of riper yellow pear fruit. It's easy and juicy, with a lip-smacking, zesty, dry finish.

A cloud of reduction still obscures the primary fruit on the nose of this wine. The palate brims with easy cherry fruit that is far juicier than the nose suggests. It's a lovely, fresh-faced red that's light but dense, toned but fruit-driven, with a tangy finish.

Attractive notes of fleshy, ripe red and black cherries set the tone for this full-fruited, crunchy and joyful red. The medium-bodied palate adds shimmering overtones of cinnamon. It's a fresh, cherry-inflected wine to serve with a slight chill this summer.

The ripe russet apple notes on the nose of this wine are framed by zesty lemon impressions. On the palate, they open into joyful, light-footed juiciness and tinglingly fresh fruit. It has a party vibe, seducing with tangerine loveliness.

Aromas of white spring wild flower, green apple and honeydew melon march over to the ripe palate along with citrus and white peach. Fresh acidity keeps it balanced and bright while a white-almond note lingers on the finish.

This is a 100% varietal wine, made in a small-production from Howell Mountain fruit. Dense black cherry and blackberry dominate around supersize tannins that are grippy and strong. It also offers a wealth of dried herb and sage. This wine will do well in the cellar; enjoy best 2023–2030.
Aromas of iris, underbrush and red-skinned berry emerge from the glass. The juicy, lively palate delivers red berry, star anise and white pepper alongside smooth tannins. Drink through 2022.

While a tad muted on the nose, ripe mulberry and plum shine brightly on the palate of this fruity full-bodied Lemberger. Hints of pine nut and toast lend some savory complexity to the midpalate. It's weighty and mouth filling, with ripe, firmly gripping tannins on the finish.

Crisp cranberry and tart black cherries are vibrant in this light-bodied Pinot Noir. It's an easy drinking, silky red wine with hints of smoke and crushed granite lending complexity to the midpalate. Fine firm tannins structure a moderately long finish. Drink now through 2023.

A deep pink color and bold fruit and spice flavors help this wine stand out from the pack. Made from mostly old-vine Carignan, it is full bodied, rounded and rich on the palate, yet has good acidity and a glimmer of tannin to add structure. Winemaker Carol Shelton achieves concentration that helps the flavors hang in there for a lingering finish.

The year 1836 is when the Companhia das Lezirias was founded. This wine, much younger than that, has density and dark black fruits. The wood aging and the bitter edge of firm extraction should soften into the impressively rich, dark-colored fruit. Drink the wine from 2021.
The aromas bring strong notes of tire rubber and raspberry. The palate is light in concentration, not able to pull it all together.

Woody aromas of berry fruit, scented soap and herbs come in front of a soupy palate. Berry and plum flavors are earthy and a bit green, while this is spicy, saucy, herbal and not real deep or interesting as a whole.

Aromas of pickled cabbage, briny citrus fruits and vanilla cookies are scrambled and sketchy. This brut nature is basic in feel, with sour citrus flavors that don't amount to much. With almost no charm to the finish, this is passable but nothing more.
Furry berry, cotton candy and herbal aromas are less than fresh. This Malbec is clampy, narrow and highly acidic. Minty flavors of plum skins are raw and a bit green, as is an edgy finish.
This is straightforward in its appeal, with ripe yellow-apple and citrus tones. The palate is soft and easy in feel.

A rich white apricot aroma wafts from the glass. The palate starts ripe, with juicy flavors of donut peach, but quickly rushes into a bitter, pithy finish with white pepper spice and spoiled clementine.
This wine's generic melon and white fruit aromas are backed by a green note of pyrazine. It's equally basic on the palate, with stalky, oxidized white fruit flavors.
This wine's unripe, stalky berry aromas smell of latex. It's tight, pulling and drying on the palate, with weedy, peppery plum flavors that finish green.

This leads with brett-derived scents and alcoholic heat. It's soft and gummy on the palate, without much structure. Heavy oak has resulted in roasted berry and clove flavors, and it's even more artificial and oaky-tasting on the finish.
This wine's tropical fruit, lemon blossom and yeast aromas are underwhelming. It's shapeless on the palate, with yeasty, oxidized flavors and a powdery finish.

A mild nose marked by tropical and citrus aromas is a high point for this Sauvignon Blanc and Verdejo blend. The palate feels oily and pinched; its mix of tropical fruit and vegetal flavors leads to a briny finish with green notes.
This herbal wine is crisp, tangy and has a strong level of acidity. It is made for food, not as an aperitif.

A most subtle glimpse of creamy cherry is all that appears on the shy nose. The frothy, fresh palate is equally light but adds some phenolic grip. This is very fresh, easy and beautifully dry. Drink soon.

Light in the glass, this bottling offers aromas of candied pomegranate, sweet sage, bay leaf and crushed hibiscus, with a touch of graphite minerality. It's fresh and bright on the palate, where cherry is dashed with dried herbs and white pepper.

Creamy aromas of butterscotch and candied corn are shot through with a vitalizing kick of lemon zest on the nose. The smooth, textured palate is bright and citrus-forward, with creamy, savory elements that broaden the feel and linger on the finish.

Fruity aromas of cherry, hibiscus and pomegranate grow more complex with wood spice, slate and clay on the nose of this widely available bottling. Full flavors of dried cherry and pomegranate juice meet with sagebrush and bay leaf on the palate.

Raspberry, chocolate, ripe plum, black pepper and a briny, black olive tang lead this wine into a palate that's equally savory and tangy. A little on the hot and rich side, the acidity just about keeps things afloat.

One of a series of wines that the producers calls Les Parcellaires, single-vineyard wines, this is an impressively perfumed wine, exotic in character. It is rich with just the lightest hints of purer acidity. Drink the wine now.

This is a snappy, well-balanced and also concentrated wine that's compelling to drink. Engaging complexity in the aromas leads to equally intriguing and spicy flavors that are well supported by good acidity and firm tannins.

Brambly blackberry flavors are seasoned with pungent aromas of cinnamon and nutmeg in this thick, rich and intensely ripe wine. Its power and concentration provide a lushness and roundly fruity approachability that doesn't hinder its lingering, textured complexity.

Strawberry flavors coat the palate delicately in this tangy, softly textured wine that shows restraint in ripeness and style. The site's volcanic ash soils contribute a mineral element that's part turned earth, part crushed rock.

Plummy and generous on the nose, and equally rich and expansive on the palate, this wine is smoothly textured and full bodied. Light tannins add a little grip to the plush sensations of black plums, strawberries and a dash of dried herbs.

Dense but also ripe and opulent, this wine has excellent potential. It has weight, richness and generosity, with black fruits and powerful tannins. The wine has a way to go, but everything is there. Drink from 2024.

Obviously wood aged, this wine is rich in spice and smokiness. It has a firm structure as well as concentrated black fruits and acidity. Ripe and firm, the wine likely will take a while to age. Drink from 2023.
This wine has concentration, with ripe baked-apple and creamy flavors. Its acidity balances with the lively white fruits and taut mineral texture. Drink now.
This is a smooth and supple Merlot that offers a mix of red plum, blackberry and a mild leafy, herbal twang. Its mildly grippy tannins and soft acidity lend to its easy-drinking appeal.
Aromas and flavors of watermelon and strawberry make for an easily enjoyable wine. While light in body, there's a nice presence of fruit on the palate, with a refreshing lemon backdrop.

This straightforward red opens with earthy aromas of game, dark-skinned berries and tilled soil. The medium-bodied palate offers Marasca cherry and tobacco flavors alongside loose-knit tannins. Drink soon.

Slightly muddied lemon and pear notes on the nose lead to a fresh easy light palate. They are joined by that characteristic whiff of white pepper and a savory edge of sage. The finish is totally refreshing.

Oily aromas of walnut and peach pit announce a mature Chardonnay that's in surprisingly good shape. Salty apple and salted butter flavors are yeasty and a touch oxidized, which isn't a shock given that this was bottled in 2014. Despite showing some age, this is round and steady on the finish. Drink now.

Piquant aromas of green fruits are feline in nature. This SB from Rueda feels chunky, with soft edges to the palate. Briny, lightly vegetal flavors of citrus fruit and bell pepper finish with just enough acid to make this worthwhile.
A smooth and rounded wine that has a creamy texture, this is soft and ready to drink. Its yellow fruits are already fully integrated.
This wine offers aromas of lemon zest, white peach and gooseberry. In the mouth there are flavors of lemon zest and lemon curd.
There seems to a rubbery onion character here that's somewhat masking the guava, passionfruit and pineapple characters. The palate is rich but crisp at the same time, with tongue-tingling acidity.
This soft, lightly woody blend dominated by Merlot is ready to drink. Easygoing red-berry fruits are lifted by some acidity at the end. Drink now.
Jammy berry aromas are cool, herbal and quiet. A fleshy palate comes with rubbing tannins, while this tastes of herbal plum and green herb. A minty, spicy finish is rough and tannic in feel.

Bursting aromas of black raspberry, bright blackberry, lavender and chaparral scrub make for an intriguing nose to this single-vineyard Tempranillo. There's a leathery Old World vibe to the palate, where gamy dusty touches give depth to dried berry and herb flavors.

This is the definition of a young ripe bomber with big berry aromas and floral notes. Hardness on the palate makes this a tough hill to conquer now—fierce tannins are unforgiving. Toasty blackberry and coffee flavors are gritty on a long finish with lasting blackness. Drink from 2019–2030.

Soupy raisiny aromas announce a fully ripe, almost overripe gran reserva with a round, dense mouthfeel. Baked flavors of ultraripe berry fruits are matched by savory notes of black olive. On the finish, there's mostly coffee and toast flavors and not much acidity or tannic grip. Drink through 2022.

Faint hints of Damask rose mingle with more intense notes of orange zest and ripe juicy mandarin on the nose. These juicy rounded flavors continue on the medium-sweet palate, offsetting the residual sugar with the zesty but ripe and aromatic notion of orange and mandarin peel. The palate is rounded and soft, the finish a little warm.

Ssaturated flavors of dark fruits are framed by firm but velvety tannins in this mouthfilling, pleasing and full-bodied wine. It has well-integrated oak aromas and flavors that hint at nutmeg, cinnamon and wood smoke but stay in the background.

Definitely falling into the sessionable and chillable reds category, winemaker Karen Steinwachs had fun with this carbonically treated wine, which shows sour red cherry and a touch of smoke on the nose. The lightly bodied palate is not particularly complex, but the tart red-fruit flavors are playful, quaffable and extremely refreshing.

From a high-elevation site where the vines enjoy volcanic calcareous soils, this lightly ripe wine is high toned in pomegranate, rhubarb and orange peel, textured with a sense of crushed rock, and easy to love. It is Gamay-like in its delicate brightness and retention of acidity.

This estate-grown, aromatic wine opens with a pretty mix of peach, honeysuckle and pink grapefruit notes. It's tart, racy and complex, with a hint of honey that carries from the aroma into the dry, lingering finish.

Black pepper and blueberry meet with tarragon, sweet mint and beef char on the nose of this bottling. The palate offers a range of minty herbal qualities, but is dominated by a black-plum-sauce richness. The structure is solid but soft enough to enjoy now.
This wine brings out the rich side of the Baga grape, giving it density, ripe black fruit and finely integrated tannins. It's balanced and juicy, with impressive fruit and structure. Drink from 2019.

This classy wine starts with cinnamon stick aromas that lead to a warm cherry pie flavor. It gains grip and complexity on the palate and finish, with moderate tannins and fresh acidity alongside a nip of sour cherry for good balance.

This wine's ripe black fruit aromas suggest prune and raisin. Rough tannins make for a drying, tough mouthfeel, with desiccated-seeming smoked meat, cassis and raisin flavors. Despite its minor flaws, it shows great quality for a difficult vintage. Drink through 2022.

Aromas of cherry, raspberry and lavender prepare the palate for well-balanced fruit and spice flavors—notably black cherry, cranberry, anise, mace and vanilla. Its pervasive acidity is backed by smooth tannins from first sip through the bright, pomegranate-laced finish.

The hints of sun-dried hay, russet pear and bright lemon that mark the nose of this wine combine into zesty freshness on the palate. It's ripe and concentrated, with a dry, lemony zing that lingers until the very last echo.

Black cherry, smoke and a hint of caramel make for a very familiar and satisfying nose on this well-priced bottling. There is a deep core of black currant fruit, with chalky tannins, a dense mouthfeel and abundant acidity that drives into the finish.

Dried berries, fennel pollen and layers of herbal intrigue arise on the nose of this blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Syrah. Bay leaf and Mediterranean spices decorate the softly tannic palate, giving depth to the lavish blueberry and blackberry flavors.

This wine's cherry, butterscotch and iodine aromas set the scene for blackberry, dark plum, sage and anise flavors. The tannins slowly build in power, offering a full-on mouthfeel and a chewy finish marked by a splash of pomegranate.

A hint of reduction adds its flinty glint to the nose of this unusual, rich wine from a truly original Austrian grape. The palate offers hints of rose oil, pear and tangy lemon zest, with richer notions of dried lemon peel. It's fluid, concentrated and almost oily-textured.
This is a soft wine with red-berry flavors, a touch of caramel and just enough acidity. A gentle, fruity wine, it's ready to drink.

Shy and closed at first, with time some barnyard and cherry-skin aromas come across the bouquet. The palate is light in weight and straightforward in feel, with soft tannins and delicate red-plum and -cherry flavors.

Floral tones of verbena and jasmine are oddly pronounced on the nose of this wine, dominating the green apple and melon rind fruit. The round mouthfeel shows a bit of flatness on the midpalate, echoed by a final note of citrus oil that lacks some needed verve.

Crème de cassis and warm blackberry preserves are center stage on the nose of this Cab, and carry through with even greater intensity to the plush, medium-weight mouth. Moderately gripping tannins lend structure, though the finish is fleeting.
This wine tastes fully mature, with aromas like balsamic and cedar, and flavors that are more earthy and leathery than fruity.
A watermelon-red color and green-leaning aromas of beets and lettuce lead to a heavy palate. Briny red-fruit flavors hint at vinegar, while this maintains a salad-dressing quality on the finish.
This fresh, pretty, fruit-driven wine is loaded with ripe strawberry, raspberry and cherry notes. The lively fruit is underscored by hints of stem and stone, finishing with a dash of barrel toast.
Smoothly rich, this is lavishly wood aged while preserving ripe fruit. The toast and smokiness are part of the richness. Add to that the opulent fruit and the wine becomes ageworthy. Drink from 2019.

This is a traditional field blend consisting of 80% Zinfandel, 18% Petite Sirah and 2% mixed blacks. It's juicy and seductively soft, a study of blackberry, wild herb, toasted oak and grainy leather. It holds its full-bodied ripeness well.

Another great value from Bogle, this wine is very polished and smooth. Blackberry and blueberry flavors abound on the full-bodied palate, with fine-grained tannins. There are no rough edges, just wonderful fruitiness and light salt-and-pepper spices.

Blending Tannat with the two Cabernets, this wine is rich and not too firmly tannic. It's ripe with black fruits, licorice and layers of spice and vanilla from wood aging. This succulent wine is ready to drink now.

Malbec, Merlot and Tannat are the blend for this wine that is the closest Lagrezette has to a second wine. It is fragrant, full of red fruits cut with acidity and with balanced tannins. The wine can be drunk soon for its fine fruit, so just wait until 2019.
A ripe wine, full of delicious fruit flavors and acidity, this has a chalky texture as well as rich white fruits tightly cut with acidity. It is ready to drink.
An intensely stony nose of wet slate and lime zest carries to the equally expressive palate. This is light in feel but electric with acidity, ending dry on tones of citrus zest and chalk.
This wine is rich and full of apple flavors along with warm acidity. Like many wines from this appellation, it is still young after a year and needs to open up its ripe fruits. Drink from 2019.
Aromas of woodland berry, sea breeze and Mediterranean brush lift out of the glass. The succulent palate doles out wild strawberry, crushed raspberry and white pepper before a fresh, saline close.

Aromas of game, wild herb, mature black-skinned fruit and a whiff of barnyard follow over to the dense, extracted palate along with prune and licorice. It's on the funky, overripe side, with a velvety texture that gives way to a dusty, drying finish. Drink sooner rather than later to capture the remaining fruit flavors and freshness.

This hits the nose with some sharply spicy aromas, then opens up broadly with ripe cherry fruit. There's a wash of chocolate to help smooth out a touch of bitter herb. Drink now through the early 2020s.

At first whiff this wine has diesel fumes that later settle into less-alarming but strong oak overtones like charred wood and grilled meat. Full body, saturated fruit and spice flavors and moderate tannins fill out its hefty profile.
This offers thick, inky road tar, wood grain and graphite aromas. It's heavily oaked and resiny, with cloying, oaky blackberry and mint flavors. It finishes with even more oak and a hint of carob.

After a couple of good vintages, this wine was clearly affected by 2014's marginal harvest conditions. The nose is gamy and full of olive and damp earth notes. The palate is tannic beyond belief, leading to a scratchy finish. In between, there are dark berry and coffee flavors.

Clove, mint and chocolate aromas and flavors dominate this wine, suggesting forced oak. In between all that wood is a cloying mouthfeel marked by weedy sweetness. This might rank as one of the most manipulated and artificial-tasting wines from Spain.

Gritty, almost-burnt aromas of rubber and chewing gum make this rosé seem far from clean and fresh. It's creamy and candied in feel, with oxidized melon and papaya flavors that hollow out on the finish.
Sweaty, yeasty aromas lead the nose of this wine. It has a grape skin-like texture and salty, bitter orange peel flavors. On the finish, it's oxidized and cheesy, with almost no fruit.
This has delicate, inviting aromas of red berry, chamomile and bread crust. On the vibrant palate, an ultrarefined perlage wraps around sour cherry, pomegranate, tangerine and a hint of white pepper.

Creamy and fresh, this elegant sparkler opens with an enticing fragrance of lilac, wisteria, pastry dough and orchard fruit. The silky palate dishes out juicy white stone fruit, lemon drop and baking spice alongside a silky perlage.

Cherry and cranberry aromas precede richer riper black-plum and black-currant flavors in this full-bodied plush-textured Rhône-style blend. The combination of bright red fruits, warming black fruits and hints of mild oak baking spices give the wine complexity and interest.

A sizable helping of 16% Cabernet Franc adds complexity to this wine, a thick, dense portrait of black fruit, sage and cedar. Textured and taut, it has plenty of mountain-grown ripeness on offer, finishing in dried herb, crushed rock and turned earth.

This is a juicy, leathery and layered wine with hearty characteristics of grilled meat, blackberry and black cherry. Bold and full bodied, it retains supportive acidity and is integrated in tannin and oak, showing lasting notes of nutmeg and clove.
This wine offers aromas of fresh cherry and berry. Smooth and gentle on the palate, the berry flavors become even more ripe on the palate and ease through the lingering fruit-and-spice finish.

A slightly darker shade of yellow in the glass, this bottling shows dried apple, wet hay and orange touches on the nose. The palate offers apple, pear and lime flavors, but without much texture or energy.
Made with organic grapes, this has delicate scents of spring blossom. Crisp, light-bodied and simple, the palate suggests dried apricot and a hint of bitter almond.
Blending half-and-half Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this wine is fruity, with a caramel edge and plenty of crisp acidity. It is ready to drink.
Jammy and juicy, this wine is full of fruit. Structure and tannins take a back seat. Blackberry flavors and acidity will give it an attractive, if lightweight, future. Drink from 2020.
There is beautiful packaging on this bottle, yet it contains less-than-beautiful wine. Aromas of vinegar-laced cranberry sauce leads into tangy cooked cranberry flavors on the sip.
This soft wine with ripe yellow fruits is rounded and smoothly textured. It's fruity, with just enough acidity. Drink the wine now.

There's a slightly coppery tone to this savory but easy-drinking, full-bodied white. Its rustic apple and pear flavors have a pleasantly cidery edge, accented by hints of earth and dried herbs. Fresh acidity brightens the finish. Drink now.

Initial smoke and earth scents fade with aeration here. It's a full-bodied, silky wine with delicate raspberry and red cherry accents. The finish is brisk but bright, augmented by hints of dried Mediterranean herbs. Drink now.
While its sour cherry and raspberry flavors are delicate, this is a revitalizing dry rosé. Full bodied yet spry in acidity, it finishes brisk and clean. Drink now.
This wine's subtle plum and baking spice aromas waft out of the glass. The simple, accessible palate delivers black cherry, star anise and green peppercorn notes alongside round tannins. Enjoy soon.

This wine has all the extroverted qualities of New Zealand's most famous wine style—brash aromas of guava, grapefruit, passionfruit, grass, tomato leaf and fresh green beans. It has zippy acidity and just a hint of creamy texture, with tons of citrusy zing.

This rich wine, reveling in the warm southern sun, is full of dense tannins that are rivaled by the big blackberry flavors. It has weight, concentration and power, a wine to age further. Drink from 2020.

Aromatic hints of Cox Orange Pippin peel are heady and aromatic on the nose. That same inviting tart but ripe apple freshness also pervades the palate while a touch of yeast provides a sonorous background against which this tasty, fresh and clean fruit can play. The fizz is a little frothy but that adds extra liveliness to the wonderfully dry finish.

This is a very deep-colored wine that has a laser-focus on ripe black-currant and black-cherry flavors and very firm tannins to shape those flavors. The texture is dry and astringent but the fruit component is so focused that it softens the tannic blow somewhat. Drink now with rich, fatty proteins or cellar until 2022 by which time it may mellowed.

This is one of a pair of single-vineyard wines from this producer. Ripe blackberry and black-plum fruits burst from the glass giving a wine that, while mature, still has plenty of fruit. The tannins are still firm behind the juicy acidity and ripeness. Drink this wine now.
