One of a half-dozen chess-themed Chardonnays from this exciting new winery, this was fermented in both barrel and concrete egg. Peach, melon, lemon oil and pineapple flavors combine, then lead into an interesting finish with vanilla wafer (from one-third new oak) and a dash of sea salt.

Richness, depth and layering all contribute to this full-bodied, Grenache-based wine's considerable appeal. It has lots of ripe blackberry and black-cherry flavors, nicely firm tannins and a mouth-coating texture. What else does a GSM-C (for 5% Cinsault) need?

A floral touch of honeysuckle accompanies fresh, zesty lemon notes on the nose. The palate is fresh with ripe tangerine and clementine notes, vivid with citrus brightness. The finish is dry and aromatic.

Ripe pear is beautifully present on the nose and freshness is already apparent. Dry but concentrated, the palate shows clearly delineated, fresh but ripe yellow pear. There is texture to the body and dryness to the long finish.

This entry level Pinot Noir is a fine introduction to the winery's portfolio of single vineyard selections. Tight and still tart, it mixes wild berry fruit with well-managed herb and bark accents. Though the tannins need more time to soften, the overall balance and depth suggest medium term aging potential. Drink 2020–2025.

The winery is making a considerable effort to downsize the alcohol in its Chardonnays, with positive results. This Dijon clone blend was fermented in one quarter new French oak barrels. A portion underwent malolactic fermentation, yielding a well-balanced wine with a steely core of pear and apple fruit. There's a pleasing touch of buttered toast from the malo, and everything stays in perfect proportion through the finish.

This biodynamic rosé is made from 65% Grenache, 25% Mourvèdre, 7% Vermentino and 3% Viognier, and aged six months in oak. It's currently toasty and woody upfront, with background notes of grilled apple, peach and orange peel in the bouquet. The palate is round and smooth, but with ample acidic lift and fruit flavors to counter the robust oak and woodspice elements. Hold until 2019–2021.

Dominated by Chardonnay, this well-aged wine is ripe and creamy. Balancing acidity reinforces the smooth texture, yeasty character and great elegance. Apple and citrus flavors are sustained by the tight mineral texture. Drink now.
Cassis, blueberry and mocha flavors are dusted in nutmeg and clove in this rich, soft and straightforward red from the famous site. The ripeness is in balance and measured.
Enticing scents of Alpine herb, tomato vine, grapefruit and crushed stone leap over to the full-bodied savory palate along with baked yellow apple. Tangy acidity keeps it light on its feet.

A vibrant dazzle of pale pink in the glass, this bottling shows fresh, focused and exuberant aromas of bubblegum, rose petal and tangerine rind. Rounded watermelon flavors meet with lemon-lime on the palate, which is persistent in expression deep into the finish.
Aromas of grapefruit, Alpine herb and a whiff of crushed tomato leaf lead the nose. The aromas carry over to the tangy linear palate along with a steely mineral note that gives a refreshing close.

A blend of whole cluster-pressed Chenin Blanc and Chardonnay sourced from Clarksburg and Napa Valley, this can is stainless steel and barrel-fermented and lovely in crisp, high-toned acidity. Apple, melon and citrus combine with aplomb, refreshing in focus and light style.

Lemon pulp and orange rind aromas start this robust but elegant Assyrtiko from Gaia. It offers zippy minerality and fresh fruit flavors in a clean and balanced package, with the characteristic smoke and saline edge from its Santorini terroir.

Alluring aromas of dark berry, saddle leather, truffle and tilled soil meld together with dark spice. The bright medium-bodied palate shows cranberry, sour cherry and star anise framed in polished tannins. Vibrant acidity lends verve. Drink through 2024.

Made entirely from Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of iris, sunbaked soil and a balsamic note. The firm palate delivers ripe black cherry, mocha, licorice and white pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink now–2024.
Bright succulent waves of red cherry, blackberry and plum play along a continuum of full-bodied style and substantial weight in this mountain-grown wine that offers plenty of complex flavors.

This wine's earthy plum and berry aromas include classic notes of tobacco and vanilla. Its solid, balanced palate delivers ripe berry, prune, cocoa and oak flavors prior to a warm, lightly herbal finish with a hint of raisin. Drink through 2022.

From a site planted in 1934, and blended with 4% Carignan, this is an earthy pungent wine that is concentrated and approachable. Tobacco, dark cherry and dried herb mingle well along a velvety smooth palate of full-bodied ripeness.

This seems stiff but clearly focused, with strong licorice and coffee flavors over lighter cranberry and pomegranate fruit. It's not a wine bursting with charm, but it does have tannic muscle and power. Light tobacco notes thread through the grainy finish. Cellar and drink during the 2020s.

Ripe black-fruit aromas are a touch baked and raisiny, which makes sense given the warmth and dryness of the 2011 vintage in Rioja. On the palate, this is dry as a bone, with cheek-pounding tannins. Flavors of roasted plum, red currant, tomato sauce and vanilla finish raw but also clean and true. Drink through 2024.

Chardonnay dominates this wine (its color comes from the addition of still red wine, a normal practice in Champagne). With its mineral texture and low dosage that give a crisp aftertaste, this is a food-friendly rosé. Drink now.

Earthy aromas of underbrush, truffle, leather and game follow over to the firm palate along with dried cherry, prune, crushed herb and clove. Close-grained, drying tannins provide astringent support while it finishes on a rather salty note. Drink 2021–2029.
The nose suggests notes of crushed mineral, pollen and sunbaked slate. Tart tangerine and green plum flavors are pristine and juicy on the palate. It finishes quite dry and refreshing.

Spicy rooty aromas of licorice, anise, fennel and dried berry fruits are a bit herbal and raw. As for raw, the palate fits that description, with bumpiness to boot. Berry, oak spice and baking-spice flavors are steady on the finish. Drink through 2023.

Smooth, spicy berry and black-cherry aromas are spread across a concentrated nose. A tight juicy palate is fresh, while this weighs in as medium-to-full. Lightly roasted berry and plum flavors include a spot of oaky vanilla, while this is mellow and emphasizes freshness and spice notes on the finish.

This straight-forward Syrah displays aromas of mulberry, cranberry, sweet oak and vanilla. The palate turns medicinal, with flavors of cherry and mixed berry tinged with menthol and touches of vanilla and cedar. Mild-mannered acidity is in balance with tannins that seem to settle on the tip of tongue, carrying some spice before slipping into the uninspired finish offering more of the same.
winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey

description: Grassy stone-fruit aromas are not fully crisp and veer into the green zone. This blend of Garnacha and Shiraz feels round and globular, without much core acidity. Mild but nonspecific fruit flavors are difficult to define.

Muddled boysenberry and plum sauce aromas unfold on the nose of this smooth, ripe wine, followed by flavors of black cherry and plum that finish with a sweet edge. A hint of warmth appears on the close, alongside a touch of milk chocolate.

Funky, sweaty aromas of brined fruits and chicken fat are not the best way to get started. This feels citric and pulpy at the same time. Salty citrus and briny stone-fruit flavors are maintained on the finish.

Reduced out of the gate, it's a bit of a challenge to get at the varietal aromas. The flavors of lees, pear and star fruit provide intrigue, tapering toward the finish, with the concentration overall seeming a bit light.

Forward aromas of plum and blackberry are dried and woody in nature, with an assertive overlay of raw wood and sawdust atop. The palate offers a creamer, full-bodied texture, with plush black-fruit tones that finish with more assertive wood flourishes.

This blend of 80% Tempranillo and 20% Syrah features rubbery berry aromas suggestive of forced oak. The palate is grippy and mealy-feeling, with slightly oxidized berry flavors and a bland, rubbery finish.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: This wine's gold color, briny citrus and lanolin aromas and flabby mouthfeel suggest it's fading quickly. Its stone fruit flavors are stale and bitter, even on the finish.
This leads with sweaty hay and bath oil aromas. The palate is heavy, lacking vivacity. Its salty melon flavors are short and a touch sour.
Baked, raisiny aromas announce an overripe wine. The thick, jammy palate matches the nose, delivering prune and baked plum flavors prior to a stewy finish.
This wine has almost no color and this seems to be reflected in the lack of taste. It is a soft wine with just hints of red fruit and light acidity.

This wine's waxy, petrol-like aromas are more suggestive of Riesling than Rioja. With only modest acidity and a high level of residual sugar, it's cloying on the palate. Its sweet mango and melon flavors finish flat and slightly bitter.
Earthy blueberry and clove tones give way to a juicy core of soft, integrated fruit. This is ultimately a full-bodied, ripe and robust wine that lingers on a baking spice note.

Plum, dried strawberry, rocky earth, nutmeg and fennel make for a brilliantly complex nose in this blend of 50% Grenache, 26% Syrah, 10% Cinsault, 9% Carignan and 5% Counoise. The palate shows a plump plum flavor and a healthy dose of baking spice, with the tannins and acidity in expert balance.

Gamy aromas of peppercorn-crusted beef smoked over an oak wood fire meet with black plum and boysenberry on the savory nose of this 80% Syrah and 20% Grenache blend. Smoky bacon flavors lead into elegant red-plum and hibiscus flavors on the medium-weight palate.

Deep cherry in the glass, this wine has a nose of raspberry and lavender. Made with the indigenous Armenian grape Areni, it is smooth on the palate, with flavors of black cherry, raspberry, dark chocolate and smoked meat. Fine-grained tannins fill the mouth and then drift off into a savory finish.

Great concentration and good balance make this medium- to full-bodied wine enjoyable. It has an intense dark color and plenty of ripe red- and black-cherry aromas and flavors that flood the layered, saturated mouthfeel.

Made predominantly from Nerello Mascalese and a small percentage of Nerello Cappuccio, this wine offers alluring aromas of red berry, blue flower, crushed stone and wild herb. It's elegantly structured and focused, evoking crushed raspberry, Marasca cherry, savory black pepper and graphite alongside taut, refined tannins and bright acidity. Drink through 2026.
This crisp, fresh wine has bright acidity and lively apple and citrus fruits. The focus is on the wine's light texture and the perfumed, ready-to-drink character.
A briny smelling nose includes aromas of pickled fruit, pineapple and pine tree. A phenolic skins-driven palate tastes briny like this smells. A quick, salty finish fades out without much fruit.
This wine has a pink tinge in the color and strong floral and fruity aromas. It is peachy in flavor, light in body and slightly sweet, making it an aromatic, picnic-style wine.

Ultra pale in color, this feather light pink from UK television host Graham Norton shows delicate notes of grapefruit, raspberry and white pepper spice amidst a bone-dry palate that's crisp and refreshing. Nothing exciting here, but nothing objectionable either.

Perfumed notes of rose and lily are joined by lime zest and candied orange on the nose of this refreshing, but simple Riesling. On the light footed and playful palate there is an orange flavored sweetness throughout, with notes of tart green apple, ripe lemon and pear. There are some chalky, mineral notes that quietly add depth to the palate, while ripe grapefruit and lime round out the finish.
Golden in color, this wine opens bright and fresh on the nose before providing a lush, creamy and fruit-forward experience of indelible ripeness on the palate.
This bottling of a Zinfandel rosé is very darkly hued, showing aromas of dark berries, cola and plum. There is decent zip to the sip, with heavy flavors of berry, plum skins and darker spices.

Condensed red- and black-berry aromas are met with tones of fresh herbs and pepper. The palate shows a good progression of ripe fruit, nuanced by sweet herb and astringent black pepper. The medium-grained tannins linger on the finish with a dusting of cocoa.

Syrah (39%) and Cabernet Sauvignon (36%) take the lead on this wine, with the balance Merlot (18%) and Cabernet Franc. The aromas bring appeal, with notes of plum, wheat and assorted dried herb. The flavors are plump in feel but still elegant, wanting a bit more tannic structure to fully stand them up. Blue-fruit flavors linger on the finish.

Juicy and fruity aromas of blackberry jam, black plum, purple flowers and a savory hint of soy show on the nose of this bottling from a San Diego winery that sourced fruit from Paso. It hits the palate with power, showing Concord grape and dark-berry flavors. But it's quite ripe despite judicious acidity and tannins.
Juicy yellow-pear notes dominate the nose. The light dry palate has lemon freshness and the merest touch of sage.

The aromas are fresh, with notes of whole green pepper, dark cherry, cocoa and wisps of vanilla and other oak spices. There's a lot of smoothness to the fruit flavors, which lean into the savory, with abundant green-pepper flavors that taper toward the cranberry and spice-filled finish.

This wine is seductive and delicious yet well balanced, from an aroma of pear tart to substantial but not showy flavors of kiwi, apricot and guava that coat the palate. The texture is generous and mouthfilling but backed by subtle acidity that keeps it lively. Vintner Jeff Morgan is doing great things with Lodi grapes.

Tart apple and bright lemon on the nose promise freshness and poise. The rounded palate follows with equally tart freshness and wonderfully fine creamy mousse. It is lively citrus that dominates from the midpalate to the long dry finish and provides just the right amount of briskness and refreshment for a perfect summery apéritif.

Never hugely sweet but certainly ripe and honeyed, this wine is impressively rich. Apricot and bitter-orange flavors are balanced by great acidity and a taut lemon-zest texture. Named to celebrate the arrival of thrushes in the spring, the wine is young and will be better from 2019.

Notes of ripe peach and rose petal potpourri combine to create a heady aroma. The palate brings even more headiness with a full flow of ripe sweet peach notes. A pleasant edge of bitter peach pit lends some counterweight to this intense wine with its medium-sweet finish.

A limited-production wine from a small parcel of old vines, this is ripe and beautifully rich. A touch of oxidation gives an extra dimension of ripeness and brings out a beautiful texture. Drink from 2019.

This is reduced and robust in oaky char and strong flavors of barbecue meat, coffee and leather. Full bodied, it's surprisingly graceful, too, with mouth-filling complexity and structured jammy blackberry fruit.

The winery's best white, this decadently rich wine is packed with ripe honeysuckle, Meyer lemon, orange, tangerine, peach and apricot flavors. It's a totally delicious fruit bomb to be enjoyed now–2022.

Young, sharp and tightly wound, this pushes a complex mix of lime, grapefruit and crisp apple fruit forward. There are subtle notes of Bergamot orange and cardamom, with a light toasty touch from having aged in 21% new oak. Delicious already, it should age nicely for up to a decade.

This is a wonderful wine, made in large enough quantities to be easily found on store shelves. Smoky, meaty and gamy aromas rise from the glass around perfumed rose. The palate is juicy and velvety, with flavors of berry pie and cinnamon.

Big and rich, there is plenty here for fans of full-bodied reds: juicy bramble berries, milky coffee, spice and a mouthfilling palate, with sinewy yet elegant tannins. Still in its infancy, this wine will age for decades. Drink now–2036.

It's a treat to welcome a new producer of Vermentino in California. This wine balances vivid herb and ripe apple flavors with vibrant acidity for a mouthfilling but still refreshing character. Touches of lime and lemon perk up the palate while an almost sweet apple-tart note kicks in on the finish.

From the famed terra rossa soils of Coonawarra, Penfold's Bin 128 is a shining example of both (relatively) cooler climate Shiraz and of the brand's own distinctive style. More broody, complex and dark fruited than many of its regional counterparts, aromas of black cherry, blackberry, dark chocolate, vanilla and mint swirl together. Tight-grained tannins weave through the rich but not overblown flavors of dark fruit and earth. Overall, this feels very approachable now but with the capacity to age for the next seven years or so.

Plush, juicy Grenache is balanced by sharper, savory tones of Syrah and Mourvèdre in this ripe, silk-textured red. It's briskly concentrated but nuanced by hints of toast, wet earth and cocoa powder. Full bodied, plush and silky, it's a satisfyingly rich but structured wine to enjoy now–2023.

This wine's tart yet ripe golden apple aromas turn into a wonderfully zesty lemon impression on the taut, tight and slender palate. There's lovely body and richness, but it's all coralled into a zesty, juicy focus. Total refreshment is guaranteed.

This wine opens with a flicker of banana, leading to a subtle hint of pear. The palate presents the same fruit notes, which envelop a ripe mandarin core. It's concentrated and soft but textured, with a zesty tang on the dry finish.

Hazelnut, seared lemon rinds and sandalwood reflect the various oak types used in the making of this wine. The palate also reflects that wood, with lightly toasted oak flavors holding up the seared lemon and herb-roasted chicken elements.
Spicy, light and ethereal in texture, this lengthy, brightly bodied wine offers delicate entry points of cranberry, rhubarb and strawberry that work well at the table or as an apéritif.

This wine's subtle, savory nose has the merest hint of redcurrant. It's light in body, with a curious combination of rusticity and elegance. Shimmering, peppery spice shines amid the tart fruit on the translucent, grippy and very fresh palate. The finish is dry and long.
Aromas of cedar, dark spice and black-skinned berry lead the nose. The dense palate evokes vanilla, black cherry jam and star anise alongside close-grained tannins. Drink after 2022.

From 100-year-old vines revived by the Calabria family themselves, this is a broody, robust red that needs time in the cellar. Ripe plum and dark berry, dark chocolate, pepper and plenty of charred oak dominate the nose. The palate dials the richness up another notch, coating the tongue like a wool blanket with more plush fruit and toasty, chewy oak. This is a beast of a wine at the moment and needs a few more years to settle. Drink 2020–2038.
Delicate aromas of rose petal, tilled soil and leather emerge from the glass. The round palate offers raspberry jam, licorice and vanilla alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2025.
This opens with subtle aromas of dark berry, underbrush and botanical herb. The taut palate offers red cherry, white pepper and clove alongside firm acidity and assertive tannins. Drink after 2022.

This stylish wine balances acidity with a firm core of tannins. Its berry fruits and spice from wood aging are now integrated to give a ripe wine that also has a fresh juicy element. Drink the wine from 2019.

Delicately alluring aromas of peach blossom, stone fruit and citrus lead the nose. Recalling the aromas, the ripe, rounded palate offers mature yellow apple, candied tangerine zest and pineapple packed in syrup.

Aromas of cherry, mocha and flint lead to flavors of blackberry, cassis, violet, roasted tomato and espresso. Velvety tannins coat the mouth, lingering beyond the bright finish that is marked with a note of coffee.

Violet-red in color, this wine has aromas of blackberry, violet and anise. Lush tannins and flavors of black cherry, cassis, anisette, lavender and chocolate coat the palate, eventually revealing a finish laced with bright cherry and a hint of smoke.
This appealing and medium-bodied wine has a light earthy, buttery aroma and plenty of butter, lemon and vanilla flavors underpinned by good, lively acidity that keeps it fresh through the finish.

From a selection by the winemaking team, this wine reflects both the region's ripe fruit and the structure in the wines. It has black fruits and young, firm tannins, ready to age further. Drink this potentially fruity, rich wine from 2019.
designation: Herdade de São Miguel Escolha dos Enólogos

description: This single-vineyard wine is rich, packed with tannins as well as complexity and black fruits. Its tannins are now well integrated into the solid blackberry flavors. Wood aging for nine months has given a polish to the wine, which is ready to drink.

Made entirely with Sangiovese, this opens with aromas of black-skinned berry, tobacco and cedar. The firm savory palate offers dried black cherry, clove and white pepper alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2024.
This is a decent-quality wine that shows mild apple and canteloupe flavors, a rather soft texture and medium body.

Plush, ripe black cherry and plum notes are quite forward and attractive, with an overlay of sweet spice and mocha tones. The palate is smooth and easy to like, with soft tannins and more juicy black-fruit flavors that show decent length on the close.

A pale pink color, this leads with light aromas of strawberry and red currant. The palate is surprisingly round and fleshy in feel, with abundant white melon and citrus flavors that finish short but clean.

Herbal, minty aromas waft first from the nose of this bottling, surrounded by fruity tones of dark plum and cassis. The medium-weight palate offers some tannic grip and more black-fruit flavors, with just a hint of coffee on the close.
There's no question of the variety, with its notes of dried and fresh herb along with green pepper. The cherry flavors are light, with the tannins bringing a lightly gritty feel.
Broken aromas of baked fruits, clove and dirt are a bit odd and unusual. A round, cushioned palate is home to burnt briny orange flavors. On the finish, this is steady but tastes salty.
This wine's celery and arugula aromas include a touch of citrus. Low acidity creates a flabby mouthfeel, where its vegetal, green bell pepper flavors stagnate. The finish is briny and vapid.
This Tempranillo's cranberry and currant aromas are lean and raw. It feels capped and rough on the palate, with acidic scratchiness and choppy plum and currant flavors.
This wine's prune, raisin and cassis aromas lead to a flabby, misdirected palate. Its black fruit flavors are candied and severely overripe. It's so viscous and syrupy that it's hard to drink.
This medium-bodied wine smells and tastes overtly oaky, as notes of maple syrup, brown sugar and cinnamon blanket the mild fruit flavors underneath.
This wine's oxidized aromas bring Cream of Wheat to mind. Its spritzy palate is green and clipped, with bready, oxidized flavors. Whatever citrus fruit it has is green and turns bitter on the finish.
This wine's berry and clove aromas include notes of forced oak. The palate is raw and grippy, with tomato, plum, green herb and clove notes. The thin, drying finish is rough with tannin.

Flower, plum and berry aromas are spicy and lightly herbal on the nose. They do a good job of capturing the essence of this Cabernet Sauvignon, which includes about one-third Syrah and Petit Verdot. A loaded palate is rough and tumble, while this tastes of spicy, foresty berry fruits. Oak, espresso and toast flavors along with heat are the big four on the finish of this cellar-worthy red blend; drink through 2028.

Warm tones of toast and spice juxtapose savory green olive and crushed earth in this fleshy but nuanced wine. Concentrated blackberry and cherry flavors are unctuous and juicy but balanced by rippling minerality and brisk acidity. An integrated, foursquare wine to enjoy now–2028.

Delicious smoky wood over red-cherry flavors make this a ripe wine. Its structure is in place as are the bright fruits. There is a juicy character to this generous wine that will age easily and will be ready from 2021.

Delicately scented but enticing, this offers tantalizing aromas of red berry, new leather, Mediterranean herb and exotic spice. The focused palate is all about extreme elegance, evoking strawberry, blood orange, star anise and a tangy mineral note framed by polished tannins and vibrant acidity. It may be too ethereal and understated for some, but others will love it. Drink 2020–2026.

There is a strong earthy and rocky quality on the nose of this wine at first, with crushed gravel aromas, but then the dark red fruit becomes more boisterous. There is also candied red fruit in the background on the sip, but the mineral tones of slate and earth are prominent and compelling.

A heady dose of Syrah lends intense minerality and a peppery kick to this full-bodied but elegant wine. Blackberry and cherry flavors are pristine and juicy, edged by very fine, supple tannins and brisk acidity. Drinks vibrantly now but should improve through 2028.

A reductive onion note initially masks this wine. Eventually, as the wine aerates it shows citrus fruit, dried green herbs and tomato leaf. Things improve a bit on the palate where a citrus tone plays alongside juicy acidity, but overall this is an austere and simple style.
A rusty shade of pink, this bottling, which includes 10% Picpoul Blanc, shows cooked cherries and baking spice on the nose. The palate is full of watery cherries.
Muted fruit tones come through in this young wine. It needs a little time to allow the citrus fruit flavors to reveal themselves. Drink from 2019.

Damp, herbal berry aromas lead to a full palate with rubbery tannins. Soft, stewed berry and spice flavors are low on kick and freshness but don't fold. On the finish, this flattens out and tastes baked and slightly cooked.

Briny citrus and bell pepper aromas amount to a lightly pickled nose. This Garnacha Blanca is solid in feel but common. Short pear and apple flavors are lightly green and vegetal, while a low-acid finish doesn't have much to offer.

Red berry, crushed mint, new leather and underbrush aromas are front and center. Savory and juicy, the taut vibrant palate doles out succulent raspberry, tart red cherry and star anise alongside youthfully tense, polished tannins. Drink 2020–2026.

This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc and Petit Verdot is a great way to see what's happening with this family-owned estate. Aromas of roasted coffee, toasted oak, ripe black plum and blackberry lead into a palate full of charred cherry, black raspberry and cedar. A rocky earthy minerality is also apparent throughout.

Exuberant hints of nettle and hedgerow fruit, green apple and citrus jump from the glass. The lively fizz emphasizes the freshness and liveliness of the flavors even more. The finish is dominated by fruit and spells lasting, refreshing joy.

This coastal wine has a feral element of exotic fruit, rhubarb and blood orange mostly, with touches of rose petal around its edges. Silky smooth and unabashedly ripe and full bodied, it has an underlying freshness of lively acidity and integration.

Sourced from 72% Monterey County, 15% Santa Barbara County and 13% Sonoma County, this bottling starts with red cherry, clove, vanilla and star anise on the nose. The palate combines sharp baking spice with baked cherry, all framed by powerful acidity.

Aromas of forest floor, red berry and Alpine herb lead the way on this 100% Nebbiolo. The elegantly structured palate offers red cherry, crushed strawberry and star anise alongside fine-grained tannins and fresh acidity. Drink through 2023.

Bright and vibrant on the nose in spiced cranberry and blackberry, there's a hint of green herb in the background of this wine. Having seen no time in oak, this light-bodied wine is all about fresh, racy currant and cranberry flavors, with a graphite edge to offer support.
Subtle white flower, nut and orchard fruit aromas lead the way in this wine. On the enjoyable palate, fresh acidity accompanies green apple, citrus and bitter almond notes.

A severely oaked nose deals aromas of shoe polish and charred wood. A chunky jammy palate is more flabby than in prime shape. Heavy oak combined with pencil lead and black-fruit flavors precede a finish with front and center oak. All in all, there's too much burnt wood on this blend of Malbec, Syrah and Petit Verdot.

Oak aromas are at the fore, with notes of vanilla and baking spice taking over, along with a light meaty note. The palate shows more of the same, with lighter-styled cranberry flavors working to get to the surface. The fruit seems overmatched for the oak.

A strong rocky minerality drives the nose of this bottling by the family of former Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda, but there are also hints of smoke and dried blueberry. The palate is fairly light in tannins and mouthfeel, showing boysenberry, crushed rock and marjoram flavors.
Light and fruity, this wine offers crisp acidity over red-currant flavors. It's balanced, tangy with a refreshing aftertaste. Drink now.

A more fruit-driven, approachable Riesling than the 1961 Block, this is already showing some honeyed notes along with peaches, orange peel and florals. There's plenty of bright citrusy stone-fruit flavors on the palate in addition to a wet stone minerality and laser-sharp acidity. Drink now–2028.

Still young, this complex, rich wine deserves aging. It has rich acidity as well as rounded apple and pear flavors. This producer, based in the Aube, has taken advantage of the ripe grapes of the region to keep the wine dry, bringing out minerality and fruitiness. Drink this wine from 2019.

Pol Roger's nonvintage cuvée is perfectly in the house style with its great balance and poise between crisp dryness and a softer character. That makes for a very drinkable wine, rich, stylish and ready to drink now.

Lavender and licorice combine effortlessly on the nose and entry of this wine, which deserves its reserve billing. Juicy cherry, currant, cedar and dried herb are the highlights, woven around a dense core of generous tannin, richness and density. Enjoy 2024–2034.

This is such a winning combination, a blend of 47% Grenache, 25% Mourvèdre, 15% Petite Sirah, 8% Counoise and 5% Syrah, all from the estate. Fuzzy apricot and peach present first within a dark pinkish-red color. Strawberry follows, the whole brightened by plenty of buzzy acidity.

Ripe, red apple on the nose joins juicy, tart lemon on the palate. This is slender and ripe but lemon darts through the palate to bring freshness and verve to this little fruit bomb. The finish is zesty, lively and dry.

Rusty aromas of dried cherry, roasted fennel and sweet smoke show on the nose of this blend of 47% Grenache, 30% Syrah and 23% Mourvèdre. Sour red-plum skins start the sip and then it warms toward red cherry with hints of anise, thyme and sagebrush. It will pair with a wide variety of foods.

Ripe but balanced, this full-bodied red offers equal parts juicy black-fruit flavor and earthier nuances of forest floor and dried herbs. It's approachable and juicy yet structured with fine, penetrating tannins. Enjoy now–2026.

This wine's pineapple and floral aromas are blowsy at first but settle with airing. Its smooth palate has a full texture, bracing acidity and lightly salty apple flavors that finish with a briny note of seashell. Overall, this balances pop with weight, capturing what can be so appealing about Albariño.
Creamy and lush in peach and swirls of vanilla, this is a textured and expansive example of the variety, floral and indeed dry, made in a full-bodied, more explosive style.

Interestingly floral and high in acidity, this white was given three hours of skin contact after the grapes were crushed, the wine then fermented and aged in stainless steel. Wet stone minerality and floral earthiness abound around sizzling freshness and peachy flavor.

Leather and tobacco tones add to the savory, grippy aspect of this boldly ripe, rich wine. Concentrated in blueberry and blackberry flavors, the palate is supple and succulent, leading to a finish of brown sugar and clove.

Based in the Hautes Côtes de Beaune, this family estate has produced this ripe wine from a small 2.4-acre vineyard, named after the prehistoric monument on the site. The wine is rich, perfumed and full of red berry fruits. Acidity and a tannic structure promise some aging. Drink from 2020.

Old vines, around 45 years in age, form the basis of this single-vineyard wine. It is beautifully fruity, crisp and with good acidity and a tangy, citrus edge. The wine is intensely fruity and well balanced.
This smooth, ripe wine is ready to drink, displaying a forward black fruit flavor and rich, well-integrated tannins. A lovely balance of rich fruit and tannic structure. Drink now.

The tannins and the firm, dark texture form an impressive part of this rich wine. They are balanced by the black fruits and the generous structure. Aged in wood for 22 months, it has a toasty character and plenty of smooth, polished tannins that will allow it to age further. Drink from 2021.

Sourced from one of Oregon's highest vineyards (2,000 feet), this is of a style different from Syrahs from Southern Oregon or further south. Its tart, sappy Marionberry and loganberry flavors come with a delicate savory note. There's a touch of cedar and coffee and enough acidity to match a wide variety of protein-based entrées.

Named after the lime trees that grew around this vineyard, this wine is structured with great minerality as well as tight citrus fruit. It has potential with its tense acidity and hints of apricot flavors. Don't drink before 2021.
The Favray estate is one parcel of 39 acres, producing a taut, mineral and citrus-fruit-driven wine. Still young, his potentially rich wine has intense acidity that needs to soften. Drink from 2019.

The luminescence of the moon is reflected in the Baron family's crisp Chardonnay. This taut, dry wine has attractive apple and tight citrus flavors. Its acidity and lively bright texture come together to give a perfumed wine touched by minerality, and ready to drink.
designation: Pierre de Lune Blanc de Blancs Brut

description: There's a palate-reviving snap to this wine, which opens with ripe, juicy flavors of blackberries. A streak of mocha carries it along, and there's a hint of something akin to eucalyptus as well.

Aromas of underbrush, exotic spice and dark-skinned fruit mingle with a whiff of camphor. The assertive palate offers dried morello cherry, clove and star anise alongside firm acidity while tightly knit, close-grained tannins leave a somewhat astringent finish. It's still austere and needs time to fully develop. Drink after 2022.

Blackberry, cassis and licorice aromas are ripe on the nose. Bright acidity creates tension on the palate, while this tastes of berry and cherry flavors offset by lactic oak. On the finish, an oaky vanilla tone wrestles with brisk red-berry acidity.

Vibrant aromas of grapefruit spray, papaya and tomato leaf carry to the textured, light-bodied palate. This is immensely crisp and refreshing in feel, with crunchy green pear and citrus ringing on the finish.
Coming in a box wine format, this wine brings light aromas of jasmine, orange zest and flowers. It drinks closer to dry than one might imagine. Still, the flavors fall a bit flat.
Deliciously refreshing and full of fruit, this bright, young wine is ready to drink. Its fruitiness and acidity are well balanced, giving a crisp wine, lively and lightly textured.

Aromas of baking spice, vanilla and anise are followed by sweet, lightly chalky-feeling fruit flavors. Coffee notes linger on the very warm finish. The oak influence is primary, making the sense of place hard to find.
A sweetness of vanilla is highlighted from the oak in this candied, fleshy and simple wine that finishes in a burst of overripe heat.

Lightly floral aromas lead to a foamy palate with grapefruit-like acidity. Flavors follow suit, namely pink grapefruit in a freshly squeezed style. A grape-skins texture makes for a raw, citric finish.
Spice and barnyard aromas give this wine an earthy character. The citrus fruit is there yet it is overrun by the earth-driven elements.
Very mapley and sweet in flavor, this wine is medium bodied and packed with ripe jammy fruit flavors and heavy accents of brown sugar.
This features incongruous stewed berry, graphite and tea aromas. The palate is soupy, with burnt oak, mint and grass flavors.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: This wine has earthy sunbaked aromas and rather lean flavors of fennel and black pepper. It's medium bodied, dry and moderately tannic.
This wine is sharp and pyrazinic, with notes of sour grapefruit and jalapeño. The finish is crisp and citrus driven.
Bell pepper and sweat aromas introduce this lean, high-acid Sauvignon Blanc with sour citrus flavors and vegetal notes. The finish is tangy, sharp and slightly bitter.
This wine's aroma can only be described as sweaty, with unappealing dankness. Its cranberry-like fruit is thin, peppered with dried-out tannins.

Inviting aromas of ripe dark-skinned berry, new leather, cocoa and forest floor emerge from the glass. The concentrated palate doles out black currant jam, licorice, black pepper and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink 2019–2027.

Aromas of animal hide, berry fruit, foresty herb and generic grit make for a firm and tough nose. High acidity creates energy and a shearing sense on the palate, while this tastes of plum and cassis, with typical herbal notes that are normal for Chile. A juicy finish with herbal leftovers is once again textbook for Chilean Cabernet. Drink from 2020 to 2026.

Spring field flower, white orchard fruit bread crust aromas shape the nose. On the vibrant, elegant palate, bright acidity energizes creamy white peach, juicy yellow apple and citrus zest alongside white almond and a hint of baking spice. A silky perlage softens the racy finish.

Rich, concentrated and structured, this wine comes from 80-year-old vines grown organically and spent 24 months in wood. It needs to age, but already the black-currant fruit glows with crispness and acidity. Wood and tannins are still softening, so drink this wine from 2022.

A deep gold color and effusive aromas of dough, toast and butter start this wine off with a bang. The flavors are rich, vivid and nicely oaky, giving up butterscotch, toast and lemon curd along with softer vanilla and pear tones. It is generous and rich in texture.

Whiffs of charcuterie, thyme and rose petal perfume this seductive blend of Grenache, Syrah, Mourvèdre and Cinsault. Full bodied yet silky, it's an opulent but restrained wine, full of fleshy plum and black cherry flavors. Complex and pretty, it finishes on fine, persistent tannins. Enjoy now–2028.

Berry and black plum aromas are herbaceous and suggest eucalyptus and hot pavement. A forward palate is edgy and grabby in feel, while highly herbal plum and berry flavors lean toward green. Saucy, herbal, soupy flavors dominate a thick finish.

There's ripe and then there's overripe; this is closer to the latter than the former. A stewy, saucy black fruit nose is slightly green in the middle. Sappy and syrupy in feel, this tastes of charred oak, raisiny black fruit and green herb. On the finish is where the overweight and overripe qualities in this Carmenère drill down.

Briny, punchy white fruit and citrus aromas are oaky. On the palate, this Elqui Valley Chardonnay feels narrow and citrusy. Yeasty stone fruit and citrus flavors are briny, and overall this struggles a bit with its flavor profile.
This is a good, basic wine with modest amounts of fruitiness and butteriness mingling on a medium body. A chalky, earthy note comes in on the midpalate and lingers.
Sliced apples and fresh citrus give this bright wine an attractive character. Light and crisp, it is ready to drink.

Spicy, herbal dark plum aromas are peppery, soupy and a touch green. This Merlot feels hard and pinched, with chewy but rough tannins. Highly herbal flavors of juniper and green herb lend a saucy character to dark berry fruit flavors, while this is lightly green and tannic on the finish.

Attractively tight in structure, this intricate and well-balanced wine pours red-cherry and raspberry flavors on the palate, backed by firm tannins and acidity and medium body. It will be fascinating to see how this develops. Best after 2020.

Gamy aromas of lamb meat and asphalt lead into violet and elderberry touches on the nose of this proprietary red blend. The palate shows elegant touches of dried purple flowers and black-plum skins, finishing on a riper black-currant flavor.

This wine offers an explosive entry of tangerine and rock salt within a context of light, integrated oak and moderate ripeness. Still, it has plenty of power and full-bodied textural complexity that makes it memorable in the glass.
Rose, iris and menthol aromas take center stage. On the bright elegant palate, supple tannins give polished support to juicy Marasca cherry, raspberry and a hint of baking spice. Drink 2020–2026.

Though quite expensive, this is an interesting argument for growing wine in the heart of West Los Angeles, as these grapes hail from Brentwood. Aromas of nectarine, lemon rind and key lime meet with a rich woody background on the nose. The sip is quite bright and refreshing with flavors of lemon and mandarin orange.

Dark red-currant, dried herbs and cigar-box aromas make for an Old World-like elegance on this blend of 36% Cabernet Sauvignon, 28% Cabernet Franc, 24% Merlot and 12% Petit Verdot. Oregano, marjoram and peppercorn meet with elderberry and black plum on the palate, which is deep in loamy flavors and finishing on a hint of carnation.

This long-standing vineyard designate is robust on the nose in forest earthiness and spicy cardamom, and pleasantly expansive on the palate in lasting concentration and jammy cherry and strawberry flavors.

Goosepen Block is a site that was planted to Pommard clone in 1998. The wine is compact, with black cherry and leather notes and firm tannins. Aged in 38% new French oak, it's wreathed in smoke and espresso accents, with a touch of dark chocolate.

This offers concentrated black fruit along with the tannins and stem flavors that result from extended maceration. It was aged 17 months in 44% new French oak, which lends smoke and espresso notes to the extended finish.
Ripe and bold in flavor, this polished, focused wine is full bodied and firmly tannic. It has effusive blackberry aromas and wonderfully dry, concentrated flavors.

Plush pink-grapefruit and pomelo flavors burst from this light-bodied but intensely ripe Riesling. It's subtly sweet yet tangy, balanced by spine-tingling lime acidity and refreshing mineral complexities. Delicious already but it should improve through 2022, hold further.

Delicate scents reminiscent of underbrush, scorched earth, flint, pressed blue flower and a whiff of toast lead the nose. The bright medium-bodied palate delivers crushed red berry, licorice and grilled Mediterranean herb alongside polished, fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2023.
Light and fruity, this wine offers crisp acidity over red-currant flavors. It's balanced, tangy with a refreshing aftertaste. Drink now.

Aromas of white grape juice, yellow peach and ruby grapefruit introduce this luscious rosé. Yellow cherry and white peach flavors are struck against white pepper and beachgrass on the palate. The polished finish introduces some stony flavors while bitter lime marks the close.

Made from 100% Sangiovese, this opens with exotic spice, French oak and black plum aromas that carry over to the taut, tight palate, along with prune and sour cherry notes. Grainy tannins leave a firm, rather astringent finish.
For pure, young Sauvignon Blanc, this is a soft, rounded wine. It is attractive to drink immediately, with quince, apple and lemon flavors. The final taste is packed with fruit.
designation: Les Hauts de la Gaffelière Sélection d'Excellence

description: Notes of stone fruit, watermelon and passionfruit carry a slightly green tinge. There's a ripeness to the feel, but a nice line of acidity helps maintain balance. Overall, a solid and straightforward buy.

Raw, sliced banana pepper, ground black-pepper, cinnamon and green-herb aromas lead to plump front-loaded cherry and pepper flavors that don't entirely stay together throughout. Cranberry notes linger on the finish.

Light and fresh aromas of lilies, kiwi and mandarin orange show on the nose of this bottling, which is reminiscent of a dewy spring morning. On the palate, the body is also lightweight and refreshing, with rounded apple and Asian pear flavors.

This is a well-balanced, well-structured wine that will be great to have on hand for almost any occasion. It is attractively dry, medium bodied, has hints of oak spice in the aromas, is full of red-cherry and blackberry flavors and has a lightly tannic texture.

Peppery and thick in cured meat, game and smoked oak, this has violet undertones and a powerful grasp of brambly blackberry and blueberry. The tannins are well managed and supportive, showing ability to age with grace. Enjoy best 2025–2028.

An intensely broad-shouldered red blended with 13% Petite Sirah, this has plenty of power within a full-flavored array of brambly blackberry, cherry and dusty cinnamon. The oak (a blend of French and American) is supportive and integrated.
Aromas of yellow apple, Bartlett pear and a hint of baking spice carry over to the creamy palate along with lemon drop, crushed herb and a hint of vanilla. Bright acidity lifts the rich flavors.

Blended with 9% Cabernet Sauvignon, 8% Malbec and 3% Petit Verdot, this is a thick and concentrated showing of the variety, plush and lushly spicy in clove and cinnamon. The fruit is plummy and rich in dark cherry, toasted oak and vanilla tea.

This luscious wine with its blend of the two Manseng grapes is full of ripe peach and apricot flavors laced with honey. As with all the wines from this region, it has intense acidity that keeps it fresh, almost crisp, certainly not heavy. The wine could age further, so drink from 2019.

A rich wine, this is full of spicy apricot, kiwi and honey flavors. The delicious combination offers a pepper edge along with great acidity. Richness and weight are balanced by the intensely crisp aftertaste. Drink this wine from 2019.

The rare Prunelart grape (also called Prunelard) is grown in small quantities in Gaillac. Owners Brigitte and Alain Cazottes are among the pioneers in preserving this grape that in 2008 was determined to be the father of Malbec. The wine is firm, densely structured although with plenty of jammy black fruits. Despite its moderate alcohol, it is powerful because of its tannins and dense fruits. Drink from 2020.
designation: L'Orée du Domaine des Terrisses Prunelart

description: This is a creamy, smooth wine. Vanilla and ripe quince flavors combine easily into a rich blend with a mineral edge. This full-bodied wine is easy to drink now and will also age. For best effect wait until late 2018.
The winery lists this as a reserve, though there doesn't appear to be any such indication on the label. The flavors are robust, penetrating and succulent, suggesting Meyer lemon, lime and pineapple.

This is a delicious, no-nonsense wine that features pure fruit flavors, little obvious oak influence, good zingy acidity and excellent balance. Its strength is a slight sense of reserve that is refreshing and mouthwatering.

There's a strong citrus component of lemon and grapefruit, underscoring wild blackberry fruit. Barrel aging for 10 months in 30% new French oak adds a streak of roasted coffee through the finish. Balanced and medium bodied, this should drink well into the mid-2020s.

Made with 100% Chardonnay, this opens with aromas of orchard fruit, toasted oak and acacia flower. The rich palate offers Golden Delicious apple and lemon alongside a note of bitter almond. Drink through 2022.

Delicate whiffs of crushed mineral, green apple and tangerine on the nose carry to the concentrated, off-dry palate. This is an uncomplicated wine, with pure flavors of juicy pineapple and grapefruit, marked by a touch of honeycomb and lemon zest on the finish. Enjoy now–2021.

This ripe and creamy wine offers fruitiness balanced by a full mousse and cut with acidity. Dominated by Pinot Noir, it displays the richness typical of the southern Aube vineyards. Drink this bottling now.

A shade lighter than most Petite Sirahs, this bottling offers dried strawberry, black plum and fresh flowers on the nose. The palate surrounds a core of black and red-plum fruits and is laced with peppery spices, proving light on its feet.

This opens with subdued aromas of dark-skinned fruit, vanilla and baking spice. The concentrated palate offers ripe black plum, star anise and tobacco alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2024.
This opens with stale, charmless aromas and a rough, raw texture. Its flavors are bland and disjointed, marked by lasting bitterness.
An extreme aroma of rose and hibiscus blossoms leads to sweet, strongly floral flavors and a grape-jelly note on the finish. It's not for anyone expecting a traditional dry wine taste.
Strong caramel and herbal aromas overshadow the fruit in this crisp organic wine. It has a sharp aftertaste.
This aggressive and tart wine pushes the limits. It has raspberry and raspberry-vinegar aromas, vivid acidity on the palate and sharp cherry flavors.
This wine's gritty aromas of sulfur, match stick and stalky fruit devolve into nothing. The palate is lifeless, marked by dull, oxidized flavors with little fruit and a yeasty-tasting finish.
This wine is barely reviewable, with totally dried out, leathery flavors.

Oxidized aromas announce a wine on its last legs. Dry low-intensity peach and cantaloupe flavors finish slightly bitter and without much vitality. Txakoli wines should be consumed during the year after harvest, thus this is past its sell-by date.

The delicate pink color of this rosato sets it apart from a lineup of darker Cerasuolos. The nose has an odd savory component, similar to nutritional yeast and grains, with a bit of shy strawberry in the background. There's some textural weight to the palate, yet the fruit flavors fall short.
The aromas are surprisingly light for the variety, seeming hard to get at. The palate seems light and dilute, with the flavors appearing washed out.

Grassy, minty red-fruit aromas are weedy and include more than a hint of oaky clove. An acidic and raw palate holds sour red-fruit flavors along with blatant green notes, while this is minty and clove-like on the finish.

Opaque ruby in color, with a thin purple rim, this shows intensely confected aromas of artificial vanilla and sweet cereal grains on the nose. It's rich on the palate, with ultraripe cherry and blackberry flavors that are covered by a thick sheen of more sweet oak.

Tart gooseberry and grapefruit aromas are soft and reserved on the nose of this wine, though they carry through to the palate with a but more intensity. There's a thinness to the midpalate, while just enough lemon-lime acidity graces the finish.

Hints of sweet licorice and cinnamon accent this dulcet wine full of juicy black cherry and blueberry flavors. It's warm and welcoming on the palate, but hints of wild mint and thyme suggest the development of savory complexities through 2026.
This is a textured and structured wine that has good aging potential. Tones of butter and ripe fruit broaden out the palate, while plenty of acidity keeps everything fresh. Drink from 2020.

Yellow wildflower, chamomile, bread crust and acacia honey aromas follow through to the elegantly sparkling palate together with yellow apple, citrus zest and flinty minerals. A honeyed almond note lingers on the close.

Made with native grape Durello, this has enticing scents of pressed wildflower, wet stone, bread crust and acacia honey. The honeyed note follows over to the palate along with ripe apple, white peach and hazelnut set against crisp acidity and a polished perlage. A mineral vein energizes the bone-dry finish.
designation: Roncà Non Dosato 60 Mesi Metodo Classico

description: Black raspberry, turned earth, baked plum and incense show on the nose of this bottling from the vineyard of winemaker Billy Wathen's good friend Rick Longoria. There is a woody core to the palate, where oak and pine flavors are wrapped around black plum and boysenberry fruit, with a touch of sagebrush.

Fresh plum fruit meets with rocky earth, pipe tobacco and dark-red flowers on the nose of this bottling by Brian and Stephy Terrizzi. The palate is wrapped in a dark earthy core with bountiful acidity and thick tannins, carrying flavors of tangy plum skin and berry fruit.
A perfumed wine, this is soft and clean, with a fine line of acidity that gives brightness. Light, creamy and hinting at tropical fruit, it is ready to drink.

Brambly berry and spice aromas are hard edged and herbal. A powerful palate is needly and tannic, while this is all about mint, spice and herbal flavors. Minty spice lingers on a wiry finish that's short on fruit.
designation: Envero Gran Reserva Estate Bottled Apalta Vineyard Selection

description: Initial yeast and dust aromas fade as this turns a bit funky and pickled on the nose. A healthy palate with briny green melon flavors flatlines on a yeasty finish. Overall this is pretty good but nothing more.

Spicy, slightly murky berry flavors show an animal note along with clove. In the mouth, this is rough and grinding, with edgy tannins. Flavors of clove and roasted berry fruit are choppy on the finish.

Prickly green-leaning aromas of mint, eucalyptus and bell pepper lead to a full and fair palate. Black fruit flavors are generic and backed by rosemary and bell pepper notes. From start to finish, this is minty and herbal.

Aromas of bell pepper and asparagus would rate as lightly vegetal in most books. A chunky, full palate is low on acidic verve, while a highly pyrazinic flavor profile means this tastes of green citrus and veggies. Mild bitterness and a note of citrus skins lead a plump, chunky finish.

This is another boundary-breaking bottling by Larry Tercero, who foot stomped this whole cluster blend of 40% Cinsault, 40% Grenache and 20% Carignan, aged it solely in stainless steel and then released it young with advice to chill before drinking. It's light in color and loaded with aromas of carnation, rose petal, red plum, cola and wet stone. The palate's rounded bright red fruit is fun and easy to glug.

Named after proprietor Bill Price's son, this bottling offers lean yet focused black raspberry and crushed purple flowers on the nose, as well as a slightly sour funky streak. The palate is framed by tangy dense boysenberry with a hint of pine tar. Patience will allow the flavors to better coalesce. Drink 2020–2030.

This estate-grown, 100% varietal wine is well made and full bodied in its thick, billowy yet tannic structure. Baked blueberry and leather provide a dense, savory core marked by lasting cedar and black pepper impressions.

This wine's roasted, savory bouquet contains blackberry, cinnamon, olive, earth and oak aromas. It hails from Pirque, one of Chile's hotbeds for traditional Cabernet Sauvignon. The palate is chewy and deep, with spicy black-fruit flavors and oak-derived notes of cinnamon and nutmeg. Dark fruit and herbal touches flood the finish. Drink now–2023.

High-toned citrus is wrapped in youthful oak in this integrated, textured wine that's medium in weight and ripeness. A dustiness of crushed rock and nutmeg ride along the underside of the palate, lending nuance and savory balance to the fruit before a bolt of acidity hits the fresh, focused finish.

Big and rich, there is plenty here for fans of full-bodied reds: juicy bramble berries, milky coffee, spice and a mouthfilling palate, with sinewy yet elegant tannins. Still in its infancy, this wine will age for decades. Drink now–2036.

This wine is a blend of 70% Grenache, 20% Mourvèdre and 10% Syrah. The aromas jump up, with notes of fresh orange, raspberry, olive, herb and wet stone. The palate is full bodied and rich, with abundant fruit and savory flavors that persist on the finish.
Fruity in dark cherry and cola spice and cinnamon, this is a moderately ripe, textured wine, toasty in oak and fulfilling in its balanced richness.

Dry raisin and prune aromas fall short of being sappy and flat. A thick muscular palate is dense and layered. Flavors of chocolate, burnt toast and oak are more prominent than berry-fruit notes, while this is ripe, meaty and loaded with residual oak on the finish. Drink through 2021.

This is from the Alegria Vineyard, originally planted in 1890 and then partially replanted in 1950. It blends within 10% Alicante, 10% Petite Sirah and 2% of a dozen other varieties found in the field. Burly, dusty tobacco is accented in cedar notes and graphite, with powerful concentration and structure at its core.

Floral and with notes of crushed rock and salty sea spray, this wine is richly round and complex, with a balanced approach to ripeness. Exotic lemon peel and lemongrass play well with the toasted oak and candied-apricot finish.

This Mencía smells more ripe than fresh, with aromas of prune, raisin and spice cake. A jammy palate is a touch overweight, while mocha, spice, raisin and cassis flavors finish rich and chocolaty. Drink now for its ripe friendliness.

This wine has a very deep color. Ample aromas of blackberry and boysenberry jam are followed by flavors that are rich and ripe. It's concentrated and fruity while staying rather low in acidity and soft in terms of tannin.

Dried grass, lemon peel and tart gooseberry set the stage on the nose of this bright wine and carry through to the tart-flavored palate. The mouthfeel is surprisingly rounded in texture, though it's lifted by ample acidity that helps to enliven the finish. Drink now.
This opens with subdued baking spice and black plum aromas that carry over to the linear palate, along with a hint of clove. It's straightforward and easy-drinking, with smooth tannins. Enjoy soon.

Earthy tones of smoke and dusty mineral blow off to reveal elegant yellow apple and pear fruit here. Despite its dry, light-bodied style, it's pleasantly mouth-clinging and supple in texture. Sprightly acidity brightens its moderately long finish.
Made entirely from Sangiovese, this has subdued black plum and baking spice aromas. The linear palate delivers prune, clove and licorice hints accompanied by relaxed tannins. Drink soon.

Apple, stone-fruit and buttercup aromas are good but basic. This Verdejo is honest and fresh on the palate, but far from complex. Salty apple flavors are reserved, while this tastes of briny apple and melon on the finish.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: This leads with high toned notes of clove, toast and plum. Its full-bodied purple fruit and spice flavors are tightly wound for now, backed by firm tannins. Abundant orange peel and black pepper flavors linger on the finish.

Full of new-wood flavors, this is a wine that shouts. It is almost black in color, full of black fruits and with huge tannins. It might be too much although those with a yen for loud statement wines will appreciate this. Don't drink before 2024.

This dry light-footed Silvaner offers tangy yellow-apple and lemon flavors elevated by whiffs of blossom, honeycomb and crushed mineral. It's a sprightly lean wine with a crisp finish. Drink now through 2021.

Intense black plum and cherry perfume juxtapose savory tones of smoked nuts and wet earth in this fresh and fruity yet composed wine. Plump black-fruit flavors are broad and rich but framed by brisk acidity and a trace of mineral complexity. A fantastic introduction to German Pinot that's surprisingly easy on the wallet. This cuvée is also labeled under the Gryphon Crest brand.

This wine comes from a blend of young vines and some that are more than 80 years old. A touch of wood aging adds spice and extra ripeness to the generous black fruits and acidity. It's still youthful in nature, so drink from 2019.

From the high, third terrace above the Lot river, this wine brings out chalky soil, as shown in its minerality and texture. It is a blend with 90% Malbec and 10% Merlot, giving both the structure and ripe, juicy black fruits. Drink this impressive wine now.
Plump and ripe, this fruity exuberant wine was made from vines planted in 1979. It has plenty of vivid raspberry, cherry and raspberry flavors, a lush, almost soft texture and a lingering finish.
designation: Reserve Spanish Creek Vineyard Old Vine

description: Ripe fruit and rich tannins mark this wine out. It shows a blend of structure and ripe fruit, along with firm young tannins. It has good potential with its generous black-fruit flavors. Drink this complex wine from 2021.

Firm tannins along with ripe and juicy berry fruits mark out this rich wine. Aged partially in wood, this blend is dominated by Merlot. Juicy, full of solid tannins, the wine will age for several more years. Drink from 2021.

This ripe, Merlot-dominated blend is packed with the berry fruits typical of the vintage. There is a spicy edge to this rich wine that offers smooth tannins and a juicy aftertaste. It will age relatively quickly, so drink from 2020.

Dense and rich, this is a full, ripe 95% Sémillon wine. It has a good balance between honeyed sweetness and acidity while the apricot and bitter-orange flavors bring fruit and richness. The wine will develop further. Drink from 2020.

Delahommeau has produced a textured, mineral style of wine that could do with some aging. It's a steely wine that's developing fruitiness. Citrus and quince flavors are showing well, bringing acidity that cuts through the fruit. Drink now.

Generic white fruit and citrus aromas show a green note of pyrazine in this wine. It's extremely citric, acidic and dilute, with tart, underripe citrus flavors. An oxidized, yeasty note that emerges on the finish.
From the minute this hits the glass, it begins devolving. Its gritty, lanolin-like aromas are atypical of Albariño. Flat, oxidized white fruit flavors lend bitterness to the finish.
This wine's wooly fruit aromas show a volatile whiff of vinegar. It's jammy and out of shape, with soupy raspberry and plum flavors.

This wine's savory berry aromas include a strong blast of mustard and leafy, minty notes. The palate is choppy, acidic and raw, with clove-laced sour berry flavors. It's thin and out of balance on the finish.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla y León

description: Scattershot aromas of green herbs, mint and blueberries introduce this hard, flat wine. Its plum flavors are raw and minty, and the finish is harsh with green notes.
region_1: Vino de la Tierra de Castilla

description: This Viura, aged five months on the lees, has wayward, blowsy vanilla and spun sugar aromas and no focal point on the palate. Its yeasty white fruit flavors are strange, unfamiliar and shapeless.
This wine needs aging. Its tight texture, although rich, is also taut and mineral. With herbal acidity and a tangy aftertaste, it shows excellent potential. Drink from 2019.
Earthy in black tea and leather, this tastes of smoky oak and dried cherry and strawberry, its texture smooth and silky. Exotic in an edginess of citrus, it finishes with a grip of tannin.

Made from 60% Chardonnay and 40% Pinot Noir, there's a pleasant chalkiness to the nose of this wine, supported by scents of pressed yellow flowers, apple blossom, hay and dried orange peel. The palate is bright and vibrant, with great tension and high acidity that lends a superb freshness through the close and dances delicately with a bread crust counterpoint.
designation: Twee Jonge Gezellen Borealis Vintage Cuvée Brut Méthode Cap Classique

description: Spicy berry, oak, vanilla and schist aromas introduce a crisp palate with resiny oak. Dark plum and raspberry flavors are bolstered by oaky notes, while this tastes dark and chocolaty on a finish with fresh acidity and scratchy tannins.

Up-front aromas of cedary oak, vanilla and spice provide framing for riper berry scents. A full palate with piping acidity is cut by creamy oak, while this tastes of red plum, currant, tobacco, savory spices and vanilla. Although a bit ripe and soupy in structure, this is a classic-style Rioja to drink now.
This is a juicy, off-dry wine showcasing a bounty of ripe white-grapefruit and pineapple flavors. It's easy-drinking and quaffable, with a refreshing tonic finish. Enjoy now–2020.
Floral white-fruit aromas offer little authenticity or depth. Ditto the palate, which is bland. Flavors of mustard, briny citrus fruits and generic bitterness linger on the finish.
Strong aromas of green pepper, herb and currant lead to quite lightly styled fruit flavors. It all seems quite underripe.

This Syrah shows aromas of campfire, charred meats and beef jerky, with red currant and violet laced around the edges. Any intrigue on the nose belies the flat palate that brings vanilla, green tobacco leaves and oak, with ripe red berries adding the only hint of life. Drying tannins are flavorless for the most part, building towards the finish and hinting at spice at its peek before sliding into the astringent  dried-cranberry finish.

A blend of 80% Malbec and 20% Syrah, strong scents of vanilla, coconut shavings, green pepper, white pepper and dried cherry are followed by quite light fruit flavors that trail on the finish. There's not enough fruit to stand up to the oak.
Dusty apple aromas are confected, as is this entire off-dry Cava. A foamy palate is decidedly sweet, with lemon-lime notes. Candied flavors carry over to a slightly cloying finish.
This wine is unduly green and chalky on the palate, with a disjointed approach to acidity. Full bodied and robust, it struggles to maintain structure.

Aromas of earthy berry fruit, compost, creamy oak and rubber don't amount to much. In the mouth, this is chunky, lazy and soupy feeling. Herbal blackberry flavors are slightly murky and green, while this is static on the finish.
While tannins dominate this wine, it also has lots of fruit potential. The richness and structure of the vintage are there, meaning the wine will develop. Drink from 2021.
Fruity and ripe, this wine is developing fast. Its tannins are already soft, giving an attractive red-fruit-flavored wine. Drink from 2021.
This wine is soft and ripe with smooth fruits, touches of caramel and honey, and good acidity. Drink now.

This needs time in glass to aerate and to show its passionfruit, pineapple, grapefruit and green herbed characters. Even then, the acidity is a little searing, just barely kept in check by some fruit weight.
Full bodied with plenty of tannins, this wine is firm and still with its dry core. It needs plenty of time for any fruit to show, although it seems it will always have a dry edge.

Spring flower, white orchard fruit and citrus aromas mingle with a whiff of bread crust. Bright and elegant, the palate doles out yellow apple, lemon zest and a hint of ginger set against a refined, continuous perlage.

Sappy, rooty aromas of baked black fruit, spice cake and chocolate announce a supremely ripe Carmenère (with 8% Petit Verdot) that's as lush, chewy and dense on the palate as possible without being overdone. Massive blackberry, cassis, chocolate and baking spice flavors finish toasty and rich. While this turns over no new stones, it's decidedly appealing. Drink through 2021.

Fragrant and refined, this has lovely aromas of white spring flower, orchard fruit, citrus and pastry dough. On the silky palate, bright acidity lifts juicy white peach, McIntosh apple, tangerine and ginger. A creamy mousse lends elegance, while the wine finishes juicy and bone-dry.

This is a traditional method Champagne blend of Pinot Noir and Chardonnay. It offers heaps of yeasty lees aromas mingled with bright apple and touches of toast and honey. The bubbles are bright and persistent, balanced by a slippery texture and a long, fruity, tangy finish.

Youthful, buoyant black cherry and berry flavors abound in this decadent blend of Grenache, Mourvèdre and Syrah. It's fruity and forward, but glimmers of dried bay leaf and thyme lend nuance. Creamy in texture yet finishing on firm, persistent tannins, it's ready to drink now but should improve through 2025.

Made from half Cabernet Sauvignon, the remainder nearly equal portions of Syrah and Merlot, this is a full-bodied ripe blend of spicy, fresh and ample flavors. With integrated tannin and oak, it is effusive in dark berry, leather and clove, with a meaty, gamy tinge on the finish.

This is a wonderful wine, made in large enough quantities to be easily found on store shelves. Smoky, meaty and gamy aromas rise from the glass around perfumed rose. The palate is juicy and velvety, with flavors of berry pie and cinnamon.

Dark candied black-cherry and baked licorice aromas make for a rich entry to this bottling by Michael Larner. A smooth yet structured texture delivers ripe flavors of cracked pepper and boysenberry sorbet.

This golden hued wine from two vineyard sources—Terry Family and Iron Filbert—was fermented in neutral barrels and tastes of bright apple fruit. Orange peel and saltine cracker highlights emerge as it persists into a tight, focused finish. Give it another couple years of bottle age, and it should drink very well through the next decade.

This inky garnet colored wine offers aromas of black currant and fennel bulb. Forest berry flavors are joined by notes of pomegranate, cured meat and thyme, with a sophisticated sense of smokiness across the palate. Firm tannins are interrupted by a splash of cranberry on the finish.

This excellent reserve celebrating the winery's 45th anniversary is a multi-vineyard blend that includes grapes from the top cuvées. It's high toned and scented with whiskey barrel aromas and hints of fresh bread, caramel and almond paste. Although there's plenty going on, the fruit plays a supporting role to all the barrel flavors. Drink now and into the early 2020s.

This wine was sourced from lots from all four of the winery's single vineyard designations. Close in quality to those bottles yet priced well below, it's thick and aromatic in tones of plum, cherry, mushroom and tangerine. Enjoy now through 2025.

A generous dash of oak spice joins rich black-plum and black-cherry flavors in this extravagant wine. Aromas of baking spices, pencil shavings and cedar are followed by warm fruit flavors and a soothing silky texture and a lingering finish.

Pure green-apple aromas are heightened by green-lime freshness. The palate has that same intense and clean-cut fruitiness which plays well with the frothy but soft mousse and the tight, clean and lively palate. This is refreshing exuberance in the glass. The finish is dry, moreish and utterly mouth-watering.

Aromas of candied blackberry, thyme and a bit of gravel make for a compelling nose in this blend of 65% Grenache, 30% Merlot and 5% Syrah. Rounded and dark yet lively in character, flavors of pomegranate, black cherry and black raspberry are framed by zippy acidity and lifted by a pinch of dried herbs.
Touches of lime and lemon zest entice on the shy but refreshing nose. The palate adds a mellow ripe-apple note, helped along by a creamy mousse. The long finish is poised and dry.

A touch of stone fruit gives a richer fruitier edge to the apple notes on the nose. The palate is wonderfully fresh but majors on that fresh crisp apple aroma, helped along by lively citrus. The bubbles are fine and consistent on the refreshing, slender and almost creamy body—a wonderful apéritif style with a dry finish.

Balsamic aromas of soy sauce, Modena vinegar, black olive and stewed berry fruits form the opening on this clampy Ribera with pinching tannins that narrow the palate. Savory blackberry and boysenberry flavors finish with some heat and hard tannins. Drink through 2035.
Accents of brown sugar and maple syrup make this full-bodied wine taste almost sweet. A sense of oaky richness is backed by tasty blackberry and boysenberry flavors and a smooth rich texture.
This freshly crisp wine has a touch of pepper to complement the red fruits. It is lively, refreshing and offers a tangy, tight aftertaste. Drink this attractive wine now.
This wine's tropical fruit and peach aromas carry over to the bright, fruity palate, along with green apple, banana and citrus suggestions. A hint of bitter almond marks the close.

The nose on this bottling is extremely shy and reserved at this stage of its life, showing light aromas of damp oak and lanolin. There is decent tension to the sip, where flavors of nectarine, Gravenstein apple and a chalky minerality barely start to show.

This opens with toast, oak and grilled herb hints. The aromas carry over to the subdued palate, along with roasted almond, grapefruit and butterscotch notes. Drink soon to enjoy the remaining fruit and freshness.
region_1: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore

description: Dried herbs, dark red strawberry and cherry and dried rose petals show on the nose of this blend of 48% Grenache, 27% Mourvèdre and 25% Syrah. The texture is chalky and the acid is solid, carrying flavors of rounded red fruit and well-integrated herbs.

Soft in texture, this wine features rounded, dry tannins and showy wood, revealing its 24 months in new French oak. Graphite, cedar and red currant give it herbal earthiness and a brightness of tangy fruit.

This is a big, beefy wine, with tart black currant, sour cherry, herbal notes and charred, savory undertones. Fine-grained tannins and more savory, herbal characters balance rich fruit on the palate. The finish is long, drying and oaky. Drink now–2028.

Floral like a rose garden, this wine appears deeply extracted and dark in color, its style intensely full-bodied. Black cherry, rhubarb, blueberry and dark-chocolate flavors make for a taste experience that's both tart and richly concentrated.

This small-production, richly concentrated wine has a dense texture and firm tannins. It is full of ripe berries laced with spice from wood aging and with some good aging potential. Drink this fruity, structured wine from 2020.

This meaty wine offers a payload of black fruit and even darker seams of espresso and charcoal. The barrels used likely had a pretty heavy toast, as the flavors border on burnt. It's rare a Pinot Noir belongs with barbecue; this one does.
This leads with jammy, foxy aromas of cherry candy and milk chocolate. Its woody, spicy flavors seem unnatural, tasting more like drugstore chocolate than fresh fruit.
A yellow color and astringent aromas of grape skins, petrol and pyrazines set this blend of Airen, Macabeo and Sauvignon Blanc off on the wrong foot. Its stale fruit and yeast flavors seem oxidized.
This wine's salad dressing and mustard aromas signal some volatility. It's jammy and shapeless on the palate, with saucy berry and mustard flavors. It was tasted twice with slightly varying results.

This wine is bewilderingly savory in tones of clove and sage, but then turns juicy and balanced from flavors of strawberry and blackberry. Grainy in complex texture and tannin, it offers a powerful full-bodied richness and wild quality that's undeniably memorable.

This wine is grown in old coastal soils and sand, driven greatly by the ground underneath it and its surrounding Laguna Ridge environment. It has density and energy in equal measure, a balance of weighty apple and pear mixed in toasted oak and freshness.

Made from a block within the producer's vineyard, which has a different soil series and clonal selection than the rest of the site, this is a stellar, memorable wine that's intensely layered and textured, with lasting, lingering acidity. Bright and inviting in fennel and dried apricot, the broken shale within the soil shows itself in stony, mineral components of oyster shell and white flower, with a fresh yet complex finish. Enjoy 2021–2025

Aromas of ripe dark berry, cedar and mocha lead the way on this full-bodied Nero d'Avola. The dense palate offers blackberry jam, cocoa and tobacco alongside close-grained tannins that need another year or two to unwind. Drink after 2020.

There's a subtle but intriguing note of dried hayflower on the nose of this wine. It also perfumes the palate, where a streak of lifted lemon spells poise and a richer, more sonorous note adds creaminess. Together, these flavors are a synthesis of freshness and mellow pear fruit.
Floral in lovely ways, this big, bold and broadly expansive wine is hugely structured, with plenty of tannin and strong black-fruit flavor. Good supportive acidity keeps it balanced in the glass.

Lightly scented, this offers delicate, alluring aromas of white spring blossom and ripe orchard fruit. On the creamy palate, fresh acidity brightens white peach, yellow apple and lemon zest. A hint of toasted almond lingers on the finish.

Delicate, enticing scents of spring wild flower and ripe pear lead the way on this bright refreshing white. Mirroring the nose, the savory, linear palate delivers apple, tangerine slice and a hint of mineral alongside bright acidity.
This blend of 45% Syrah, 45% Grenache and 10% Barbera is citrus-driven and textured, winning in its light touch and refreshing grasp of acidity. Peach and melon add complexity and lasting fruitiness.

This sources from multiple appellations, combining grapes into a cohesive unit of deep richness and dusty mineral. The richness takes form in flavours of chocolate-covered-cherries and currants, with accents of graphite and dried herb.

From the opening gun, this is overtly and massively ripe, hence it smells of maple, raisin and prune along with crème de cassis liqueur. A heavyweight from front to back, this tastes of brandied black fruits, chocolate cake, clove and other baking spices. An unctuous finish is the opposite of light and dainty.

Underbrush, pressed rose, truffle and leather are some of the aromas you'll find on this medium-bodied red. The already rather approachable palate offers dried cherry, clove and roasted coffee bean alongside fine-grained but rather drying tannins. Drink after 2020.

Apart from the fine spray of fizz, this nose might pass as that of fresh fruit juice, so vivid are the notes of Mirabelle plum and yellow apple. The palate is more vinous, with a smooth backdrop of yeast and generous dosage. This is easy, dry and fruit driven, but very fresh.

Aromas of barrel spice, baking spice and earthy plum form an inviting nose. This is chewy and full on the palate, with good balance. Roasted berry, spiced plum, baking spice and clove flavors close up shop on an edgy finish, with popping acidity and residual roasted notes.
