A shy nose gives off just a little carbon dioxide from the fizz. The substantial palate, however, shows lots of yeasty roundness. This is mild but full bodied and leaves a long impression of lees and grapy freshness. Just a little pepper tingles on the finish of this Grüner Veltliner-based Sekt.
Bready lightly oxidized aromas and a gold color are not overly encouraging. A mostly lifeless palate is pickled and tastes of brined citrus fruits, while a dry hollow finish is the ending.

Grassy berry aromas and oaky clove scents are unconvincing. This blend of Tempranillo and Garnacha feels wiry and a bit like vinegar. Blatant oak and tart plum flavors finish with a distinctly strong note of clove.

A tan color along with severely oxidized aromas make one guarded as sweaty notes of apple juice and cider roll out. A foamy amorphous palate is not a plus, while this organic varietal Xarello tastes of dried peach and apricot in front of a finish with can't-miss notes of nuts and popcorn. For a Cava leader such as Alta Alella, this overpriced organic bottling is weak.

Minty clover and raw red-berry and plum aromas announce a wine that's less than ripe. That impression is confirmed on a rough and scratchy palate. Sour plum and currant flavors finish crisp and grating.

Surprisingly dense and dark scents of licorice and medicinal black cherry set the stage on the nose of this wine, with a subtle warmth as well. Medium in weight, it shows more black fruit-skin flavors on the palate, with astringent tannins that linger.
This is a soft wine, surprisingly so considering the grape and its origins in northern Vinho Verde. It has fruit but it does seem to miss out on flavor and definition.
designation: Lua Cheia em Vinhas Velhas Maria Papoila

description: Named for the falcons that nest above this single block, this bottling offers aromas of cooked cherry, dried herbs, nutmeg and charred oak. The palate is wrapped in clove spice and dried red fruit, with a persistent tension and overall earthy flavor profile.

From a vineyard planted by winery in 1997 that overlooks the Santa Ynez River, this bottling shows clean black-cherry, vanilla, clove and star anise aromas. There is a strong red-plum and orange-rind tang on the palate, which is framed by strong acidity and a chalky texture. Potpourri and black cherry pop on the finish.

This is an unusual commingling of old-vine Petite Sirah from the Napa Valley and Tempranillo from Luc's Vineyard in Sonoma County, a 50-50 partnership between the two. Made in a carbonic style in stainless steel, it tastes of fresh strawberry, raspberry, with a fresh floral aspect to the palate that's juicy, plush and bursting with energy.

Delicious fruit flavors, subtle spices and a generous mouthfeel come together in this full-bodied, luxurious wine. It has a mouth-filling texture due to lots of fine-grained tannins, very ripe and pure black-cherry flavors and excellent concentration that helps extend the finish.

Complexity and concentration mark this wine as a standout. It has a deep, dark color, with aromas of black cherry, currant and mint. Layered flavors of ripe fruit and mild spice are bolstered by a velvety texture of fine-grained tannins. The finish lingers nicely, and the wine will surely improve in the cellar. Best after 2021.

This multi-faceted wine from a new winery that specializes in Italian grape varieties exudes light floral and almond aromas, then brings ripe fruit, a touch of vanilla and great acidity on the palate. It starts out subtly but builds richness with each sip, ending with a long finish.

Tangy cherry fruit anchors this wine, which is highlighted with scents and flavors of stems and tea leaves. There's a light hint of tanned leather, and the palate-pleasing texture keeps the mix of flavors lifted and compelling. A touch of toast emerges on the finish.

Light on its feet, this cool-climate Syrah shows just-pressed elderberry and boysenberry on the nose, with hints of cedar, herbs and game. The palate is restrained, likely a reflection of the young vines, with clean and easy flavors of berry, thyme and white pepper.

Full bodied but well balanced, dry and somewhat restrained in fruit flavors, this wine brings on the complex earthy meaty untamed aromas and flavors of the grape variety as well as blackberry and blueberry that build on the finish. It's a good way to put more adventure in your diet.

Soft aromas of nectarine, raspberry granita and cotton candy come across as extremely fresh, crisp and clean on this rosé of Mourvèdre from Camp 4 Vineyard. There is a great zesty quality to the palate, which is full of life and taut with flavors of red pear, Pink Lady apple and grapefruit zest.

Fresh white blossom and grapefruit perfume this light-bodied but deeply textural white wine. Dry in style, it's a spry citrusy Scheurebe balanced by zesty notes of lime and gooseberry. The finish is long and intently mineral. Drink now through 2022.

Lifted notes of golden honey already show great intensity on the nose and come out in full force on the palate. Here they are joined by pleasantly bitter notes of waxy honeycomb and candied peach, countered by some lemon freshness. It's a wine of uncommon richness, intensity and luscious sweetness.

Jumpy aromas of iodine, foxy berry fruit, green herb and gamy meat are all over the place. This Syrah from a rain-plagued vintage feels wide, grabby and tannic. Gamy, herbal berry flavors finish minty and oaky. For a tough El Niño year, this is good, but that's it.
Light in color and flavor, this wine smells tangy and citrus-like, and tastes lean and low in fruit and acidity. It's clean and simple in character.

Raspberry Kool-Aid aromas don't suggest anything serious. This blend of Merlot and Cabernets Sauvignon and Franc is chunky and blocky in feel, with little shape to the palate. Minty red fruit flavors wrap up on a sticky, tannic finish.
This wine seems sweet due to candied-fruit aromas and flavors and oaky spices like vanilla and maple. It is medium bodied and soft in texture for the varietal.
Ripe and fruity, this wine has apricot and apple flavors and a soft texture that just hints at minerality. Drink now.
Aromas of honeysuckle, green apple and citrus lead the nose. On the simple palate, fresh acidity accompanies pineapple and lemon zest.

Focused and well concentrated, this medium-bodied wine starts with hints of smoke and earth, then delivers ripe, well-defined flavors of red cherry and black cherry. Bright acidity and moderate tannins offer balance and length on the finish.

Suave and well-mannered, this medium-bodied wine is like suede in feel. Flavors of red and black cherries give an overall impression of breadth and gentleness that's hard to resist. It has attractive oak nuances of baking spices and light-roast coffee to add complexity.

Dark cherry and cranberry scents mesh with wood-spice and forest undergrowth aromas on the nose of this bottling from a region that's starting to gain more attention. Chalky tannins provide a very firm structure on the palate, certainly due to the 28 months of French oak aging. Strong acidity slices through the red-fruit and allspice flavors. Drink 2019–2028.
Dark cranberry in color, this medium-bodied wine is abundant in dark cherry, wild strawberry and melon flavors. The midpalate is powerfully built with bright acidity offering crisp refreshment.

An intriguing an ultimately successful blend of 80% Albarino and 20% Chardonnay, this bottling starts with intriguing tangerine, freshly cut melon and light almond aromas on the nose. It's racy on the palate with both bright, lasting acid and a pithy texture, offering rounded nectarine flavors and a hint of lemon cream.
An inviting nose of wild strawberry and cherry open this delightfully focused and fresh wine. The acidity is refreshing and clear, supporting light-bodied layers of rhubarb and melon.

This opens with toast, oak and grilled herb hints. The aromas carry over to the subdued palate, along with roasted almond, grapefruit and butterscotch notes. Drink soon to enjoy the remaining fruit and freshness.
region_1: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Classico Superiore

description: This has subdued aromas of cooking spices and dark-skinned fruit. The straightforward palate offers black plum and clove alongside relaxed tannins. Drink soon.

Aromas of raspberry candy, fresh flower, dried orange peel, herb, smoked meat and tire rubber are followed by soft fruit flavors that coat the palate, then taper. Orange-peel notes linger on the finish.

Cranberry, pomegranate and black pepper aromas introduce a lush wine. Gentle tannins and well-balanced acidity add to the easy flavors of juicy red berries and vanilla speckled with peppery spice. The finish is all red fruit, with a whisper of vanilla and white pepper.

This is a tasty, focused young wine from vines just entering maturity. Pleasing highlights of chocolate mint carry from the nose to the finish, adding interest to tightly wound cranberry and raspberry fruit.

Aromas of violet, mint and a whiff of French oak lead the nose on this blend of 90% Sangiovese, 5% Canaiolo and 5% Ciliegiolo. The lively elegant palate offers raspberry preserve, star anise and cinnamon alongside fine-grained tannins. Drink through 2023.
Floral in aromatics—think lemongrass and jasmine—this estate-grown wine is creamy yet light in feel. The palate brings distinct flavors of crisp green apple, apricot, lime and wet stone.
designation: Don Miguel Vineyard Estate Grown & Bottled

description: This wine has a fruity entry of dark cherry and plum: flavors that are dusted in a lightness of cinnamon spice. Well put together, it's soft and round on the palate with a full-bodied ripeness that minds its manners and plays well with its more elegant intentions.

A spicy cedary minerally aroma leads to bright raspberry and cranberry flavors in this medium-bodied, complex and appetizing wine. It has good acidity and fine-grained tannins to help the grip, and pleasant light flavors that will be great at the table.

Sweet toast and concentrated fruit aromas introduce this forward and appealing wine. Suggestions of berries, tree fruits and light tropical highlights combine gracefully. It's ready for immediate enjoyment and will reward any extra attention you give it.
This wine is marked by a powerful extraction of tannin and sizable oak, the texture robustly grippy. Dust, crushed rock and sage define its imprint on the palate.

Juicy black cherry and blueberry wrap around big, expansive tannins in this hearty red that is sourced from several of the producer's best sites. With a backbone of structure and oak, it's toasty in character yet robustly fruity.

Fairly thick on the nose, this blend of Syrah and Petite Sirah shows black currant, fudge, caramel and licorice on the nose. It's also concentrated on the rich, ripe and heavy palate, but the hoisin sauce and black-currant-paste flavors are enlivened by fresh acidity and vanilla spice.

This is more than likely the first vineyard-designate of this variety that's been put in a can—the size of the can the equivalent of half a standard glass bottle. It works in the way a white or lighter style red would, laying low on the tannin and oak (there's actually zero oak, the wine fermented and aged in stainless steel) and preferring to effuse a fruity essence that refreshes.

Inky red violet in color, this wine has blackberry, juniper and vanilla aromas. It offers black cherry, strawberry, mocha, vanilla bean and black pepper flavors, its bold fruit and acidity overcoming the somewhat chewy tannins. It culminates in a smooth, milk chocolaty finish.

Black cherry and dried plum aromas and flavors give this deeply colored wine more lively, juicy fruit flavors than usual for the varietal. Aged for 17 months in previously used French barrels It has firm tannins, good acidity and medium to full body.

From a separate block near Durell Vineyard, this wine is completely overtaken by heady floral and mineral notions of beauty and intrigue. High toned and surprisingly delicate, it's buoyant and fresh in crisp green apple and fleshy citrus flavors, with medium-bodied weight and lovely texture.

From a ridge-top, western-facing site greatly influenced by the Pacific Ocean, this is exotic and distinct in character, with tones of white pepper, tart cherry, rhubarb and strawberry. Gorgeously layered, delicate and structured, it has length and richness to the tannin profile, as well as a notion of peat that adds to the dramatic complexity of the wine.

This is such a beautiful wine, incorporating blocks from the nearby Allen Vineyard, also farmed by the Rochiolis. Reduced nicely on the nose, it's lemony with a great core of juicy acidity around grainy, gravelly texture and minerality. With an exotic edge, it finishes elegantly in lemon peel and orange blossom.

This iconic wine's blackberry, cedar and vanilla aromas fill the glass. The elegant, structured palate delivers juicy black currant, black cherry, exotic spice, crushed herb and menthol flavors alongside taut, fine-grained tannins. It boasts a fantastic combination of delicious, ripe fruits, balanced by remarkable freshness and agility for the hot vintage. Drink 2022–2035.

This sources from blocks planted in 1991 and 1997, older selections that show grace and power in the wine. Exotic in lemongrass, ginger and Asian pear, the vineyard-designate doesn't hold back on supportive Meyer lemon-crisp acidity, enough to balance out the richer concentrated fruit aspects and classic oak. This is delicious.

A tightly textured white, this is earthy and spicy in Gravenstein apple, blood orange and hazelnut—the nuttiness taking on a toasted quality that adds warmth and flavor. Bright, refreshing and well-rounded, it has concentrated richness that finds its balance in juicy acidity.

Polished aromas of raspberry sorbet meet with sumac, cinnamon and a very strong pine-oil element on the nose of this bottling. Red-cherry fruit shows on the sip alongside woody flavors of juniper and forest floor.

Aromas of coconut, dark-skinned berry and exotic spice come together on this. The taut linear palate offers dried cherry, star anise, sage and a hint of espresso alongside brisk acidity and tight close-grained tannins that grip the close.

Berry scented candle and baking-spice aromas comprise an exotic nose. On the palate, this is as soft as a goose-feather mattress, with very little notable acidity or lift. Deeply ripe and baked black-fruit flavors taste of cassis and blueberry on a thick finish. Drink through 2020.
Thick and intensely ripe, this appellation red is hearty and substantial on the palate, a richly interwoven mix of dried herb, strawberry and cola.
Thick, concentrated and strongly built with tannins, this wine is made in a big full-bodied style. It has a generous helping of blue fruit that is lightly spiced in nutmeg and cola.

A tan-leaning color and a nose defined by toasty oak on top of pear and apple aromas make for a good opening. This Tupungato Chardonnay is plump, viscous and well balanced, with a mix of oaky spice and melony flavors. A steady finish confirms that this is of high quality.
A harsh nose smells more of gasoline than fruit. This is rubbery and astringent in feel. Yeasty flavors of papaya are tired, while this tastes of white bread on a finish without much snap.
Aromas of fruit cocktail, herb and plastic are followed by medium-sweet fruit flavors. The concentration seems quite light.
This blend of Touriga Nacional and Merlot produces a soft, caramel and red berry flavored wine. It is carried by a mild vein of acidity.
Extreme aromas of garlic and onions lead to crisp lemon and garlic flavors that push the envelope of acceptability, but may suit some people's taste buds.
A quiet nose of pear and yellow apple translates to the light-bodied palate. This is straightforward and simplistic in its appeal.
This is a straightforward, quaffable offering of this variety in a box wine format. There's little complexity but the price is right.

This highly acclaimed family owned and operated Margaret River producer is in possession of some of the region's top vineyard sites, all dry farmed with minimal chemical interventions. Each year, Woodlands names its top Cabernet after a family member or friend. At eight-years-old, Heather Jean (one of the founders) is old school Margaret River, showing intense of potpourri-like oak spice, still-plush cassis fruit, tomato leaf, dried flowers, milk chocolate and a savory leathery spine. It's a big Bordeaux-like wine with plenty of ripe fruit left and silky, tightly knit tannins. There's plenty of life left in Heather Jean yet. Drink now–2028.

This reserve bottling from five vineyards—principally in the Chehalem Mountains AVA—is layered and complex. It leads with tart berry and Bing cherry fruit, building toward lighter notes of Dr. Pepper, mushroom soup and miso as it opens. Then, it charges back into lush berry flavors through the palate-rousing finish.

Plentiful blueberry, plum, orange peel, potpourri, spice and herb aromas are followed by plump, fresh, palate-coating blue and purple fruit flavors in this wine. It's a textbook example of the variety and how delicious the state's renditions can be.

This intense wine has rooty, tarry aromas, dried berry notes and a tinge of raisin. Its spiced berry and plum flavors are dry and persistent. A long, tea-inflected finish suggests it's nowhere close to done. Drink through 2032.

Though not labeled as such, this was made entirely from Crannell vineyard fruit and fermented in stainless steel. It's a lively mix of pear, apricot, starfruit and lemon curd notes, with crisp and juicy minerality. In short, it's lip-smackingly delicious, with impeccable freshness.

Green and red apple join bright lemon zest on the nose. A touch of bruised apple shows on the concentrated palate alongside wonderfully brisk lemon, creating a vivid mouthful of refreshment. The finish is dry, lasting and superclean.

This is an original, authentic-tasting wine (made from 65-year-old vines) that doesn't follow a commercial profile. Instead it offers subtle fruity, savory and spicy aromas, and an abundance of ripe and dried fruits ranging from blackberries to figs and dates. It feels wonderfully mouth-filling but has enough fine-grained tannins for good structure.
Aromas of ripe dark berry, underbrush and cocoa lift out of the glass. The smooth, polished palate delivers dried black cherry, mocha and tobacco alongside polished tannins.

Slightly foxy, jumpy aromas include notes of mint gumdrop, plum, currant and wild berries. This Cabernet Sauvignon (with 10% Petit Verdot and Syrah) is intense on the palate, with hard tannins and drawing concentration. A strong set of flavors includes baked berry fruit and spice notes, while this is raw, rubbing and fully loaded on the finish. Drink through 2027.

Heady aromas of wild berry, spring flower and stone fruit lead the way along with a whiff of bread crust. Linear and bright, the elegant palate delivers Rennet apple, creamy nectarine and hazelnut alongside a silky, polished mousse. It has a bone-dry finish.
This is a complex wine, rich in both tannins and dense fruit. It is concentrated, with juicy berry flavors and balanced acidity to go with the solid structure. Drink from 2022.
This inviting sparkler offers apple, exotic fruit and baked bread aromas. On the round, creamy palate, an elegant mousse underscores white peach, baked pear, lemon drop and a dollop of vanilla.

The nose offers aromas of Marasca cherry, candied orange and sharp angostura bitters over subtler tones of sawdust and aged oak. Fairly tart upfront in flavors of plum and red cherry, the palate is bolstered by sandy tannins and tangy acidity.
A full bodied and ripe wine, this is rich and concentrated. The tropical fruits and spice give it a full character that does not leave enough opportunity for balanced acidity. Drink now.
High-toned apple and cherry aromas are followed by a scratchy feeling palate marked by gritty tannins. The tannins don't seem to have fully ripened, and the variety is hard to find.

Aromas of peppercorns, earthy licorice, pumpernickel and black currant are intriguing on the nose of this blend of 45% Syrah, 35% Mourvèdre and 22% Grenache. Ripe fruit flavors are propped up by juicy acidity over sandy tannins. This remains juicy towards the finish, with a touch of peppery spice.

Briny, pickled aromas are challenging. On the palate, this is initially foamy and then dull. Apple, green herb and vanilla flavors carry over to the finish. As a whole, this brut is just good enough but has faults.
Briny citrus aromas pass muster while dealing a note of compost. A fair palate rates as basic. Dry, spicy lime and apple flavors are slightly bitter on a finish that's fresh and forward.

An intriguing an ultimately successful blend of 80% Albarino and 20% Chardonnay, this bottling starts with intriguing tangerine, freshly cut melon and light almond aromas on the nose. It's racy on the palate with both bright, lasting acid and a pithy texture, offering rounded nectarine flavors and a hint of lemon cream.
An inviting nose of wild strawberry and cherry open this delightfully focused and fresh wine. The acidity is refreshing and clear, supporting light-bodied layers of rhubarb and melon.

This is a delicious, aromatic wine with good fruit and touches of oak aging. Spicy, crisp and fresh from the Códega de Larinho grapes, it is still young. This rich, ageworthy wine will be ready from 2020.

The top wine from this estate, this is a blend of Syrah and Braucol. Wood aging still shows strongly in the smoky spicy character although the black fruits are equal to the wood flavors. Tannins accompany the concentrated berry and currant flavors. This wine needs more time to integrate the wood. Drink from 2020.

This is smoky and aromatic, showing whiffs of tobacco and the dark highlights that typify the winery's four Merlots. The palate brings roasted cherry fruit, and finishing streaks of coffee, licorice and dark chocolate.

This toasty buttery wine is sourced from a Golden Mile Bench vineyard planted more than four decades ago. Aged for 18 months in half new French oak, it's lightly herbal and quite fresh, with notes of apple, pear and peach set against naturally uplifting acidity.

Savory in aromas of black licorice, sage and rose, this is a tremendously impressive, deliciously crafted wine that is delicately layered in cranberry and rhubarb flavors. The complex texture is grainy yet polished, with a succulence that makes it irresistible from start to finish.

From a block growing at high elevation on the extremes of the coast north of Fort Ross, this wine is bright up-front with youthful tannins, its center juicy and densely packed in mocha, coffee and cocoa powder. Soft and structured, the dark cherry and blueberry fruit is dusted in dried herb and lavender.

This wine is extremely deep, complex and concentrated in flavor while maintaining wonderful finesse in texture. It starts with fragrant aromas of freshly baked bread and cinnamon. Those are followed by a creamy mouthfeel, pinpoint bubbles and subtle peach, white cherry and apricot flavors that are both delicate and focused at the same time, leading to a long finish. It is so tempting now but best after 2020.

From Bien Nacido Vineyard's Z and X blocks, with 3% Viognier, this is a lovely and rich Syrah with lavish aromas of black currant, caramel, teriyaki and German chocolate cake. The palate is similarly thick and chewy, but with elegance and balance, showing black cherry, blueberry, white pepper and crushed rocks, leveled by a steadily rising acidity.

From a site awash in Goldridge soils, the vines still on AXR rootstock, this white offers a wealth of high-toned aromatics, a rich robust nose that's unexpectedly bright, focused and fresh. The body takes on more richness and density, with highlights of caramel, brioche, fennel and salty pear.

Reduced on the nose in welcoming, complex ways, this white is intensely spiced and earthy, evolving into a light balanced take on caramel apple, pear and shavings of lemon zest. From a cool windy site in the Sebastopol Hills section of the larger appellation, the lemon takes on a candied note that boosts the acidity to fresh high-toned heights.
Plum jelly, sarsaparilla and cola aromas show on the inviting nose of this bottling. There is great freshness and liveliness to the palate, where white pepper spices up the grenadine flavors.
Dusty concentration and big oak offer a lasting impression of power and body in this wine, followed by a depth of rich red cherry and cassis, a sprinkling of dried herb lingering on the finish.

This is a highly perfumed wine with ripe tannins and layers of spice as well as a herbal edge. Released as a regional wine, the Syrah does well in the Douro, giving bold wines with plenty of black fruits, acidity and a generous layer of tannins. Drink from 2020.

While this estate does concentrate on wines, it also makes some fine Ports. This balanced aged tawny combines the fruitiness of this style with hints of spice from wood aging. The wine is ready to drink.

Light in color and made to be acid-driven and fresh, this wine succeeds with a slightly carbonic expression of stemmy earthiness and intrigue. Strawberry-jam aromas are followed by a layering of citrus that persists through an understated finish.

Lightly ripe, this boasts clean varietal fruit amidst lushly toasty barrel flavors. Aged one year on the lees in half new and half neutral barrels, it's fresh and tasty, with sea salt caramel notes that enliven the finish.
This straightforward approachable wine offers a friendly sense of richness, rounded in lush apple, mango and integrated oak. The finish is bright and fresh.
This has subdued dark-skinned fruit and culinary spice aromas. The straightforward palate shows black cherry, clove and green peppercorn touches. Drink through 2020.

Sparkling Provence rosé is the logical next step in the success story from the south of France. This one is soft and off dry, making it a great apéritif. It's bubbly, crisply textured and ready to drink.
designation: Coeur Clémentine La Pétillante Brut Rosé

description: Full bodied and nearly sweet, this very ripe and fruity wine smells like waffles and maple syrup and tastes like strawberries and blackberries. Should be good to pair with salty and spicy dishes.
The simpler of the two cuvées from this estate, this is full of raspberry, red-currant and citrus flavors. Softly textured although having plenty of acidity, the wine is ready to drink.

The nose on this twist-top bottling is a bit reductive at first, with a touch of petrol, citrus pith and Anjou pear rinds. That petrol quality extends to the sip as well, where is fits in with more pear skins and some beeswax.

This a big and proudly oaky wine that's aromatic, full flavored and concentrated. It shows scents of cedar, clove and cinnamon, with blackberry and maple syrup on the palate. The texture is velvety and smooth.
Peppery, meaty and herbal, this wine is well rounded and concentrated in structure, with a lasting note of sandalwood and cedar.

White-grapefruit acidity and hits of lemon pith and blossom add lift to this generous, slightly waxy white wine. Dry and full bodied in style, it's a rich, silky sip finishing on lingering notes of spice and vanilla. Lovely now, it should hold well through 2022.
Yeasty scents accent this wine's lovely, bright lemon-like tanginess. The lovely lemon streak also comes through on the easy, light but beautifully textured palate. The finish is juicy and dry.
This vivid, seductive wine has a bright pink color, exotic floral and plummy aromas and opulent fruit flavors that are concentrated and layered. It's light bodied, well balanced and delicious.

Blended with 13% Aglianico, this wine hails from Serra Pedace, Seven Hills, Loess and Mill Creek Upland vineyards. Its light sour cherry, anise, cigar box and spice aromas lead to tart fruit flavors with lightly grainy tannins and a long finish. All about subtlety, it needs food alongside it to fully deliver.

Sawdust, oak-driven spice, dark-fruit and tobacco aromas slowly emerge from the glass. The dense palate offers espresso, licorice and cherry steeped in spirits alongside tightly packed tannins. Drink 2021–2026.
Subtle aromas of baking spice, dark berry and tilled earth lead the nose. The forward palate offers raspberry jam, licorice and green peppercorn alongside chewy tannins. Drink 2019–2025.
Aromas of white stone fruit, citrus and pistachio take center stage on this fresh white. The fruity aromas carry over to the savory, light-bodied palate along with yellow peach.
Subtle aromas of leather, dark berry and underbrush lead the nose. The juicy palate offers black cherry, star anise and clove alongside firm tannins that grip the finish. Drink after 2022.
This is a star effort given the volume and price point. A toasty frame sets up tart fruit flavors of raspberry hard candy. It's got more grip and focus than most of the inexpensive Oregon Pinots.

Aromas suggesting oak, vanilla, baked plum and a whiff of burned rubber all take shape in the glass. On the assertive palate, grainy tannins offset fleshy black cherry, cake spice, espresso and vanilla before an astringent, drying finish. Give the tannins several more years to unclench. Drink after 2024.

Ripe, yellow apple and chamomile tisane are heady on the nose. The palate is rich and concentrated, brimming with ripeness. Some dried fruit notes are starting to appear but lemon zest highlights the dry, long finish.

Roasted blackberry and black-plum aromas meet with milk chocolate and baking spice on the nose of this bottling, which sees 21% new oak. The flavors are broad and rich with violets, black currants and blueberries, framed by strong tannins and a persistent deep acidity.

Made from estate-grown Pinot Noir, Chardonnay and Pinot Gris, this wine is focused in acidity, with dry, fresh components of lemon and green apple. Complex in mineral overtones, it offers a taste of oyster shell and wet stone.

Lifted lemon headiness on the nose continues onto the palate where flavors of lemon zest and juice are concentrated, pure and fresh. Underneath are more aromatic hints of bergamot and peach. This is brisk, dry and full of fruit, with a lip-smacking finish.

This pale copper-hued rosé gets Joe Wagner's new Oregon project off to a great start. It's packed with delicious ripe fruit, recalling citrus, pear and peach. Despite the low alcohol, it has exceptional concentration and depth of flavor, with a sprinkling of pepper at the tail end.

Ripe, juicy notes of pear have zesty lime freshness on the nose. The same interplay between juicy ripeness and zesty tang happens on the slender palate that is shot through with lemon brightness. This wine has impact, tons of freshness and a dry finish.
Cheesy aromas dominate the nose on this flat rubbery-feeling Garnacha. Gritty berry-fruit flavors are a bit weedy, while this is lifeless on the finish.
The aromas bring a slightly tinny note that distracts. The palate seems to fall flat, without the concentration or structure to hold it together.

Underripe aromas of a burning field mixed with stale sweat socks are not the stuff of legend. A thick soupy palate deals dense berry flavors that are tainted with rot. Call it herbal or call it murky, but overall this isn't cutting it.

Floral aromas suggest lilies more than fruit. On the tongue, this is a foamy mass with no focus. Muddled citrus flavors come with a candied sweetness, while this brut sparkler with a weird Italian name offers only oxidized notes on the finish.
This dry lean wine is medium bodied and has a sunbaked mature character. The fruit aromas and flavors are minimal, conceding to dusty dry-earth notes.
Quiet aromas of dark chocolate and mint mix with a bit of char on the nose. The palate is carried by a sweet oak tone reminiscent of Bourbon.

This perfumed wine has spice and a core of firm tannins that are surrounded by ripe black-cherry and plum flavors. Its structure is still young with dryness at the moment. But the weight of the fruit will ensure that the wine will open with warmth and richness. Drink from 2020.

Woody earth meets carbonic strawberry in this lightly spiced, delicately crafted, estate-grown wine. With elusive notions of pomegranate and cherry, it is light and balanced, finishing gracefully soft and supple.

This is a crisp wine, fresh and with a texture that includes both minerality and light tannins. The wine is still young and very fruity, delicious now but better with some aging so the crispness can tone down a little. Drink from 2019.

Concentrated in tannic layers of vanilla, cassis and sage, this wine offers a sauvage quality of mountain air and power. Its full-bodied ripeness and richness is complemented by a lifted hit of bright acidity that lingers on the finish.

A blend of 55% Grenache, 23% Mourvèdre, 11% Syrah and 11% Cinsault, the aromas explode, with notes of fresh raspberry, blue plum, black pepper, fresh herb and huckleberry, showing a sense of freshness. The palate is light and elegant yet textured and flavorful.
Delicately scented, this has enticing aromas of ripe pear, white wildflower and a whiff of Alpine herb. On the juicy palate, fresh acidity supports mature golden apple, peach and a flinty note.

Relatively quiet on the nose, this wine offers notes of red current and strawberry, backed by a savory spine. The palate is on the hot side and lacking some of the elegance, with woody drying tannins that are on the clunky side. The fruit feels a little sour on the finish, too.

Raspberry and strawberry aromas include a note of tomato sauce. This feels fairly spineless, but not outright flat. Herb-infused flavors of berry fruit and bell pepper finish steady but are devoid of complexity.
Soft, fruity and open, this wine has attractive red-berry flavors and light tannins. It should develop quickly. Drink from 2020.
This wine has soft tannins and juicy acidity. It is light and fruity, with an open character that means it will be ready to drink from 2019.
A ripe, juicy wine with attractive berry flavors and acidity, this is likely to develop relatively quickly. Drink from 2021.
This fruity wine has good acidity and a light structure. Easy and fresh, it offers light, well-integrated tannins. The wine should be ready from 2021.

Light in color, there is lots of juicy pomegranate fruit on the nose of this bottling from the centrally located estate, alongside red-licorice and cinnamon scents. It's crisp, lively and fresh on the palate, with bright red-fruit and rose-petal flavors.

Smashed blackberry, purple flowers and loamy earth aromas show on the nose of this bottling. Sticky tannins frame the palate, though it's a fairly fresh take on the grape, with boysenberry and fresh purple flowers meeting with leather and smoked meat flavors.

Fresh spring grass, lemongrass, grapefruit, pear blossom and a hint of flint show on the nose of this bottling. The palate is framed by a compelling texture that's both fleshy with stone fruit and racy with sharper lime rinds, providing great depth.

Those seeking a fresh, detailed Chardonnay from Paso Robles will be pleased with this bottling. Light, easy aromas of lemon balm, white peach and clarified butter into a palate full of lemon zest, creamy cherimoya and brioche flavors.

Aromas of black plums and purple flowers meet with savory roasted meat and crushed gravel on the nose of this bottling. Firm tannins frame the palate, holding up flavors of blackberry, black olive and dried herb, with a flash of vanilla on the finish. It's built to last, so drink 2020–2030.

Always one of this winery's best bang-for-buck bottlings, this blend of 36% Cinsaut, 30% Counoise, 21% Mourvèdre and 13% Grenache is extremely fresh, starting with aromas of strawberry, star anise, hickory and white pepper. The palate is juicy, spicy with pepper and zesty with acid, so chill it down slightly and drink up.
Crisp and perfumed as well as herbaceous, this is a fruity wine with lively acidity and a clean, bright aftertaste. Grapefruit and lemon flavors dominate this ready-to-drink wine.
This blends in 7% Cabernet Sauvignon. The wine is pungent and earthy in forest and tobacco, with smooth thick full-bodied waves of green tannin and light accents of clove spice.
This is a concentrated wine rich in red fruit that remains light in the glass. Herbal, earthy undertones of oystershell and dill mix with cedar and currant.
Vanilla, baking spice, sliced green-pepper and dried cherry aromas are followed by ripe sweet cherry and herb flavors. It finishes with a tart plum and vanilla-filled finish. Bitter notes linger.

This could be a poster child for Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc, offering all the hallmarks of the style: white grapefruit, pineapple, passionfruit and peach skins with, of course, a lick of grassiness. Its racy acidity and slightly chalky texture make for an easygoing summer sipper.

Made from organically grown Sangiovese, Canaiolo, Colorino and Malvasia Nera, this opens with earthy aromas of scorched earth, leather and black-skinned berries. The straightforward palate doles out licorice, clove and black cherry jam flavors alongside round tannins. Drink through 2021.

A clonal exception to the majority of this producer's white wines, the grapes for this wine are grown at 1,800-feet elevation from Mt. Eden and old Wente clones, technically within the new Moon Mountain appellation. It starts rich and robust in juicy salty concentration before allowing in a streak of bright floral acidity that gives it freshness and life. White flower and salty stone persist on the palate.

Compost earthiness underlies a juicy, expansive and richly layered palate of fruit and spice that lingers expertly on the finish. Polished tannins support crisp strawberry and red cherry flavors that are adorned with cardamom and orange zest.

This is a wine of great concentration and density that's also savory and earthy. Hearty, heady violet-floral aromatics make for a grand entry into explosively succulent wild strawberry flavor and supple texture. The tannins are robust and rounded and there's a delicate layering of white and black pepper that dominates on the finish. Enjoy best 2020–2030.

This is comprised of fruit from two coastal sites, but it does not hold back on flavor or complexity. A juicy entry of spicy red and blue fruit is surrounded by moderate structure and an imprint of rose petal. Lasting in intensity and acidity, it's dotted in citrus and polished tannins.

This is a Martinelli family-farmed site, a mark of excellence and history that's hard to beat. Floral and textured, it is marked by bright focused acidity around a core of textured baked-apple flavor and hazelnut crème brûlée. It tastes complete and complex, with undeniable richness and concentration.

This is a standout wine, earthy in juicy red fruit, spicy clove and citrus peel. It is well integrated and robustly built, with a backbone of acidity that provides lasting structure and a finishing touch of elegance.

Pronounced aromas of smoke and crushed earth dissipate with aeration revealing crisp yellow peach and tangerine. While dry in style, this offers plush sunny stone-fruit flavors balanced by brisk acidity and a tart bite of green apple on the finish.

Zesty notes of kiwi and green apple lend a green-fruited vibrance to this mouthwatering dry Silvaner. It's juicy and forward in style but anchored by streaks of lime acidity and fresh herbs. Hints of lightly toasted nuts linger on the finish.

This is a lovely expression of the grape, from climes significantly cooler than that of Barossa. A good lick of savory, earthy funk, wet leaves, olives and grilled plums carry the nose and palate. This is soft and velvety, with gentle tannins and a long, savory finish.

This spicy, round, fruit-powered wine offers a pleasing mix of berry and cherry flavors. The fruit is annotated with citrus rind highlights and has a firm, substantial finish with well-built tannins and a touch of toast.
This is a smooth, round and likable wine, richly interwoven in baked cherry, cassis and cinnamon bark that's somewhat smoky in a good way on the lengthy finish.

Three quarters Pinot Noir and one quarter Chardonnay, this young sparkler is tart and tangy with lemon, pink grapefruit, green apple and orange flavors. There's a dash of baking spice and a slightly earthy note in the aroma, but overall it's enjoyable.

Miso notes mingle with ripe Conference pear scents on the nose of this wine. The palate adds a yeasty texture and lively lemon flavors, making it a very expressive, dry and totally refreshing Grüner Veltliner.

Zesty and light footed, this dry varietal Marsanne offers a fresher expression of this typically lavishly textural grape. There's a delicacy to the palate marked by slightly creamy tones of fresh yellow apple, Asian pear and peach. The finish is rimmed by a pleasantly salty tone. Enjoy now–2022.
Dark gold in color, this wine offers uplifting acidity and matchstick—strong elements that balance well against powerful layers of green apple, melon and pear. The ripeness is in check.

This wine, like so many in the Loire, was aged in the chalk caves around the town of Saumur. An elegant blend of Chardonnay and Pinot Noir, it conveys a cool feel along with bright acidity and a creamy, apple aftertaste. Drink now.

Gentle hints of tart cherry break though on the subdued nose of this wine. The palate is slender, with a finely woven grip and wonderfully bright freshness. It's understated yet satisfying, with a dry, refreshing and subtle finish.

Subtle notes of nuts, spice and crushed earth lend complexity to buoyantly juicy black-plum and mulberry flavors. It's a plush, richly concentrated wine offset by crisp acidity and ripe, mouthfilling tannins. Enjoy now–2026.

This blend of 58% Syrah, 26% Mourvèdre and 16% Grenache hails from Boushey and Heart of the Hill vineyards. Subdued out of the gate, it offers raspberry, white pepper, herb, cherry pit and marionberry aromas as it opens. The flavors are graceful, pretty and balanced.

The nose only gives hints of lemon freshness. The palate adds ripe pear notes, boosted by a dollop of residual sweetness, to the lemon freshness. This results in a rounded, perfectly balanced medium-sweet wine that has both poise and texture.

The standard nonvintage from this producer benefits from its policy of blending in a high percentage of older reserve wines. That gives the wine its richness and smooth, ripe character. Hints of apples are still there along with a good balance between acidity and toastiness. Drink now.

Rich black fruit flavors anchor this excellent wine, which accents its brambly character with complex hints of olive, bark and citrus. It's solid, substantial and a fine value, finishing with a touch of alcoholic heat.

Leather, tobacco and smoky char define the opening of this full-bodied, rich wine, blended with 15% Merlot, 3% Petit Verdot, 3% Malbec and 2% Cabernet Franc. Woody and structured, its fruit leans dark and plummy, ending on a touch of dark chocolate.
Savory aromas of dried apricot, tangerine zest, date and jasmine carry over to the creamy palate alongside fresh acidity. Notes of pistachio and vanilla linger on the persistent finish.

This wine offers melon, lemon and fig tones that are bright and ripe without being jammy. A toasted coconut-oak note serves to support rather than overpower, and the lees work adds just enough texture and complexity to compliment a tight, grainy texture. Drink now–2025.
Here is a fruity mix of light red berries, accented with lemon and pineapple acidity. Forward and fresh, it carries a light thread of graphite into the finish.

There are many layers of ripe fruit in this relatively soft wine. It has sweetness, berry fruits and integrated tannins. Already attractive, the wine is obviously going to develop quickly. Drink from 2026.
Red berry, cooking spice and leather aromas emerge from the glass. The solid palate offers crushed raspberry, blood orange and clove alongside austere, youthful tannins. Drink after 2022.
Aromas of cedar, dark berry and eucalyptus shape the nose. The solid full-bodied palate offers dried black cherry, clove and white pepper alongside firm tannins. Drink 2020–2028.

Delicate aromas of acacia, white stone fruit and hazelnut lift out of the glass. On the lean but elegant palate, you'll find dried yellow apple slice, citrus, honeyed nut and a mineral note alongside fresh acidity. Drink soon to capture the remaining fruit.

Herbal, smoky berry aromas taken as a whole smell much like a burning field. On the palate, this is clamping and short. Tart plum and red-currant flavors are also salty, while this is pinned closed on an acidic finish.
Stony citrus aromas are as good as it gets. A highly citric, foamy palate lacks refinement and charm, while this tastes of underripe pineapple and lime.
Light cherry and raspberry aromas are earthy and don't amount to much. Scattershot plum and berry flavors lack focus, while this is strangely chemical on the finish.

Cooked aromas of raisin open this flabby Garnacha. Stewed berry flavors along with clove and nutmeg notes don't amount to anything serious, while this tastes like spongy spice cake and exhibits almost no tannic grip on the finish.

There's a cheesy underlay to the nose of this wine, with more pleasant and pronounced scents of toasted apple and bruised citrus upfront. The medium-weight palate is round and soft, with low acidity and a short finish.

A rusty color and odd aromas of clove and cardamom are unconvincing. A wide palate lacks focus and punch, while this tastes of Middle Eastern spices but not much, if any, fruit. A soapy-tasting finish with bitterness is of no help.
This firmly structured wine has fine tannins and layers of wood. The fruit is forward, juicy with blackberry flavors and acidity. Drink this wine from 2020.
This wine is dry, firm and seems to have too much extraction. The fruit glimmesr in the background and needs plenty of time to develop, so wait until 2021.

Briny citrus aromas are common for a basic brut rosé. A fairly healthy palate holds its own, while this tastes vaguely of orange and cantaloupe before turning more bitter and medicinal on the finish. This is a blend of Trepat, Monastrell and Garnacha.
This rich wine from the Phillipe family's organic vineyard is full of yellow fruits cut by lime acidity. It has weight and ripe fruitiness, and is ready to drink.

Berry, leather, animal and herbal aromas make for a fair nose. This feels lean, with minimal structure. Savory, slightly green berry flavors are minty and herbal on the finish, all of which is normal for standard Carmenère.

Spicy berry aromas are oaky and deliver an odd citrusy scent. A chunky palate offers just enough structure and balance to be taken seriously. Plum and berry flavors are a touch green and grassy, while this holds on to its minty green essence on the finish.

Iris, rose, forest floor and menthol aromas come to the forefront on this fragrant red. On the taut linear palate, bright acidity and refined tannins balance juicy sour cherry, red raspberry and star anise. Drink through 2024.

Lively notes of tart green and red apples fill the nose. The palate continues with this lively, green and spice-tinged freshness. There is something of green pepper here and the zesty tang of fresh green citrus. The lively mousse makes this even fresher. The finish is dry, zesty and long.

A defined nose of sauced blackberry and red cherry melds with a mix of charred tobacco leaf and walnut. This is a bruiser on the palate, boasting an abundance of firm tannins yet plenty of acidity for balance. It's deep and penetrating in feel, ending on a dusting of powdered, dried herbs and tar. Drink from 2022.

Soft red-cherry aromas meet with dark spice on the nose of this 52% Cabernet Franc and 48% Merlot blend. Framed by firm, sticky tannins, the medium-bodied palate shows flavors of red currant, cedar and oak.

The aromas are generous, with notes of dried pineapple, mango and apricot. The stone-fruit and tropical-fruit flavors are rich, sweet and focused, showing a lovely sense of balance that carries through the finish. Bright acidity provides the frame.

A vivid ripe-apple note melds with spiced cookie and tangy grapefruit peel tones on the nose. The palate shows great harmony between these rich but brisk, ripe but fresh, generous but slender elements. The result is a very creamy, rounded but apple-driven fizz for all occasions.

From old vines, some more than 80 years in age, this wine is aromatic and intense, with generous yellow fruits. The fresher side of the wine comes from the tangy texture and good acidity. A dense wine, it has a ripe feel that is letting it age. Drink from 2020.

This wine is packed with tannins and, with a slight farmyard character, it will need time to come together. But the potential is there, with smoky flavors vying with complex tannins and acidity. Drink this richly textured wine from 2023.

This vintage is richly endowed with black fruits and ripe tannins. It has weight, layers of wood aging, acidity that plays with the smoky berry flavors and rounded aftertaste. The estate dates back to the 14th century, although vines were not planted until the 19th. Drink the wine from 2021.
Firm, dry and with solid tannins, this wine still has space for attractive black fruits. The two elements will soften to give a wine with structure and impressive richness. Drink from 2022.

This intensely forward, fruity Gigondas offers loads of silky black cherry and plum flavors marked by spicy twists of anise and tart cassis. Its fresh, primary style is accentuated by approachably smooth tannins. Easy drinking already but should meld nicely through 2026.

Perfumed notes of violet and lavender lend a breathless quality to juicy blackberry and plum flavors in this Grenache-Syrah blend. It's a potent, full-bodied wine but finessed on its feet. Silky tannins and a luscious mouthfeel linger nicely. Enjoy now–2026.

Released each year around Valentine's Day, this carbonic experiment was an immediate hit. Served with a chill and very light in the glass, it shows primary aromas of strawberry, cola and rosewater. The playful palate is zippy with acid and dances across the tongue with flavors of tart red fruit. A great sunny day wine, but buy multiple bottles because they go fast.

Bountiful dark red-fruit aromas meet with cocoa and herbs on the nose of this bottling, which leans toward slightly stewed fruit. The palate is framed by chalky tannins and lively acidity, carrying lavish fruit flavors and making for a very tasty if straightforward sip.

Deep and fresh black currant aromas meet with dried fennel on the nose of this bottling by a winery based in Los Angeles. A penetrating acidity kicks off the sip, where solid tannins carry dark fruit and rosemary flower flavors.
This wine is lovely and expressive in stony mineral, lemon rind, apple, quince and bread. It's medium-bodied, with a pleasant lushness that unfolds on the midpalate.

Smoke, yellow stone fruit and a whiff of Spanish broom lead the nose. Bright and savory, the enveloping juicy palate delivers yellow apple, lemon and toasted hazelnut alongside fresh acidity and a flinty note.

Black-plum sauce, star anise, concentrated rose and strawberry-jam aromas make for a luxurious and inviting, if a bit powerful, nose on this bottling. Strawberry paste, white pepper and a gravelly minerality show on the sip.

From one of the older blocks of the famous vineyard, once looked after by this winemaker, this wine is beautifully golden in color with a reduced, salty nose of caramelized pretzel. Robustly built, it shows fleshy, lush layers of honey and tropical richness.

Just a dash of Petit Verdot is added to this wine, with the Cabernet Sauvigon coming from the Martin Stelling Vineyard that stands regally behind the winery. This starts off with soft aromas of cassis and red cherry, which appear on the palate that's built by sizable tannins and texture. The richness is defined in dark chocolate, with just enough acidity to keep the mouthfeel succulent and lush.

Made entirely from Chardonnay from multiple vintages, this gorgeous, chiseled, zero-dosage sparkler offers citrus zest, pineapple, pastry dough and Alpine herb aromas. The vibrant, pristine palate boasts pure fruit and mineral sensations, doling out crisp yellow apple, juicy nectarine, vanilla and flint notes. Bright acidity and an elegant perlage give it remarkable freshness and finesse.

This wine is gorgeously floral, with a pretty nose, inviting in its formidable blend of savory spicy tartness and intrigue. The fruit leans into elegant flavors of strawberry and orange peel—a backdrop of rose petal and lavender in the background. A grainy, textured finish sears into the brain's memory with a pleasing length and breadth.

Warm baking spices ride along a contour of juicy spiced plum, cherry and strawberry in this medium-bodied youthful wine. Expansive on the palate, it offers underlying structure and a boldness of polished tannin and integrated oak. Still, it will do well in the cellar: enjoy best 2025–2030.

This wine opens in muted aromatics that slowly blossom into a shaker of oystershell and saline, a salty and bold character of slate and stone that gives it texture and complexity. Green apple, quince and white flower mingle on the expansive ethereal palate within a medium-bodied balanced context of concentration.
This wine's dark berry and tilled soil aromas emerge from the glass. The easygoing palate delivers black plum, tobacco and white pepper flavors alongside pliant tannins. Drink soon.

A lighter expression of Syrah on both the nose and palate, this bottling starts with aromas of coffee, black currant and a bit of vanilla dust. The palate is fresh and easy but also somewhat simple, without much mouthfeel, structure or bold flavors.
Bright and crisp, this attractive wine is spiced with a touch of pepper and plenty of red-berry fruits. It has a good balance, everything in its place. It is ready to drink.

Dark and golden in color, this 100% stainless-steel fermented white is steely on the midpalate, with an integrated, rich thread of vanilla that gives it a tropical tease of sweetness, though the wine finishes dry and defiantly light.
This leads with Spanish broom, acacia honey and dried yellow stone fruit aromas. The honeyed note carries over to the palate, together with mature apricot, pineapple and citrus hints.

This wine is mostly Roussanne (70%), with the balance equal parts Marsanne and Grenache Blanc, with the fruit coming from Olsen and Boushey vineyards. Lemon verbena, grape-nut, peach and apple aromas lead to broad stone-fruit flavors.
A 100% varietal wine, this is impressive in spicy clove, powerful plum and supple lengthy layers of flavor surround in polished tannin. It finishes with a silky smoothness that's not easy to forget.

Hazelnut, honey, Spanish broom and yellow apple aromas carry on to the elegant, structured palate along with a hint of pear and lemon zest. Fresh acidity brightens the rich flavors while bitter almond and a hint of saline linger on the close.

Mature apricot, toasted hazelnut, crushed stone and acacia aromas delicately lift out of the glass. The full-bodied enveloping palate delivers ripe yellow apple, pear and lemon zest while a notes of bitter almond and beeswax underscore the finish. Thanks to the fruit richness, you can barely detect the elevated alcohol content. Drink through 2021.

The faint but fresh ripe lemon notes on the nose of this wine segue into even more lemony brightness on the slender, taut and brisk palate. This is all about freshness, drive and verve. The lip-smacking, dry finish carries wonderful zestiness.

Reduction still clouds the aromas in this slender wine, but the palate reveals aromatic hints of citrus foliage and ripe tangerine peel. The body is juicy and bright—full of mandarin and tangerine notes. The finish is clean, zesty and dry.

Honey, brioche and layers of pineapple and mango give this youthful estate wine a richness that's hard to resist. It's supported by integrated oak that's toasty and sprinkled in a nutmeg tone. Steely acidity provides a backbone of freshness.

A vast improvement from the previous vintage, this standout wine is a sophisticated expression of a grape that's staking a valid claim to being Southern Oregon's signature red. Black fruit, tanned leather and strong tobacco and clove suggestions combine. The flavors are wrapped in a supple, polished package and show exceptional balance and length.
2Hawk does exceptionally well with its Viogniers. This one is bright and spicy, its flavors jumping agilely from citrus to apple to pineapple to mango. This is well balanced and lingering.

This rosé bridges the gap between sunshine-driven fruits and the more mineral character of a classic pink wine, starting with a nose that blends ripe melon, strawberry and bubblegum aromas with wet river stones. The palate is crisp, bright and very stony, yet there is a peach element as well. Sure to please many palates.

Bright, dusty leather and raspberry cola highlight this lovely vineyard-designate, which shows cool-climate aromatics and retention of acidity. In balance, it's both fruity and weighty, with varietal highlights of pepper and garrigue.

This Aube-based producer's latest vintage release is rich and creamy. It is young, although it is possible to find the texture and density that will allow it to age. It is in a crisp style, tight with acidity, finishing taut and mineral. Drink from 2019.

Light aromas of carnation and snappy black raspberry meet with the elegant touch of bay leaf on the nose of this cool-climate Merlot. Its grapes grow on a southwest-facing orientation, which is the only reason they get ripe at all. The palate's red-currant and cherry tones are overcome by herbal touches of bay, juniper and mint, wrapped in zesty acidity.

Earthy plum and cherry aromas offer a touch of wet clay to keep things grounded. This Reserva is medium in body, with good acidity and balance. Earthy berry flavors shows hints of oak and raisin, while plum and prune notes carry over to a finish with dry edgy tannins. Drink this proper Rioja through 2023.

Aromatically speaking, this is gritty and rough. In the mouth, this Reserva from a shaky vintage is soupy but not out of shape. Sappy plum, prune and tomato flavors are classic for Rioja but finish without much punch, so best to drink this soon.
This ripe, medium-sweet wine is crisp as well as full of honey accents. Almonds, spice and delicious baked-apple flavors are well integrated into this stylish wine. Drink now or, better, from 2020.
designation: Cuvée V Vieilles Vignes Grande Réserve

description: This small appellation west of Sancerre produces a style of wine that is softer and cooler than its big-name neighbor. That makes for a wine, like this, that is charming and smooth when young, with its attractive citrus character rounded out. Drink now.

A textured wine, properly mineral and with a taut structure, this is crisp while also having a riper background. The dosage is sufficient to give it a soft edge to contrast with the more mineral texture. Drink this wine now.
designation: Charles VII Blanc de Blancs Brut

description: This sophisticated, crisp wine has a dry character that brings out fresh red fruits. Tangy with a mineral edge and tight acidity, it is ready to drink.
The nose of this rosé is superlight in character, with just-there hints of melon rind and grass. The lightweight palate continues on that trend, finishing with a pronounced, pithy astringency.
Straightforward notes of citrus and apple have a light cabbage tinge on the nose. The palate is light and relatively neutral in flavor, ending on a crisp citrus note.
Quite light aromas lead to washed-out-seeming fruit flavors. The variety and vintage are hard to place.

Gritty aromas are fruitless, fishy and simply not inviting. Bitter nutty flavors show almost no fresh fruit, while this never comes around. Marqués de Cáceres has long been a reliable producer of basic rosé, but this is a departure in the wrong direction.
Jumbled aromas of yeasty red fruits, cinnamon and funk are off the mark. A flabby chunky palate lacks directness, while this tastes weird and artificial, with a flat finish that goes nowhere.
Aromas of mulch and green beans are flat-out underripe. A raw tannic palate and green-berry and plum flavors finish weedy.

A mix of grilled pineapple, citrus oil and sea spray starts off this rich white. Time in oak is apparent yet integrated, offering a delicate brûléed edge to the citrus, pineapple and apricot flavors. Persistent acidity balances it all, leading to a lingering cured lemon finish.

Aromas of red berry, leather and rose petal take shape in the glass. The structured juicy palate offers red cherry, clove, tobacco and a touch of cinnamon alongside youthfully austere tannins and bright acidity. Drink 2021–2029.

This wine is exceptionally smooth and polished, showing a gentle but not too-soft texture that carries fresh apple and lime flavors and subtle oak accents like nutmeg and vanilla. With medium to full body, it feels like a barrel-fermented wine but without obvious oakiness, and shows good layering and concentration.

Quite dark in the glass, this reserve bottling shows cassis, olive and savory earth aromas of dried herb and peppercorn on the nose. A roasted beef in blackberry sauce flavor meets with notes of black plum, mint and shaved chocolate on the palate.
Minty sage and an intensely tart sense of citrus and rhubarb shine in this balanced, coastal-influenced red, which retains plenty of tannic power against its fresh bubbly acidity.

This lightly earthy wine is soft in mouthfeel despite bright underlying acidity and fine-grained tannins. Hints of leather and barnyard lead to generous flavors of red and black cherry as well as light baking spices on the palate.
This wine is viscous and sweetly ripe in baked apple and honey flavors, with a thickness that persists.
This is a good picnic wine to serve with cheese or salty snacks. It's sweet, smooth and very fruity, with medium body, low alcohol and soft acidity.

Aromas of Satsuma, lychee, gooseberry and lily are luscious and inviting. A burst of sweetness paired with zesty acidity quickly mellows into soft ripe flavors of honeydew melon, white peach and lychee. The palate is creamy in feel, with some tangy acidity on the fringe to balance it out. Ripe yellow peach and sweet Valencia orange linger on the finish.
The aromas seem muddled, needing more clarity. The palate drinks medium-plus sweet, with peach and orange flavors. It doesn't all come together, living off the sugar.
Richly structured, this wine is dense and complex. With rich fruits as well as some firm tannins, it is a balanced wine that will age well. Drink this full wine from 2022.

Sultry black cherry and cassis flavors are accented by hints of crushed granite and wild mint in this supple Grenache-Syrah blend. It's full bodied and generous in character, but hints of coffee and olive lend savory complexity. The finish is marked by firm, fine-grained tannins. Enjoy now–2026.

Delicate scents evoking field flower, orchard fruit, toasted bread, and just a whiff of Mediterranean brush lift out of the glass. Reflecting the nose, the silky palate doles out white peach, yellow apple, juicy citrus and a hint of hazelnut alongside a creamy perlage.

Bright, tangy acidity helps lift a soft midpalate of polished tannin in this appellation wine. It has enviable structure to offer around a layered flavor array of cassis, red currant and black cherry, its secondary characteristics playfully savory in black pepper and clove.

Superripe flavors of black cherry juice and blackberry jam give this full-bodied wine richness and depth. It is concentrated and deep, showing dark chocolate and blueberry flavors, with light spicy, oaky accents of vanilla, cedar and mocha.

Aromatic but not bombastic, this shows grapefruit, apple and lemon aromas on the nose that are followed by herbal notes of tomato leaf, mint and grass. There's a focused line of acidity on the palate that cuts through the fruit and rounded texture but doesn't jut out. Drink now–2023.

Smooth and flavorful, this wine has plenty of pear and light herb aromas. Light spice, mineral and melon flavors offer a good sense of layering on the palate, all leading to a generous mouthfeel and lingering finish.

Firm and tannic, this is classic Cahors. With its bold tannins and structure permeated with black fruits, the wine is ripe, poised with acidity, flavors of berries and licorice, with a solid aftertaste. Drink from 2021.
Vibrant white flower, lychee and candied ginger aromas are followed by bone-dry fruit flavors in this wine. It shows exquisite length and balance, with a flavorful finish.

From a vineyard in the Pinhão Valley, this lightly structured and fruity wine is buoyed by red fruits and great acidity. Its tannins and acidity are a balanced part of this lightly wood-aged, rich wine. Drink from 2019.

This is an impressive wine with its mineral structure, firm tannins and rich fruit. Dark blackberry flavors are filled out with the solid core of the wine and lifted by the acidity. From a field blend of old vines, the wine needs some aging. Drink from 2021.

This ripe, wood-aged wine is full of rich tannins and generous black fruits. Its structure is young and firm, although the weight and opulence of the fruit will soon show through to give a generous wine that will still age. Drink from 2021.

This wine's ripe Conference pear aromas get their full billing on the juicy, pear-flavored and wonderfully fresh palate. Lemony zestiness tingles along, with a little white pepper-like spice. The finish is lip-smacking, fresh and dry.

High-toned lime zest, lime leaf, white peach, honeysuckle and mineral aromas lead to sleek, well-balanced stone fruit and green apple flavors in this wine. It's delightful on its own, but would also shine at the dinner table.

The high amount of chalk in the soil of this estate shows in the strongly mineral texture of the wine. With layers of black currant flavors, the wine is fruity while also structured. Its tannins and firm core promise some good aging. Drink from 2022.

This wine's gentle notes of russet pear peel and fresh, ripe apple suggest both texture and fruit. The pear and apple flavors fill the palate, framed by freshness and a lovely texture reminiscent of pear peel and lemon zest. The finish is dry, fresh, clean and vivid.

Black cherry, cedar and cola aromas are followed by pungent red berry, leather and olive flavors in this fresh, versatile Xinomavro. The mouthfeel is velvety, with a touch of acid lift. It finishes with black pepper and spice, seeming built for grilled meat and tomato tapenade.

This is a very tasty, vivid red wine that sends up chocolate, cherry and berry aromas and equally expressive flavors tinged by an appealing earthy meaty note. While full bodied it is not heavy, due to good acidity that lifts the mouthfeel.

This is a solidly made, wallet-friendly Sauvignon Blanc that offers heady, fresh aromas and flavors of lemon zest, oregano and snow pea, with a slightly creamy texture to balance all that zingy acidity. Drink now.

Pungent in oak and strong, warm aromas of crème brûlée, this wine offers a lush profile of mango, papaya and baked peach, slightly tropical and rich while being moderately balanced and the right kind of rich.
This wine's delicate scents reminiscent of wild flowers and orchard fruit lift out of the glass. The rounded, straightforward palate offers white peach, yellow pear and light bitter almond notes.

This light-salmon-colored wine was made from the unusual combination of Grenache and Nebbiolo grapes. It is light bodied but has substantive qualities like an earthy raspberry aroma and a smooth texture that spreads canteloupe and cinnamon over the palate.

Being 100% varietal, baking spice, dried savory herb, dried tobacco and cherry aromas are followed by plump lighter-styled fruit flavors, with red-fruit and black-tea notes on the finish. The tannic structure is surprisingly light for the variety.

Aromas of licorice, brandied cherry, red currant and black pepper show on a nose. This is a solid Cabernet Franc, if slightly over oaked, with juicy flavors of cranberry and pomegranate upfront leading to nutmeg, toasted oak and more black pepper. Tangy, lifting acidity keeps it in balance, with dusty tannins lingering through the oaky finish of muddled cherries and more spice.
winery: The Winery At Holy Cross Abbey

description: With its complex nose melding whiffs of fresh raspberry and violet with savory spice, smoke and nut tones, it's hard not to be mesmerized by this wine's bouquet alone. The palate is pure and lavish, boasting pristine blackberry and mulberry flavors held taut by a firm tannic backbone. It's remarkably integrated and supple now but should improve through 2035 and hold substantially further.

This combines grapes from the Martinelli family's Charles Ranch Vineyard in Fort Ross-Seaview with grapes from Platt Vineyard, a site long sourced by Ramey overlooking the Pacific Ocean near Freestone—the producer's coolest site. It melds exotic ginger with apple skin, melon rind and bright focused acidity that remains fresh, succulent and lingering.

This single-vineyard wine comes from a parcel that sits at 1,300 feet facing the Mediterranean sea. Its dark color, fabulous ripe fruits and perfumed character give it both richness and longevity. With 95% Mourvèdre, it has all the structure, dark tannins and spice of this grape that is at its best in this appellation. Drink this wine from 2023.

This is a juicy, expansive and textured wine, incredibly delicious in ripe raspberry and strawberry flavors. It has sanguine undertones, with clove, cardamom and black tea that stand out against polished tannins.

There's extreme, maybe even obscene, amounts of cracked black pepper on the savory nose of this cool-climate expression, which comes from the same 12 rows each vintage. There are also scents of roasted beef, asphalt and a pinch of lavender. The pepper character coats the palate too, diced by lively acidity. This is, perhaps, the most pitch-perfect show of Côte-Rôtie in California to date.

This gorgeous white has a density and weight to it that never becomes heavy, instead remaining complex and steely in character. Wet stone, apricot and key lime intermingle effortlessly around a core of balanced richness and supportive acidity, the oak well-integrated and nuanced.

From the winery's coastal estate property, this is inviting in candied strawberry Jolly Rancher and peach. With lovely acidity and freshness, it offers enough body and mid-tier weight to be a nice companion at the table as well as stand up on its own.

This wine's blackberry, cassis and plum aromas are plump and fruity, with no garish oak notes. On the palate, it's fleshy, with inky blackberry flavors and tapered tannins. Those tannins persist long into the finish. Drink now–2030.

Three cheers for this much-improved release from the Russell-Grooters estate vineyard. Refined and complex, it deftly mixes cherry and citrus flavors. Blood orange flesh and rind notes come through, leading to a midpalate stiff with tannins and a finishing whiff of chocolate.

This full-bodied wine wraps subtle fruity and floral flavors in a rich mouthfilling texture that feels sweet even though it's a dry wine. It has layers of light honeysuckle, vanilla and apricot that persist from the aroma through a lingering finish.
A 100% stainless-steel white, this is quenching and substantial in weight, with a grainy texture that shows complexity and layering of flavor. The fruit is a pleasing mix of Meyer lemon and kiwi.

A blend of 70% Nero d'Avola and 30% Frappato aged in used barriques, this has delicate scents of wild red berry, dark spice and a light whiff of menthol. It's elegantly structured, with fine-grained tannins weaving through ripe blackberry and juicy Marasca cherry. A white-pepper note signals the close.

A tan-meets-orange color and vegetal aromas are neither clean nor fresh. This is dilute on the palate, with flavors of tomato leaf, oregano and murky fruit. An oxidized finish is yeasty and bready, a clarion signal that this is past its prime.
This is a drinkable but very bland wine showing almost neutral flavors, low alcohol and a soft texture.
This sweet style of Vinho Verde, with a light prickle to give it a lift. It is sugary, tasting like fruit candy. Drink now.

High-toned aromas of black cherry and blackberry dominate nose, with tones of rose, black pepper, herbs and vanilla in the background. This wine attacks the palate with metallic flavors of copper pennies, hickory and extremely underripe cranberry. Sharp and lacking in structue, dusty tannins make an appearance on the finish attempting to reign in the matallic and tart berry notes, but are ultimately outmatched.
Murky funky aromas of rhubarb and red cabbage are a red flag justified by fairly weedy and tart red-berry flavors. Salad notes are found on the finish.

A dense nose of stewed red and black fruit carries a sheen of spice and resin. This is simultaneously sharp and thick in feel, with harsh acidity and grainy tannins underscoring ultratart berry tones.

Ten years ago, Quatro was one of Chile's more consistent value-priced red blends; not so much anymore. This smells as basic as basic gets, with herbal overtones. A plump, chunky palate lacks definition, while this tastes of generic berry fruits and green herbs. Green notes linger on an underwhelming finish; this is Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Carmenère and Malbec, hence the Quatro (four) name.

Fruit salad aromas of green melon, citrus and kiwi lead to a plump, chunky palate that's lacking in spine. Green, lightly vegetal flavors of melon and bell pepper are plodding through a slightly bitter finish.
Clean, fresh and fruity, this wine has plenty of acidity as well as a tangy texture. There are touches of tannin as well as some perfume from the Cabernet Franc in the blend. Drink now.

Sunset hued, this rosé shows notes of candied strawberries and tropical fruits. The palate, while not lacking in acidity, is oily in texture and a little hot from the alcohol. This is a ripe, rich style of rosé that's a little lacking in freshness.
A softly herbal wine, this offers crisp citrus flavors as well as riper white fruits. Plenty of acidity maintains freshness. The wine is ready to drink.
Prickly lime and pine needle aromas set up a lean palate with sharp acidity. Tart, punchy citrus and passion fruit flavors finish with lasting tang and grip from green tannins.

This will be an outstanding dinner wine when a roast or steak is on the menu. It has a good, gripping texture and firm acidity that will stand up well to fatty dishes. A nice core of blackberry and black-cherry flavors is surrounded by hints of clove and cinnamon.

Engaging aromas of forest berries and wild herbs are touched by savory white pepper and blue flowers on the nose of this light red. On the palate, delightful flavors of ripe red cherry, cranberry, granite and crushed thyme are supported by barely perceptible tannins and a peppery spice. There is a charming vein of acidity right from the start that weaves all the way through the wild black raspberry and white pepper-inflected finish. Drink now–2025.

Noticeable upfront oak results in aromas of graphite, cool mint and vanilla along with expected black fruits. This blend of Malbec and Cabernet Sauvignon deals rubbery tannins and blackened, slightly bitter black-fruit flavors. Spice and berry flavors are controlled on a finish that's not overly expressive or expansive. Drink through 2024.
designation: Tomal Vineyard Estate Grown El Corte

description: Aromas of dark berries, cured beef, green herbs and licorice carry the nose. This is tight and shocked by loud acidity. Flavors of black fruits are lightly herbal, while the long finish is dry and tannic. Drink through 2027.
designation: Terroir Series Edición Limitada Finca Laborde Single Vineyard

description: Honeyed and with the characteristic dry edge of botrytis, this orange-marmalade-flavored wine is sweet, intense and smoky. Its richness comes from the mature Sémillon and Muscadelle and the wood fermentation and aging. Drink this wine now, although it will age for many years, certainly until 2025.

Crisp aromas of candied cherry and raspberry are straightforward, while wet river stones add minerality and cola adds spice to the nose of this wine. Those elements converge on the palate, picking up ginger-spice and pomegranate juice flavors.

Thirst quenching in Meyer lemon, wet stone and salty oak, this wine evolves in the glass to become something more robust in body and ripeness, delving into concentrated apple and pear laced in ginger.

This is a lovely white, vibrant and citrus-driven in acidity and freshness and focus. Nicely melded flavors of melon, lime and grapefruit accent a light-bodied, elegant style that will do well as an apéritif or meal accompaniment.

Aged in new oak, this wine is rich and syrupy thick. The oak takes on smoky overtones that mesh well with the ripe cherry fruit, with flavors of sage and clove as well. The tannins are polished yet burly, adding sizable structure into the mix.
Smoky and fruity, this rich wine has fine tannins and a sumptuous texture. Fresh red fruits balance the generosity. It is just starting out and will not be ready to drink before 2023.

Cola, mint and eucalyptus aromas are attached to a spicy berry tone. The full-bodied palate is saturated yet balanced, while pepper and blackberry flavors come with an herbal undertone. Drink through 2025.

Blackberry and cherry flavors are fleshy and forward in this intensely juicy, fruity wine. Made from 70% Grenache, its silken and supple but builds in density and tannic structure. The finish has a slightly puckering note of Asian salt-cured plums. Approachable now but should improve through 2028.

A wine that is still available in limited amounts, this aged red offers classic secondary aromas of leather, tobacco and raisin, with a seasoning of clove. Drink soon—it risks being quickly past its prime.
Citrus blossom, peach and white stone fruit aromas lift out of the glass. The juicy savory palate doles out yellow pear, apple, crushed herb and white almond alongside crisp acidity.

From the neighboring vineyard that has done so much for the variety in this appellation, this white is grainy in toasted oak and caramel crème brûlée, rich and made in a full-bodied style. The richness is kept in check by juicy notions of baked tangerine and Meyer lemon.

Named after a nearby 13th-century church, this wine comes from a portion of the slope above the Osse river in Gascony. It is already delicious, ripe with apricot flavors and a delicate touch of honey. Dense and well balanced with acidity, it's a great food wine.

Medium bodied, with a core of black cherry fruit, this is nicely textured and has a streak of cola. The earthy flavors of the AVA are in evidence, leading to a tannic finish. It improves significantly with generous aeration.

This wine is predominantly Cabernet Sauvignon, blended with small amounts of Merlot, Petit Verdot, Cabernet Franc and Malbec. Smoky, toasted oak underlies rounded layers of blueberry, black cherry and plum, leaving the palate rich and pleasing.
